Title: High Court stays single judge order against Tamil university vice-chancellor posting
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

IN MIDST OF A ROW

MADURAI: A division bench of the Madras high court has granted interim stay on a single judge order which set aside a government order (GO) that appointed G Balasubramanian as the vice-chancellor (VC) of Tamil University at Thanjavur .

Balasubramaniam, in his petition stated that he was appointed as the VC of the university on October 5, 2018. A candidate K Ravindran who applied for the post of VC filed a petition before the high court Madurai bench challenging the GO on ground that he did not possess the required qualification in conducting not less than one international level event as per clause 5 of the eligibility criteria.

Balasubramaniam stated that Ravindran also raised another ground that the senate nominee and syndicate nominee of the search committee who were holding positions earlier in the university are ineligible to be members of the search committee as per provisions of the UGC regulation and as per Section 12 of the Tamil University Act, 1982.

He said that the single judge had allowed the petition and quashed the GO appointing him as VC on December 20, 2019, citing that the senate and syndicate nominee of the search committee were earlier holding positions as syndicate member and VC of the university by misinterpreting Section 12 (2) of the Act.

The appellant submitted that Section 12 of the Act states that “The person nominated shall not be a member of any of the authorities of the university or shall not be connected with the university or any college or any recognised institution of the university.” He cited that the word ‘shall be’ only denotes ‘at present’. He further submitted that the senate and syndicate nominees of the search committee are no way connected with the university at present.

He noted that though Ravindran was well aware of the earlier positions held by the search committee members, he submitted his application before the same committee and merely because he was not selected, he cannot question the constitution of the search committee.

Hence, the appellant filed an appeal before the high court Madurai bench seeking to grant interim stay on the single judge order. When the appeal was heard on Tuesday, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran granted interim stay and adjourned the case to January 10 for further hearing.

Title: Renovate Purnia’s grain market: CM Nitish Kumar
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: Chief minister Nitish Kumar on Tuesday asked the officials of agriculture and building construction departments to ensure immediate renovation of Purnia’s famous Gulab Bagh Mandi, which is the state’s biggest grain market.

Nitish was holding a joint review meeting with the officials and elected peoples’ representatives of Purnia, Katihar, Araria and Kishanganj at Purnia collectorate as part of his ‘Jal-Jivan-Hariyali’ Yatra. He also asked the officials to conduct a fresh survey of public wells in Araria district before taking up their renovation work.

“As soon as I drew attention of the CM towards the dilapidated condition of roads, drains and buildings in the famous Gulab Bagh Mandi, the CM turned towards the government officials and asked the reasons behind not taking up the renovation work,” BJP’s Purnia MLA Vijay Kumar Khemka told TOI over phone on Tuesday.

“The CM asked a senior official of the building construction department in Patna through videoconferencing as to why the renovation work of Gulab Bagh Mandi has so far not been taken up despite a detailed project report (DPR) prepared by the agriculture department,” Khemka said.

Earlier, Khemka, while speaking in the review meeting, informed the CM that the agriculture department had approved a DPR of Rs15 crore for renovation of the famous mandi. The BCD has to execute the renovation work. But the matter is pending due to lack of coordination between the two departments.

Spread over an area of 68 acres, Gulab Bagh Mandi is facing a lot of problems due to its dilapidated roads, drains and ruined building, Khemka said, adding he had also raised this issue in the assembly in 2016 and at a previous review meeting of the CM in 2018. Reviewing the developmental works in Katihar, the CM asked the officials to take necessary steps to promote organic farming in different blocks of the district. “Katihar should be included in the list of 12 those districts where government has planned to promote organic farming,” the CM said at the meeting. “I urged the CM to upgrade Korha block headquarters as a subdivision and also open a degree college there,” Congress MLA Punam Paswan told TOI over phone.

Earlier in the day, Nitish, accompanied by several ministers and MLAs, visited Routara village under Korha block in Katihar district and Rupaspur Khagha panchayat in Purnia district and inspected several schemes being executed under the Jal-Jivan-Hariyali Abhiyan.

Title: BJP mass contacton CAA from today
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: As part of reaching out to households across the state to explain the Centre’s stand on Citizenship (Amendment) Act and National Register of Citizens, Telangana BJP has decided to cover at least 50 lakh population. The mass contact programme, which will be taken up from January 8, will continue till January 15.

Booth-wise members would visit each household in the villages and mandals, while the state-level leaders would interact with prominent citizens.

BJP activists would distribute pamphlets to family members in the households and explain to them on how National Population Register is a regular process and CAA is not against any particular community.

Central leaders from Telangana and Andhra Pradesh Muralidhar Rao and Ram Madhav are already taking part in seminars and addressing various fora on CAA and NRC. Union junior minister for home G Kishan Reddy undertook an yatra on the issue.

Sources said the state BJP unit is also keen to win over the hearts of people by reaching out to them ahead of the municipal elections and expose the failures of the Telangana Rashtra Samiti government.

Meanwhile, BJP state president K Laxman met Union tourism minister Prahlad Singh Patel on Tuesday and demanded that the Centre declare Sammaka-Sarakka jatara as a national festival.

Former Telangana TDP leader Motkupalli Narasimhulu joined BJP in the presence of BJP national president JP Nadda in Delhi on Tuesday.

Title: Patna girl among 4 die in two road accidents
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

BHAGALPUR/BEGUSARAI: A 29-year-old Patna girl, Kiran Kumari, who was posted at Nathnagar branch of UCO Bank in Bhagalpur as branch manager, died in a road accident on Tuesday. Her colleague Sanju Kumar, hailing from Kangra district in Himachal Pradesh, was also injured in the accident.

The incident occurred when the two were on way to bank. A speeding tractor hit their two-wheeler near Dogachhi road bypass at Nathnagar. Kiran, who received head injuries, died on the spot due to profuse bleeding. Sanju, on the other hand, received leg injuries and was rushed to Jawahar Lal Nehru Medical College and Hospital (JLNMCH) at Bhagalpur.

Kiran was the third of four daughters of an ex-Army man based at Patna. Bhagalpur police sources said Kiran was riding the ill-fated two-wheeler. Meanwhile, UCO Bank zonal manager Subhash Chandra Mahapatra and other bank colleagues expressed shock over the incident.

Bhagalpur city DSP Rajvansh Singh said, “We have made a detailed inquiry and a case is being lodged. The tractor that hit the two-wheeler fled from the spot. The body of the victim has been sent for postmortem.”

In another incident at Begusarai, three people were killed on Monday night when a speeding sports utility vehicle (SUV) hit them while they were sitting near a temple premises in Manjhaul under the same police outpost on Begusarai-Rosera road.

Police sources said the victims were identified as Raja Sahni (26), Raj Kumar Sahni (40) and Dina Sahni (33). The incident occurred when the driver of the SUV lost control over the vehicle and hit them. The victims were rushed to Begusarai sadar hospital, where they they succumbed to their injuries. The driver of the SUV managed to flee along with the vehicle.

All three victims hailed from Manjhaul village. Police said while Raja and Raj Kumar were daily-wage workers, Dina was preparing for government job.

Title: Harsh winter season spells happiness for apparel retailers
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Chennai: With several parts of North India reeling under the chill weather, most retail players have seen the sales of winter wear jump by 15%-20% year-on-year in most cities.

Puma for e.g. has seen a 40% growth in winter sale in the north of the country. “A part of this is a result of rising sales of jackets and sweatshirts,” Abhishek Ganguly, MD, Puma India said.

Vineet Jain, head, north zone, Big Bazaar and Future Group seconds the thought. “Over the last two weekends, we are able to sell at retail prices while last winter we had begun discounting at around this time. Hence, we are seeing better margins on a like-to-like basis,” said Jain.

Harkirat Singh, MD, Aero Club (the makers and traders of brand Woodland), said that the last fortnight saw 15%-20% jump in sales compared to previous winter season. “Winter apparel is driving sales in North India from December, a welcome change from subdued consumer sentiments that prevailed earlier in 2019. Jackets and sweatshirts are seeing a demand. Fortunately for us, winter accounts for 65% of our sale,” he added

JP Shukla of tier-2 town focused ‘1-India Family Mart’ added that even with the onset of year-end sale, sentiments were down until December 15. “With increased demand for winter wear, we are running out of stock and are sourcing jackets from other neighbouring cities,” he added.

It is not just the brick and mortar shops that are experiencing the trend. E-commerce players like Myntra have also seen a sale of over 4 lakh jackets being sold in just 3 days — Dec 22 to Dec 25.

Title: Ed-tech co Testbook raises Rs 60cr
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Bengaluru: Testbook , an education technology startup focused on central government and state government job exams, has raised Rs 60 crore in a new financing round led by venture capital firm Iron Pillar . The company said its existing investors Matrix Partners India, Better Capital, AngelList India and Vikas Choudhury (Reliance Jio president) have also participated in this funding. The Mumbai-based startup wants to expand in southern India and grow the number of exams on its platform to help aspiring candidates.

Launched in 2014, Testbook, so far, is largely present in north Indian cities and towns where it also has around 70 offline study centres. “We are looking to increase the number of exams to 400 from current level of 100. As we expand in south India, we are looking to add regional languages for state government jobs. So far, over 35,000 students have successfully passed such exams via our platform,” said Ashutosh Kumar , co-founder and CEO, Testbook. It has about 1 crore registered users and 5 lakh of them are paying subscribers. It has subscription offerings — for mock tests and access to course material.

Kumar said Testbook has an annualised revenue run rate of about Rs 30 crore. He is aiming to clock about Rs 20 crore monthly revenue going forward as he expands operations using the new capital. “This investment fits well with Iron Pillar’s approach of backing visionary entrepreneurs who are driving innovation along with proven execution and capital efficiency,” said Sameer Nath, managing partner, Iron Pillar.

Title: TCA leads $1mn bridge round in Chai Kings
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Chennai: Tea retail chain Chai Kings on Tuesday raised a $1million (approximately Rs 7 crore) from investors, led by The Chennai Angels. Investors including Hyderabad Angels and TiE India Angels have also participated in the round. The current investment is a pre series A bridge round

This is the second round that the city-based angel fund has put in the startup. Chai Kings raised Rs 2 crore as an angel investment in August 2018.

Jahabar Sadique, CEO and co-founder, Chai Kings said, “This funding round will help us expand into newer cities. We hope to enter Coimbatore, Bengaluru and Hyderabad in this current year and get closer to our target of 100 stores in 5 years. Apart from expansions, bulk of this funding will be utilized to strengthen our operations and supply chain management.” The chain will initially open 4 stores in Hyderabad and 3 in Coimbatore. Overall, by the end of next month, Sadique hopes to have 50 stores in 3 cities

“The new investment reiterates our commitment towards building a sustainable and scalable Indian QSR.”, said Piyush Bhandari who lead the investment from TCA.

Title: Met predicts light showers in Bihar for two days from Wednesday
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The India Meteorological Department (IMD) on Tuesday issued a forecast for scattered rainfall across the state on Wednesday and Thursday. The rain , however, is expected to be light in intensity.

An official at Patna Meteorological Centre attributed the showers to a western disturbance, the weather systems originating from Mediterranean Sea, Red Sea and Caspian Sea, which cause snow and winter rainfall in north-western Indian subcontinent.

“A western disturbance approaching Bihar through Rajasthan, Punjab, Haryana, Uttar Pradesh is expected to cause light intensity rain across the state on January 8 and 9,” the official said.

Private weather agency Skymetweather also reported on Tuesday that scattered rain and thundershower activities are expected to begin in eastern parts of Madya Pradesh by Wednesday afternoon, which will gradually start affecting Bihar and Jharkhand.

“We expect rain and thundershower activities to lash eastern parts of Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Jharkhand on January 8 and 9. In Bihar, the weather is expected to become dry from January 10,” the Skymet report stated.

As far as mercury readings during the rainy spell are concerned, weathermen have claimed that while night temperature may increase slightly, the day temperature may plunge by a few notches owing to the cloud cover.

The minimum temperature in Patna on Tuesday was recorded at 9.2 degrees C, which was at par with normal for the day. The minimum temperature readings at Gaya, Bhagalpur, Muzaffarpur, Purnia, Chhapra and Forbesganj were recorded at 8, 9, 10.7, 7.1, 10.5 and 10.0 degrees C, respectively.

“The minimum temperature is likely to increase slightly at most places in the state over the next two days, but it will again plunge by a few notches after the cloud cover clears. Apart from plunge in temperature, dense fog cover is also expected in the early morning hours at most places in the state,” the weather official said.

The meteorologists are of the view that the peak winter period will start departing henceforth, even though cold conditions will continue for a few more weeks. “The days have started getting longer from December 28 and the solar rays have also started falling perpendicular along the equator. Hence, peak winter season will gradually depart,” the official at Patna Meteorological Centre said.

Title: Nirbhaya case convicts to be hanged with ropes prepared in Bihar jail
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The four convicts of the Nirbhaya gang rape case in Delhi will be hanged to death with ‘Manila’ ropes prepared... Read More

PATNA: The four convicts of the Nirbhaya gang rape case in Delhi will be hanged to death with ‘Manila’ ropes prepared by the inmates of Buxar central jail , sources in the prison department said on Tuesday.

The Buxar jail has already supplied 10 such ropes to Tihar jail where the four convicts — Mukesh (32), Pawan Gupta (25), Vinay Sharma (26) and Akshay Kumar Singh alias Akshay Thakur (31) -- are lodged and to be hanged on January 22. The ropes were supplied to Tihar jail authorities in December last year on the directive of the prison directorate in Patna.

Buxar jail superintendent Vijay Kumar Arora said he can’t share much information with the media as it is a sensitive issue. “What all I can say at this stage is that the hanging ropes made by the jail inmates were supplied to the authorities concerned much earlier,” he said.

Arora said the Buxar jail inmates have the expertise in making the wax-coated ‘Manila’ rope with 7200 threads meant for the hanging of those sentenced to death. A 16 feet rope costs around Rs2,120. “The rope can easily withstand the tension and pressure caused by the fall of a person weighting up to 150kg,” a senior jail official said.

Sources said the state prison directorate was told about the appropriate height and weight of all the four convicts at the time of placing demand for supply of the ropes in the first week of December last year. The length of a ‘Manila’ rope is 1.6 times more than the height of the convict and its thickness is proportionate to the convict’s weight, sources said.

Last time, the hanging ropes were provided to Tihar jail for the hanging of Afzal Guru on February 9, 2013. He was a convict in the 2001 Parliament attack case.

Earlier, the rope was supplied from Buxar jail in 2004 for the hanging of rape convict Dhananjay Chatterjee at Alipore jail following his conviction in a rape-cum-murder case. The prison has a history of making ‘Manila’ ropes since 1930.

Meanwhile, a pall of gloom descended on the native village of Akshay Thakur in Aurangad district. The family members of Akshay, a resident of Lahangkarma village under Tandwa police station area in Aurangabad, are still hopeful of getting reprieve from the court. Akshay’s wife Punita Devi said, “Nirbhaya ko insaaf milna chahiye lekin kisi ke pariwar ko ujad kar nahi (Justice should be done with Nirbhaya but not at the cost of anybody’s family).”

Akshay’s mother Malti Devi said, “Hume ummid abhi bhi hai (I still have a ray of hope).” A number of residents thronged Akshay’s house soon after the death warrants were issued by the court against the four convicts on Tuesday.

Title: No need to be precise and slow, be ‘roughly’ right & fast
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

By M Muneer

Most early stage career seekers tend to follow the path of their seniors since that is what their peers and family expect them to do. So, they follow the crowd. Succumbing to the social pressure to do what is expected of them, they do not have a successful career strategy at all.

The essence of strategy is to have a differentiated value proposition and, even in a transient advantage era, the differentiation is key to success. The disruptive world of today has invalidated the two major assumptions of strategy that industry is everything, and competitive advantage once identified is sustainable. When advantages are transient, strategy needs a new playbook, according to US management scholar Rita McGrath.

Management structures that directed resources and talent to strategic business units were associated with high performance. The talent of tomorrow will need the ability to quickly disengage and engage with new things, be able to shift continually, be fast & roughly right instead of precise & slow, and be disconfirmation-seeking, among other things.

Here are some strategies to become career superstars:

Go where there is less competition: I know a few Indians who learnt Japanese and migrated to Japan and built a successful career there. Very few foreigners speak native languages fluently and enterprises are embracing diversity in a big way to drive innovation in the transient advantage era. The essence of a successful strategy is to redraw competition and this is one way to succeed in your career. One can also think of entering an industry like pharma, which is not preferred by most MBAs because of low starting salaries. Find out where competition is less and map skills and interests with those industries or countries. White space-mapping and even blue-ocean strategy can be applied to personal career assessments.

Find a job where you can add unique value: For instance, if you are a doctor and then do MBA, you will add tremendous value to the healthcare industry. Or, if you are a data analyst with human resource specialisation, you could guide organisations in managing their workforce in the age of artificial intelligence (AI). If you have experience in a particular industry, like transportation with operations management tools, you will have unique value to offer to a variety of businesses where process efficiency is key.

Find your own path: Shed the herd mentality. Just because your peers and friends are working a 9-to-5 job doesn’t mean you have to follow suit. If you want to start your own business, then think about what you’d need to excel as an entrepreneur instead of doing a job. You can probably create a disruptive model and unseat many existing business models. Plan for it even when you are employed in a place so you can find your path one way or the other. My partner started a deep tech startup at the age of 55.

Do a risk-return analysis: You can take a riskier strategy, such as joining a startup. If you had jumped into Flipkart in its early days, your risks were huge and of course the returns too when it was acquired by Walmart. Just as there is a trade-off between risk and return in the financial markets, there is one for careers as well. Playing it safe may be — and certainly feels — comfortable. But if you really want to accelerate your career, implementing a higher variance, a riskier strategy may be the way to go.

During the course of your career, you may want to choose one of these four strategic options and at appropriate career junctures, depending on the opportunities and competitive positions. The risk you take is not that risky as you might imagine. If things don’t work out, you can always do what you were going to do in the first place.

Over the course of a 30-40-year career, taking prudent risks in early stages seems very sensible. And who knows, you may drive an important function at a huge, rapidly growing firm — much earlier than even you expect. Career success is not measured by where you end up in the first half of your career. What matters is where you are in the second half. Your investment in the first half matters most for that. Just as in a movie, the second half decides whether it is a success or failure.

(The writer is co-founder of Medici Institute Foundation for Diversity and Innovation)

Title: ChrysCapital exits IPCA Labs in Rs 560cr deal
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Rupali Mukherjee | TNN

Mumbai: Private equity major ChrysCapital has exited mid-size drug firm IPCA Labs , offloading its entire stake to 10 mutual funds, for around Rs 560 crore.

The PE firm offloaded its 4% stake in the company recently, sources said, mopping up returns of nearly 2.5x on its investment. The firm had invested Rs 245 crore spread over two lots — in 2014 and 2016.

ChrysCapital, the largest homegrown PE fund, has approximately $4 billion of assets under management (AUM) across eight funds, with marquee investors including sovereign wealth funds, endowments and pension funds.

ChrysCapital officials were not available for comments, while IPCA Labs did not respond to a email till the time of going to press. The firm has invested in over 80 companies, with strategic mid-to-high teens’ stake in companies like Intas Pharma, Mankind Pharma , GVK Bio and Curatio. At present, ChrysCapital has half a billion invested in healthcare firms, with a bulk — around $320 million in Mankind alone.

The firm picked up around 10% stake in Mankind in 2018. This is the second time ChrysCapital invested in the Delhi-based drug firm, after exiting its 11% stake in 2015 to Capital International for $214 million, with a tenfold return in seven years.

The PE firm has mopped up returns of around 5x on the investments made in healthcare, making it one of the best bets for investors.

Interestingly, 2018 was one of the best years for exits in the last decade, with 265 exits valued at nearly $33 billion, signalling investor confidence in the Indian market, says Bain & Co’s, ‘2019 India Private Equity Report’. A few large exits dominated in 2018, with the top 10 exits accounting for 70% of total exit value. Nearly half of last year’s exit value resulted from the $16 billion sale of Flipkart to Walmart. Apart from Flipkart, these included Intelenet Global Services (Blackstone), GlobalLogic (Apax), Star Health and Allied Insurance (multiple funds) and Vishal Retail (TPG).

Exits increased across sectors, with the primary contributors to exit values being consumer tech, IT, ITES, and BFSI.

The public market remained the most preferred mode for exits—though there was a spike in strategic exits, primarily driven by consumer tech. Over the last five years, funds have made reasonable returns across most sectors, with consumer tech, IT/enterprise tech and BFSI having the highest multiples on invested capital.

Further, the industry had an excellent run at raising funds to the tune of $714 billion from investors during the year, the third-largest amount on record, bringing the total capital raised since 2014 to $3.7 trillion, it adds.

Title: Bail to Kabir brings cheer to family, friends
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Lucknow: Not only friends and family in Lucknow but social activists and acquaintances in Delhi also had tears of happiness in their eyes when social activist and theatre artist Deepak Kabir was granted bail on Tuesday evening.

Kabir’s wife Veena Rana was at Constitution Club in Delhi to attend a solidarity meet in defence of human rights activists and people of Uttar Pradesh when she got the news that Kabir has been granted bail.

“My immediate aim was to get bail for him. I was speaking in Delhi on behalf of all the people who were arrested by UP police for protesting against new citizenship law. As soon as I got the news of his bail and shared it with the audience, people could not stop clapping. Ek sukoon sa lag raha hai ab (Feeling a bit relaxed now),” said Veena.

She immediately booked a flight to Lucknow to complete paper work for Kabir’s release.

Kabir, 48, was arrested on December 20 when he went to police station to enquire about some people who went missing after the anti-CAA agitation on December 19.

According to police, Kabir was arrested on charges of rioting and preventing public servants from performing their duty.

While Rana was sharing her happiness with Kabir’s supporters in Delhi, the real joy was for his 15-year-old son Sufi Kabir, who is anxiously waiting for his father to return.

“I know he is a strong man but we were worried about him because of the pain and injuries he sustained in jail. The moment the court’s decision came in, my phone did not stop ringing. We only hope that everything will be fine once he returns,” Sufi said.

Title: Patna air ‘very poor’ again, Muzaffarpur AQI worst in country
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: After a brief respite, the air quality in the state capital slipped from ‘moderate’ to ‘very poor’ category in the last 24 hours. Experts said it may further deteriorate due to low wind velocity and fall in temperature, as predicted by the Air Quality Early Warning System of the Union ministry of earth sciences.

Track the pollution level in your city

According to figures released by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), the Air Quality Index (AQI) of Patna increased from 115 on Monday to 323 on Tuesday, while the AQI of Muzaffarpur stood at 394, which was the highest in the country.

Among the 99 cities, Patna figured among top five polluted cities in India after Talcher, Varanasi and Kanpur. The AQI level at Gaya stood at 121, which falls in the ‘moderate’ category.

Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB) officials stated that the overall AQI of 365 for Patna was the average recorded at the air quality monitoring stations at planetarium (400), BIT-Mesra, Patna (339), Eco Park (295) and SK Memorial Hall (257).

Ankita Jyoti, a senior programme officer of Centre for Environment and Energy Development (CEED), told this newspaper on Tuesday that continuous fluctuation in weather conditions, including fall in temperature and high humidity are the major factors behind the rise in AQI.

“The wind velocity is good but it contains moisture, which creates thermal inversion in the atmosphere. Due to this inversion, the pollutant dispersion is very minimal,” she said and added: “The worsening of air quality in Muzaffarpur can be attributed to relatively calmer winds, which are not dispersing the pollutants.”

Pradhan Parth Sarth, the standing committee member of Bihar State Action Plan for Climate Change, said the air quality of Patna might improve under the influence of a western disturbance that is expected to impact the weather in Bihar on January 8 and 9. “The western disturbance will lead to strengthening of surface winds. Nevertheless, the air quality in Patna will remain poor to very poor till January-end,” he said.

Title: Patna: Online study centre at A N College soon
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: A free of cost online study centre , the first in any campus in the state, to help students do self-studies in leisure hours, is being developed at A N College here. Initially, the centre will be available only for students of the college. However, its services will be extended to poor students from other colleges on a normal charge in the near future.

“The online study centre, being developed with a financial assistance of Rs 3.25 crore from the state government in the humanities building of the college, will have 220 computers. The centre will start functioning from March this year,” said principal of A N College Dr S P Shahi.

Students enrolled in any class from Intermediate to postgraduate and vocational courses can avail the facility. The college has about 15,000 students enrolled in various courses.

Shahi said after assessment of the students’ response and their participation in this online self-study programme, the college will throw it open for poor students of other colleges in the evening hours, though with a minimal charge.

“Course materials of all subjects and references will be available online for students. However, there will be no provision for private chatting and misuse of the computer systems. A committee of senior teachers will manage the functioning of this study centre. The idea behind establishing online study centre is to provide a better option to students to use their leisure hours,” Shahi said.

He added that foundation stone for a multi-purpose building involving an expenditure of Rs 10 crore will also be laid in the college this month. “This building will have an auditorium with 540 seats and six conference rooms, each with seating capacities ranging between 100 and 150 students. The rooms will be equipped with modern facilities,” Shahi said.

Apart from its own functions, the auditorium and conference rooms will also be let out for other programmes. “Being the state capital, several academic, scientific and other programmes and meetings are regularly held here and letting out these venues inside the campus will help generate internal an annual revenue of around Rs 1 crore,” the principal said.

Shahi said altogether Rs 30 crore was received from the state government for these development projects, including a new boundary wall around the campus.

Title: Nagpur: Rich treat of classical music at Kaole fest
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kaole Parivar organised the classical music festival at Soham Hall ,Sitabuldi , on Saturday

NAGPUR: A two-day classical music festival was organized to commemorate the 100th birth anniversary of violinist Pt Shridhar Parsekar and in memory of Pt Vishnupant Kaole and Pt Bhaskar Moroney. The festival, that commenced on Saturday, was organized by Pravin, Parag and Sachin Kaole, under the aegis of South Central Cultural Centre (SCZCC) at Soham, Sitabuldi. The programme commenced with violin recital by Pravin and students. They presented raag Nayaki Kanada and Hamsadhwani in Carnatic style. The performance had an enchanting effect and set the tone for the evening. This was followed by the vocal recital of Jayshree Chanekar. She beautifully sang ‘Darshan kaise pau main’ in vilambit khayal in raag Champakali. ‘Chunari rang bhari sari mori’ in trital, followed by thumri ‘Ghir ghir aayi badariya kaari’ in Dadra, kept the audience engaged. The accompanying artistes were Narendra Kadve (harmonium), Amol Urkude (tabla) and Sharvari Naik (tanpura). Vidnyaneshwar and Nitin Khadse captivated with shehnai recital. They presented raag Madhukauns and Abhogi in vilambit jhaptal. They were accompanied by Ram Khadse on tabla. Classical vocalist from Mumbai Manas Vishwaroop was at his best when he presented raag Shyam Kalyan. Bandish ‘Jiyo mero laal’ and ‘Aisa tumhi ko main jaanat hoon’ in jhaptal had the desired effect. Vishwaroop concluded the programme with a tarana in raag Jog. He was accompanied by Kadve on harmonium and Khadse on tabla. Anjali Parnandiwar introduced the artistes. On the second day, violinists Pt Kamal Kamble from Indore and Pravin, and tabla player Yashwant Vaishnav from Mumbai, performed. (Reporting by Manshika Vaikkath)

Title: Delhi assembly elections: AAP manifesto to be out by January 20
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Atishi

NEW DELHI: Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) will be ready with its manifesto for the Delhi assembly elections by January 20 . A three-member committee, headed by party functionary Atishi, has been formed to prepare the manifesto, which will include AAP’s vision for the capital and Delhiites’ suggestions.

Atishi, AAP’s national spokesperson, was also in charge of the manifesto committee for the 2015 elections. The other members are Dialogue and Development Commission of Delhi vice-chairperson Jasmine Shah and former Jamshedpur MP Ajoy Kumar who had joined the party a few months ago. The polling is scheduled on February 8 and the result will be out on February 11.

While Atishi, an Oxford alumnus, is the key person behind the AAP government’s education policies, Shah, who had studied at Columbia University, has been part of the planning process of various policies. Kumar, a former IPS officer, is currently one of the national spokespersons.

“We will launch the manifesto between January 15 and 20. Many valuable suggestions, received during the town hall meetings and the door-to-door campaign, will be incorporated,” AAP Delhi convener Gopal Rai said on Tuesday.

The manifesto is likely to deal considerably with the issue of making Delhi clean. “It is the responsibility of the municipal corporations, run by BJP for the past 15 years, to make Delhi clean. But people are unhappy with sanitation services and waste management; they demand that AAP should take some steps,” Rai said.

Other important issues include cleaning the Yamuna, tackling pollution, providing 24X7 water, free bus rides for students, redesigning roads, improving public transport, and solving parking chaos and traffic congestion.

AAP has already said people will continue to get 200 units of electricity and 20,000 litre water per month free if it returns to power. While the free pilgrimage scheme and free bus rides for women will also be there, the free Wi-Fi connectivity will be expanded across the city.

Rai said over 30 lakh people had already got the government’s report card through the town halls, 600 mohalla sabhas and the door-to-door campaign.

The party plans to take it to 5 lakh more people thorugh around 60,000 volunteers in the next few days. “After completing the second phase of AAP’s election campaign on January 10, we will prepare the manifesto,” said Rai.
