Title: Students, alumni renew demand for JNU VC’s ouster
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

(From left) Sitaram Yechury, D Raja, Yogendra Yadav and others addressed students during the meeting called by... Read More

NEW DELHI: With leaders across political spectrum, JNU alumni and Bollywood actress Deepika Padukone coming out in solidarity, the meeting called by JNU teachers and students on Tuesday saw emotions overflowing and a renewed call for removal of the vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar.

Former JNUSU president Kanhaiya Kumar, CPI leader D Raja, CPM leader Sitaram Yechury, Congress leader Sharmistha Mukherjee, activists Yogendra Yadav and Kavita Krishnan and doctor Shah Alam Khan addressed the students after dodging the guards and entering from different gates. They all criticised the administration, the government and Delhi Police for inaction over the violence which unravelled in the campus on January 5.

Yechury said that MPs from different political parties will soon write a letter to the President of India, who is also the visitor of the university, requesting dismissal of the VC .

Towards the end of the programme, Padukone made an appearance taking the crowd by surprise. She did not address the students and teachers gathered and said that she was present to express her solidarity with the students. Kanhaiya Kumar, along with other students, raised slogans of “Aazadi” and “Sarfaroshi ki tamana ab hamare dil mein hai.”

JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh, however, later said that Padukone should have spoken as Bollywood celebrities are looked up as role models.

Sohail Hashmi, Shamsul Islam, Omkar Goswami and others took part in march called by the varsity alumni.

When Kavita Krishnan was addressing the students, a drone made an appearance in the sky. Students waved back at it and the speakers later questioned where was the drone when students and teachers were being attacked.

Kanhaiya Kumar said the BJP government had no issue to fight in Delhi elections so they picked up JNU. “The JNU administration says that students switched off the server, but it is the government which is known for switching off the internet. MHRD and JNU administration have different narratives on the same matter,” said Kumar.

“January 5 attack is not a normal assault, we have to understand why JNU was chosen for such an attack,” said Yechury.

Yogendra Yadav said: “This is not left versus right, but right versus the wrong. The vice-chancellor is the enemy of the institution he heads, so he has to go.”

Jamia teachers had also gathered on the campus to express their solidarity with the students and teachers of JNU.

Title: Assistant teachers exam: Allahabad HC dismisses pleas on qualifying marks
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Allahabad high court

LUCKNOW: The Lucknow bench of Allahabad High Court on Tuesday set at rest the controversy regarding the declaration of result of the Assistant Teachers Recruitment Examination-2018, and dismissed about 60 writ petitions, keeping into account the lower qualifying marks as fixed by the government order (GO) issued on May 21, 2018, which was later withdrawn.

The order came from a bench of Justice Abdul Moin, who held that after detailed discussions in the judgment, he did not find any merit in any of the petitions, which challenged the GO dated February 20, 2019 and demanded that the results should be declared as the qualifying marks set by the GO dated May 21, 2018.

Opposing the petitions, additional advocate general Kuldeep Pati Tripathi had argued that the decision of the state government was lawful, owing to the indulgence of the court as regard the previous GOs. Tripathi further added that the decision was taken to pick and select best candidates for the job. While recruiting the candidates, the state government had issued GO dated January 9, 2018 whereby fixing 45% qualifying marks for general and OBC candidates and 40% for SC/ST category. Later, the state government issued another GO on May 21, 2018 whereby decreasing the minimum qualifying marks as 33 for general and OBC and 30 for SC/ST. Subsequently, after an interference by the HC on a writ petition, the state government on February 20, 2019 cancelled the GO dated May 21, 2018 and started process for examination by keeping in account the previous GO dated January 9, 2018.

It was argued on behalf of the petitioners that if minimum qualifying mark was lowered as was set by GO dated May 21, 2018, more candidates could be adjusted against the posts as number of posts are already vacant. HC held that no case was made out for interference in the matter.

Title: Bengaluru: Special voter drive draws only 7,242 applications
Content:
Representative image

BENGALURU: The three-day ‘ Minchina Nondani ’, a special voter-enrolment drive, saw a mere 7,242 applications on the first two days. The drive will end on Wednesday.BBMP commissioner and district electoral officer BH Anil Kumar admitted that more measures need to be taken to create awareness among potential first-time voters in the city.On the first two days, enrolment applications were filed by 2,319 voters in the 18-19 age group and 4,923 by those falling in the category of 20 years and above.“Unless we know the population of those in the 18-19 age group in Bengaluru, we cannot say the special drive has resulted in poor response from first-time voters. Monday was the first day of the drive and we cannot force somebody to come and enrol as voters. This is a voluntary programme and we can only make an appeal,” Kumar said.“The objective was to ensure civic officials involved in election work reach out to potential first-time voters and enrol them.From Thursday, those wanting to enrol as voters can submit applications with assistant electoral returning officers,” he added.The projected population of Bengaluru for 2020 is over 1.4 crore, while its draft electoral rolls has more than 91 lakh voters. According to the Election Commisison of India, 3% of voters should be in the age group of 18-19 years.New voters can login to www.nsvp.in to register, while names on the electral rolls can be verified on www.ceokarnataka.kar.nic.in.

Title: Ensure safety at all edu institutes, say Nizamia students
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Charminar: Protesting against the recent attack on JNU students in Delhi, students of Government Nizamia Tibbi College organised a here on Tuesday. They demanded that governments ensure safety of students at educational institutions across the country.

Taking exception to the police inaction, Nizamia students said the nexus between the attackers at JNU and security personnel has been exposed, and the central government has failed to protect women in the country.

“It does seem security failure in Delhi and Uttar Pradesh, which encouraged the thugs,” said Ayesha, one of the agitating students. “The goons continued to disturb peace and tranquillity in presence of police at leading educational institutions. The security personnel appeared to have surrendered to these goons who were on a rampage.”

The students felt that the move to bring CAA , NRC and NPR has not only united people, but also made take to the streets. “We have gathered to stand by students who were beaten up brutally in India’s leading university. We want to give a clear message to hate-mongers that their policy will not go on, and their attack unite us all further,” said Mohammed Maas Hussain, a student.

Title: Farm distress hits tractor sales
Content: Ahmedabad: Registration of tractors in Gujarat has fallen for the second year straight, indicating distress in agriculture. Tractor registrations in the state stood at 41,000 in 2019, down 14.58% from 48,000 in 2018. In 2017, tractor registrations in the state stood at 53,000, which had declined by 9.43% in 2018. Figures show that in the last two years, tractor registrations have declined by 22.65%.According to farmers, the decline in tractor sales is due to the bad monsoon and overall economic distress combined with a severe liquidity crunch.“Agriculture is rapidly becoming unprofitable. Due to the liquidity crunch, many farmers are choosing to rent tractors rather than buying them,” said Vithal Dudhatra, a farmer leader from Amreli.Dudhatra added that two consecutive bad monsoons have added to the woes of farmers and their income has declined while their expenditure has increased. Ramesh Patel, another farmer from Amreli, said he was planning to buy a tractor but scrapped the idea. “There is a government subsidy scheme but after the calculations, I decided to rent rather than buy. If I buy a tractor I will have to pay instalments. Renting a tractor for Rs 500 per day reduces my burden,” Patel said. A senior state agriculture department official said that due to the decline in farm yields, farmers have been incurring losses for the last two years. He said that there are very few takers for the government subsidy on tractor purchases. He said tractor sales may further fall next year due to a chain reaction in the economy.

Title: Micron strikes biggest SEZ lease deal in T, picks up 1M sft
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: American IT major Micron Technology picked up 1.03 million square feet (10.3 lakh sft) of space at Phoenix’s Tech Zone in Nanakramguda, making it the single largest leasing deal among Telangana’s SEZs.

The lease application was approved on Tuesday, confirmed A Ram Mohan Reddy, zonal development commissioner of Visakhapatnam SEZ (VSEZ) which comprises AP, Telangana and Chhattisgarh. He said the firm would soon occupy 14 floors in the newly constructed SEZ.

“Beginning February 28, 2020, Micron will operate from a temporary incubation space measuring 91,625 sft in the SEZ. Once the permanent office is ready, the operations will move there,” Reddy said. “Micron’s projected investment for the next five years is Rs 3,820 crore, with exports of up to Rs 6,228 crore. The company has also assured employment to 5,000 people – 3,500 men and 1,500 women – over the next five years.”

Industry sources said the leasing agreement between Micron and Phoenix was brokered by global real estate services firm Cushman & Wakefield.

Jayesh Ranjan, the state’s IT secretary, said: “They (Micron) had conveyed their intention to expand in Hyderabad significantly on the day of their inaugural. I am happy that the ramp up has happened much faster than expected.”

Micron Technology, which made its first stop in India at Bengaluru, entered Hyderabad in 2019 and set up its Global Development Centre in Madhapur. The centre was officially inaugurated in October last year.

“In the last nine months we have sanctioned lease for 73 units across the 53 SEZs in the zone. Of this, 70% are in Telangana and rest in Andhra Pradesh. Some of the big leases, apart from Micron, have been between 1 lakh and 3 lakh sft,” Reddy said.

Headquartered in Boise (Idaho), Micron provides computer memory and computer data storage solutions. It has a presence across 18 countries and 37,000 team members.

Title: ‘Efforts will be made to regularise share autos’
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Chennai: TOI spoke to transport minister M R Vijayabaskar on the proliferation of share autos and what plans the government has, if at all, to regulate them.

The number of share autos in the city has gone up steadily but there has been no effort to regularise their operation. Why?

It is not that they are completely let off the hook. We are trying our best to take action against those who violate rules. But most of the operators approach courts and orders are issued keeping connectivity to interior areas in mind. But share auto drivers end up driving on the main roads.

By operating on main roads that are also bus routes, aren’t share autos eating into MTC’s revenue?

Yes. It has affected revenue. As of now, there is no rule specifying routes for share autos. They are everywhere, operated as per the driver’s wish. But efforts will be taken to frame rules and regularise their operations in the future.

So after regularisation, will they be run as stage carriers or as contract carriages?

It is difficult to comment on this now as staff strength during enforcement drive will be a problem. We need more hands to look into all these details. But we will check tax, permit, route and other major violations.

Besides permits, crimes involving share autos suggest that they are becoming unsafe and there is hardly any accountability. What steps will be taken to prevent such crimes?

It is not that we can’t track share autos. Details of vehicle owners can be tracked using the registration number. But it is true that owners are renting out vehicles to drivers without checking their antecedents. We have told collectors to keep a tab on this.

Title: AMU to reopen in phases from Monday after extended winter break
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Aligarh Muslim University (File Photo)

AGRA: Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) administration has decided to reopen the varsity in phases from Monday after a long winter break which was preponed following violence that erupted on the campus in December during protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA).

The university will reopen in three phases from January 13 to 24. According to the administration, this decision was taken in a consultative meeting of deans of faculties, principals of colleges and polytechnics and other functionaries under the chairmanship of AMU vice-chancellor Professor Tariq Mansoor.

In the first phase, the faculties of Medicine, Unani Medicine, Management Studies and Zakir Husain College of Engineering and Technology will open on January 13. The exams which could not be conducted in these faculties due to protests will commence from January 16, AMU officials said.

While faculties of Law, Commerce, Science, Life Sciences and Agricultural Sciences will open in the second phase on January 20 and their exams are scheduled from January 23. The third phase will start from January 24.

In the third phase, faculties of Arts, Social Sciences, International Studies and Theology, Polytechnics and the Community College will resume classes and their exams will begin from January 27.

The detailed examination schedule will be uploaded on the varsity’s website, controller of examinations (CoE) Mujib Ullah Zuberi said. He added that off campus AMU centres at Malappuram (Kerala), Murshidabad (Bengal) and Kishenganj (Bihar) will also open faculty-wise in a phased manner.

According to the AMU administration, AMU schools will also open in three phases beginning January 9. Classes I to VIII will restart from January 9 and classes for X and XII will begin from January 13 in the first and second phase respectively. In the final phase, classes for IX and XI will start from January 17. The last date for submission of examination forms for Senior Secondary School Certificate (Class XII) has been extended to January 20.

Title: Couple lifts $300 from Kyrgyzstan national at e-way coffee shop
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Agra: An unidentified couple allegedly stole 300 USD from a Kyrgyzstan national, who was buying snacks and sandwich from a coffee shop on Yamuna expressway while returning to the national capital from Agra.

The incident took place at around 8 pm at a public convenience near milestone 100 on Monday. However, the FIR was lodged on Tuesday afternoon based on the victim’s written complaint.

Victim was identified as Bakeeva Nazira. She was traveling with her friend. In her complaint, she wrote, “We were buying sandwich from a coffee shop at Yamuna expressway, when a man and woman came to us and started chatting. They asked us our nationality and told us, that they would be traveling to Kyrgyzstan soon. They enquired about Kyrgyzstani som (currency) exchange rate for one dollar and asked if we had a few Kyrgyzstani som for them to to see.

“Since I had a few som left, the couple continued talking with us. While the man enquired about Kyrgyzstan currency, his partner engaged my friend blocking her from approaching or seeing me. Within a few seconds, the couple dash out from coffee shop. Sensing something amiss, I checked my handbag and found my 300 USD missing,” read the complaint copy.

Bakeeva Nazira in her complaint also mentioned that woman was wearing black coloured clothes with a scarf, while man was bald and wearing beige t-shirt.

Dharmendra Dhaiya, station house officer of Maant, said, “The unidentified couple has been booked under IPC section 379 (theft).”

Title: 5 lakh ride 60,000 share autos daily, but operators follow no rules in Chennai
Content:
School Students travel by over loaded vehicle in Chennai

CHENNAI: Share autos may be a cheap and convenient option to commute, but the attempt to kidnap a woman in a share auto near Chembarambakkam on December 25 has thrown the spotlight on safety of passengers.Despite transporting around 5 lakh people in Chennai every day, the government is reluctant to regularise share autos. It does not have any data on drivers, routes and fares.Anyone can buy a maxi cab, register it as a goods carriage and use it to ferry people by calling it a share auto, illegally.Though rules prevent vehicle owners from modifying interiors of such vehicles, nothing has stopped share auto owners from fixing chairs and covering the roof with tarpaulin.Commercial vehicles, with yellow number plates, involved in public transportation are given permits that detain specific routes on which they should operate. The government earns a significant revenue by issuing such permits. Violation of permit conditions attracts penalty. For instance, a private bus allowed to operate along the Chennai-Madurai route cannot ply on the Coimbatore route. The same applies to government buses. But such rules do not apply to share autos that can be operated anywhere.RTOs in and around Chennai have stopped issuing permits to share autos long ago, but the vehicles have proliferated. From 12,000 in 2010, the number of share autos in Chennai, Chengalpet, Kancheepuram and Tiruvallur has crossed 60,000.“Now that they have become an inevitable last-mile connectivity option, it doesn’t make sense to ban them. Instead, the government should regulate their operation and make them a revenue source in the form of permit fees and taxes,” said R Rengachari, a transportation activist.A senior MTC official said share autos should augment government bus services instead of operating along same routes. “If it is not done, MTC is going to lose revenue further because many passengers prefer share autos over buses. Share autos guarantee a seat and the passenger can alight as per his or her wish, unlike with buses that halt at stops,” he said.Rengachari said regulation was necessary to make share autos safer. “Owners rent out their vehicles to anyone. The transport department should give separate commercial badges with unique ID numbers for this category of vehicles as they ferry public on a daily basis,” he said.“In the suburbs, share auto drivers take to the wheel when drunk. There is hardly any police checking along poorly-lit and deserted roads. This emboldens criminals,” said Subramani, a resident of Manimangalam.A senior officer from the Chennai police said in most cases, victims entered vehicles after seeing other passengers inside. Number brings a sense of safety, but a commuter would never know the motive of the passengers and the driver, he said.

Title: Madurai: Stir over Avaniapuram jallikattu panel spills over to second day
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

MADURAI: Protests continued for the second consecutive day at Avaniapuram against the district collector’s order that the organising committee of the jallikattu this year would include the name Thenkal Pasana Vivasayigal Sangam.

The protesting villagers say V K Kannan, an outsider who claimed to be the president of the sangam, was trying to usurp the rights of the traditional organisers of the game by staking claim to the organising committee. The villagers want the committee to be named Avaniapuram jallikattu organising committee. However, the collector has said that Thenkal Pasana Vivasayigal Sangam should also figure in the name.

On Tuesday, about 75 villagers staged a protest near the bus stand alleging partiality by the district administration towards Kannan, who they said was not giving due consideration to the welfare of all villagers.

Their main demand is that the name of farmers association be removed from the organising committee. They also said that Kannan was holding talks with members of other communities who were not the real community leaders. “This was not a real representation of the communities,” said K R Murugan, one of the protesters.

On the other hand, members of Thenkal Pasana Vivasayigal Sangam put out posters in Avaniapuram thanking the district collector for allowing them to conduct the games this year.

Meanwhile, members of five communities from Alanganallur submitted a petition to the collector seeking representation for all communities on the committee of the famous Alanganallur jallikattu this year.

Title: Amroha: Two infants die at private hospital, kin allege doctors gave them wrong injections; probe on
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

On Tuesday, Amroha's chief medical officer (CMO) Ramesh Chandra Sharma visited the hospital to question the do... Read More

AMROHA: Two newborns, aged four days and six days, died at a private hospital in Amroha district , leading to protests by their family members who alleged that “wrong” injections administered by doctors led to the deaths. Officials of the district health department rushed to the hospital and ordered a probe into the deaths in Gajraula town on Monday.

The children died three days after their admission at the hospital, and their parents claimed that their bodies had “turned black”.

The first infant, born six days ago, fell sick and was admitted to the private hospital three days ago. Pintu, the father of the child and a resident of Sihali Gosai village of Gajraula, said he had admitted the child after a pediatrician asked him to do so.

While the other infant was born at a government hospital four days ago. He and his mother Yasmeen were discharged from the hospital after normal delivery. “But, the child was not taking milk and was crying constantly,” his father, Usmaan, a resident of Azad Nagar, said. He also took the child to the private hospital in Gajraula.

Both the infants died on Monday evening.

“Pediatrician of the hospital told me that the child will be fine soon. He gave him some medicines and injections. The child turned black and died,” alleged Usman.

The family members of the other accused made the same allegations.

On Tuesday, Amroha’s chief medical officer (CMO) Ramesh Chandra Sharma visited the hospital and questioned the alleged doctor.

Chandra said, “I went to the private hospital. I inquired about the matter thoroughly and found that Pintu’s wife had premature delivery in a separate hospital. The child weighed only 1.5kg, and was badly infected. Besides, the other infant was born in a government hospital. He was later admitted to the private hospital by his family members as he was crying and not taking milk. Doctors had asked the family members to show him to another doctor. The family members were taking him to another private hospital when he died on the way. He was suffering from abdomen infection. However, a probe is on.”

Title: Come forward with evidences: AMU’s student leaders appeal to all after HC order
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Aligarh Muslim University (File Photo)

AGRA: Student leaders of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) on Tuesday asked all those who witnessed the December 15 violence against the students or were injured or illegally detained to come forward and submit their personal accounts before the National Human Right Commission (NHRC). The Allahabad high court on Tuesday asked the NHRC to probe the role of police into the violence.

Meanwhile, a group consisting students and teachers of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) on Tuesday moved Allahabad high court with a writ petition, seeking probe into the role of district administration, paramilitary force and varsity administration in the December 15 violence. The legal team of AMU Coordination Committee filed the writ on Tuesday.

In its directive, the court said, “The commission is requested to complete the process of inquiry/investigation within a period of one month from the date of presentation of the complaint by the officer authorized. Also convey its findings and recommendations, if any, to this court immediately after conclusion of the inquiry”.

Former president of AMU’s students union, Salman Imtiaz, said, “We have asked all students to submit videos, photographs or any other related evidence to AMUSU or NHRC for further action. We demand AMU administration to provide us with the CCTV footages of the university campus of the December 15. We will provide the necessary assistance to the witnesses.”

Welcoming the high court decision, another student leader Faizul Hassan said that students are hopeful of a fair inquiry into the matter. “We hope that the commission will look into the complaints of students as they have been subjected to police brutalities and several FIRs have been lodged upon them to suppress their voices,” said the student leader.

Title: Don’t suppress dissent: Evicted lawyer
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

NEW DELHI: A day after 27-year-old lawyer from Kerala , Surya Rajappan , and her roommate were evicted from their rented flat in Lajpat Nagar for protesting against CAA and NRC during Union home minister Amit Shah ’s door-to-door campaign, the former argued in favour of letting “voices of dissent to be heard loud and clear”.

The two women had displayed anti-CAA-NRC banners from the balcony of their flat when Shah was in the area on an election campaign on Sunday. Asserting that they were only exercising their “constitutional and democratic right to peacefully protest”, Rajappan said in a statement on Wednesday: “As a common citizen, this was the perfect opportunity for me to register my dissent in front of the home minister himself. I sincerely believe that had I failed to do so, I would have failed my own conscience.”

Speaking to TOI, Rajappan said, “Our intention was not to malign a party...but being evicted for holding a political view is wrong and should not become the norm.” She added that “fence-sitters” need to speak out because this was the time to fight for the “idea of India” and not any political ideology.

She said the intent of their peaceful protest was to assert that not every onlooker to Shah’s pro-CAA parade was in support of it. “My flatmate and I displayed a home-made handcrafted banner bearing the words ‘Shame’, ‘CAA’ (crossed out), ‘NRC’ (crossed out), ‘Jai Hind’, ‘Azaadi’ and ‘#NotInMyName’. A conscious decision was made on our part to ensure that there were no derogatory, rhetoric words or phrases directed against or towards Shah, or any other members of the ruling dispensation,” the statement added.

The lawyer said that those participating in the rally were enraged and “visibly agitated” when they noticed their protests and “verbally harassed and intimidated” them. Some of them first made derogatory and misogynistic remarks and, then, forced their way up the stairs that led to their residence. Rajappa said she did not anticipate such a strong and violent reaction to a peaceful protest, and, fearing for their lives, they locked themselves inside their house while the “mob” violently banged at their door, until the police intervened.

She also said that her landlord, who was part of the angry crowd, bolted and locked the common entrance, which led to the stairway of their apartment, forcing the duo to call friends for help. The women, she said, were locked inside for nearly four hours until her father was allowed to enter the premises along with a police officer.

When TOI reached out to the landlord, he first refused to identify himself and later claimed he had handed over a notice to the tenants since, their “act” had caused “problems for the others”. Requesting anonymity, he also claimed that he would have told them to leave immediately, but gave them a notice since they were women. “I don't want to speak about it further,” he said. Rajappan’s neighbours said the women had acted “irresponsibly”, as a result of which they drew people’s ire.

Title: Controlled calorie intake can cure diabetes: Docs
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Agra: Diabetes patients need not to take drugs throughout life, research in the US has revealed that consuming fewer calories can cure diabetes.

On the second day of the Annual Conference of the Association of Physicians – APICON 2020, doctors from various states and countries presented research papers and participated in technical discussions concerning medical science.

President of International Diabetes Federation Dr Andrew JM Bulton said that diabetes is reversible. Once the medication starts, it can’t be stopped.

While delivering his lecture, Dr Amit Ghosh of the Mayo Clinic in UK said, “Doctors should try to explain the medical condition and suitable treatment to the patients. It is the responsibility of doctors to address all the queries of the patients.”

President of the Indian Academy of Diabetes, Dr Shashank Joshi said that there is a need to work on prevention more than treating diabetes.

He said, “The prevention of diabetes is possible. Having meals on time, getting full sleep and walking for 45 minutes daily will help in balancing weight according to height. Obesity is the major cause of diabetes.”

Title: Ruling party MLAs fear backlash over capital relocation
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Amaravati: YSRC legislators in most of the districts from Krishna to Chittoor are remaining silent about chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy’s decision to shift the capital city as they are worried about the party’s prospects in upcoming local body elections.

Although the ministers were supporting the plan, many legislators are not on the same page. But none of them is ready to go against the party president’s decision.

Sources said MLAs from Krishna and Guntur districts were upset about the new capital proposal.

“As a legislator from Krishna district, I, too, wanted the capital to remain in Amaravati. But I will abide by the party line,” said Vasantha Krishnaprasad, YSRC MLA from Mylavaram in Krishna district.

Rejecting the TDP call to quit the assembly, Krishnaprasad said opposition leaders were raking up needless controversy.

In order to placate capital city farmers, YSRC legislators are promising that the chief minister would do justice to them. “Farmers should not fall prey to Chandrababu Naidu’s designs. The CM is committed to do justice to farmers. Our government will not act against their wishes,” said Mangalagiri MLA Alla Ramakrishna Reddy. The chief minister held a special meeting with the legislators from Krishna and Guntur districts last fortnight soon after taking a call to shift the administration to Visakhapatnam and appraised them of the situation.

The legislators who attended the meeting reluctantly agreed to the proposal as they were aware of the consequences in their constituencies. “Whether we are happy or unhappy is not an issue here. We are with our leader and we will back any decision taken by him,” said Ambati Rambabu.

The legislators from Krishna and Guntur districts knew well that real estate sector would boom even in remote constituencies only when the capital is in Amaravati. The rise in land value and real estate sector could be the biggest resource to them and party functionaries down the level to consolidate their financial position to fight polls.

They fear it would be difficult for them to find resourceful candidates in upcoming elections given uncertainty over the capital. “We can manage the situation as long as people do not believe that the decision to shift the capital was taken to target a particular community. This kind of feeling might make others too distance from the party,” said a legislator from Palnadu region.

Sources said the YSRC leadership had closely tracked the situation in Rayalaseema and was relieved after finding that the situation was under control. Initially, the party leadership suspected that protests might spread to Rayalaseema as they would be the biggest sufferers due to shifting of the capital.

According to sources, the party leadership is relaxed after getting intelligence reports that suggested that Rayalaseema region was not concerned about the move.

Title: Lease of Jagannath temple’s land nixed
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Ahmedabad: The charity commissioner on Tuesday restrained the Jagannath Mandir Jamalpur Trust from alienating any of its properties, after the commissioner received complaints that the trust was handing out its land to the minority community.

The charity commissioner condemned the deliberate action on part of the temple trust to alienate trust property to “the stranger”.

The commissioner ordered that the possession of such alienated properties must be handed over to the trust “for the purpose of maintaining the rule of law and public tranquillity and sentiments”.

The commissioner said so after observing that the Jagannath temple is associated with the Rath Yatra for over a century and people’s sentiments are attached to the temple and its activities.

The charity commissioner also said that if the trust wants to alienate any property, it must follow the procedure under the Bombay Public Trusts Act.

The charity commissioner held that the efforts to alienate properties in 11 different survey numbers are in violation of statutory provisions and are nothing but the “sale of the properties” and are “non-executable”. The charity commissioner also ordered the district collectorate and Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation not to allow a change in the revenue records without following due procedure. “If any entry is mentioned, it must be cancelled,” the order reads.

The charity commissioner, however, did not find evidence proving all complaints, but found that the trust and the sole trustee, Mahant Dilipdasji, had leased out four land parcels and properties in Behrampura and Danilimda areas to private persons.

Lease land to developer, Yasin Ghanchi, who was granted a plot in Survey No. 138 for three years had recently generated lot of controversy.

But the charity commissioner said that the type of lease document signed by the trustees was nothing less than alienation of the property by the trust.”

Title: On Day of strikes, students to boycott classes
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: The students’ community from city universities has geared up to participate in the all India general strike on Wednesday in solidarity with the students of Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) in Delhi.

Students from University of Hyderabad (UoH), Maulana Azad National Urdu University (Manuu), English and Foreign Languages University (EFLU) and Osmania University (OU) have decided to participate in the strike by voluntarily boycotting classes.

“Since many students have exams, we have given a call for voluntary boycott of classes. All students will be assembling near the Life Sciences building from where we will march towards the administrative building,” said Abhishek Nandan, president of UoH students union. Condemning the JNU attacks in Delhi, the Students Federation of India wing at UoH held a protest at north and south shopping complexes within the campus on Tuesday evening.

The EFLU students’ union also issued a statement condemning the violence unleashed at JNU. “The ruling government at the Centre has notoriously tried to crush the students’ movement in universities across the country by using the state machinery as well as its stormtroopers (ABVP),” read the statement.

Students termed the attack on JNU students as a war declared by the Modi government on “university students who have been the principal voice of opposition against the anti-people, anti-poor, anti-farmer and anti-minority violence unleashed by the same Delhi police against the students of Jamia Milia Islamia University.”

Amid the strike call, there are many students who are worried about their exams that are scheduled on January 8. “Osmania University has their LLB exam tomorrow. This in view of the Bharath bandh, which many trade unions are supporting. Also, auto strike is there tomorrow in Telangana,” tweeted Naresh Jain.

Schools and degree colleges have decided to go ahead with the schedule despite the strike call. “We have practical exams for Class 10 and Class 12 students,” said Varalakshmi, principal of Jubilee Hills Public School. “There is no way that we can afford to lose more academic days in view of bandhs. We will be going as per schedule given out by the Central Board of Secondary Education.”

Title: TDP behind attack: Pinnelli
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Guntur: Macherla MLA and government whip Pinnelli Ramakrishna Reddy on Tuesday alleged that the attack on him was sponsored by TDP .

He said Chandrababu Naidu was using farmers’ protests to disrupt law and order in the state. Pinnelli along with legislators Ambati Rambabu and Vidadala Rajani met chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy in the evening and explained to him about the attack.

Later, speaking to reporters, Ramakrishna Reddy said Naidu and his son Lokesh would not be able to step on to streets if they resorted to violent politics.

“Naidu, keep in mind that I am from Palnadu, known for its courage! I am not going to be scared by your silly tactics. Remove your mask and try to touch YSRC leaders and see the consequences,” Reddy warned. “Unless it is planned, why would the protestors be ready with stones and sticks?” Reddy asked.

He suggested to farmers to meet the chief minister and tell him their requests. He said TDP was trying to divert the protest and create law and order trouble. tnn

Title: Nagpur registers highest-ever dengue positive cases in 2019
Content:
Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) data shows 626 patients tested positive for dengue, the most dreadful vecto... Read More

Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) data shows 626 patients tested positive for dengue

NAGPUR: Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) data shows 626 patients tested positive for dengue, the most dreadful vector-borne disease, in 2019.Until now, the highest-ever dengue positive cases were 601 in 2014. Second highest 566 were registered in 2018. There were 352 cases in 2013, 230 in 2015, 199 in 2017 and 195 in 2016.The number of suspected patients was low in 2019, at 2,356 cases. Private hospitals test patients in their in-house laboratories or get the test done from private laboratories using rapid diagnostic kit (RDK) technology. Patients found positive under RDK are termed as suspect cases by NMC. Private hospitals start treatment of dengue for all suspect patients.Then, NMC tests blood samples of these patients using the state government’s enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) technology.Highest-ever suspected cases of 5,684 were recorded in 2018. Earlier, highest cases were 3,722 in 2014 followed by 1,405 in 2017, 1,254 in 2015 and 1,236 in 2016. The cases were below 1,000 in rest of the years.Highest suspect as well as positive cases were registered in September, October and November, which are basically post-monsoon days. Cases started to surge from August. Cases came down in December with commencement of winter season.Fortunately, only one patient died of dengue in entire year, in September.The high number of dengue cases hints at unhygienic conditions in various parts of the city, especially in residential areas. NMC has been initiating various measures since 2016 to curb cases. For last three years, civic body is conducting activities through out the year like inspection of households, destroying mosquito-breeding spots, awareness etc. Still, cases are not coming down.NMC official told TOI surge in cases was due to various reasons. “Humidity was high in monsoon compared with previous years. Monsoon was late and heavy rainfall was witnessed in September and October too. Besides, earlier NMC used to test using IgG Elisa kit, which changed to NS1 Elisa kit, which gives a perfect report,” the official said.The official added private hospitals and laboratories started to give timely and accurate reports to NMC, which is also an another reason for increase in patients. “Earlier, reports used to come from very few hospitals and laboratories. It is a welcome move that reports are coming to NMC. We send teams immediately to areas where suspect patient stay and undertake mitigation measures. It prevents spread of dengue,” the official said.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Bishops’ council condemns attack on JNU
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

TAMIL NADU: The Tamil Nadu Latin Bishops’ Council has condemned the attack on the students at the Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) in New Delhi.

In a statement, Archbishop of Madurai Rev Dr Antony Pappusamy has said that there is no reason to believe that the attack on the students of JNU was not a preplanned one. “It is an attack which is highly condemnable. JNU is one of the most reputed institutes of higher education in the country and it is a matter of shame that such an attack took place in its campus,” he said.

Such an attack on students who were only demanding the rights of the people was undemocratic and against the soul of India. Nobody who believes in democracy would accept the attacks on the students.

Universities are not just places of giving knowledge, it is a place which shows the students to be sensitive to the needs of the outside world. The Indian society knows well that this university has been providing this to the students. It is the reason why renowned scientists, philosophers and thinkers who are beyond religion have emerged from this campus. It is the responsibility of the rulers that this continues in this institution, he added.

Title: Surat: Shatabdi Express food leaves 35 women ill
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

One of the women who suffered food poisoning at Bhestan station

SURAT: A one-day picnic to enjoy ponk , a famed winter delicacy of Surat, turned into a bitter experience for a group of 35 women from Mumbai after they suffered food poisoning on-board Shatabdi Express on Tuesday.

The women from Borivili and Kandivili suburbs of Mumbai started falling ill one after another after eating packaged bread and butter provided by the pantry staff of the train. The women, mostly housewives, were on a day’s picnic to Surat from Mumbai to enjoy a ponk (a snack made from tender roasted sorghum grains) party.

After many of them started vomiting and complained of stomach ache, some of them stopped the train by pulling the chain at Bhestan station at around 8:25am. Four women whose condition had worsened were given immediate treatment at the station.

Jagruti Mehta, who had organized the trip, said, “We were given bread and butter in breakfast in C7 coach. Both these items were infested with fungus. The bread packet had expiry date of January 5, 2020. Some of us had asked the staff not to distribute unhygienic food to us, but they didn’t listen. Some of the women had immediate effect and began to vomit. We stopped the train at Bhestan at 8.25am by pulling the chain.”

Anju Chokshi, another affected woman, said, “More than 30 of us suffered because of the unhealthy food. We had spent so much of money to travel in Shatabdi Express, but recklessness of the pantry staff made us fall sick. The condition of four of us was terrible.”

The IRCTC has penalized the contractor of Rs two lakh and issued a notice of termination. On board supervisor of the train has been suspended too.

Surat railway station director TL Garuda said, “Two were given injections and two treated with oral medicines. We brought the train to Surat station and the affected patients were kept under observation for two hours.”

Rakesh Shah, member of Zonal Railway Users Consultative Committee (ZRUCC), who was in Ahmedabad, boarded the return Shatabdi Express and checked all food samples at Ahmedabad and Vadodara.

Read this story in Bengali.

Title: Nithyananda sadhvis’ bail pleas opposed
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Ahmedabad: The complainant and the father of children who were allegedly detained at the Nithyananda ashram vehemently objected the bail applications filed in the Gujarat high court by two ashram administrators – Sriharini Chellapan alias Pranapriya and Ridhi Ravikiran alias Tatvapriya.

Both sadhvis of Nithyananda sought bail from the high court after a sessions court refused to free him over the complaint of illegal detention of minor children, abusing them and forced labour in the ashram, which was being run on the Delhi Public School (East) campus.

The complainant also said that his older daughter called him and “mentioned a conspiracy being hatched by Nithyananda himself with ‘Ranjitha’,’Ma Pranapriya’, ‘Ma Priyatattva’ and ‘Ma Bhaktipriya’ and that too with complete support of socialite ‘Ma Pooja Manjula Shroff’ and ‘Shree Amitabh Shah’ to smuggle my daughters out of the country without the knowledge of my wife and I”. The complainant also claimed that his two minor children have given statements under Section 164 of the CrPC before a judicial magistrate, that have not yet been placed in the investigation papers.

Title: Standing panel trims hike in building plan sanction charges
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Nagpur: Standing committee of the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) on Tuesday reduced the revised rates proposed for sanctioning building plan for new constructions or regularizing unauthorized constructions.

Standing committee chairman Pradip Pohane told media persons that the town planning department had upped the development and building plan sanction charges to 60%. “The town planning department had proposed to revise building plan sanction charges from existing Rs15,000 to Rs24,200 per square meters. We have reduced the same to Rs17,000,” said Pohane. Similar cuts have also been suggested in fees of other heads too, he added.

The panel also reduced premium being charged to exclude staircase, passage, lobby, lift etc from carpet area from the existing 4% to 2.5% of the ready reckoner value of the property. The department had proposed to hike the charge to 5%.

The department’s proposal to revise tree deposit was, however, kept unchanged. The department had proposed to double the tree deposit from existing Rs500 to Rs1,000 and it remains intact, he said.

“Now, the proposals will be tabled before the general body and then only the revision will come into force,” said Pohane.

Along with this proposal, the standing panel also okayed 59 other proposals wherein it cleared administrative approvals to civic works worth Rs18.18 crore and work orders for development works worth Rs18.65 crore.

The functioning of the NMC’s estate department has come under scanner after it submitted a proposal to sanction 7,000 sqft plot on Orange City Street to Madhucon Project to operate its ready mix plant (RMP) for a monthly rent of Rs1.38 lakh. While bagging the contract to concretize 5.5km tar road along Orange City Street, the firm had claimed it owns a ready mix plant at Pardi. In reality, the firm does not have such a plant. Though the firm had started the RMP way back, the estate department submitted the proposal now and the standing panel had also okayed it. When pointed out, Pohane said the NMC will recover rent from the firm from the date it had started the RMP.

Title: Locusts: Rs 31.50 cr govt aid for farmers
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Gandhinagar: The Gujarat government on Tuesday announced a Rs 31.50 crore assistance package for farmers of north Gujarat who have been affected by locust attacks.

R C Faldu, state agriculture and farmer welfare minister, said that during the survey to estimate damage to crops caused by locusts, it emerged that crops of some 11,000 farmers in 285 villages of 15 talukas of two districts – Banaskantha and Patan – have been affected. The two main crops damaged in the recent locust attack are castor and cumin, the minister said.

“Rs 31.50 crore in relief money will be paid to around 11,000 affected farmers in the two districts. They will be paid crop damage compensation of Rs 18,500 per hectare,” Faldu said. Deputy chief minister Nitin Patel said the survey of losses is was still ongoing at many places and the total compensation figure is likely to increase.

Title: YSRC leader writes to President, demands capital in Amaravati to be declared illegal
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Amaravati: Former minister and senior YSRC MLA Dharmana Prasada Rao has requested the President of India to declare Amaravati capital city as illegal as it was selected against Professor Sivaramakrishnan committee recommendations.

In his letter to the President, Dharmana said the TDP government declared Amaravati as new capital without considering the expert committee’s recommendations. “The report was not discussed in the cabinet or in the assembly/ legislative council. Declaring Amaravati as capital is unconstitutional as it violated the fundamental principle of justice and equality of opportunity enshrined in the Constitution,” said Dharmana.

He said declaring Amaravati as capital was illegal as it violated the provisions of the AP Reorganization Act 2014 and did not follow the expert committee’s recommendations. Moreover, the decision was not notified in any official gazette or by any government order. He said it was unfortunate that constitutional functions were not conducted from the common capital Hyderabad and were run from a place which did not have legal sanctity.

The expert committee had suggested that the new state capital should not be in Vijayawada-Guntur-Tenali-Mangalagiri region since it has fertile agriculture land and not suitable for high-rise buildings and expensive cost of construction.

He said the YSRC government was making a serious attempt to revisit decisions taken by the previous government by following the recommendation of the expert committees.

In this context, Dharmana requested the President to use his good offices to direct the government of India to recognize that the decision on Amaravati as unconstitutional, illegal as it was not notified either by gazette or by any government order and make necessary changes in the map of India published by the Survey of India.

Title: Agra: MCD junior engineer, woman arrested for murder of her husband
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

AGRA: A 39-year-old woman and her paramour, a junior engineer with MCD South Zone, were arrested by Agra police on Tuesday for alleged murder of her husband two days ago. The two came to know each other through social media and were desperate to get married, cops say.

According to police, BSNL junior technical officer Virender Kumar, 45, was found murdered some 400 meters away from his home near Deep Inter College of Shahganj police jurisdiction in Agra on Sunday morning. Virendra was married to Bhawna for nearly eight years and had two children. The family was living in Panchsheel colony of the city .

Agra SSP Babloo Kumar said: “Within 48 hours of murder, three persons, including the victim’s wife, her paramour 31-year-old Kapil Kumar and his associate Manish Kumar Singh were arrested.”

“During the probe, our team came to know about the illicit affair between Bhawna and Kapil. They came to know each other through Facebook and later decided to get settled. A month back, the two accused along with Kapil’s associate Manish hatched a plan to eliminate Virender Kumar. On January 4 evening, Kapil borrowed his colleague Deepak’s car and drove Agra along with Manish. At around midnight, the two entered into Virender’s house with the help of Bhawna and murdered him,” the SSP said.

Speaking to TOI, Shahganj SHO Arvind Kumar Singh said: “The deceased Virender Kumar was heavily drunk. The three accused strangulated the victim with the help of mobile phone’s USB cable and also rained kicks and punches to ensure that he dies of internal bleeding. Later Kapil and Manish carried his body in the and dumped it near Deep Inter College. The two then went back to Delhi.”

“In order to misguide the police and family, accused Bhawna claimed that Virender left home with Rs 7000 cash after he received a call on late Saturday night and did not return home. Examinations of phone call records of the victim and his wife revealed that Bhawna was lying and later confessed to her crime,” the SHO added.

Kapil Kumar hails from Ashok Vihar Colony of Agra which is close to the victim’s house, while co-accused Manish is immediate neighbour of Virender. According to police, Manish was preparing for government job while Bhawna has done MSc in zoology.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Cabinet nod to online draw for bhang shops
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

CM Yogi Adityanath

LUCKNOW: A cabinet meeting chaired by chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Tuesday cleared six proposals including new rules to allot bhang shops through e-lottery.

The new UP Excise (Licensing of Bhang Retail Shops) Rules, 2019, will allow upload of information such as list of bhang shops, details of licence fee and guaranteed annual minimum quantity of production onto the excise department’s website. The shops will be geo-tagged and geo-fenced for easy identification.

The cabinet revised the permanent monthly allowances to benefit more than 1.5 lakh employees working in various state departments. With an average increase of Rs 100-200, the government will incur additional annual expenses of around Rs 20 crore.

A proposal to demolish buildings in the old primary health centre to upgrade it to a community health centre in Kotwa village of Allahabad district was also taken up.

The cabinet further approved revising the Uttar Pradesh Jagadguru Rambhadracharya Handicapped University Act, 2001, under which the word ‘divyang’ will replace ‘disabled’. Among proposals, a 200-bed hostel for students of medical technology at Sanjay Gandhi Postgraduate Institute of Medical Sciences, Lucknow, was cleared at the cabinet meeting too.

Title: Spiritual body not above law, disclose money collected: HC
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Bengaluru: Observing that spiritual organisations are not above the law, the high court on Tuesday directed Isha Foundation , headed by Jaggi Vasudev , to file an additional statement disclosing the amount it has collected so far for the ‘ Cauvery Calling ’ project and state if it had the authorisation to collect money from the public.

A division bench headed by chief justice Abhay Shreeniwas pulled up the foundation for not specifying if the amounts are being collected voluntarily. While looking at the statement submitted by the foundation in response to a PIL filed against the project by city-based advocate AV Amarnathan, the bench noted that it had claimed to be a spiritual organisation.

“Even spiritual organisations are bound by law. In the name of spirituality, what are you doing? Don’t be under the impression that if you are a spiritual organisation, you are not bound by law,” the bench noted. It pointed out that in its first statement of objections, the foundation hadn’t mentioned the contributions were voluntary.

Looking at the number of eminent persons, including a retired Supreme Court judge, who have been shown as part of the foundation, the bench asked whether consent of those persons had been obtained or not.

During the hearing, Isha Foundation’s counsel claimed the project is to create awareness among the public, especially farmers, about the environment.

However, the bench said though the cause is a good one, the same cannot be embarked upon by forcing people to pay money. The bench also wanted to know whether it had got any authorisation for collecting money.

State got no complaints

The court also took the state government to task as to why no enquiries were made about Isha Foundation collecting money for ‘Cauvery Calling’. The additional advocate general stated that no complaints have been received and no government land is being used to carry out the project.

The state government said it is not sponsoring or financing the Cauvery Calling project and the foundation is participating in the agro-forestation project of the state government, just like any other agency.

In his PIL, Amarnathan claimed that Isha Foundation was collecting Rs 42 from the public to plant each sapling and aims to collect Rs 10,626 crore from planting a targeted 253 crore saplings along the 639km Cauvery river basin. He claimed that the project was being undertaken without any study or permission and private organisations cannot be permitted to collect money with-out prior approval of the government.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: 17-year-old juvenile rapes five-year-old girl in Krishna district
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

Title: Allow medical help to Bhim Army chief: Court to Tihar
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

New Delhi: A city court on Wednesday directed Tihar Jail authorities to immediately provide medical aid to Bhim Army chief Chandra Shekhar Azad who, according to his lawyers, is suffering from a blood thickening condition — polycythemia .

The hearing, however, was adjourned to Thursday owing to non-production of Azad’s medical reports. The jail authorities have sought time to file Azad’s medical report in response to his application seeking treatment at AIIMS.

The plea filed by Azad’s lawyers claimed that his condition required continuous check-up from the doctors concerned. “His treatment is going on for a long time under the supervision of the doctor concerned and requires day-to-day check-up. He needs to be treated within a week or maximum 10 days when the blood turns thick, which may lead to a cardiac attack,” the plea added.

Azad was arrested after he surrendered before Delhi Police early on December 21. He was refused a bail and sent to Tihar Jail for 14 days in judicial custody by a court.

He and 15 other people have been charged under sections 147, 148, 149, 436, 427, 323, 186, 353, 332, 120B with Section 34 of IPC and sections 3 and 4 of Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act, 1984. Delhi Police claimed that all the accused indulged in violence in the garb of Citizenship Amendment Act and National Register of Citizens protests.

Title: Four of family elected to panel, vendors move HC
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

CHANDIGARH: Street vendors have challenged the town vending committee election and taken the panel to the Punjab and Haryana high court over alleged derogation of statutory provisions of their governing law.

The high court has issued a notice to the UT administrator, municipal corporation, MC commissioner, and committee chairman to seek their reply. The vendors want the court to dismiss the notification of March 30, 2016, by which the committee was formed, and then order for its proper constitution. The hearing is on February 25.

The petitioners’ lawyer, Deepender Patwali, argued that under the Street Vendors (Protection of Livelihood and Regulation of Street Vending) Act, 2014, the local authority has to first identify and register the vendors before conducting elections to select their representatives. In the present case, the town vending committee was made without first registering the vendors. Petitioners claim that it robbed them of the right to participate in the election and file nomination.

They claim that the constitution of the committee is illegal and arbitrary, since four vendors shown to have been elected as members pay tehbazari (rent for the stall) and belong to one family . The petition says there had been no real election as well, since these four were the only nominees. Petitioners are shocked that in the ongoing dispute of re-election and allocation, this group of four will now protect the interest of registered vendors.

It was submitted that the city had only 465 tehbazari vendors as opposed to 21,622 street vendors of the other kind, of which 9,356 are registered, and this itself proved that former did not represent the interest of the entire group. Also, of all those tehbazari vendors, only 64 are registered, and four out of those could not be true representatives of their business community. Petitioners claimed the town vending committee was constituted without their knowledge, which was another violation of the 2014 Act and 2015 Rules.

Petitioners claim they were under the impression that after registration, they would have the right to participate in elections to a proper committee constituted by the respondents in consonance with the provisions of the Act. Since relocation, vendors have been running from pillar to post to protect their rights. They say that after being shifted to Sector 15, they realized that the respondents had failed to constitute a proper panel. They are most angry about being robbed of their right to vote.

Title: HC clears the decks for Telangana municipal polls
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: After keeping the State Election Commission (SEC) on tenterhooks for a day, the Telangana high court gave the green signal to issue the notification for polls to 120 municipalities and 10 municipal corporations late on Tuesday.

A bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy dismissed the PIL filed by PCC chief N Uttam Kumar Reddy accusing the SEC of confusing people with its actions in respect of poll notification and poll schedule. SEC had issued the poll schedule on December 23 and fixed January 7 as poll notification day. Senior counsel D Prakash Reddy, appearing for Uttam, had said that Telangana Municipalities Act clearly mandated that poll notification should be issued first, followed by the poll schedule.

Countering it, SEC senior counsel C V Mohan Reddy said that small infractions of law should not be shown as reasons for seeking stay on elections. “The local bodies do not have elected executive and there is a constitutional mandate thrust on SEC to hold polls on time,” he said.

When the bench sought to know what harm would be done if the poll schedule release preceded poll notification — even if it was a violation of law — Uttam’s counsel pointed out that all consequent notifications issued after the release of poll schedule had reduced the time frame for various phases of works such as survey of SCs, STs & BCs and fixing reservations.

“Even for receiving objections and resolving them, the time was reduced to a mere three days from 30 days,” he said.

But the bench cited Supreme Court’s Ponnuswamy case judgment that even pre-election work should be seen as election work and, hence, could not be interfered with. “If anyone is aggrieved, they have the remedy in the form of an election petition which should be filed before an election tribunal after the poll process is over,” the bench said, before dismissing the plea.

The bench, however, issued notices to the state and SEC regarding women’s reservations in Badangpet municipal corporation and sought counters from authorities within four weeks.

Title: UP fares well in Niti’s devpt score, but lags in India rank
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Lucknow: Uttar Pradesh has witnessed a jump in Niti Aayog’s markings for sustainable development goals ( SDG ) as compared to last year, but needs to gear up on overall ranking where it is placed 24th among 28 states. As compared to 2018, UP’s score has gone up from 42 to 55.

Out of 15 goals, UP has made significant progress under most parameters but its score has fallen in three categories – ‘No Poverty, ‘Zero Hunger’ and ‘Quality Education’.

“Uttar Pradesh has improved its overall score from 42 in 2018 to 55 in 2019, and is the highest gainer. The biggest improvement has been in goal 7 (Affordable and Clean Energy) in which the jump has been by 40 points. Scores in goal 6 (Clean Water and Sanitation) and goal 9 (Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure), have climbed by 39 and 34 points, respectively,” the report said.

Under ‘Clean Water and Sanitation’, the state ranks second with a score of 94. UP has shown an achievement of 99.20% coverage for households with improved source of drinking water and 100% coverage of rural homes for toilets, even as the process for providing toilets to household left out of the 2012 survey is still on.

In five goals, UP ranks in bottom five states. In three goals – ‘No Poverty’, ‘Reduced Inequality’ and ‘Life on Land’ – UP is fourth last.

In ‘Zero Hunger’ goal, UP scores its lowest 31 marks to figure fifth from last. In ‘Good Health and Well Being’ goal, UP settles for 34 points to figure second last, ahead of Nagaland.

It has been marked zero for ‘Under 5 mortality rate per 1,000 live births’ which in Uttar Pradesh is 78, the highest among 28 states.

Government spokesperson Shrikant Sharma told TOI: “When our government took over on March 19, 2017, it inherited a hopeless situation. However, we have been giving our best and the state has been showing constant improvement. We are working on all possibilities to ensure that soon Uttar Pradesh figures among top 10 states in ranking.”

Title: Vehicle sales lose lustre in Diamond City
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Surat: The severe downturn in the diamond industry coupled with liquidity crunch dragged down registrations of new vehicles in Surat for the third consecutive year.

Though the fall in sales in Surat was not as steep as that recorded in Ahmedabad, Rajkot and Vadodara, dealers are not very optimistic about recovery soon.

The overall passenger vehicle registration in Surat dropped by 8.88% in 2019 as compared to previous year. While two-wheelers sales witnessed a reduction of around 6%, the negative effect was more in cars which saw a drop of 20.59% in 2019.

Experts and dealers said that the cash flow in diamond and textiles, the two main economic mainstays of Surat, has been stifled due to recession, which has affected the buyers sentiments.

Gaurang Joshi, transportation expert at Sardar Valalbhbhai National Institute of Technology (SVNIT) said, “The negative growth is mainly due to economic reason. Public transport ridership is stagnant at 2.3 lakh to 2.5 lakh people daily. It is not that people have turned to public transport, but they simply don’t want to afford a new vehicle.”

In textile industry, the average income of a power loom worker has come down to Rs 12,000- Rs 15,000 from Rs 25,000 and in diamond sector, it has come down from an average Rs 30,000-Rs 35,000 amonth in 2017-18 to around Rs 20,000. This has affected the luxury purchase greatly.

Title: Ahmedabad: Temperatures may dip by Friday, says IMD
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Tuesday recorded 3.3 degrees and 3.9 degrees higher than average maximum and minimum temperatures. According to India meteorological department (IMD), the weather may cool down slightly by Friday.

Ahmedabad recorded 31°C and 16.7°C as maximum and minimum temperatures, forcing the citizens to shun woollens. On Wednesday, the minimum temperature is likely to remain around 16°C.

“Change in wind direction and morning’s induced cyclonic circulation over southwest Rajasthan and neighbourhood caused the weather change. In Saurashtra and Kutch, the minimum temperature is likely to drop by 2-3°C from Wednesday whereas remaining parts of the state will have to wait for two more days,” said an IMD official.

All weather stations in Gujarat recorded above 10°C minimum temperature on Tuesday with Naliya in Kutch recording 11.6°C. Surat was the hottest city with 20.2°C minimum and 31.4°C of maximum temperature.

Title: Chandigarh: Three held for assaulting cops in Dadumajra
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: Police arrested three people for allegedly assaulting cops , rioting and damaging public property at Dadumajra Colony in Sector 38 on Monday night.

A court on Tuesday remanded Rishabh (20), Abhishek (19) and Harish (27), all residents of Dadumajra Colony, Sector 38, to judicial custody for 14 days.

In his complaint, Ranjeet, a constable deployed with the PCR (police control room) van, said he was on duty along with home guard volunteer. They reached near the police beat box at Dadumajra around 11pm and found 20 people creating ruckus and fighting with each other. Ranjeet tried to stop them. The accused allegedly pushed him and tore his uniform. The accused allegedly pelted stones at the police beat box and cops, forcing them to run for their safety.

Constable Ranjeet informed the police control room about the incident. Cops from Maloya police station and extra police force reached the spot and caught the three accused.

Police registered a case under sections 147 (punishment for rioting), 148 (rioting, armed with deadly weapon), 149 (every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object), 153 (wantonly giving provocation with intent to cause riot), 332 (voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from his duty), 353 ( assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty), 427 (mischief causing damage to the amount of fifty rupees) of the IPC.

Police said efforts are on to arrest the other accused.

Title: Lt Gen P N Hoon picked up golfing skills during 1965 war in Pakistan
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Former Army chief Gen V P Malik pays tributes to Lt Gen P N Hoon before his body was consigned to flames at th... Read More

CHANDIGARH: While the mortal remains of one of the oldest military veterans of country, Lt Gen P N Hoon (90), were consigned to flames on Tuesday, many stories about his four-decade military service remain alive. An interesting account Gen Hoon had shared a few years back was about his journey of learning golfing skills, and that too at the battlefield during the 1965 Indo-Pak war.

During one of his interactions with TOI on the 50th anniversary of 1965 Indo-Pak war in August 2015, Gen Hoon had recalled that after completing his staff college, he was posted as General Staff Officer-2 (GSO-2) with Ist armoured division based at Babina-Jhansi in Madhya Pradesh. He, being an officer from the infantry, was not accepted “wholeheartedly” by the armoured corps officers, who consider themselves “superior” and “elite”, because he was not even introduced to the game of golf at that time.

He had revealed that soon after his posting, 1965 war broke out and armoured division led by Major General Rajinder Singh Sparrow was ordered to move for Amritsar area in Punjab. As a GSO-2, Hoon was holding key responsibility of coordinating in operation room of the division and to coordinate with other troops.

He further informed that while deployed in Amritsar area, they had almost cut down the Lahore area from another part of their country but due to change of plan at the last moment, they were given marching orders to move for Sialkot area. “We left one unit at Amritsar area, which later gave a befitting reply to Pakistan’s armoured brigade that was advancing into Indian territory with Patton tanks, and given burial to most of the Pattons in the famous battle of Assal Uttar,” he had explained.

Thereafter the division moved to Zaffarwal-Pasroor area in Sialkot sector, where they occupied a considerable portion of Pakistan territory after confronting with the enemy’s troops.

The veteran had explained how they managed to occupy a huge fertile land in Sialkot area of Pakistan owing to the strategic handling of the operation by Commander Major Gen Sparrow. Gen Sparrow was later awarded Maha Vir Chakra (MVC) for his role in the 1965 war.

He had said after declaration of ceasefire, they had to stay in Pakistan area for around 15-20 days before receiving further orders and it was only then that he learnt the basics of golf.

“We used to prepare ground with waste oil of the tanks mixing with sand and play golf. It was this period of war in the battlefield that an infantry officer fined-tuned his golfing skills and brought them at par with the elite armoured corps colleagues,” Hoon had informed.

He had also informed that how a visit to the battlefield by the then prime minister, Lal Bahadur Shastri , was a morale booster for the troops at that time.

Cremated with military honours

Lt Gen Hoon, who had retired as army commander, Western Command, was cremated with full military honours at the Sector 25 electric crematorium on Tuesday. Lt Gen R P Singh, general officer commanding in chief (GOC-in-C), Western Command, along with other senior officers of Western Command laid floral tribute to the departed soldier. Senior INLD leader, Abhay Singh Chautala, former Army chief General N C Vij, a large number of military veterans from the Tricity and family members/relatives of Gen Hoon attended the cremation. Gen Hoon (90) had breathed his last at the Command Hospital, Chandimandir, on Monday evening. He was suffering from old age related ailments.

Title: Traders gather outside Supreme Court panel office against sealing
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Shopkeepers from local shopping complexes gathered outside the office after discussing the issue at a joint me... Read More

NEW DELHI: Hundreds of traders of sealed shops gathered outside the Supreme Court-appointed monitoring committee’s office in south Delhi on Tuesday morning to pursue their cases for de-sealing of properties.

With the sealing drive still on a year after it began, traders said it was going to be a key issue in the run-up to the upcoming Delhi assembly elections. Shopkeepers from local shopping complexes of Defence Colony, Greater Kailash, Green Park, South Extension, Kirti Nagar and other areas had gathered after discussing the issue at a joint meeting last week.

Most of them were carrying all papers of their shops, which they claimed were ‘purely commercial’. They sought de-sealing of their shops immediately.

After long wait, the committee accepted 108 de-sealing applications. “We reached the place by 11am in huge numbers. Cops had to intervene to deal with crowd. All of us had the same question — why were we not getting relief despite amendments in the master plan and guidelines issued by the municipalities, to de-seal the shops,” said Harsh Bansal, a trader from Defence Colony market. His shop was sealed two years ago and since then he had been running his business from staircases in front of his shop.

After accepting the de-sealing applications, committee members called the traders for a meeting in the afternoon. “We told the committee members that these shops were purely commercial and not shop-cum-residence structures. We also said that the sealing were carried out as the corporation officials were themselves clueless about the norms. After hearing us, the monitoring panel members asked for a week’s time to revert,” said Rajat Arora, a trader from Kirti Nagar.

According to him, the monitoring committee has called a joint meeting with the principal secretary of the Delhi government and the three municipal commissioners on Wednesday, to discuss the matter in detail before taking any action.

Meanwhile, another 150 traders from local shopping centres were likely to apply for de-sealing of commercial shops this week, to the monitoring committee.

A monitoring committee member, on the condition of anonymity, said, “We are bound by the court’s direction and will not order de-sealing unless we get direction from the court. We have accepted their applications as routine affair and will look into the matter. However, there is no specific direction given to commissioners for meeting on this issue,” he said. He added that the traders were trying to put pressure ahead of the elections.

Title: New launches up 176%, sales rise 3% in ’19
Content: Ahmedabad: Real estate sector in the city seems have seen traction with jump in launches of new residential homes and improvement in sales. New home launches galloped by 176% to 11,487 new units in 2019 from 4,167 units launched in 2018, says a report released by real estate consultancy firm Knight Frank India.The jump in 2019 looks steeper because of the low base of new launches in 2018. State government decision to temporarily allow manual or offline mode of approving building plans and focus on homes costing from Rs 25 lakh to Rs 50 lakh provided a much-needed impetus to the real estate market.The year 2019 also saw sales improving by 3% with 16,713 units being sold as against 16,188 units in 2018. Although the sales growth remained moderate, the number of sales in 2019 was the highest in past four years. The prices continued to remain stagnant with 2% rise year-on-year basis, the report added.“Steady uptake of ready-to-move in or near ready residential inventory in Ahmedabad has been instrumental in sales trends maintaining a positive momentum despite the real estate sector itself undergoing a structural change in the recent past,” Balbirsingh Khalsa, branch director, Ahmedabad, Knight Frank India.With low unsold inventory, developers would be motivated to plan future residential supply to cater to the inherent residential demand in periods to come. “We can expect new launches to improve further in 2020,” he added.Apart from residential, office space witnessed 4.88 million square feet of new supply — the highest in past five years — during 2019. The supply stood 58% higher than 3.09 million sq ft in 2018. Office leasing also surged by 50% to 1.55 million sq ft. Higher supply than off-take kept the office market rents stable despite the significant rise in-office transactions, which mostly maintained the market’s competitive edge.“The office market in Ahmedabad has seen a strong growth in 2019. With the necessary physical infrastructure in place, developers are stepping in to meet the requirements of companies either moving into the city or expanding their presence in the city,” Khalsa said.

Title: Viveka murder: HC to hear petitions seeking CBI probe
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Vijayawada: The high court will hear all the petitions seeking Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) probe into YS Vivekananda Reddy murder case on Wednesday. Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy and Vivekananda Reddy’s wife Sowbhagya moved high court seeking CBI probe into the murder before the elections.

Former minister Adinarayana Reddy and TDP MLC BTech Ravi also moved the high court seeking CBI probe into the case after the elections. Interestingly, all the petitioners found fault with the special investigation team (SIT) probing the case.

Jaganmohan Reddy and Sowbhagya in their petitions have argued that the actions of the police and SIT were arbitrary, unconstitutional and ultra vires to the provisions of Criminal Procedure Code. They sought investigation by an independent agency, which is not under the direct control of Andhra Pradesh director general of police (DGP) and the state government.

Adinarayana Reddy and Ravi have also made a similar plea, terming the SIT investigation as ultra vires to the provisions of CrPC.
