Title: TDP leaders behind Rs 700cr deposit fraud: Madhusudhana
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Keshava Reddy group of institutions chairman Madhusudhana Reddy on Tuesday alleged that TDP leaders Nara Lokesh and Adinarayana Reddy were involved in the Rs 700-crore deposit fraud case involving the group. He also met Kadapa SP K K N Anburajan and sought police protection claiming there was threat to his life from the family members of Adinarayana.

It may be recalled that the founder chairman of the group, Nagireddy Keshava Reddy, was arrested in connection with the multi-crore fraud case in 2015. Investigations by the CID had revealed that he had collected a whopping Rs 700 crore as deposits from parents of wards studying in 40 odd residential schools in AP and Telangana. He was arrested for defaulting in paying back the deposits to nearly 11,000 depositors and 800 other individuals. Three cases were registered against him at Nandyal and two cases at Panyam in Kurnool district.

Madhusudhana, who took over the group after Keshava Reddy’s arrest and is its present chairman, has now lodged a police complaint against former minister Adinarayana, blaming him of usurping the Rs 700 crore collected as deposits by the Keshava Reddy group.

“It was due to this that the school failed to repay the refundable deposits to depositors. After the founder chairman’s arrest, I was asked to take over as chairman while his son-in-law Bharat Reddy was appointed as secretary of the group. Before I took over, I was assured that all depositors’ money would be refunded. But when I started pressurising them to repay the deposits, they started threatening me. My life is at threat and I fear Adinarayana Reddy’s family members will try to kill me which is why I have lodged a complaint against them and sought police protection,” alleged Madhusudhana.

He further alleged that Nara Lokesh had appointed his own people in the group. “I was pressurised me to appoint Lokesh’s men as members of the society and I had no option but to oblige,” he claimed.

When asked, Lokesh dismissed the allegations as “completely baseless”. “This is yet another attempt by the YSR Congress to defame me. YSRC is still behaving like an opposition party. They should realise that they are in power now and have all the resources at their disposal to probe the allegations. I challenge YSRC to first prove these allegations instead of instigating someone to make false accusations against me,” he told TOI.

Title: 'I am ready,' says Meerut hangman after Delhi court issues death warrant for Nirbhaya killers
Content:
File photo of Pawan Jallad

MEERUT: Hours after a Delhi court issued death warrants against the four convicts in the brutal rape-cum-murder of a paramedic student, Nirbhaya, and set the date for January 22, third generation hangman from Meerut , Pawan Jallad, said on Tuesday that he was ready to carry out the executions.“As of now, I have not received any official word from Tihar jail administration about carrying out the executions. But, I am ready for it. A few days ago, I was asked by Tihar to remain on standby for the executions in Nirbhaya case. Being a father, I will be satisfied if I get to hang those rapists,” Pawan told media outside his home in Meerut.The execution will be carried out on January 22, at 7am in Tihar jail. The court said the convicts can use their legal remedies within 14 days.UP’s director general (prison administration and reform services), who had in December confirmed Tihar jail administration's correspondence for hangman, said that Tihar administration has not sent any fresh correspondence to UP jail authorities on requisition of hangman.As the preparations of hanging kick-starts, all eyes are on UP which would be sending one of its hangman for the job. UP jail authorities have two hangmen, one in Meerut and the other in Lucknow, on retainership basis. Tihar administration had recently written to UP jail administration requesting to keep hangman on standby and their services would be sought as per requisition.Hired by UP Directorate of Prisons in 2013, Pawan is still itching for his “first kill”. He missed an “opportunity” four years ago when high court commuted Surinder Koli’s death sentence to life imprisonment in the Nithari case. “For seven days, I strenuously prepared for the execution. But he got away,” Pawan had said.Pawan is hopeful this time.Six people were convicted for brutally raping and murdering the 23-year-old student in a moving bus while she was on her way back home on December 16, 2012 in Delhi. She died from her injuries. Of the six people convicted in the case, one was a minor and was sent to a rehabilitation centre. Another, Ram Singh, committed suicide in the Tihar jail.

Title: Bijnor: Labourer, 22, buried alive as soil caves in well
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

BIJNOR: A 22-year-old labourer was buried alive on Tuesday when soil caved in on him while he was working in a 20-foot-deep old well.

The deceased was identified as Sanjay Kumar of Manakpur village. His body was fished out three hours later. The cave in occurred around 12:30 pm at Sadaruddin Nagar village under Nahtaur police station area.

Sanjay’s family staged a protest at the site, demanding compensation for his death. They were pacified only after police reached the spot and assured them that a case would be filed against Viresh Singh, the farmer who had hired him for excavating the bricks from the well.

According to villagers, the old borewell’s walls were constructed with bricks several years also. At present, the well was dry. The farmer had hired some labourers to excavate the old bricks.

Sanjay was inside the well and taking out the bricks when the soil collapsed on him. The farmer and other labourers tried to dig him out but it took three hours and by that time, he was dead.

His family filed a complaint with police, alleging that Viresh Singh had hired Sanjay for agriculture work but assigned him the task of digging out old bricks from the well.

According to station house officer, Satya Prakash Singh, police are still probing the matter. The deceased’s body has been sent to the district hospital for post-mortem.

Title: Bijnor: Forest department to use ‘cat lure’ to trap leopardess
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

leopardess

BIJNOR: A day after a villagers gunned down a leopard in Najibaabd area, forest authorities have stepped up efforts to capture a leopardess that has killed at least three people around Mohandiya village in Mandawar area. At the suggestion of experts of Wildlife Institute of India (WII), forest department will now be applying “cat lure” chemical to trap the elusive leopardess.

Bijnor divisional forest officer M Semmaran said, “We are using ‘cat lure’ -- a pheromones molecule compound of leopards. The smell will attract the big cat to enter a cage. We will then trap it.”

Several techniques have been used to trap the leopard but it has eluded capture. Earlier, forest authorities had set up six cages and over a dozen camera traps at different points of the area. They had kept dogs and goats inside cages as bait. Later, they put chicken and mutton to lure the big cat but it did not work. Now, they hope to apply ‘cat lure’ to attract big cats inside cages.

The development comes a day after villagers killed a leopard hours after it mauled to death a 14-year-old boy at Bhogpur village in Najibabad area.

Several senior forest department officials, including chief conservator of the forest (Bareilly zone) Lalit Verma and Moradabad forest conservator Javed Akhtar, visited the area where villagers had killed a leopard on Tuesday.

Soon after, an FIR was filed against 50 to 60 unnamed people at Najibabad police station under the Wildlife Protection Act. Villagers created a ruckus after learning about the FIR.

Najibabad divisional forest officer Manoj Kumar Shukla said, “We have filed an FIR against 50 to 60 (mob) unidentified people for killing a leopard under relevant sections of the Wildlife Protection Act.”

Big cats are posing a threat to farmers who are busy with harvesting sugarcane. In the past one month, over 100 sightings and attacks were reported across the district. They have been here in Bijnor for many years but recently they have started attacking humans. Expert say lack of prey is forcing the big cats to turn towards human habitats around sugarcane fields.

Title: Sachin Pilot takes potshots at his govt over Kota kid deaths
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot addresses students at Rajasthan University in the city on Tuesday.

JAIPUR: Deputy CM Sachin Pilot on Tuesday said those with small hearts hide their failures and shortcomings.

Though he did not name anyone, but his remark was seen as a dig at CM Ashok Gehlot and health minister Raghu Sharma, who have blamed the previous BJP government for lack of infrastructure that led to deaths of 112 kids in 37 days in JK Lon Hospital in Kota. The deputy CM was addressing students at the inauguration of Rajasthan University Students Union Office here on Tuesday.

“Only those with a mighty heart can admit their shortcomings and failures. If your intentions are bad and don’t have courage to own your mistakes, you will make excuses to hide. If those who are holding positions tend to react on the basis of their affiliations, it will make a negative impact on the minds of youths,” said Pilot.

His remark that the government can’t escape responsibility and accountability has be to fixed in connection with the Kota child deaths has caused political storm. The next day, Sharma took a dig at Pilot by demanding accountability on Pilot’s PWD.

Earlier in the day, while reacting to Sharma’s political barb, Pilot said, “I have told that accountability has be fixed (over the deaths of infants in Kota) and I am telling it today also that accountability is must so that such incidents are not repeated in future. If the affairs continue without fixing any accountability, it will hamper the government.”

Taking a step further, Pilot asked for the inquiry on those found guilty of negligence in the Kota fiasco.

Continuing his attack on his government, Pilot reiterated that deaths of infants in Kota was a sensitive issue and the government should have handled it with all seriousness. “I am equally pained to hear the reports of infants dying in the similar manner in other cities,” said Pilot, while reacting to the deaths of infants in Jodhpur, Bikaner and Ajmer.

Taking on the BJP for praising his statement, Pilot said the BJP should focus on their role of an opposition. “I as a president of Rajasthan Congress will continue to raise issues concerning public,” said Pilot while advising the BJP to not sit at home and act as an opposition.

Title: Real-time weather updates on screen at tourist spots in state
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Jaipur: The next time you visit a tourist spot in Rajasthan, you will get alerts on the weather conditions, pollution levels, humidity and other factors.

The Jaipur meteorological office is coming up with Automatic Weather System ( AWS ) where the minimum and maximum temperatures and other readings would be taken automatically and would be displayed on large screens. The system is likely to be installed at 5-10 cities of tourist importance in Rajasthan in association with the state’s tourism department.

This is a project by Niti Aayog in which ministry of earth sciences has been given the responsibility to install AWS in various cities across the country including Rajasthan.

In every state, the local weather office would get a memorandum of association (MOU) to start the service.

“Logistically, we would need a free space, security arrangement and electricity connection by the state government and we would provide technical support and take care of the electricity bills,” said a senior officer of IMD, Delhi.

Talking to TOI, Shiv Ganesh, director, Jaipur meteorological office, said, “AWS would be installed at almost 10 cities of tourist importance in Rajasthan in the first phase. And the state government, especially its tourism department, will have to select these cities. We will have to coordinate with the tourism department to select the stations, space and other technical support.”

With the system, the tourists and locals would be able to get an update of the minimum and maximum temperatures, humidity levels, air quality, ultraviolet index and other important information. “Also, the system would enable our local weather office to get online update on the weather information and we won’t have to go for manual reading of the temperature as we do in the weather observatory,” said an officer.

However, the local weather office has not been able to discuss the modalities with the state government. They have written to chief secretary D B Gupta and are trying to get in touch with the tourism officials. For AWS, 10x12 metre open space is required and a 10x10 screen.

Title: ‘Better primary healthcare can reduce infant death rate’
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Surat: Hospitals of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) registered 79,732 births and 1,540 deaths of infants in 2019. Of those who died, 50 per cent had succumbed to malnutrition , pneumonia , diarrhoea and septicaemia.

Infant deaths happen because of diseases, congenital deformities or birth injuries but birth asphyxia does account for maximum neonatal deaths. Whenever stress causes foetus to forceful gasps, then amniotic fluids containing meconium is breathed in and it gets deposited in the lungs of child. This fluid may block newborn’s airways, sources said.

Dr Pradip Umrigar, medical officer of health (MOH), SMC, said, “Proper hygiene in hospitals and nutritious food can prevent many deaths which occur due to less immunity in infants. There should be no compromise on maintenance of hygiene in hospital ICUs. It is not difficult to prevent deaths of children due to malnutrition, pneumonia, diarrhoea and septicaemia.”

Against national average of 30 deaths per 1,000 live births, Surat’s infant death ratio is 14 deaths per 1,000 live births, the sources added.

Dr Nirmal Choraria, head of department of paediatrics NICU, PICK at Nirmal Hospital on Ring Road, said, “Premature births, birth asphyxia and neonatal pneumonia are top causes for infant deaths in Gujarat. Prematurely born children have low immunity. Maternal malnutrition, delayed diagnosis, absence of tertiary health care and shortage of trained nursing staff are among other reasons for infant deaths. To reduce infant death rate, we need to strengthen our primary healthcare and improve nutritional status of mothers.”

Box

Year Registered Births & Infant Deaths In Surat

2015 76,443 1,417

2016 77,671 1,429

2017 77,749 1,392

2018 76,289 1,666

2019 79,732 1,540

Title: Madurai: Father booked for hitting 3-year-old
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

MADURAI: A 39-year-old man from K Pudur was booked under Juvenile Justice (care and protection of children) act, 2015 for beating up his three-year-old child. The complaint was registered by the child’s mother.

The man identified as S Kulandaisamy, 39, from Ramalakshmi Nagar 3rd Street in K Pudur had married Benazir Fatima Mary, 28, from Rakkiyapalayam in Tirupur, four years ago.

They have got a three-year-old son, who was under the care of his father in Madurai city.

In her complaint, Benazir stated that Kulandaisamy called up Benazir over the phone on Friday and abused her verbally.

The child, who got to learn that his father was talking to his mom, urged to talk to his mother. Kulandaisamy scolded him and beat him up even as Benazir was listening to the child’s screams from the other end over the phone. A case was registered under section 75 of JJ act (punishment for cruelty to child).

Title: Faith in judiciary restored, Nirbhaya’s mother to fight on for others
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Nirbhaya’s mother outside Patiala House Court in New Delhi on Tuesday. (Photo: PTI)

Title: Health wing to form separate cadre for building and repairing hospitals
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Jaipur: With 15 new medical colleges coming up in the state, the medical education department and health department will develop its own cadre for construction of the new institutes and repair of existing medical colleges and attached hospitals.

The National Health Mission has its own civil wing, which is involved in construction and maintenance of community health centres, primary health centres and sub-health centres.

While divulging details about the new cadre, health minister Raghu Sharma said 900 PG seats and 350 UG seats have been allotted to the state and more funds would be allocated to the state. “Against 900 PG seats, the state will get Rs1,000 crore and against 350 UG seats, a fund of Rs 420 crore will be allocated. The money will utilised for construction and repairs of the medical colleges and attached hospitals,” said Sharma on Tuesday.

Sharma said he had issued directions to medical education department and health department to prepare an action plan and to submit it at the earliest.

Sharma said over the past eight months, they have managed to get approval from the Centre for 15 new medical colleges, which will boost medical education in the state.

According to a health department official, the separate cadre will give pace to construction and maintenance work. At present, the medical education department and health department allocate work to Public Works Department and pay accordingly to them.

Apart from this, new doctors will be recruited. Sharma said at least 700 doctors will be deployed in government-run hospitals to fill the vacant posts.

Title: ‘No discussions held between BJP & Kanthapuram on CAA’
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kozhikode: The BJP ’s campaign to garner support for the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) suffered another jolt with the media department of Jamia Markaz coming out with a statement denying that Sunni leader Kanthapuram A P Aboobacker Musaliyar had held discussions with party leader A N Radhakrishnan on the controversial law.

Reacting to Radhakrishnan’s Facebook post which claimed that he had met Kanthapuram and had a ‘preliminary’ discussion on CAA, the Markaz Media asserted that the Sunni leader had abruptly ended the conversation when the BJP leader raised the issue.

“Kanthapuram Ustad was invited for a ‘nikkah’ in Thrissur. One person tried to talk to him when the guests were having lunch. When enquired, the person introduced himself as Radhakrishnan,” said the statement from Markaz Media.

“When the person mentioned CAA, Ustad made it categorically clear that the law is against the Constitution and it is aimed at keeping Muslims outside. When the person continued the conversation, Ustad sternly told him that CAA is not a simple issue to be discussed over lunch,” the statement added.

“Kanthapuram told the person that people in Kerala cutting across caste and religion are united against the law. The conversation ended there and the propaganda related to the incident is baseless,” said the statement.

Sources told TOI that a photograph was taken during the conversation without Kanthapuram’s knowledge and was used for the BJP’s propaganda. Kanthapuram is angry that the BJP is spreading the claim that the Sunni leader has agreed for a detailed discussion.

Karat Razack, LDF-backed independent MLA from Koduvally, also has expressed his displeasure over the BJP using his photograph for CAA campaigns. Local BJP leaders had met the MLA at his house to hand over the propaganda material to him.

Title: Meerut: Pillars to come up on disputed UP-Haryana border areas
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

MEERUT: With the Uttar Pradesh-Haryana border being in dispute for years as the land of various UP farmers went to Haryana after Yamuna river changed its course, Meerut divisional commissioner on Tuesday took a meeting of officials of 11 districts of UP and Haryana, and asked them to set up strong pillars on the border.

“Strong pillars bordering UP-Haryana border should be set up. While 132 UP villages have a common border with Haryana, 102 Haryana villages have a common border with UP. No cost has been fixed for these pillars,” said Meerut divisional commissioner Anita C Meshram.

TOI in October 2019 reported that Meshram had asked all the districts to prepare an action plan in this regard by November 25, 2019. The Survey of India officials were also roped in for the purpose.

The issue pertains to a four-decade-long dispute. At that time, the Yamuna, which is the borderline of the two states, had changed its course and the then central government had changed the borderline from river stream to a fixed area in some districts, however, several others remained dependent on the river line, which keeps changing its course.

Due to its changing course, it has often led to disputes between the farmers of 11 districts on both the sides and has resulted in violent clashes.

“Pillars should be set up keeping the border in mind. While the odd number pillars will be set up by Haryana, the even number pillars will be set up by UP. Baghpat, Gautam Buddh Nagar, Shamli, Saharanpur and Aligarh share their borders with Haryana. These are the main areas where many disputes were reported in the past. Meanwhile, Yamuna Nagar, Karnal, Panipat, Sonepat, Faridabad, and Palwal share border with UP. All the pillars should be set up and it should be seen that they are strong enough,” said Meshram.

Title: Army man under inquiry attempts suicide
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

MADURAI: An army man attempted suicide by holding a high-tension terminal in a transformer on the premises of the Madurai district collectorate on Tuesday. As he fell down from around 10 feet high, he was rushed to the Government Rajaji Hospital, where he is being treated. Police sources said that burn injuries were noticed only on his hands, chest and stomach. Although he had suffered less than 20% injuries, he remains under critical care as it will take more time to ascertain damages to his internal organs. He was identified as P Muthu, 25, from Melaurappanur village in Madurai district. He is working in the Indian army and posted in Rajasthan. Muthu had appeared before the revenue divisional officer (RDO) on Tuesday, after his wife, who attempted suicide a couple of days back, died in hospital not responding to treatment.

Muthu married Thenisha from Nilakottai in Dindigul district three-and-a-half months ago. There were a dispute in the family over dowry. She had consumed poison on Sunday and was rushed to a private hospital in Batlagundu, where first aid was provided. She was shifted to the GRH in the early hours of Monday where she died. A case was registered with the Nilakottai police under 174-CrPc and an inquiry was carried out. Meanwhile, an RDO inquiry was also in progress. Muthu, who came out of the RDO office, went straight to the transformer and climbed on to it. His relatives and others gathered there tried to pacify him. While the melee lasted for a few minutes, he touched the live terminal. After a loud thud, he fell down. Madurai Red Cross shifted him to the hospital.

Title: Mummy & papa, get ready for lessons from kids on cleanliness
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Nagpur: While the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) is working to keep the city clean, the role of Nagpurians in the task cannot be debated.

Last year, city ranked 58th in Swachh Bharat ranking, and to move up the rankings, the NMC is all set to launch ‘Mummy, Papa You Too’ campaign emphasizing on the role of residents in keeping the city clean, said mayor Sandip Joshi on Monday.

Joshi pointed out that in 2013, corporators and officials from Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) had visited Nagpur city to study NMC’s solid waste management plan. “But today Indore has moved far ahead in cleanliness because its residents are playing an equally important role along with IMC,” he said.

“So, in Nagpur too participation of citizens is required to improve the city’s ranking,” said health committee chairman Virendra Kukreja.

The NMC, in association with state education department and traffic police, will be launching the campaign from January 13 to 19. The NMC will approach 3.10 lakh students of 1,400 schools across the city as part of the campaign.

Joshi said that under the campaign the NMC will ask children to educate their parents on keeping the city clean. “The campaign has a hidden agenda which conveys through children that ‘Mummy Papa we are ashamed of you for throwing garbage on road, spitting, urinating in open places etc’” he said.

Giving details of the plan, Joshi said that on January 8 the NMC will convene a meeting of schools principals at Suresh Bhat auditorium where they will be informed about the campaign.

The NMC will organize various competitions during this period and prizes will be given on February 2. The mayor said the Central government Swachh Survekshan team will arrive anytime this year and sounded confident about improvement in city’s Swachh rankings.

According to him, last year the city bagged 58th position among over 4,000 cities, while this year around 6,500 cities will participate in the survekshan.

Events under NMC’s initiative

January 11 | Parent-teacher meet in all schools of the city at 9am. Ward corporators, social workers and teachers will talk to parents about the campaign. PowerPoint presentations will be given on cleanliness and awareness created on road transport laws.

January 13 | National-level elocution competition on ‘Mummy Papa you too?’. First three winners to get Rs11,000, Rs5,000 and Rs3,000, respectively.

January 14 | Street play competition on ‘Swachha Nagpur, Sundar Nagpur’. First three winners to get Rs11,000, Rs5,000 and Rs3,000, respectively.

January 15 | Makar Sankranti holiday

January 16 | Debate competition on ‘Is city cleanliness sole responsibility of municipal corporation?’ and rangoli-making competition on ‘Swachha Nagpur, Sundar Nagpur’ for mothers of students.

January 17 | Formation of human chain with signs at designated squares between 8:30am and 9:30am

January 18 | Essay writing competition for parents on ‘Indore can be the number one city in terms of cleanliness, why can’t Nagpur?’ School-level winners will compete at the Central level

Title: Nagpur: Kin of Sena civic poll candidate murdered in Kanhan
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Local crime branch (LCB) of rural police on Tuesday nabbed four persons for allegedly murdering a relative of Shiv Sena candidate contesting Kanhan Municipal Council elections.

The deceased Sanju Khadse was stabbed in the stomach before being stoned to death outside a bar following a drunken brawl on Monday night at Kanhan. Police sources have ruled out political rivalry behind the murder.

The arrested persons have been identified as Sachin Wadibhasme, Bhupesh Shahu and Nitesh Patle. While the police have detained Swapnil alias Chuha Marathe, he was yet to be formally arrested. Sources informed that intially Nitesh tried to hoodwink the cops by not revealing his name and instead identified himself as Sagar Chaudhari.

According to sources, Daniel Shinde is contesting Kanhan Municipal Council election, scheduled for next week, on Shiv Sena ticket . Khadse, a relative of Shinde, was engaged in the campaigning. On Monday night, Khadse had gone to a bar where the accused were already present. As the accused were creating scenes in the bar, Khadse reportedly asked them to behave. This irked the accused and a quarrel broke out following which Khadse slapped Sachin. Thereafter, the accused left the bar only to return to avenge the insult.

After some time, when Khadse came out of the bar the accused were waiting from him. Sachin stabbed Khadse in the stomach and one of the other accused smashed his head with a stone and fled the scene. Khadse succumbed to the injuries.

On getting information, Kanhan police rushed to the spot along with LCB counterparts. LCB in-charge Anil Jittawar deputed a team to nab the absconding accused and on a tip off raided a slum in Kamptee area. On seeing the approaching cops, Sachin fled the slum. The cops managed to nab Sachin after a chase of nearly four km. The police also arrested two of the accused Bhupesh and Nitesh. On Tuesday evening, the cops nabbed Marathe from city’s red-light area Ganga-Jamuna.

Further investigations are being carried out.

Title: Probe on after clip of Saharanpur district hospital nurse taking bribe goes viral
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

CAUGHT IN THE ACT

MEERUT: The administration of Saharanpur district hospital on Tuesday ordered a probe after a video of a nurse purportedly taking bribe from a patient in the emergency ward went viral on social media.

Officials said a panel of two doctors has been formed to check the veracity of the video, as the management has claimed that the nurse was not on duty at the emergency ward at the time of recording the incident.

“A video has come to the fore, wherein a permanent employee – a staff nurse—at the district hospital, Sita, was caught on camera taking bribe from a patient. The time and date of the video is not clear, and it looks like it was shot in December-end. An inquiry has been set up with two senior doctors on the panel,” said Dr SK Varshney, superintendent-in-chief, Saharanpur district hospital.

Meanwhile, the nurse has been removed from the position until the inquiry is completed.

The video purportedly shows nurse Sita taking money from the patient and telling the latter to come to her for any kind of help.

BS Sodhi, chief medical officer, Saharanpur, said, “The superintendent-in-chief of the district hospital has set up an inquiry. If the nurse is found guilty, then strict action will be taken.”

Title: Women’s groups renew call for speedy justice, systemic reform
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Even as the National Commission for Women and various women’s organisations welcomed the death warrants issued against the Nirbhaya convicts , they renewed their call for speedy justice within a stipulated timeframe and warned that death penalty should not be seen a solution to the problem of rape as the focus should be on prevention of violence against women and systemic reforms to ensure that.

Reacting to the court order, NCW chief Rekha Sharma said, “Justice is delayed but not denied this time”. “ I would have liked if the decision could have come much earlier. The hanging of these convicts will send out a strong message and act as a deterrent,” she added.

Echoing similar sentiments, Delhi Commission for Women chief Swati Maliwal demanded all such cases be decided within six months. “Even though it has taken seven years and is delayed but this order of the court has come as big relief and respite to all the Nirbhayas across the country. Finally justice will be done.”

Ranjana Kumari, director of Centre for Social Research said while the court order is welcome, the fact that it took seven years reflects that fasttrack justice is still to become real. “Also no one should assume that death penalty will lead to end of such crimes. These crimes can be prevented by ensuring the judicial process is fast tracked. In fact, Nirbhaya’s case itself should be studied to understand what took seven years and can be a case study for assessing the reason for the delay,” she added.

To create awareness around the issue of women safety, NCW is now planning to reach out to districts. “We will be holding campaigns across states in collaboration with state commissions during the course of the year,” Sharma said.

National Federation for India Women general secretary, Annie Raja said, “Bringing amendments to the existing laws when a case gets highlighted is not the solution. Reforms are required. We need to focus on witness protection, more forensic laboratories, police and judicial reforms and a review of implementation of existing legislations.”

Enakshi Ganguly from Haq: Centre for Child Rights asked, “If death penalty is the deterrent, it is promised to be, then all rapes must end with four men being hanged. Isn’t that what we are always told — death penalty is essential to instil fear and be a deterrence.” Ganguly said if we really want deterrence then there was need to focus on preventing violence. Ganguly and her team are working closely on cases and counselling of survivors of sexual assault, rape and violence.
