Title: Yavatmal local self government members to vote in MLC poll on January 31
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Yavatmal: A total of 490 voters are eligible for casting their franchise in the Legislative Council election for Local Self Govt Authorities of Yavatmal , which is scheduled for January 31.

The Election Commission has declared the election schedule on January 3 and the Model Code of Conduct was imposed in the entire district from January 4. The bye-election of this constituency has been necessitated by the resignation of sitting Shiv Sena MLC Tanaji Sawant, who was elected to the State Legislative Assembly.

Tuesday was the first day for filing nominations but nobody turned up, said collector and Chief Returning Officer Ajay Gulhane. There will be seven polling stations, at Yavatmal, Wani, Pandharkawda, Ralegaon, Darwha, Pusad and Umarkhed.

The voters are members of zilla parishad, nagar parishads and nagar panchayats. The voting will be between 8am and 4pm.

The counting will take place on February 4 at Bachat Bhavan, and the result will be declared immediately.

The final list of voters will be published.on January 14. Since panchayat samiti chairmen election is scheduled on January 8, the names of newly elected members will be included in the list to replace outgoing members.

The election will be by secret ballot and not by EVMS. Of 490 eligible voters, there are 247 male and 243 female voters.

Title: Teacher attacked in school, robbed of cash, chain
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Madurai: A unidentified gang attacked a school teacher inside the school premises and stole cash and a gold chain from him. The injured teacher was treated in a hospital for cut injuries.

The incident took place at the CSI Primary School in South Marret Street in South Gate Police station limits on Monday evening.

Based on a complaint from the teacher identified as J Selvakumar, 42, from Pasumalai in the city, a case was registered against the three-member gang. A gold chain worn by the teacher weighing three sovereigns and Rs 40,000 were robbed from him.

According to the teacher he had gone to bank in between the school hours and had withdrawn the money. He suspected that the gang could have followed him from the bank. The gang demanded him to part with the chain, but he refused. So, they inflicted injuries on him forcing him to give away the cash and chain.

Once they left, Selvakumar screamed for help. A police team visited the campus and conducted an inquiry. They are checking the CCTV footage available nearby to find out the identity of the robbers.

Title: As elephants wreak havoc, Belthangady villagers fume
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Man-animal conflict

Mangaluru: Villagers of Singanur , Nandikadu Parla-Makki in Belthangady taluk bordering Chikkamagaluru district are an angry lot. A herd of elephants has been troubling them for the past one week and the forest department has done little to tackle the problem, claim villagers.

On Monday night, a tusker and a herd went berserk and damaged banana, areca and paddy fields within a 15-km radius. More than 300-400 areca and banana plants were destroyed and in some places paddy fields too were completely damaged. The estimated loss is expected to run in to several lakhs of rupees, say villagers.

Using crackers and fire to chase away the elephants did not work but only increased the damage, a villager rued. “The jumbo menace has spread to over a 15-km radius in Didupe limits. If government sets up a camp every 5km, it would save crops worth lakhs. We have been living with this problem for the last two years and nothing has been done,” said angry villagers.

As many as 50 arecanut trees belonging to Vasanthi were uprooted, Ramanna’s naga bana damaged and Sanjeeva’s banana plantation become fodder for the elephants. Apart from it, in Addatodi a water pipeline too was damaged. Villagers say a lone tusker has been spotted wandering during day time on the Charmadi Ghat stretch.

Manjunath, range forest office, Belthangady, said that they have not received any complaints from villagers. “We will take action if villagers request us,” he said.

According to forest officials, in 2018-19, 16 applications were received and 15 persons were compensated with Rs 1.90 lakh for crop damages. In 2019-20, so far 11 applications were received and 5 people were given Rs 77,000 in total.

Title: Meerut: Thieves come in truck, take away 68 LPG cylinders from godown in UP’s Hapur
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The security guard present at the spot was overpowered by the thieves, who took at least two hours to load 68 ... Read More

MEERUT: A bunch of thieves, who came in a truck, broke into a LPG cylinder godown in Hapur’s Hafizganj area and decamped with 68 cylinders on Monday night. An FIR under sections 457 (lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment) and 380 (theft in dwelling house) of Indian Penal Code has been registered at Hafizganj police station.

The security guard present at the spot was overpowered by the thieves, who took at least two hours to load 68 cylinders in the truck.

They had also kept another set of 54 LPG cylinders at the main exit to transport it to a discreet location later, but the guard managed to alert the owner and local police by then.

“The guard woke up due to commotion, but he was in his bed and didn’t raise any alarm after seeing himself outnumbered. He alerted the godown owner and local police later. But, by the time help arrived, assailants had decamped with 68 cylinders. They were planning to ferry another set of 54 cylinders in the next trip,” said Sarvesh Mishra, additional superintendent of police in Hapur said.

The guard later narrated the sequence of events.

“At least 10 to 12 men barged into the premises at around 2am. They broke the locks of the godown to get inside. One of the assailants held me at gun point near the watch tower,” said Sattu Singh, the guard.

Title: Recession effect: Vehicle sales in Rajkot down 19%
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Rajkot: Vehicle dealers in Rajkot continued to reel under poor sales that have witnessing a downward spiral since 2017.

The sales of cars and two-wheelers declined steadily in Rajkot in 2019 too, according to the vehicle registration figures of the union road transport ministry.

While two-wheeler sales declined by nearly 20.5% compared to 2018, while car sales were down 14.3% in the same period.

Dealers, however, said they saw a better uptake of vehicles in the months of October and December. “The sales were good in October and December because the manufactures announced attractive schemes for buyers. We hope that the sales will recover in 2020, but it depends on the union budget,” Harish Chandra, CEO of a dealership.

Shyam Raichura, a car dealership owner, added, “There was an overall recession in 2019 that affected all the sectors and resulted in a drastic fall in vehicle sales. We are hopeful of some correction in 2020 as the sales increased in December across all the brands.”

In Ahmedabad, registration of vehicles registered a drop for the second consecutive year in 2019. The city recorded a drop of 16% compared to 2018 figure. While the two-wheeler segment registered a decline of 18.44% in 2019, sales of car dipped by 13.44%.

Compared to 2017, car sales registered a sharp decline of 20% in 2019 in the city. Against 2.13 lakh vehicle registrations in 2017, the city registered only 1.71 lakh vehicles in 2019.

According to a senior RTO official, one of the reasons for the decline in car sales is economic slowdown. “People have been finding it tough to manage their home budgets. I think, parking issues and traffic drives too have contributed to the decline,” he said. The RTO official said that the steep hike in traffic fines also affected the sales figures. “People have been going for car pool or taking radio cabs to escape hefty fines,” he added.

Title: Criminals uproot ATM with Rs 4.24 lakh, escape
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Criminals on Tuesday uprooted an ATM containing Rs 4.24 lakh and fled with the machine in Sikar on the intervening Monday-Tuesday night. Cops are checking the CCTV footages installed in the nearby places. According to police, criminals used a tempo to take away the ATM. The criminals had tried to break open the ATM but when they failed in their bid, they had their plan B ready, which was to uproot ATM.

Title: Puthumala model village to come up in new location near Meppadi
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kozhikode: The location of the proposed model village to rehabilitate Puthumala landslide victims in Wayanad has been shifted from the earlier identified site at Kalladi to a new area near Meppadi .

Wayanad district authorities said the change in location has been necessitated as it was found that the eight acres at Vazhakkala estate at Kalladi, which was initially identified for the project, was caught up in a civil case over ownership dispute.

Wayanad district collector Adeela Abdulla said the media house which had promised to provide seven acres for the model village will now hand over alternative land held by them at Puttakkoli Estate near Meppadi to the state government on January 16.

“While we are planning to set up the model village at the new location, parallelly we are also moving ahead with providing Rs 10 lakh to those victims who have identified land on their own for setting up houses elsewhere,” Adeela said, adding that 10 victims have so far submitted applications for obtaining the Rs 10 lakh relief and processing of their applications are underway.

She said the district administration has received commitment from various sponsors to build around 60 houses in the model village.

It was earlier announced that the model village is to be constructed at a cost of Rs 12 crore, which has 56 houses in the first phase. The houses are to be constructed in an eco-friendly manner and the village will have a playground, anganwadi, health centre, rainwater harvesting and drinking water supply systems.

The deadly landslide on August 8, 2019 had totally wiped away the plantation village of Puthumala. However, the residents of the village had expressed their wish to the authorities to live together as a community rather than being rehabilitated individually following which the authorities drew up the project for a model village.

Meanwhile the district legal services authority (DLSA) on Monday distributed household items provided by the judges of the Supreme Court to the landslide hit families of Puthumala . Household items including furniture were distributed to 40 families at the function held at Meppadi public library. DLSA chairman and district sessions judge A Harris inaugurated the programme.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: SP workers tonsure head, cover mouth to protest against JNU attack
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

MEERUT/MUZAFFARNAGAR: Scores of members of Samajwadi Party took to the streets in Meerut and Muzzafarnagar on Tuesday to protest against the brutal assault on the students of Delhi’s Jawaharlal Nehru University.

In Meerut, the party members covered their mouths with black cloth to showcase that the voices of the masses are being “muzzled”.

“It is concerning that the students are being thrashed with lathis and rods in their hostels in JNU, and the police did not even try to enter the premises to take action against the accused,” said Babur Chauhan, SP member.

Meanwhile, in Muzaffarnagar , the SP workers gathered at Ahilyabai Bai Chowk and started the protest against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), and violence in JNU. They also raised slogans to demand employment for the youth. The protesters staged a dharna and got their heads tonsured. As many as three party members got their heads shaved.

SP member Aleem Siddiqui said, “The BJP government is trying to disturb the communal harmony by imposing CAA. We are against the BJP's policy, and to oppose the government’s policies we will keep on protesting every Tuesday.”

Title: Devpt officer held for taking bribe
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Jaisalmer: A village development officer in Jaisalmer was arrested for taking bribe of Rs 10,000. He had demanded the bribe for PM Awas Yojana.

ACB on Tuesday arrested Rajiv Kumar, development officer of Bairisiyal village at Sam panchayat samiti in Jaisalmer, while taking bribe. He had demanded Rs 10,000 for payment of outstanding instalments of the approved loan in PM Awas Yojana. Jaisalmer bureau DySP Anil Purohit said that complainant Khet Singh had lodged a complaint that a loan was sanctioned under PM Awas Yojana at his village Kadha, but village development officer Rajiv Kumar was not giving the payment and demanding bribe of Rs 10,000.

After verifying the complaint, Khet Singh was sent to Kumar’s office at Sam panchayat samiti on Tuesday. ACB caught Kumar red-handed while taking bribe.

Title: Youth booked under Pocso Act
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

MANGALURU: A 23-year-old youth has been booked under the Pocso Act for sexually abusing a minor after abducting the victim in Puttur .

The accused is Aneesh Dias , 23, a resident of Chikkamadnur . According to police, the accused had befriended the minor who was studying in a I PU college.

Five days ago, when girl had gone to college, he abducted her and took her to Mangaluru, where he sexually abused her for two days.

The victim’s parents had filed a missing complaint, after which she was traced by the authorities.

During the course of the investigation, the victim revealed about the sexual abuse undergone by her, after which Aneesh was booked under the Pocso Act.

The accused is now absconding and a search is on to trace him. A case has been registered at the Puttur Rural police station.

Title: Madurai: As crowds grow, Teppakulam turns dump yard
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

A peep into the tank showed many dead mice floating amidst empty milk packets, cups, paper plates and other wa... Read More

MADURAI: Nearly 40 years after it started receiving water through its traditional supply channels from Vaigai river, the Mariamman Teppakulam appears to be fast turning into a dump yard of plastic waste and dead rodents.

A city known to be bereft of recreational spots, the water-filled tank has been a major attraction of late with people thronging it in the evenings. Many roadside eateries have sprung up around it, but this has resulted in the pollution of the tank. On Tuesday, morning walkers were hit by the stench of animal carcass. A peep into the tank showed many dead mice floating amidst empty milk packets, cups, paper plates and other waste .

“The smell was unbearable and it was a sorry sight as the water which was clean when it flowed into the tank had become very dirty,” said S Mahendran, a morning walker. He expects the pungent smell to turn worse since the filling of the tank is over and the water has been stagnant. As the afternoon temperatures rise it will start drying up.

Co-ordinator of Vaigai Nathi Makkal Iyakkam M Rajan, one of the people responsible for filing a petition to bring water into the tank through its traditional channels, said the eateries that had mushroomed around Teppakulam were contributing to the waste being dumped there. ``So much effort was taken to bring water to the tank, now it should also be maintained well. Youngsters are bathing in it and people continue to throw waste into it. On Tuesday it seems like somebody found it convenient to dump mice they had trapped in large numbers into the tank,’’ he said adding that the HR and CE department which was in charge of the tank should take steps to maintain it well. Proper lighting and regularisation of the eateries was a must to ensure that the waste generated was disposed properly. Industries in Madurai would be ever willing to help deploy watchmen to ensure cleanliness near the tank, he said.

Joint Commissioner of Sri Meenakshi Sundareswarar temple N Natarajan said that steps were being taken to clean the tank regularly using a boat. ``Steps are also being taken to prevent people from polluting it,’’ he said.

According to him, the dead rats were not dumped in the tank but were the ones that inhabited it when it was dry. “Now when the water filled it, the rats drowned and are floating,” he told TOI. The rats in the central mandapam which has building and plants are also falling into the water in search of food, he added.

Title: Girl attacked by wild animal
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Spot where the incident took place

Rajkot: A four-year-old girl was injured after being attacked by some wild animal in Hadmatiya village of Tankara taluka on Morbi district on Monday night.

The girl Sonal Adivasi was sleeping a thatched hut beside her mother. Suddenly, some animal grabbed her by the mouth and tried to drag her. However, it fled after she raised started screaming.

Forest department officials ruled out leopard attack and said she might have been attacked by some other wild animal.

Sonal was rushed to the Rajkot Civil Hospital in 108 emergency service ambulance. Her father works as a farm labourer in the village.

Title: 700 litre of spurious ghee seized in Jodhpur
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Jodhpur: Jodhpur police seized 700 litre of ghee and 120 litre of edible oil, busting a manufacturing unit at village Tabadia Kalan in Bhopalgarh subdivision on Tuesday evening and arrested one person in the matter. This spurious ghee and oil had been manufactured to be used during the upcoming panchayat elections in the district in the mass banquets for villagers.

SP (Jodhpur Rural) Rahul Barhat said that total 47 tins of ghee and eight tins of oil have been seized from the unit, which belonged to one Gopal Singh Rajput. He said that information was received that Rajput had been manufacturing spurious ghee and oil in his unit in village Tabadia Kalan and selling it under the brand name of Amul, Best Dairy and Samrat Dairy etc.

According to the informer, the stock was kept for selling during the panchayat election for the banquets organized by the candidates for the villagers. “We formed a team and raided the place, where we found Rajput manufacturing ghee in the unit. We seized 47 tins of ghee weighing 700 litre and eight tins of edible oil weighing 120 litre,” said Barhat.

Besides this, packets, packing material, seals and other equipment have been seized from the unit. Officials from the Food Safety department were also called for taking samples of the material.

According to the official, Rajput had been arrested earlier also for making spurious ghee and facing trial currently for that case registered by the Karwad police in Jodhpur.

Title: Nagpur: Whatever your age, get your name added in birth certificate before May
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

NAGPUR: In a major respite for citizens rushing to get their documents updated before the National Population Register ( NPR ) and National Register of Citizens (NRC), the Nagpur Municipal Corporation ’s (NMC) birth and death registration department has clarified that those wanting to add their names in birth certificates can do so by May 14, 2020, which is the final cut off date. There is no age criteria for the process.

After the deadline, no extension to the age limit waiver would be allowed as per Maharashtra government’s resolution dated July 27, 2015.

Medical officer and sub registrar Ateequr Raheman Khan told TOI that earlier, the addition of names used to be done at the zone office level for kids up to the age of 5 years. “Later, the age was extended up to 15 years by the Central government for those born after January 2020. Now, the age limit has been removed. People must utilize this opportunity to add their names in birth certificates,” Khan said.

As names are finalized later, many used to get birth certificates without the name, but with the names of their parents, date and place of birth and gender. Often, people didn’t bother to add names in the birth certificates.

With NPR and NRC linked to the sensitive issue of proving one’s citizenship, people, primarily Muslims, are a worried lot as their birth certificates do not carry their names.

Khan said names of parents and date of birth in supporting documents must match with the NMC records as well as those on the birth certificate without the name.

In case the details mismatch, citizens will have to go through a long drawn process of getting fresh birth certificates. As per Section 13 (3) of Registration of Births and Deaths 1969, applicants will have to prepare a non-availability (NA) proposal to be put before JMFC. The proposal too requires government IDs such as leaving certificate, SSC marklist, Voter ID, Aadhaar, etc. The process requires several rounds to the NMC office followed by the court which issues the order. It takes around two months to get a birth certificate with the fees between Rs3000 to Rs4000.

Muslims outnumber others

Members from the Muslim community have outnumbered the others in queries related to birth and death records in the wake of the NPR and NRC implementation across the country. On Tuesday, the NMC birth and death registration department started keeping a count after it was flooded with people coming with such queries since the last one month. On the first day, 225 queries were recorded with only 45 from non-Muslims. The rest of the queries were from Muslims who mainly wanted details of birth and death certificates of their grandparents, parents, children and themselves. By the first week of January, the NMC received 28 applications for major corrections in certificates as they need to match with other ID proofs. In December, 72 such applications were received for the same purpose while the number count in November was 76.

Title: Madurai: Disabled man petitions collector alleging bias in MBBS admission
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Arunkumar

MADURAI: After more than two years of ongoing court battle over being denied an opportunity to write the National Eligibility-cum-Entrance Test (NEET) exam, a differently-abled man has now petitioned the district collector Dr T G Vinay seeking his help.

Arunkumar G, 27, from Villapuram wrote the NEET exam in 2018 and secured above the cut-off mark for the differently-abled persons quota. However, he was not given a chance in counselling that year despite being declared fit and issued a certificate of disability by the regional medical board in Chennai. Arunkumar had lost three of his fingers, including his thumb, after being injured during an accident in 2008. After his complaint to the director of medical education (DME) did not receive any reply, the 27-year-old took the matter to court. “As it was argued that my fitness certificate was only valid for 2018, the court ordered me to appear before a panel of doctors from the regional medical board, Chennai again in 2019. They declared me fit. However, I was not called for counselling that year also. I felt betrayed and filed for contempt of court,” said Arunkumar.

During the hearing of the case, the defendant’s advocates argued that since the differently-abled man had written the NEET exam only in 2018, he cannot be called for counselling in 2019 just on the basis of the fitness certificate.

On Monday, he petitioned the district collector alleging wrongful discrimination against differently-abled persons on the basis of physical appearance when it comes to providing jobs and education of their choice and driving licence, which is basic for commuting. “It is very common for such discrimination to happen. Despite availability of quotas, rarely do people from our community get a job that is equal to their educational qualification and paid on a par with those without disability,” said S Raja, district secretary, differently-abled welfare association.

Arunkumar has a diploma in medical laboratory technology from Madurai Medical College. “I’m able to handle equipment and I cleared both theory and practical exams during my course. However, wherever I go, I’m being denied jobs just because of my missing fingers.”

Title: Kerala: Engineering entrance exam to turn simpler, NCERT syllabus to be included
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The Kerala entrance examination for admission to engineering and allied courses in the state is likely to become a bit simpler from the current year onwards as the state government has decided to assimilate the changes in the National Council of Educational Research and Training ( NCERT ) syllabus over the years while preparing question papers.

Instructions were given to question paper setters, mostly from outside the state, to keep the questions analogous to the existing syllabus that NCERT follows for Class XI and XII. Though it was over a decade ago when NCERT made any comprehensive change in syllabus and curriculum, changes were taking place in dribs and drabs over the last few years. “Some of the chapters in physics and chemistry were removed altogether in the recent years. There were also additions too that keep the syllabus more timely and connects students with latest developments in science and technology,” said a P Sathyanesan, academic consultant, Kerala State Council of Educational Research and Training (SCERT).

Several academic experts had pointed out that entrance question papers need to timely assimilate the changes that took place in the syllabus in the last few years. “This, however, would not lead to any structural changes in the examination. The number of questions, its pattern and everything else would remain the same. Only thing is that questions would keep a close connection with the syllabus that students followed in their higher secondary course. This could make the test becoming simpler a bit,” sources close to the developments said.

Meanwhile, there could be less number of entrance examination centres this year. “As per the trend over the past few years, there is an average 10% decrease in the number of candidates appearing for engineering entrance. The number of participants was below one lakh in 2019. There were 325 examination centres within the state and three centres outside, in Mumbai, New Delhi and Dubai.

The association of self-financing engineering colleges had been demanding the government to introduce mechanism for assessing the engineering aptitude of students seeking admission to the course. “We feel that the practice of choosing students based on their academic skills alone should come to an end. But, there seems no move in that direction,” said self-financing engineering college managements’ association secretary K G Madhu.

The state engineering entrance examination is scheduled to be held on April 20 and 21.

Title: Madurai: Four-year-old girl, woman die of fever in a day
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

MADURAI: Two people, a four-year-old girl and a 23-year-old Sri Lankan refugee woman, reportedly died of fever in Madurai district on Monday.

Arshithasri S, 4, who was suffering from fever for the past four days, had been admitted to a private hospital in Jaihindpuram. On Monday, after her fever intensified, the girl’s parents took her to Government Rajaji Hospital. However, doctor declared her dead on arrival.In another case, Hailin Renosha V, 23, a Sri Lankan refugee, was suffering from illness for the past three months and was undergoing treatment. She was brought to GRH after she fainted at her house in Anaiyur. However, doctors declared her dead on arrival. In both cases, the cause of death is unknown. Police have registered two cases of unnatural death under Section 174 of CrPc.tnn

Title: Nirbhaya case: If he was bad person, why would he be awarded, says convict’s father
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Vinay Sharma’s father shows his certificate and medals he won for his performance on I-Day in 2017.

Title: Fish trader shot dead in Kota
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kota: A 38-year-old fish trader was shot dead by a man in Kota on Tuesday. The victim has been identified as Shakir Qureshi.

Qureshi’s family created ruckus at MBS Hospital where his body was brought for autopsy. However, they agreed for post-mortem and took the body after police convinced them for immediate action in the matter.

Kaithunipole SHO Pawan Kumar Meena said accused Aman Baccha along with a few others reached fish market late on Tuesday morning and began an argument over monetary dispute with another fish trader near the fish stall of the deceased. When Qureshi intervened, Bachha and his men became irritated and fire at him killing him on the spot, Meena said.

Bachha immediately fled and was yet to be nabbed by police.

Title: Unidentified men throw acid on railway employee in Bareilly
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Bareilly: Three unidentified men threw acid on a railway employee leaving him seriously injured in city’s Izzatnagar railway colony on Tuesday morning. The attackers are yet to be identified and the reason of the attack was also not clear, police said, adding that they were waiting for a written complaint to register an FIR. Police suspect that the attack might be fallout of old enmity.

Manish Kumar Chaubey, 48, an employee in signal department of railways’ Izzatnagar division, was on his way to office when a car pulled up near him and a person asked for an address. After the inquiry, the car moved ahead but returned in a while and a man threw acid on Chaubey. He was rushed to the district hospital with burn injuries on his chest and shoulder.

“The acid was quite strong and his jacket saved his life,” said a doctor who attended Chaubey.

Later, police was informed and SHO of Izzatnagar police station AK Verma recorded the statement of the victim. Verma told TOI later, “The incident was reported near gate number 2 of Izzatnagar railway colony on Bareilly-Nainital state highway. We sent a police team to the spot after speaking with the victim and also recorded the statement of locals. The motive of the attack is still not known but it looks like the accused had enmity with the victim. We are waiting for a written complaint for filing an FIR but investigation in this case is on.”

Title: Cong MLA demands removal of Kota zila pramukh over graft
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kota: Bharat Singh, the Congress MLA from Sangod in Kota , on Monday shot a letter to CM Ashok Gehlot, PCC chief Sachin Pilot and AICC general secretary and state in-charge Avanish Pande demanding immediate removal of zila pramukh Surendra Gurjar and his dismissal from the party for alleged involvement in corruption.

In a letter dated January 6, Singh wrote that after three decades, Congress got its zila pramukh in Kota, Surendra Gurjar, and the partymen had struggled hard to enthrone him on this post but charges of corruption levelled against him by ACB are painful for the party. Singh claimed that in a meeting held on January 2 in Simliya gram panchayat, the party workers consented to remove Gurjar from zila pramukh’s post and dismiss him from the party. He added that for the first time in the state’s history party workers of state assembly area have demanded removal and dismissal of their own party member.

Stressing that conveying message to the public was necessary in the political system, the MLA reminded CM Gehlot about his budget speech on July 10, 2019, that his government would work on the policy of ‘zero discretion, zero corruption and zero harassment’. He referred to the standards of best behavior in public life as mentioned in CM’s budget speech and also to the ‘Seven Sins’ propagated by Mahatma Gandhi.

“Where there are talks for commitment to zero corruption, 100% corruption is underway in mining department of the government,” the MLA stated in his letter.

Title: Bizman exposes towed vehicle racket in city
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Grab from the video shared by the businessman

Surat: A 31-year-old businessman from Varachha submitted an application to city police commissionerate on Tuesday alleging that traffic police and tow crane staff were collecting money for towed vehicles, but not issuing receipts to traffic violators. The businessman has levelled serious corruption allegations against the cops and shared videos on social media too. The complainant has also submitted an application to anti-corruption bureau (ACB).

Milan Desai, owner of a mobile service franchise, in his application demanding action against the cops alleged that his friend Dharmesh Khunt’s motorcycle was towed away by traffic police crane on Monday evening. He accompanied Khunt to get the motorcycle released.

Desai inquired about the seized motorcycle from a cop at Gitanjali on Varachha Road. “The policeman asked me to talk to a staffer on the crane. I went to him when the man told me to give Rs400, Rs100 less than regular charge, to get the motorcycle released,” Desai told TOI.

After Desai paid Rs400, they were given the motorcycle but the traffic cops did not give any receipt. “They told us you will have to pay Rs500 if you want receipt. If anyone agrees to pay Rs500 for a receipt, the cops start demanding driving licence, PUC, insurance and registration papers,” he added.

Desai shot the entire incident with three different phones’ cameras. He contacted other victims on the spot from whom the cops had collected Rs400 but did not give them the receipts.

“To avoid harassment and to save Rs100, a number of people were paying Rs400. It is a racket and I have written about it to police and anti-corruption bureau, Desai added.

“I have received the application and we will conduct an inquiry. I am yet to get the videos,” said Prashant Sumbe, deputy commissioner of police, traffic.

Sumbe claimed that when a towed vehicle is brought to the storage area, it gets registered and an entry is made when it is returned to the owner. But there exists no regular checking system to match the seizures and the fine collected against each vehicle, he said.

Title: Nagpur: Jai Prakash Nagar station doubles Metro’s ridership
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The opening of the Jai Prakash Nagar station on the Sitabuldi-Khapri stretch (Reach I) has proved to be a boon... Read More

NAGPUR: The opening of the Jai Prakash Nagar station on the Sitabuldi-Khapri stretch (Reach I) has proved to be a boon for Nagpur Metro as the ridership has almost doubled. The station was opened on November 20, 2019. Another reason is the increase in the frequency of trains from November 27. Earlier, it was every 30 minutes. Now, it is at 15-minute intervals.

Figures compiled by MahaMetro show that the average daily ridership in November 2019 was about 1,812 and the daily collection was Rs34,966. The corresponding figures for December are 3,613 and Rs65,085. The monthly ridership of November was 54,356 and collection was Rs10.49 lakh. The figures increased to 1,11,990 and Rs20.18 lakh in December.

A MahaMetro official said that the increase in ridership was due to the opening of the Jai Prakash Nagar station. “A lot of people board the Metro from there and many get down as well. You can always see commuters at this station. The increase in frequency has also increased ridership,” he added.

The official further said that the Rahate Colony station would be opened soon followed by Chhatrapati Nagar. “We are expecting ridership to increase significantly after opening of these stations,” he added.

MahaMetro had planned to open all the stations in Reach I by the end of December 2019. However, it has missed this target. Only one station started after the initial five. The remaining stations are expected to open by March end. Various reasons have delayed the opening.

The official feels that ridership of Reach I will also increase after Reach III (Sitabuldi to Lokmanya Nagar stretch) becomes operational. “People from Lokmanya Nagar or Subhash Nagar going to say Jai Prakash Nagar or the Airport can change trains at Sitabuldi. Similarly, if a person living in Jai Prakash Nagar wants to go to the Institution of Engineers, he can take the Metro,” he said.

Despite tall promises by Metro officials, feeder services are not available at the stations. This is a big discouragement for people desirous of using the Metro. Unless shared taxis and autorickshaws are made available there, only people living near the stations will use the Metro. City buses have provided connectivity to the stations, but their frequency is not sufficient. These things will have to be sorted out by Metro officials if they really want Nagpurians to use the Metro.

Title: Madurai: 2-year-old with rare auto-immune disease recovers at Government Rajaji Hospital
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Vigneshwaran with parents and doctors at GRH

MADURAI: A two-year-old boy, suffering from a rare auto-immune disease affecting his nervous system, has recovered after surviving months on ventilator support at Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) in Madurai .

The boy, Vigneshwaran R, from Anna Nagar in Madurai, was admitted to the GRH’s pediatric ward on May 24 last year after the boy went into a sudden full-body paralysis. He was diagnosed with the Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS), an auto-immune disorder which results in rapid-onset of muscle weakness caused damage of the peripheral nervous system by the immune system.

Initially, doctors from the pediatrics dept treated Vigneshwaran with Immunoglobulin and Methyl Prednisolone after which the boy suffered breathing difficulties. For seven months, he was put on ventilator. “The boy was prone to infection and complications being on mechanical ventilation, but our pediatric team successfully ensured his gradual recovery. It is not an easy feat to keep a 2-year-old child on ventilator support for seven months,” said GRH Dean Dr Sangumani J. Treatment through administration of antibiotics, chest physiotherapy and nutritional support were also provided. After eight months of treatment Vigneshwaran has fully recovered and is able to walk with support and consume food. He is set to be discharged on Wednesday. The treatmentwhich could have otherwise cost up to Rs 1.5 crore in a private hospital was done free of cost for the child, under the Chief Minister’s Comprehensive Health Insurance Scheme.

Title: Gujarat: Dust your helmets, they could be compulsory again
Content:
People buying helmets in Ahmedabad

GANDHINAGAR: Just over a month after the Gujarat government made the wearing of helmets optional in cities and towns, it could be forced to eat humble pie and reverse its decision. Following a rap from the Supreme Court-monitored road safety committee and the central government issuing an advisory to states that they cannot lower penalties below the level prescribed in the new Motor Vehicles Act, it seems the state government will soon withdraw its relaxation of the mandatory helmets rule.Deputy chief minister Nitin Patel on Tuesday said, “People have to use two-wheelers frequently. Women have to use two wheelers to drop and pick up their children to school and tuition classes. This was a problem and we had taken the decision (to make helmets optional) after getting feedback from the people. We will now act according to directions of the Supreme Court or central government.”In a cabinet decision on December 4, 2019, the government passed a resolution stating that wearing helmets will not be compulsory in areas under municipal corporations and municipalities. The decision was taken after the government received several representations from the people against making the use of helmets compulsory.The state government could find itself in more trouble over notifying penalties for various traffic offences.

Title: Rajasthan: Farmers, govt join hands to fight locusts in Jodhpur division
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Farmers spray pesticides at a field in Jaisalmer on Tuesday.

JAISALMER: The locust menace has created havoc in the entire Jodhpur division . The insects are destroying crops in Jaisalmer, Barmer, Jalore, Sirohi and Pali. The efforts to control locusts are proving insufficient. So, farmers along with government authorities are trying to control the problem

Meanwhile, BSF has sounded high alert over likely invasion of swarm of locusts from Pakistan on Monday. On Tuesday, BSF DIG Mukesh Singh held a meeting with all commandants, ADM O P Vishnoi, locust control and agriculture department officers. In the meeting, it was decided to share information and increase coordination.

BSF sources said it has directed company commanders and jawans to keep watch on locusts entering into India from Pakistan and inform immediately to BSF headquarters and district administration.

In Western Rajasthan, the situation has gone totally out of control and locusts have destroyed crops and farmers now themselves have started destroying locusts.

Locusts have spread over 1,000km area in last few days. Swarms of locusts have attacked Ramgarh and Mohangarh canal areas and 5,000 farmers have spread in the area with their tractors. These farmers, along with department teams, are spraying pesticides. The farmers are also burning material to control the insects. Women and children beat plates to drive those insects from their fields.

On Monday night, locusts attacked in Bhi, Bhopa, and other villages. Farmers, locust and agriculture department officials, including joint directors Jagpal Singh, Dr. J P Singh, locust control officer Om Prakash Chaudhary, agriculture department deputy director Radheyshayam Narewal, joint director Om Prakash and teams have started destroying locusts.

A company has launched two drones to spray pesticides. A drone in one minute sprays pesticides in three bighas of land.

According to sources, locusts have laid eggs in Pakistan and the young ones will once again create problems for India. Pakistan has requested China and Saudi Arabia to help in killing locusts. Locusts have affected 6,364 villages in10 districts of Rajasthan.

Title: Nirbhaya case: Time to prepare will, make peace with god
Content:
All four convicts will be counselled on a daily basis by the jail counsellor and their health monitored. (File... Read More

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

NEW DELHI: All the four convicts in the Nirbhaya gang rape and murder case , who were handed the death sentence on Tuesday, will now be shifted to a solitary cell in jail number 3 . During the 14-day period, they will be allowed to meet their family members, prepare a will and listen to readings of religious scriptures . All four of them will be counselled on a daily basis by the jail counsellor.Special care would be taken to ensure that their health does not deteriorate. They would be kept on a simple diet and allowed to keep one set of clothes and only necessary personal belongings. Sources say that the convicts can still opt for a mercy or curative petition during this period, subject to the pleas being granted by the court, even though the one-week period allotted for them to file for a mercy plea has lapsed.Under the new jail rules implemented in 2018, the family members of the convicts would be handed the death sentence in a red envelope. The acknowledgement, along with the date of receipt, should be entered in a register. The death sentence would also be read out to the convicts.“During the period of 14 days, the convicts hand over their personal belongings to the family members. Death row convicts are shifted to a brightly lit, solitary confinement cell where they are kept under the watch of a warden through the day,” said a jail source.After being shifted to the confinement cells, the four convicts can be allowed to meet each other, but only in presence of a jail staffer. The jail authorities would also take their measurements for the clothes that they will be made to wear while being hanged.The source added that convicts under a death row run into bouts of anxiety and depression after their mercy plea is rejected. “In case of hanging of Ujagar Singh and Kartar Singh alias Ranga Billa, one of them had run into a state of depression to the extent that he had started developing bouts of illness.”

Title: Trichy corporation, railways plan to redevelop Salai Road RoB
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The RoB across the railway tracks between Trichy Fort and Mutharasanallur railway stations was built with bric... Read More

TRICHY: Trichy City Corporation has embarked on a study to widen the approach roads of the Road over Bridge (RoB) on Salai Road by utilising the infrastructure and amenities fund of the state government. The civic body jointly with the Southern Railway has also planned to replace the centuries-old British-era road over bridge near Trichy Fort railway station.

Salai Road RoB often called Maris Theatre RoB serves as a crucial link between the commercial streets namely Main Guard Gate, Karur Bypass Road and Thillai Nagar. The RoB across the railway tracks between Trichy Fort and Mutharasanallur railway stations was built with brick and lime mortar in 1866. While the approach roads of the RoB are maintained by Trichy City Corporation, the span of the bridge over the tracks are managed by the Southern Railway. Though the RoB was strengthened in 2011 with epoxy grout, both the Railways and the civic body arrived at a decision to replace the RoB because of its age. The proposal was only in talks since 2017, and the corporation came forward to widen the approach roads under Smart Cities Mission in 2019. But now, changing the plan, the civic body has opted to avail the infrastructure and amenities fund of the state government. Subsequently, a study by a consultant is initiated.

While the approach roads will be redeveloped by the civic body, the RoB over the railway tracks will be jointly developed by Southern Railway and Trichy City Corporation. “We have written to the Commissionerate of Municipal Administration (CMA) seeking fund. Railways have sought for 50-50 share in bearing the cost of building a new span of the RoB,” a senior official with the corporation said. The Southern Railway has estimated the cost of the new RoB at Rs 20 crore. The study will also estimate the cost to widen the approach roads and the feasibility to widen the road to a maximum possible extent.

The corporation said that the existing RoB will be demolished for constructing the new RoB once the proposal is materialised. “The proposal should be expedited swiftly. Width of the RoB’s span over the track should be at least 10 metres, for the smooth flow of traffic,” Subash Chandran, a resident of Woraiyur, said. The civic body added that no land is acquired for widening the approach roads.

Title: More than 13% long-time mobile users face hearing loss: Survey
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Nagpur: A recent study conducted in Nagpur to evaluate hearing status in chronic mobile phone users reveals that about 13% of them could face hearing loss if they continue long duration calls on cellphones.

Students and professors of ENT department at city’s NKP Salve Institute of Medical Sciences and Research Centre (Lata Mangeshkar Hospital) conducted the survey and published it recently in the panacea journal of medical sciences.

“The study was like an in-house exercise of our college in which 60 MBBS students were selected as subjects. They were using mobile phones for at least a year and did not have any other causes of or family history of hearing loss,” said Dr Nitin Deosthale, professor of ENT department.

“In the study group, dominant ear of the subjects was included and non-dominant ear was considered as a control group. We conducted pure-tone audiometry to evaluate their hearing status,” he said.

Pure-tone audiometry is described as the gold standard test for assessment of a hearing loss.

Of the total students, 76.66% were using their right ear as dominant ear during calls while 23.33% were using their left ones. After the audiometry test, it was found that dominant ears of 86.66% had normal hearing and 13.33% had hearing loss in high frequencies (4,000 and 8,000 Hz). Interestingly, hearing was normal in non-dominant ear of all subjects. Mean hearing threshold (burden) in dominant ear was 10.54 + 5.75 dB while in non-dominant ear, it was 6.67 + 3.76 dB.

“More serious issue was the type of hearing loss identified in these 13% subjects. They were identified with sensorineural hearing loss which is generally called ‘permanent’ because there is no pill, medication, or surgery that can restore natural hearing. It can be treated only with the use of hearing aids or cochlear implants,” said Dr Deosthale.

Several other studies conducted on the similar subject by other medical colleges in India also show similar conclusions. Many ENT specialists don’t even recommend over use of head phones, earphones and Bluetooth speakers fixed in ear.

“Headphone-induced hearing damage cannot be ruled out if the use is more. To avoid it, we must break some habits. Firstly, reduce the listening time. Then turn down the volume of headphones. Using good quality head phones is also important,” said Dr Devendra Mahore.

He said that ENT surgeons will discuss these issues during the 72nd Annual Conference of the Association of Otolaryngologists of India (AOICON 2020) that is scheduled to be held in the city between January 9 and 12. More than 480 scientific research papers will be presented during the four-day conference.

Title: Info officer can’t pass order on behalf of FAA, says CIC
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kota: The Central Information Commission (CIC) in a video conference hearing of an appeal by Kota-based activist made a benchmark direction observing that Central Public Information Officer (CPIO) cannot pass an order on behalf of the First Appellate Authority (FAA) and FAA should be senior in rank to CPIO.

The commission also expressed its displeasure at the conduct of the public authority for handling the RTI applications in such a negligent and inappropriate manner.

Activist Sujeet Swami in 2018 filed four applications under RTI Act to CPIO, office of the registrar, Indian Institute of Technology, Mandi and sought information on various points. Finance officer and CPIO, IIT, Mandi, J R Sharma on one of the four RTI applications, made reply on July 2018 but the appellant Swami was not satisfied with the reply, particularly on point number five.

On being dissatisfied with the response, Swami then moved to file online first appeal to the FAA but the CPIO at IIT Mandi, putting the RTI Act’s provisions far aside, made reply on behalf of the FAA and the reply to all the points were the same. The CPIO charged Rs 54 for photocopy of 27 pages but Swami was provided with only eight pages of the reply, instead of 27.

Further disappointed by the same reply by the same officer, Swami on August 11, 2018 moved to file second appeal in the matter on which the hearing through video conferencing was held last week. CIC Vanaja N Sarna from New Delhi heard the matter through video conferencing and sought explanation from CPIO Sharma.

On a query by the commission to explain as to why the first appeal was disposed of by the CPIO on behalf of the FAA, the CPIO was unable to explain anything in this regard.

Referring to Section 19(1) of the RTI Act, the commission stated in its order that it is clear that the FAA should be senior in rank to the CPIO and nowhere it is mentioned or can be interpreted that the CPIO can pass an order on behalf of the FAA. At the FAA stage, the CPIO’s reply is under challenge and the duty of the FAA is to address the issues raised by the appellant in his first appeal while passing a speaking order and as a general principle, a man cannot be a judge in his own cause. It cannot be expected that a CPIO who gave a reply will find fault in his own reply. This shows clear violations of the provisions of the RTI Act in the respondent organization, the commission said.

Title: Kerala cabinet allots Rs 961 crore to repair roads damaged during floods
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

CM Pinarayi Vijayan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: State cabinet on Tuesday decided to spend Rs 961.24 crore from Chief Minister’s Distress Relief Fund for renovating and repairing roads under civic bodies (LSGI) which got damaged in the floods.

The works will be carried out under a project christened ‘chief minister’s scheme for local road renovation’. The government has identified 11,880km of roads in rural as well as urban areas in need of immediate repair and renovation following the deluge that hit Kerala in 2018. Committees would be set up at local level for implementing the project on an urgent basis. District-level technical committees would also be formed to oversee the works. Engineers from local bodies would be members in the committees, a statement from the office of CM’s office said. Wayanad and Kannur districts would get the highest allocation from the scheme. While Wayanad would get Rs 149.44 crore, Kannur would get Rs 120.69 crore. Kasaragod (Rs 15.56 crore), Kottayam (Rs 33.99 crore) and Idukki (Rs 35.79 crore) would be getting the least amount of allocation from the scheme.

Industrial force to be expanded

The cabinet has also decided to expand the strength of state industrial security force (SISF). A total of 2,000 posts would be created in two phases with 1,000 in the first stage. The post creation would be as per the conditions proposed by finance department. The statement, however, did not elaborate the conditions put forward by the finance department. A committee would be formed with additional chief secretary (home) as the chairman and it will submit a report on recruitment, training and deployment of the force. State police chief and Kerala police academy director would be members in the committee.

The force was set up in 2011 for providing security to major state government offices and other government and private establishments. The force, modelled on Central Industrial Security Force, now has a strength of 979 personnel.

In order to smoothen the functioning of Kerala Karunya health insurance scheme, the government would set up a state health agency. As many as 33 posts would be created for this.

The cabinet has decided to close down the centre for science and technology entrepreneurship development society (C-STED) under science and technology department.

Anoop Nambiar has been appointed as managing director of Kerala State Handloom Development Corporation (Hanveev). Pullanikkatt Suresh is the managing director of Steel and Industrial Forgings Limited. Former agriculture director A R Ajayakumar would be new food safety commissioner.

Title: Bharat bandh in Gujarat: Bank, rail unions on strike in Gujarat
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Members of Maha Gujarat Bank Employees Association (MGBEA) along with Gujarat Mazdoor Panchayat hold rally at ... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Public sector banks across Gujarat are on a strike on Wednesday as part of a nationwide stir. Some 40,000 members of Maha Gujarat Bank Employees Association (MGBEA) are participating in the strike. Bankers are protesting because their salaries have not been revised.

“We have demanded that wilful default be declared a criminal offence. At the same time, the government should initiate efforts to make recruitments in the banking sector,” said Janak Rawal, general secretary, MGBEA.

Trade and industry bodies have raised concerns over the closure of public sector banks across the state. They say the move will halt crucial business.

All India Railwaymen’s Federation (AIRF) and Western Railways Employees Union (WREU) had announced on Tuesday that they would support the strike by holding protests at various places.

“The Union government is speeding up the process of privatization and now is eyeing the railways,” said RC Sharma, assistant general secretary AIRF and WREU president. “The government is not able to control the economy so it has decided to sell the railways.”

Sharma said that the government has been trying to sell land parcels of railways lying in prime locations to some industrialist.

Title: Temple ritual to be plastic-free
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

MANGALURU: The Brahmakalashotsava at the Kateel Temple being held from January 22 to February 3 will be plastic-free . The temple management has decided for zero-plastic use during the upcoming celebrations, and have decided to continue the same in the future.

According to the temple management committee, the Brahmakalashotsava is expected to draw around 25 lakh devotees from across the country, and they have already made arrangements to serve food and prasadam without the use of plastic. Hari Narayana Asranna , temple priest, Kateel Shri Durgaparameshwari Temple , told TOI that earlier the temple served everything on plastic, including the prasadam. However, soon the temple will go plastic-free.

He said starting from this Brahmakalashotsava, the temple has decided to go plastic-free wherever possible. The prasadam will be served in paper covers, and cloth or paper bags will be given to devotees. The temple already procured materials for the same.

Plastic is used in serving food and beverages. Coffee and tea will now be served in paper cups. “Food will be served on plantain leaves, and steel and areca sheaths will be used. The temple is also mulling to use plates made out of fibre for serving food, but it’s not yet finalised,” said Hari Narayana.

The use of plastic will also be cut down in outdoor publicity materials such as banners and buntings. Hari Narayana said that all the banners and buntings will be made from cloth. The management has also strictly banned the use of packaged drinking water bottles inside the temple premises. “In order to provide drinking water to devotees, we have installed a reverse osmosis plant. The water from this plant was put in 20 litre cans and placed around the temple premises, for drinking purposes,” he said. However, holy water or teertha will be continued to be served in plastic bottles. Hari Narayana Asranna said that they increased the grade of plastic of teertha bottles and are exploring alternatives to replace them with non-plastic bottles.

Title: Two arrested for smuggling animal parts
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Bareilly: A joint team of forest department and Sashastra Seema Bal (SSB) nabbed two alleged poachers on the Dudhwa-Nepal international border on Monday. They seized animals parts from them. One of the arrested men is a Nepalese.

The accused have been identified as Jangiram Chaudhary, a native of Nepal’s Kailali district, and Ram Autar, a resident of Lakhimpur Kheri district. During a joint inspection by SSB and forest team of Bankati forest range of Dudhwa Tiger Reserve, they received tip-off that the accused were on way to sell animal parts. The team caught the two men and sent them to jail.

Sanjay Pathak, field director, Dudhwa Tiger Reserve, said, “We have recovered claws of a vulture and a crane, a monkey’s leg and a few other parts of animals. An FIR has been lodged against both under the Wildlife Protection Act and Indian Forest Act. They have been sent to jail in Lakhimpur Kheri.”

Title: Nourish soil, soothe mind and body
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The passion of gardening came to me when I was battling severe diabetes. It helped me engage my mind and body ... Read More

The passion of gardening came to me when I was battling severe diabetes. It helped me engage my mind and body in creative pursuits. Today, I take pride in designing my entire garden by making the best from waste . In fact, involving myself in these activities has helped me to almost get rid of my illness, and because of it I’m healthier than ever.

There is a hut in the garden made of waste carton, a black hill which is basically a slag of ferromanganese and a small well made from a paint drum. I have also created vertical gardens from scrap cupboards, bamboo sticks, used bottles and broken pipes. Bamboo roots are effectively used for decorative purposes. I have nice, healthy papayas in the terrace garden, mainly through the use of kitchen waste.

There is also a small castle waterfall made from broken wall hangings fixed in a paint drum. Other drums are used for making organic fertilizer, and many succulent plants are placed in cooler tanks.

I have a tin container where I put all the natural waste, such as fruits and vegetable waste, dry leaves, petals, grass etc and alternatively layer it with mud and water. Within a few weeks, good quality manure is generated from that, which is used to soil the papaya tree. I have also placed an old bathtub on my terrace. I have soiled it and it is now a beautiful kitchen garden where I grow tomatoes, chillies, radish etc.

I try not to use chemicals and keep everything natural. Often, I even scatter petals from dried out flowers on the roots of the plant. It automatically dissolves in the soil and makes it healthier.

As a child, I was always attracted to plants. Even now, I do not just place plants anywhere randomly. Everything is calculated and thoughtfully placed to meet my vision. Gardening through waste management has helped me immensely in achieving a healthy mind and body, all the while reducing pollution and benefiting the environment.

Title: Dust the only concern in Maradu
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Jet Demolition company managing director Joe Brinkmann (left) briefs his team in front of the Jains Coral Cove... Read More

Ever since the demolition of the illegal apartment complexes at Maradu was ordered, apprehensions had been raised by the residents on the safety aspect. They were mainly sceptical about the impact the demolition would have on their houses. TOI speaks to Joe Brinkmann , managing director of Jet Demolition, the premier South African demolition company that assists Edifice Engineering, which demolishes three of the four apartment complexes in Maradu — Jains Coral Cove, Holy Faith H2O and Golden Kayaloram — about the demolition and the risk involved.

Can you detail about the risk involved in the demolition of the buildings?

Well, we cannot say that any implosion project is fully safe because a risk aspect is always there. We would rather call it challenging than risky. But what we do is minimizing the risk so that the impact or damage caused is near to zero. We can assure you that the apprehensions of the public are mere imaginations. We will carry out the demolition safely if the people comply with the guidelines promptly.

The chance for an accident is extremely remote as this is an implosion where collapse behaviour of the building will be controlled. The gravity will push the entire structure down into itself and there is no chance of the building going sideways. Once the implosion is done you can see a pile of concrete up to 25 metres height at the building site.

There are three layers of protection. Right around the columns where the explosives are fixed, we have around five layers of wire mesh. On top of that there is a five-layer geotextile cover. We call this the source protection which will contain the rubble from being thrown to distance. All those floors where the explosives are fixed are covered with geotextiles.

As the secondary protection, we have the perimeter curtains, again made out of the geotextile, on all sides of the buildings. The tertiary protection is the wind curtain (made out of geotextiles) on those sides where we have houses or building. These curtains will be installed along the boundary lines of nearby buildings. Because, the falling building will displace the air to surroundings along with the dust and these curtains will stop it.

What about the vibration impact of the implosion?

Implosion will be done in such a way that the building does not fall down directly on the ground creating high seismic shock. Here the buildings will crumble down and will have a waterfall effect. Moreover, the explosives are not placed on the ground but on the building columns, hence there won’t be any direct impact or transfer of energy directly to the earth.

The buildings are situated on marshy land. Will it affect the demolition?

The soil investigation reports show that all these buildings are situated in soft soil, which is alluvium. I think the soft soil will give us an advantage here because they are good at absorbing the impact. Hence the vibration will be much lesser compared to hard soil.

Which among the three buildings is more challenging?

We think bringing down Golden Kayaloram is the real challenge because of an anganwadi that is situated in less than 10 metres. We were given the liberty to ignore the school’s safety but we took it as a challenge. We have taken special precautions and extra work to protect the school. We will split the building into two and it will fall in two directions.

With only a few days left for the demolition, what’s your advice to the people staying near the exclusion zones?

I request the people to comply with evacuation guidelines and move to safe places rather than taking risks. Dust will be the only concern . Take measures like closing the windows and doors to sort out the dust factor. They can keep their LPG cylinders, home appliances and even vehicles at the houses and no need to take them away. It is better to cover the well mouths with some sheets to prevent the dust getting settled down in the drinking water.

Title: Nagpur: One-day strike by trade unions today; to oppose NRC-NPR
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

NAGPUR: Work in central and some of the state government offices is expected to be hit on Wednesday as trade unions, barring Sangh Parivar-affiliated Bharatiya Mazdoor Sangh (BMS), have called for a one-day strike.

The unions will also be raising a banner against the proposed national register of citizenship (NRC) and national population register (NPR), said a press release issued by the Centre of Indian Trade Unions (CITU).

The CITU press release said Shiv Sena-backed unions have also supported the strike. The agitation is mainly against the changes in various labour laws by the central government. The unions will also raise farmers’ cause and NRC-NPR issues and come up with a 12-point charter of demands.

Major offices where work is expected to be affected include banks, Western Coalfields Limited (WCL), LIC, apart from various central and state government units in the city.

The strike may not have a major impact in the ordnance factories as BMS, which has a dominant presence in the factories, has not supported the strike call over the NRC-NPR. There are three ordnance factories in Vidarbha region employing a considerable workforce.

Shriram Batwe of Bharatiya Pratiraksha Mazdoor Sangh (BPMS), a BMS-affiliated union in ordnance factory here, said even as other causes will be supported, the union will not take part in the strike as NRC issue will also be raised during the agitation.

Apart from unions in government organizations, some of the farmers’ unions, associations of anganwadi workers and medical representatives will be taking part in the strike.

Title: Banquet hall owner booked for commercial use of domestic cylinders
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Pilibhit: A banquet hall owner in Pilibhit city was booked for using domestic LPG (liquefied petroleum gas) cylinders for commercial use in wedding and other ceremonies.

The FIR was lodged on Monday at Sungarhi police station by an inspector of the district supply office (DSO), Veer Singh, after obtaining permission from the district magistrate, Vaibhav Shrivastav.

Veer Singh said the commercial use of domestic LPG cylinders was detected at Shiv Shakti banquet hall on January 4 during an official inspection. The documentary evidences in the matter were listed before the district supply officer (DSO), AP Singh, in the the first week of December last year.

Following this, the proprietor of banquet hall, Nand Kishor, was issued notice by the DSO on December 11 to file his clarification, following which he was produced before the office on December 19, Singh said.

Finding this as sufficient evidence for legal action and violation of the LPG order of the year 2000 under section 3 of the Essential Commodities Act (amended), the two domestic cylinders were impounded.

The SHO of Sungarhi police station, Rajesh Kumar said following a written complaint filed by the supply inspector, Veer Singh, an FIR against Nand Kishor was lodged under section 3, 7 of the Essential Commodities Act.

Title: Tree plantation done in casual manner
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Wires seen penetrating the stems or the trunks of the trees

Surat: Barbed wires and paver blocks around trees have an adverse effect on their growth, but little thought is given to this aspect by the local authorities. Paver blocks in particular because they prevent recharging of groundwater, sources said. Karamveer Bhatt, an expert in tree protection, said, “Paver blocks prevent roots from penetrating the ground to get required nutrients and water supply. There is very little space left for the roots to grow and spread. In bigger trees where trunks are hardened, barbed wires don’t cause much damage, but in trees with soft stem this means a slow death for them.”

Trees with barbed wires can be found at Napura, Athwalines, Adjan and Pal. Here the wires can be seen penetrating the stems or the trunks of the trees. Barbed wires are put to protect the trees from animals. City light, New City Light and Pal have trees with paver blocks around them. “It is estimated that there are over 25,000 trees which are barbed wired and their full area covered with paver blocks in the city,” Bhatt said.

Planting wrong trees at wrong place also damages them. The civic body’s garden department plants trees at places where there are overhead wires or hoardings. “At such places, short growing trees need to be planted. A tree grows by self-balancing itself. Haphazard cutting also disturbs a tree’s balance, increasing its chances of collapsing and uprooting,” Bhatt said.

“It is wrong to say we are callous. We plant trees in a scientific manner and ensure there is enough space for their roots to spread,” said an officer of Surat Municipal Corporation.

Title: Kin of Virpur royal family spar over ancestral house
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Rajkot: Durgadevi Bhanjdev (45), daughter of erstwhile ruler of Virpur state in Rajkot, Thakur Pushpendrasinh Jadeja , has accused her cousin of trying to usurp her portion the family’s ancestral house ‘Virpur State House’ in the city.

The police on Monday evening registered a case of encroachment of property against Devendrasinh Jadeja, cousin of Durgadevi and nephew of Pushpendrasinh; and his mother Chandakumariba Jadeja. The Rajkot crime branch is investigating the case.

According to case details, the ancestral house ‘Virpur State House’ located on Moti Tanki Chowk was occupied by Pushpendrasinh and his brother Yaduvendrasinh Jadeja’s family. It was divided into half, with both families having separate entrance to the house.

After Pushpendrasinh’s son died in 2013, he and his wife used to live alone in the huge house. In August 2016, Pushpendrasinh made a gift deed and transferred his portion of the house in the name of Durgadevi, who was not settled in Bhuvaneshwar in Odisha. The gift deed was registered with the sub-registrar of property in August 22, 2016.

After Pushpendrasinh’s death on July 25, 2019, Durgadevi took her mother Alaknandadevi with her to Odhisha. In December last year, Durgadevi came to know that her cousin Devendrasinh and his mother Chandakumariba had encroached upon their portion of the ancestral house. So she returned to Rajkot on December 18, 2019. But she was not allowed to enter the premises by the accused.

Durgadevi approached the Rajkot police commissioner and submitted an application against Devendrasinh and Chandakumariba.

Both the families had been in talks since then over the property rights. As there was not decision, police on Monday evening registered an FIR against Devendrasinh and Chandakumariba with the city crime branch and launched investigation.

Title: Four killed as private bus rams car at Vaikom
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The accident happened around 6am. Mangled remains of the car

KOTTAYAM: Four in a family were killed after a speeding private bus rammed their car at Vaikom on Tuesday. The deceased were residents of Udayamperoor in Ernakulam. All of them were killed on the spot.

Vishwantahan (65); his wife Girija (61); their son Sooraj (33); and Ajitha (48), wife of Viswanathan's brother, were killed in the accident . Sooraj was driving the car. The bodies were taken out after breaking open the car.

The accident happened around 6am. The family was heading to Velorvattom Maha Deva Temple near Cherthala, when the accident occurred near Cherum Chuvadu Bridge.

Ten of the passengers in the bus were also injured. The bus was operating in the Vaikom-Ernakulam route. The bus rammed the car, which was entering the Vaikom-Vechur Road from a bylane. The bus, which rammed the car, went on to hit a wall before coming to a halt. CCTV visuals showed that both the vehicles were speeding.

Woman killed in accident

Kochi: A woman was killed in an accident near Kundanoor Junction in Eranakulam on Tuesday when a truck knocked down her scooter. Police identified the deceased as Greeshma Susan Mathew (29). Greeshma and her friend Nancy, who got injured, are both project officers at Cochin Shipyard. Greeshma leaves behind husband Jomon and a three-month-old baby.

Title: Despite campaigns, men stillshy away from vasectomies
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

MYSURU: Even though the health department conducts massive promotion drives about birth control programmes, men in Mysuru district seem reluctant to undergo sterilisation surgery . In many cases, men averse to it force their wives to do it instead.

To motivate men to go in for it, the government has announced incentives. Only six men from the district opted for it from April to November 2019, while 3,012 laparoscopic, 2,531 minilap and 2,163 Postpartum Sterilisation (PPS) tubectomies were conducted on women.

The number of vasectomies in the district has come come down over the years. In 2012-13, 39 men underwent vasectomies while there were 9,132 tubectomies.

The health department officials claim that despite awareness campaigns that vasectomies are safe and simple when compared to tubectomies, men avoid it due to fear of losing potency and failure in surgeries.

“We highlight that there will be no stitch after surgery and the patient can go home in less than an hour, and be active in sexual activity, there are still false beliefs which make men stay away. They fear losing potency,” a health officer said.

Mysuru District Health Officer Dr R Venkatesh said: “There is a fear among men that after surgery there will be side-effects like scrotal haematoma or scrotal swelling or loss of interest in day-to-day work. Even though some men want to have it, his friends or relatives will misguide him and he stays away. There are very rare failures in the surgery. Government employees who have the operation get an extra increment.”

Title: nirbhaya convicts hanging: ‘Phansi kotha’ at Tihar recast to bear the weight of four convicts
Content:
Four Nirbhaya rape case convicts. (Photo: PTI)

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

NEW DELHI: The phansi kotha ( hanging courtyard ) at Tihar Jail has been restructured to hold the weight of all four Nirbhaya case convicts during the hanging process.Jail authorities got an additional support structure constructed to allow the nooses of the four death row inmates to be fixed at intervals. The moving hatch on which the convicts would be made to stand has also been redesigned. Apart from this, an earthmover was used to extend the well below the gallows.Sources said the hanging courtyard and the gallows were constructed in the early 1950s. They consist of a metal crossbar erected on two concrete pillars. Loops have been made for the hanging rope. “As the metal bar weakens due to weathering, we have tested its strength with the help of experts. Additional construction was done to increase the strength and length of the bar to hold the weight of four men,” said a jail official.Eight ropes prepared by prisoners at Buxar Jail, known as manila ropes, have been procured by the authorities. Sources said the ropes made of soft cotton and butter or wax are used to keep it soft, yet strong. A day before the hanging, the hangman will brush wax or butter onto the rope to allow the noose to fall smoothly on the neck of the death row inmate.“The rope is made in such a way that it doesn’t cut through the neck of the convict. While hanging, multiple knots ahead of the noose are greased with butter so that it gradually untangles and presses against the neck of the convict giving a less painful death,” jail sources said. A trial for this was conducted on the existing gallows to check whether it would be able to withstand the weight.It is mandatory to execute all the four convicts at the same time, said jail sources. If one of the convicts falls sick or unconscious due to anxiety, the execution would be called off.The four inmates will be shifted to jail number 3 and kept in different cells. Each of them have been allowed to meet their family members at least once in the past fortnight. “We have not noticed any behavioral changes, except for occasional bouts of anxiety among the convicts. They have been meeting their lawyer to discuss their case,” said a jail officer.In Video: Gallows recast to hold Nirbhaya convicts' weight
