People fly a kite during the inaugural of the International Kite Festival 2020 in Ahmedabad. (Photo: AFP)

Title: Proposal to hike building plan sanction charges by up to 60%
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Nagpur: The NMC’s town planning department has decided to revise development and building plan sanction charges by up to 60%.

The department’s proposal on revision of charges will be tabled before the standing committee meeting to be held on January 7. The civic administration has also submitted 59 other proposals collectively valued at Rs44.75 crore.

The NMC’s general body had approved Rs15,000-Rs75,000 per sq MTR for building sanction plan but the department proposes to levy Rs24,200-Rs 1 lakh per sq MTR, which amounts to a near 60% hike.

Similar rates were also proposed for stocking building material. The administration has proposed to levy Rs24,200 per sq MTR up to Rs75,000. However, the rate passed by the general body was Rs15,000 per sq MTR to Rs50,000, the proposal stated.

It also proposes to revise tree deposit. The department has proposed to double the tree deposit from existing Rs500 to Rs1,000.

Along with this, the town planning department has also proposed to regularize unauthorized constructions like enclosure of balcony into rooms, to exclude staircase, passage, lobby, lift etc from carpet area by paying premium of 5% of the Ready Reckoner value of the property. The existing charge is 4%.

However, the department has proposed no change of fees for regularization of unauthorized construction of floors. The proposal stated to regularize the floor relaxation by levying existing 4% on the construction of property below 180 sq MTR area for all residential, commercial and industrial categories.

The department also proposes to double the fees to connect sewage network while giving sanction for construction of any new properties. It also proposed to double the charges for division or amalgamation of properties.

The proposed revised rates will also be applicable in the jurisdiction of Nagpur Improvement Trust as the state government on August 27, 2019 had appointed NMC as planning authority.

Even though the NMC’s financial condition is poor, the sports department has proposed to organize Adiwasi Mahanatya by spending Rs30 lakh at Futala lake. Besides, the social welfare department proposes to hold women entrepreneurs’ expo at Reshimbagh ground from January 19 to 26 and sought a nod to sanction Rs91.78 lakh for the purpose. The social welfare department also proposed to allocate Rs1.87 crore for purchasing e-rickshaws to be allocated to 70 handicapped unemployed youths.

Title: Deodar mamlatdar, his driver held taking Rs 25K bribe
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Palanpur: Pran Panchal , mamlatdar of Deodar and his driver Gandabhai Thakor were arrested taking bribe of Rs 25,000 from a contractor for hiring his heavy vehicle for ferrying road construction material.

The accused duo was arrested by the officials of anti-corruption bureau (ACB) on Tuesday from the mamlatdar office in Deodar, Banaskantha.

According to ACB sleuths of Palanpur office, Panchal had demanded money from a road contractor for hiring his heavy vehicle to ferry road construction material. Officials said that since the contractor had failed to pay the amount, they were harassing him.

Tired of the constant harassment, the contractor contacted the ACB, which laid a trap to catch the mamlardar and his accomplice red handed.

According to ACB inspector K J Patel, both the accused have confessed to their crime.

Title: Citizenship (Amendment) Act: IUML to form Desha Raksha Mathil
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

MALAPPURAM: The district committee of Indian Union Muslim League (IUML) will form ‘Desha Raksha Mathil’ in Malappuram on January 12 to protest against Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA).

The mathil (wall) would be formed in 106 locations from Angadippuram near Perinthalmanna to Mamburam near Tirurangadi . The party workers representing 94 grama panchayats and 12 municipalities would participate in the programme. White guard volunteers of the party will monitor the protest programme. Apart from party’s national and state leaders, religious scholars, representatives of different religious organizations and eminent writers are expected to participate in the protest.

As part of the programme, protest meets would be organised in 12 locations at 5pm. The meets would be held at Angadippuram, Tirurkkadu, Ramapuram, Makkaraparambu, Kootilangadi Malappuram, Kunnummal, Kottappadi, Karathod, Vengara, Kacherippadi, Kakkad, Tirurangadi and Mamburam.

The campaign ahead of the protest programme has already begun in the district. Special conventions were held in all panchayats in Tanur assembly segment on Tuesday.

The party has also decided to conduct door-to-door campaign against CAA prior to the event. Party workers will visit all houses in Angadippuram, Puzhakkattirri, Makkaoraprambu, Koottilangadi, Malappuram, Oorakam, Vengara and Tirurangadi, where the protest programme would be held. Apart from these, campaign rallies and ‘Desa Raksha Sadassu’ would also be organized.

Title: Tanur college project set to be fast-tracked
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

MALAPPURAM: The long-standing demand for a permanent Government Arts and Science College campus in Tanur is all set to be realised with the government deciding to acquire land for the purpose this month.

SJ Vishnu and Nimisha Sunny, officials of Kitco, the agency implementing the project, visited the proposed 5.5-acre site in Ozhur, on Monday, as part of procedures to acquire the plot from a private party.

Construction of a permanent building for the college would begin by the first week of April, said V Abdurahiman MLA.

The government has allotted Rs 8 crore for land acquisition and Rs 10 crore for infrastructure facilities. Kitco is expected to submit the project report within a week.

The project is to be implemented in a phased manner. Construction of the administrative and academic blocks, library, canteen and compound wall would be completed in the first phase.

Abdurahiman said Kitco has been directed to speed up project implementation. Kitco officials who visited the proposed site also held discussions with the MLA, local body authorities and college representatives. The college was formally inaugurated in July 2013 by then chief minister Oommen Chandy.

An amount of Rs 5 crore was earmarked in the 2012 budget to set up a government college in Tanur constituency. Following this, then MLA Abdul Rahman Randathani submitted a report to the government regarding availability of land for the college in December 2012.

Finance minister KM Mani granted final nod for the college in the 2013-14 budget.

Title: Retired English prof spreads awarenessabout mental disorders through play
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

MYSURU: Retired English professor R Purnima has been creating awareness about neuropsychiatric disorders by performing plays , not just across the state but also in different states in the country.

People are aware about fever, dengue, cold and other common diseases but they’re not much aware about neuropsychiatric disorders. Taking note of this, Purnima directed the play ‘Stage Chemistry: Neuropsychiatric Disorders’ on May 21, 2018 and the 240th show was held on December 12. She has been involved in one-woman show 200 times. She also imparts free English coaching classes to government school and college students. She retired from the English department at Manasagangothri in 2016.

She said: “Nearly two decades ago, the umbrella of Children’s Literary Club, a voluntary organisation which I founded had done a programme titled ‘Talented Madmen’. In 2018 summer, I got the idea for this play about disorders. Besides a keen interest in nurturing English theatre in Mysuru, I’m interested in interdisciplinary studies. The play, with several short scenes, is interdisciplinary in nature. The main objective is to make the target group understand, accept and motivate them to get involved, to facilitate growth, promote mental health, and achieve catharsis, so that the world becomes a better place to live in for the affected. Besides English-medium students, those in government, government-aided high schools, higher primary schools, PU colleges in Kannada medium watched and responded positively to the play.”

She mentioned that the play has been staged in educational institutions in Maharastra, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Assam, Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh under the auspices of Children’s Literary Club. It has been staged in Mysuru, Kolar, Chikkamagaluru, Yadgiri, Kalaburagi, Tumakuru, Kodagu, Hassan, Dakshina Kannada, Uttara Kannada, Belagavi, Dharwad, Gadag, Haveri, Chamarajanagara, Bengaluru, Chitradurga, Shivamogga, Davengere, Mandya and Udupi districts in Karnataka.

She has done concept design, script, stage management, costume design and direction, besides acting and producing.

Neurosurgeon and Hindustani vocalist Dr MS Bhaskar appreciated the performance.

Title: Govt has taken steps to simplify taxation: Nirmala Sitharaman
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman (PTI photo)

NEW DELHI: Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Tuesday said the government is taking various steps to simplify taxation system and eliminate harassment of honest taxpayers .

Addressing an event organised by Confederation of All India Traders (CAIT), the finance minister said the government is open to suggestions for the betterment of GST filing system .

Based on suggestions received from various stakeholders, the government is taking steps towards simplification of taxation system, she added.

In a bid to curb harassment of taxpayers, she said, a faceless e-assessment scheme was launched in October to eliminate interface between an assessing officer and a taxpayer.

The tax department has implemented a computer-generated document identification number (DIN) to ensure greater transparency and accountability in tax administration.

The DIN system, which became operative from 1 October 2019, will apply to all kind of communications from the income tax department, whether it is related to assessment, appeals, investigation, penalty and rectification, among others.

This development will also help taxpayers to detect fake notices and letters as the notice would be verifiable on the department's e-filing portal.

Besides, the finance minister said, such cases have to be closed within 30 days. She also said that there would be shopping festival held across the country soon.

In a bid to boost trade, Sitharaman had in September last year announced Dubailike mega shopping festivals in India, starting March 2020.

The commerce ministry is working on this and it will provide a big platform for traders to sell their goods.

Title: Four arrested in builder kidnapping case
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Mahesh Savani

Surat: Four persons were arrested by Umra police for extortion and kidnapping a 65-year-old builder on Tuesday. However, main accused Mahesh Savani, a reputed businessman, is yet to be arrested and has disappeared. Police sources said Savani is likely to approach high court to request it for quashing of the complaint against him.

Those arrested were Gopal Thummar, Ankit Savani, Arpan alias Appu Limbachiya and Chirag Timbadiya.

Savani and five others were booked at Umra police station on Saturday for extortion and kidnapping Gautam Patel, a builder, from his residence at Parle Point. Initially Savani’s men had gone to Patel’s residence to ask him to come along. When Patel refused, Savani himself took Patel to his office from the victim’s bungalow in his car.

Patel was dropped back home by Savani’s men in a car. Meanwhile, police arrived at the bungalow as Patel’s wife had already alerted cops and detained the four persons. They were taken to police station from where they disappeared mysteriously when the offence was being registered.

Title: WRMS to hold ‘Save Railways’ conference
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Vadodara: On the call of the National Federation of Indian Railwaymen (NFIR), all zonal unions of NFIR including Western Railway Mazdoor Sangh (WRMS) have decided to hold ‘Rail Bachao Sangoshti’ (conference) from January 8 to 10.

The sangoshti is being held to protest against heavy outsourcing, privatization and selling of national assets of Indian Railways including railway colonies in all divisions, corporatization of production units like Raibareli Coach Factory, Chittaranjan Locomotive Works, diesel locomotive works, Varanasi, Diesel loco modernization works, Patiala, integral coach factories at Patiala and Chennai among others.

“It is necessary for NFIR and railwaymen because at all costs, unions would like to protect this kind of attitude taken by the government,” said J G Mahurkar, general secretary of WRMS and vice-president of NFIR.

“Other important topics to be discussed include railway’s performance, role of rail workforce, railway ministry’s policies, capital investment and financial health of railways,” he said.

The earning side of the railways will also be discussed during the sanghoshti. “NFIR is on the opinion that railways has been incurring losses to the tune of Rs 35,000 crore every year on account of coaching services being provided below the operational cost while the railway ministry has been indifferent on this vital matter,” he said.

Railway minister Piyush Goyal will be holding a meeting with 300 delegates of NFIR and AIFR on January 16 to sort out issues with the recognised federations.

Title: The legends of Tasker Town’s ‘jail school’
Content: BENGALURU: The people of the neighbourhood call it the “ladies jail”. It seems that the name is well deserved. It’s an old building complex - clearly built well before independence. The walls are old stone, and solidly thick. The windows are barred. The dark corridors are flanked by high doors along their lengths.This is not a jail, though its inmates might make that comparison. It is the Government Telugu High School - also known as the Jail School - in Tasker Town near Shivaji Circle in Shivajinagar . If you go in there on a weekday, you’ll probably see over 300 students who studied there, sequestered in classrooms that resemble jail cells. If ever a building did duty as a prison, this is it, you may think. But nobody knows for sure.“Everyone refers to this as a ladies prison complex from the British era which was later converted to a government office under the BBMP and now a school,” says Veerabhadrappa, principal of the Telugu school.I decided to find out more. The first stop was the Karnataka Prisons Department. Records there provide information - in voluminous detail - about the Bangalore Central Prison complex which is now the Freedom Park. But there was no information about this women’s prison. Further searches in city records for more information about the Tasker Town building - in books and maps at the Mythic Society, the state archives and the State Central Library in Cubbon Park - also drew a blank. The detailed seven-piece map of Bangalore City and cantonment, dating back to 1884, which is considered a civic treasure by historians for its accuracy, shows Shivaji Circle in detail but there is no information on the so-called prison.When all my attempts at primary research failed, I did what I should have done in the beginning - consult historians whose areas of expertise included Bengaluru’s history. I reached the Indian Council of Historial Research (ICHR), near the Mysore Bank circle, and met Dr SK Aruni, the regional director of ICHR here. “Yes, I remember reading about the building. It is of Indian architecture and is possible a 100-year-old structure. It served as a zenana, a reserved area for women of the household which remains at bay for men mainly outsiders,” Aruni said.A senior researcher who has studied old Bangalore history and its temple and architecture, Aruni believes that the structure could have been owned by some rich Muslim traders who had flourished in the cantonment area that was dominated by Europeans and British defence personnel decades ago before independence. “There are no records of a prison or a sub-jail in the Shivajinagar area apart from the well-recorded history of a small prison cum judicial complex which functioned from inside the present day police commissionerate during the British days,” says Aruni who believes that the Shivajinagar structure could have got the jail tag from people in the locality referring to it as a place where women were kept away from the men and over the years, public imagination turned the cause of the confinement of women in the building from cultural to punitive.There aren’t many records on the school building, something that has sharpened the curiosity of both locals and historical researchers. Government records show that the stone structure was sold or taken over by the government post-independence and has served as a school since the mid 1970s. “In the late 90s, the Block Education Office of the State Education Department which was then functioning inside Mayo Hall was shifted to the present school building in Tasker Town. The structure also doubled as a school textbooks godown. The Government Telugu School , started in 1993 was functioning from a building on OPH Road in Shivajinagar ,” says M. Venkataramanappa, a retired Head Master, who served at the Telugu School.In 2006, the Block Education Office shifted out of the colonial structure to Kamaraj Road to make way for the Government Telugu High School which witnessed a growing student number. However, the primary section of the school still functions out of the structure on OPH Road.Suresh Moona, city historian and author, who has researched and written extensively on the Bangalore cantonment area says the zenana angle needs a further investigation. “The possibility of such a zenana in the area is slim. Who was the rich trader who built such a big structure nearly a 100 years ago to house the women. The famous names who lived in Shivajinagar have been recorded in detail in history texts and we need to find out who could have owned this stone building,” says Moona.But that, again, is the tragedy of Bengaluru. It’s said that, Indians lack a sense of history. If our own governments lack records - despite asking for reams of forms to be filled for each interaction - to identify the background of a significant piece of real estate, it may well be true.

Title: Man threatens to shut down gurudwara
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Rajkot: A bakery owner in Junagadh , who had converted to Sikhism two years ago , has lodged a complaint against a garments shop owner for allegedly threatening to disrupt the Amrit Sanchar ritual at a gurudwara.

Girish Tilwani, who embraced Sikhism along with his brother, has been offering prayers and service at the gurudwara. He told police that ever since 2017, shop owner Karan Dakshina had been harbouring a grudge against him for religious conversion. While Dakshina had been frequently hurling jibes at him for the past two years, Tilwani had preferred not to hit back. On January 1, Tilwani had gone to see off some guests at the railway station. When he came out, Dakshina again confront him and started hurling abuses in the presence of some Sikh people from Amritsar accompanying Tilwani. He then allegedly hit Tilwani on his head with a pipe, police said. Dakshina was arrested the same night.

On Monday night, Dakshina, who was released on bail, went to Tilwani's house and demanded Rs five lakh ever year, failing which he would disrupt Amrit Sanchar ritual at the gurudwara.

Tilwani again approached the police and Dakshina was arrested. He was booked for extortion and criminal intimidation.

Amrit Sanchar refers to the Sikh baptism ceremony that was established in 1699 when Guru Gobind Singh first initiated five followers of his faith and then was baptised himself by them.

Title: Forum seeks judicial probe into selection of gazetted probationers
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Mysuru: Suspecting corruption in the selection of gazetted probationers of 2015th batch, Karnataka State Backward Classes Awareness Forum president K S Shivaramu on Tuesday demanded a judicial probe into the alleged wrongdoing and sought revaluation of answer scripts of candidates.

Recently, KPSC announced provisional list of 428 selected candidates who wrote the exams in 2015. But bright and ‘eligible’ candidates have failed to make it to the final list and this has raised suspicion about the entire process of selection of candidates, claimed Shivaramu.

Nearly 35% candidates selected are among only two communities which both put together had only 36 reserved seats. “This has made us suspect something amiss in the selection. KPSC authorities also have cut down the number of days to raise objection. According to rules, a minimum of 15 days time should have been given, but here only 7 days are given,” he said.

Interestingly, it has come to our notice that expert valuators have not been hired to evaluate answerscripts. Instead, they have been assessed by pre-university lectures. Another major irregularity is digital evaluation of scripts and the method in which they have been done. Usually, evaluators have to set passwords on their own and close the scripts after the evaluation. Here, passwords have been set by the KPSC. There is every chance of misuse as passwords were with the authorities.

There is also information that KPSC members visited the valuation centres several times.

Moreover, the time taken to announce the results is three years from the day of examination. Even there is violation in inviting more candidates for interview beyond prescribed ratio, said Shivaramu, who has threated to launch a state-wide protest.

Title: NRI-rich Dharmaj town to celebrate pink power this year
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Dharmaj Day has become an annual feature of the lush green Charotar belt of central Gujarat

Vadodara/ Anand: As NRI-rich Dharmaj town of Anand district gears up to host 14th Dharmaj Day celebrations on Sunday, the town will be painted ‘pink’ to celebrate women power.

Dharmaj Day which has become an annual feature of the lush green Charotar belt of Central Gujarat this year is dedicated to daughters and daughter-in-laws.

“We are calling it DD for DD,” said Rajesh Patel, part of team Dharmaj, which has been organising Dharmaj Day celebrations as an attempt to connect generation next of NRI with their roots since 2007.

So, theme colour for the forthcoming programme is pink. And it promises to be an all women show – starting from women who welcome the guests to the ones who will occupy the dais and also those who will be conferred awards for their contribution to society.

“We will be also unveiling the ‘vanshavali’ or the family tree which for the first time will include names of daughters and daughter-in-laws of the community. Usually, the community tree just bear names of sons or grandsons. Daughters are not given their due in family or community trees as such a space is left blank. But we are revamping this. We had started efforts for this last year itself,” said Patel.

A majority of Patels of Dharmaj are descendants of Ranga Patel, the patriarch, who had migrated from Virol village near Sojitra, to the present day Dharmaj before 900 years.

The drive to include name of female members of each family was launched during the international women’s day celebrations last year by women of team Dharmaj all dressed in pink with forms which were also filled in pink letters.

“After we launched online link to reach out to members of our town spread across the globe on December 8, we have collected 430 forms. We have offline data of 11,000 individuals,” he said.

The town will also be felicitating Trupti Patel, the first female civil engineer from Asian community in UK and currently president of Hindu Forum, UK with Dharmaj Gaurav award.

She carries with her 30 years experience in the field of highways, traffic and transportation having managed various divisions at Salford City Council , Manchester City Council and Three Rivers District Council.

Also, two female doctors and sisters from the same father – Dr Rupande Patel and Dr Gorande Kanabar, currently settled in US and London, will be felicitated with Dharmaj Jyoti award.

Title: Sketching beauty of nature on seashells
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Luminous 11 a Sea Shell Art Exhibition by Sreeja Kalappurakkal

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Sreeja Kalappurakkal , a self-trained artist from Nilambur, who is known for arts works on feather and stone, is back with a seashell art exhibition. Titled as ‘Luminous 11’, the exhibition began at Kerala Lalithakala Akademi Art Gallery at the Vyloppilli Samskrithi Bhavan on Tuesday.

The exhibition features around 130 paintings done on seashells. Paintings are done in acrylic on carefully selected shells collected from different coasts of south India, and each frame depicts the beauty of nature from different angles. Also on display are replicas of Sree Padmanabhaswamy Temple and Vadakkumnathan Temple, Thrissur, made of seashells.

For Sreeja, what began as a childhood hobby became a serious passion later in her life. She, who calls herself as a passionate traveller, feels art in anything and everything and finds inspiration from tough and unique materials like feathers, stone and seashells.

“In 2016, while I was doing works of stone art, I started collecting shells for seashell arts. For paintings, I specifically select mother of pearl shells. The recent and last year’s flood had affected the availability of shells. Another challenge is painting the shell as like a marble piece it won’t absorb direct paint. So I have to give it a primer coating and also dry it in sunlight,” she said. The largest ones among the painted shells measure up to 40cm long and 25cm wide.

To make the expo totally eco-friendly, wooden frames and wooden sheets are used to fix the shell paintings at the gallery.

On display are seashell arts portraying ‘Nilavilakku’, butterfly-shaped shells which depicts two red parrots, elephant tusks, water lilies on butterfly-shaped shells, swans, waterfalls and pictures of 2018 and 2019 Kerala floods.

“It took around four months for me to complete the work on Padmanabhaswamy Temple. But it gives me immense pleasure when people praise my hard work. I am also planning to work on seashell models of Thrissur Pooram with Thiruvambady and Paramekkavu temples on my expo scheduled on March,” Sreeja added.

The expo, which was inaugurated by V K Prasanth, MLA, will be on till Friday. Gauri Parvathi Bhai of Travancore royal family unveiled the seashell sculpture of Padmanabhaswamy Temple. The exhibition will be open from 10am to 6pm.

Sreeja’s earlier works on feather and miniature paintings done on stones had also won critical acclaim.

Title: Ambardi safari park echoes with roars of two lions
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

A lion from the wild that came close to the captive lion in Ambardi park

Rajkot: Tourists visiting the Ambardi Safari Park in Amreli got the first hand experience of how a lion’s roar sounds like in the wild on Tuesday. A video clip of two lions roaring went viral on social media after some visitors near the park posted it online.

According to forest officials, there is one pair of lion in the safari park brought from Sakkarbaug Zoo in Junagadh. On Tuesday, one of the lions inside the safari park encountered a lion from the wild. They came face to face and were separated only an iron grill.

Foresters said that lion inside the safari park, which was born in captivity, could have seen a wild lion for the first time.

According to sources in the forest department, there are many lions in the forest area outside the park.

In the video wild lion is seen roaring at the lion inside the park, which tried to avoid the confrontation. However, the wild lion follows the captive lion who is seen moving away from it.

Title: Gujarat: Transporter slapped Rs 1 lakh fine for dumping garbage into Vishwamitri river
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Video grab of the transporter throwing bags of garbage into Vishwamitri

VADODARA: The Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) on Tuesday slapped the highest fine ever for reckless disposal of garbage. A man whose video throwing garbage into the Vishwamitri river had gone viral landed in trouble after his identity was established by the civic body.

The video recorded on a mobile phone by an alert citizen showed a man standing in a mini truck throwing bags full of garbage into Vishwamitri river near the Vadsar bridge.

The citizen had also recorded the garbage bags flowing in the river.

As the video reached VMC officials, they swung into action and identified the owner of the vehicle using its registration number.

The civic body slapped a fine of Rs one lakh for the act as disposal of garbage in a waterbody attracts very high fine.

Assistant municipal commissioner Bhupendra Sheth said that the persons who was slapped the fine was a transporter. “He had a social function at his residence and a lot of food was left over. He had filled this in bags and disposed it in the river on Monday morning,” said Sheth.

Sheth said that the transporter who had his office on the Gotri Road paid the fine on Tuesday itself when the notice was issued to him. The notice had warned the transporter that if he did not pay the fine, action could be taken against him under the Gujarat Provincial Municipalities Act as well as the Environment Protection Act.

According to Sheth, the man was not aware about the consequences of his act.

“We collect garbage for a small charge after such events. He could also have contacted any NGO that collected food left over after incident and fed the needy,” he said.

Title: Kerala HC: Modernized bunks needed for rehab of street vendors
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

KOCHI: Highly-modernized bunks should be provided to rehabilitate street vendors considering the importance of Kochi as a tourist destination, said the high court . The court has now directed Ernakulam collector to convene a meeting of stakeholders to chalk out a plan.

Justice A Muhamed Mustaque issued the directive after considering a total of 11 petitions seeking proper measures to rehabilitate street vendors within the limits of Kochi corporation.

A total of 2,122 street vendors were identified and approved by the corporation council following a court directive. Of the lot, areas were identified by corporation for rehabilitating 1,535 vendors. Concurrence of traffic regulatory authority is required for rehabilitation, it said.

Corporation, which informed the court that it is not able to identify more area, has suggested that the issue of rehabilitation can be resolved if some of the areas under the control of GCDA are utilized.

The court was also told that the nature of the bunk also needs serious consideration as many vendors are engaged in operating ‘thattukada’ (roadside food outlets) and there were complaints of nuisance and pollution by nearby residents. An amicus curiae appointed by the court submitted that an architect has come forward to design the bunks for free.

Regarding the nature of the bunks, the court said in the interim order, “It is to be noted that hygienic conditions will have to be maintained... The bunk must be of particular dimensions... The highly-modernized bunks will have to be erected considering the importance of Kochi as a tourist destination.” The court then ordered the collector to work out a plan to implement the rehab scheme and file a report by January 28.

Title: International folk dance festival from January 9
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Surat: Surat will host the International Folk Dance Festival for the first time from January 9, where artists form Poland , Indonesia , Romania , Slovakia apart from India take part.

This four-day festival will see folk dancers performing on Dumas beach and in front of old castle at Chowk Bazar apart from open lawns at Vesu Ground. An art mela has also been organized on the occasion.

Meanwhile, the International Kite Festival will be held on January 10 at plot next to river front party plot where 50 international and 40 domestic kite fliers will participate in the day long event. TNN

Title: Expert stands by Sheena Bora’s digital superimposition deposition
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Sheena Bora

MUMBAI: A forensic science expert on Tuesday denied the defence suggestion that his work relating to the ‘ digital superimposition ’ process done in the Sheena Bora murder case is amateurish and not befitting scientific process.

Last week, the witness, the 60th in the murder trial , had deposed that with ‘digital superimposition’, he had concluded that a skull recovered in the case is a ‘100%’ match with Sheena’s ‘smiling’ photographs. During cross-examination by accused Indrani Mukerjea’s lawyer, he denied that his opinion was erroneous. The witness also denied the defence suggestion that he had prepared a false report to oblige the CBI.

Earlier in the hearing, when asked if he had done a course in forensic odontology, the witness said he had not taken a specific course. “The knowledge of dental science relating to teeth is a part of MBBS MD course, therefore I know forensic odontology.”

Responding to the defence, the witness said it was not ‘perfectly’ correct to say that courts have considered facial reconstruction and cranio facial superimposition as useful, but that they are not to be relied upon by itself to determine victims’ identity. tnn

Title: Air India divestment: GoM nod for share purchase pact
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: The ball has been set rolling for the Modi government's second attempt to divest in Air India (AI). Union home minister Amit Shah-led GoM on Tuesday cleared the expression of interest (EoI) along with the share purchase agreement (SPA) for the debt-laden carrier's privatisation and these two documents are likely to be issued for bidders this month, said a senior official.

The last GoM meeting had taken place in September 2019. It had then approved complete exit from AI, AI Express and also selling AI's stake in JV AISATS. A voluntary retirement scheme (VRS) and debt restructuring plan for AI were also cleared then.

Losing almost Rs 25 crore daily, the Maharaja's total debt is over to Rs 74,000 crore, which includes nearly Rs 60,000 crore of aircraft and working capital debt and Rs 14,000 crore of net current liabilities or payables. A special purpose vehicle - AI Asset Holding - has taken on Rs 29,464 crore of the airline's debt along with some assets.

Unlike the last failed bid when bidders for AI, AI Express and AISATS were expected to take over debt of Rs 24,576 crore and current liabilities of Rs 8,816 crore, this time the debt burden for potential buyers is likely to be mainly limited to aircraft loan.

Air India's net loss in 2018-19 was around Rs 8,556 crore. The airline has now virtually run out of funds and is finding hard to sustain itself.

Aviation minister HS Puri said AI will keep running till it is privatised.

The government is trying its best to come out with terms of sale that investors find attractive enough to buy the Maharaja. Among the likely suitors are Tata Group-Singapore Airlines JV Vistara and IndiGo . Some international airlines are also learnt to be looking closely at the final terms of sale and may join the fray if they find the same making business sense.

Title: VMC to foot bill for tackling dogs at SoU
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Vadodara: The Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) will foot the bill for the Animal Birth Control (ABC) activities it performed through agencies at the Statue of Unity (SoU). The civic body had vaccinated and performed ABC operations on around 120 stray dogs in and around the SoU campus.

The civic body was called for taking care of the stray dogs at the site ahead of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s visit on October 31 last year to mark the first anniversary of the inauguration of SoU. Two agencies working for the civic body – the Vadodara Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (VSPCA) and Humane Society International (HSI) – were roped in for the task.

The agencies have submitted bills totalling to Rs 3.62lakh to the civic body for the work done there. The VMC administration has put up a proposal before the standing committee seeking a nod to make the payment to the agencies.

Title: Green travel: Maharashtra e-vehicles cross 20,000-mark in 2 years
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: The electric vehicle population, including two-wheelers and buses, is growing slowly, but steadily, across Maharashtra , with registrations crossing the 20,000-mark in January 2020, said sources in the state transport department on Tuesday. The state government had formulated a policy for the promotion of e-vehicles in 2017-18.“We are yet to witness a spurt in e-vehicle registration though the governments—both at Centre and state—are promoting these environment-friendly vehicles and encouraging motorists to buy them,” said a transport official, requesting anonymity. He added that in Mumbai alone, there are over 2,000 e-vehicles, with maximum sale of e-scooters in the past one year.The state government is now planning to push for e-autorickshaws , especially in the Mumbai metropolitan region (MMR).According to sources, the blue-and-white e-autorickshaws—either four-seater or five-seater— are likely to ply on roads in the MMR some time this year.Unions have demanded subsidy as well as charging stations at all fuel stations if e-autorickshaws are introduced on city roads.“Unions want battery-swapping facility at pumps which can expedite the changeover from a drained battery to a charged one. They want such battery stations across suburbs where dealers can take a deposit for battery swapping,” said Thamby Kurien, Mumbai Rickshawmen’s Union leader.The BEST undertaking too plans to introduce 80 e-buses this year.Bhagwan Kesbhat, founder of NGO Waatavaran, said: “The pollution levels in Mumbai are unprecedented and rising rapidly daily, hence we need more environment-friendly electric vehicles...We are promoting green mobility and want public transport to run on this clean energy to make the city-pollution free.” The NGO is working with the BEST undertaking to promote e-vehicles, Kesbhat added.According to transport expert Vivek Pai, the state government should first ‘create a strong infrastructure for vehicle charging and battery replacement, for the e-vehicle population to grow faster’. “Besides, the electricity at the existing charging points is not completely green as it is not all derived from renewable sources,” Pai pointed out. He added that ideally, charging stations should have solar sources.

Title: Rajkot: Man sentenced to life in jail for rape of 12-year-old girl
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: A Dhoraji court of Rajkot sentenced a 39-year-old man to life imprisonment for rape and abduction of a 12-year-old girl. Additional sessions judge H A Dave also imposed fine of Rs 14,000 on accused Amrut alias Raju Thakor and ordered the government to pay compensation to the rape survivor.

The trial in the case was completed in a record time of a little over two months, said assistant public prosecutor Kartikey Parekh.

According to cased details, Thakor, who used to work as a casual labourer in Upleta town, had lured the minor girl saying that he would take her shopping. He along with his wife took the girl to Dhoraji on August 14, 2019.

The girl was carrying a piece of paper with her father’s phone number written on it. But Thakor snatched it from her after reaching Dhoraji. He then too the girl to a village in Rapar Kutch where he raped her after his wife went to sleep in the night. Police said that Thakor continued to rape the girl every night. But one night his wife woke up and caught him in the act. She called the police and got Thakor arrested.

Meanwhile, the girl’s father also lodged a kidnapping complaint on August 28 last year and the police started search for Thakor.

Kutch police informed the Upleta police of the missing girl, who later informed her parents. Thakor was booked for rape, abduction and relevant sections of POCSO Act.

Assistant public prosecutor Kartikey Parekh told TOI, “The court observed that the accused had destroyed life of a young girl and sentenced Thakor to life imprisonment.”

Title: NSUI stages protest against ABVP
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Vadodara: The Vadodara unit of National Students’ Union of India (NSUI) on Tuesday staged protest against its rival student outfit – the Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) for Sunday’s violence in the Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) campus in Delhi and the one that Ahmedabad witnessed on Tuesday.

Following the clash between ABVP and NSUI members at Ahmedabad, student leaders linked with the NSUI staged protest at the main building of MS University’s Faculty of Commerce and later at Kalaghoda circle.

The NSUI leaders burnt posters of ABVP, raised slogans against the RSS-affiliated student outfit and demanded action against the perpetrators who they said were armed with sticks and other sharp-edged weapons attacked their workers in Ahmedabad.

“This clearly reflects their mentality. We are demanding strong action against the perpetrators. They were the same person who had attacked a peaceful gathering at Sabarmati Ashram before a couple of days,” said NSUI leader and former general secretary of MSU Students Union Vraj Patel.

“ABVP goons are creating violence at campuses across the country but police is watching as mute spectators,” said NSUI president Devang Thakor.

The student leaders later were detained by Sayajigunj police for staging protest at Kalaghoda circle without necessary permission.

Title: City registers steepest fall in vehicle sales in Gujarat
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Vadodara: Vadodara witnessed steepest fall in registration of vehicles compared to all cities of Gujarat including Ahmedabad, Surat and Rajkot in 2019.

Registration of vehicles in Vadodara city (GJ-06) registered a drop of 72 % compared to 2018 figure. While the two-wheeler segment registered a decline of 68.54 % in 2019, sales of car dipped by 75.24%.

Compared to 2017, car sales registered a sharp decline of 75 % in 2019 in the city. Against 28,000 vehicle registrations in 2017, the city registered only 26,000 vehicles in 2019.

Main reason for the drastic decline in car sales is economic slowdown. “People have been finding it tough to manage their home budgets. I think, parking issues and traffic drives too have contributed to the decline,” said an official from Regional Transport Office (RTO).

Shwetal Patel of a car dealership said, “Sentiments have dropped due to economic slowdown. Also, the sales have been impacted due to the shift from BS-IV cars to BS-VI cars. At local level, infrastructure of Vadodara is really not supportive as there are traffic jams. Multi car buying is not happening.”

Nikhil Chawla, director of two-wheelers dealership, added, “The automobile sector across the nation is witnessing a decline. Vadodara has a mix of chemical, fertilizers and other industrial sectors. Plus, there is salaried class population in bigger numbers. But sales in Vadodara witnessed a decline due to floods and excess rainfall which impacted the purchasing power of buyers from the rural belt.”

Title: Mumbai: Marathi writers meet against CAA, NRC, NPR
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

MUMBAI: When Marathi writer Harishchandra Thorat sought admission in school as a six year old, he was asked to touch his right ear with his left hand.

“That was enough to determine my age. I did not have a birth certificate and I did not need one,” said Thorat at a protest against the amended citizenship law and NRC and NPR at Azad Maidan . Over 150 writers, journalists and theatre personalities of Maharashtra , including Laxmikant Deshmukh, Kishore Kadam, Ganesh Viskute, Mukund Taksale and film critic Meena Karnik, took part. Thorat, who believes the process of “conversion of men into a set of documents” to be wrong, said: “It’s people who have created institutions. So those institutions like religion and country cannot be greater than the people. They can only be for the people. But the administration seems bent on branding of people depending on the religion.”

Title: Maharashtra: Release of water for rabi crops halted a month ahead of schedule
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The release of water for rabi crops from Khadakwasla dam was stopped on Tuesday, about a month before the sche... Read More

PUNE: The release of water for rabi crops from Khadakwasla dam was stopped on Tuesday, about a month before the scheduled end of rotation.

The water rotation started on December 15 and was expected to continue for 60 days until mid-February. However, water release continued for only over 21 days.

The state irrigation department has said that water will now be released from the dam based on ‘demand and supply’ principle, instead of continuous discharge. The experiment of demand-based release is expected to save more water in reservoirs thereby making the resource available during the summer months, the department has stated.

About 4 TMC water is expected to be released from Khadakwasla dam into the canal during the winter rotation. The discharge will restart after the department receives fresh demand for water release from the farmers.

“We have stopped the release of water from Mutha canal,” an official from the state irrigation department said on Tuesday.

A senior irrigation department official added, “About 2.17 TMC water has been released in 21 days of rotation between December 15 and January 6. A review of water availability was undertaken over the last few days in which it was observed that the demand for water from the farming areas of the district was met. This prompted the department to discontinue water release before the scheduled end.”

The water release from Khadakwasla dam, underway for the last 21 days, was part of the first winter rotation for crops. Every year, water is released in two rotations for Rabi crops. This year, the first rotation was delayed by almost two months.

An official said, “The first rotation begins around October 15. However, the extended rainfall last year postponed water release up to December 15 and it has also been stopped ahead of the scheduled time. We may restart the release after 15 to 20 days if the demand is raised. The remaining 2 TMC water is expected to flow out in the second rotation,” the official added.

The collective water stock in the four dams supplying water to the city was 23.5 TMC (80%) on Tuesday. Last year on the same day, the collective stock stood at 17.3 TMC (60%). The four dams have 29.15 TMC storage capacity.

At the canal committee meeting of Khadakwasla irrigation circle held last week, deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar had said that the city will receive adequate water during the summer months.

Title: Fresh survey for flyovers at 7 junctions
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Vadodara: The Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) will get a fresh survey conducted for improvement of seven traffic junctions in the city. The state government has already given an in-principle approval for construction of six flyovers in the city.

The state government had sought details of flyovers that could be constructed within a cost of Rs 50crore each from the VMC last month. The VMC had suggested seven different locations where it could construct flyovers to streamline traffic movement.

Subsequently, the state government has given an in-principle approval for six flyovers in the city. The flyovers will cost around Rs 270crore. The state government will also release 10 per cent of this amount to the civic body as grants. VMC will have to bear any extra expenses involved in construction of the flyovers.

In wake of the development, the VMC is looking to get surveys conducted by the Central Road Research Institute (CRRI) at seven junctions. These include the Vrundavan Crossroads, Khodiyarnagar Crossroads, Sardar Estate junction, Sangam Crossroads, Vasna Road Crossroads, Sama pond crossroads and Manekpark Crossroads.

VMC will be paying Rs 26lakh and GST to CRRI for the study. The study will be completed in three months. A proposal in this regard has been put before the standing committee of the civic body.

Title: MNS, Cong, NCP demand end to weekly closure of supply
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Pune: The Congress, Maharashtra Navnirman Sena ( MNS ) and Nationalist Congress Party (NCP) have jointly approached Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) demanding that water closure should not be enforced every Thursday.

In a memorandum submitted to the water supply department, the leaders of the parties said that the administration should carry out maintenance in a better manner instead of imposing water cuts across the city. The leaders have claimed that although PMC announces water cut for a day, several areas fail to receive water supply the next day due to poor distribution system.

Rupali Thombre of MNS said that an extensive audit was required to check what works are carried out during closures. “We have also been receiving complaints of water theft during maintenance of valves. The top officials in civic administration need to conduct an audit to avoid water thefts and losses,” she said.

Mahesh Hande of NCP said that the civic administration must introduce better techniques for maintenance and repairs to avoid daylong water cuts. “The water distribution system in the city is weak and needs an overhaul. A complete closure of water often leads to break down of valves and restricts the flow of water due to air bubbles. Eventually, water supply gets affected for the next few days,” Hande added.

Besides the three political parties, BJP MLA Chandrakant Patil had raised objections about the Thursday water cuts and asked the authorities to explain its necessity at a recent canal committee meeting.

Title: Uncle, nephew die after tractor overturns
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Pilibhit: Two farmers of Azampur Barkhera village died on Tuesday morning after their sugarcane-laden tractor trolley overturned in a ditch at the roadside near Veersinghpur crossing on Deuria – Bisalpur road.

Both got buried under the heap of sugarcane bundles and died on the spot, police said.

According to the SHO Shahroz Anwar, “The two men were going to Bisalpur cooperative sugar mill to supply their sugarcane when the accident took place. They were identified as Jitendra Kumar (25), who was driving the tractor, and his uncle Mangli Prasad (45).”

Jitentra is survived by his parents, wife and 5-year-old daughter while Mangli Prasad has left behind his wife, two sons and daughters.

Tehsildar of Bisalpur circle, Vijay Kumar Trivedi, said the kin of both the deceased would be extended compensation of Rs 4 lakh each under the Kisan Bima Durghatana Yojana, provided they have agricultural lands registered in their own names.

Title: R-Power defaults, lenders face insolvency deadline
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Reliance Power on Tuesday informed the stock exchanges that it has defaulted on a debt of Rs 685 crore. The company said that the default pertained to the quarter ended December 2019.

On July 6, 2019, all the main lenders of Reliance Power had signed an inter-creditor agreement (ICA). Based on the ICA, lenders had agreed to a six-month standstill, during which they would not initiate recovery of their loans. The objective of the standstill agreement was to implement a resolution plan during the same period.

Reliance Power's default has coincided with the expiry of the 210-day deadline set by the RBI for resolving all stressed loans through an inter-creditor agreement allowed under the central bank's June 6, 2019 circular.

In terms of the circular, if banks failed to arrive at a resolution by January 7, they would have to either initiate insolvency proceedings or set aside as additional provisions, 20% of the stressed loan.

Lenders, through Indian Banks Association, have sought more time from the RBI to complete resolutions of some stressed loans, including loans to the power sector. They have said that their efforts would go waste if they are forced to abandon the resolution discussions and initiate insolvency proceedings because of the deadline expiry. In July 2019, rating agency ICRA had downgraded the company from 'C' with a tag 'issuer non-cooperating' to 'D' on confirmation of delays in debt servicing.

"The liquidity profile of the company, along with its subsidiaries, continues to remain stretched as evident from the considerable decline in the net cash accruals in FY19 and net-worth erosion due to significant impairment of assets," ICRA had said.

R-Power, a part of the Reliance Group promoted by Anil Ambani , is the primary vehicle for investments in the power generation sector. The company's generation capacity stood at 5,945 MW, including 5,760 MW of thermal capacity and 185 MW of renewable energy-based capacity.

Its operational projects include Rosa Project at Shahajahnapur, Uttar Pradesh (1,200 MW); Butibori Project at Nagpur, Maharashtra (600 MW), UMPP at Sasan (3,960 MW); solar PV Project at Dhursar, Rajasthan (40 MW), concentrated solar power project at Pokhran, Rajasthan (100 MW) and wind project at Vashpet, Maharashtra (45 MW).

Title: Assessors of SSC & HSC exams demand hike in remuneration
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Teachers assessing the answer sheets of SSC and HSC board examinations have demanded a rise in per paper remuneration.

The teachers said they were being paid around Rs5 for evaluating each paper in comparison to Rs 12 per paper being paid to their CBSE counterparts. There had been no rise in remuneration for the last seven years, they said, adding that the hike would help in accurate and quality assessment.

The Shikshak Hitkarni Sanghatna, an association of junior college teachers, on Monday submitted a letter to the commissioner of state education department Vishal Solanki in this regard, requesteding immediate action.

Prakash Pawar, a member of the association, said, “The state board takes examination fees from every SSC and HSC student. They have also been increasing the exam fees from time to time. But, for the past seven years, the remuneration paid per paper to the teachers has been less.”

Pawar said the teachers’ associations across the state had been urging the government as well as the state board to increase the fees, but to no avail. “These two exams are a turning point in the students’ careers. One mark here and there would make a huge difference. So, it is important that the teachers are given attractive remuneration per paper to ensure accuracy,” he said.

Citing the example of experts assessing the papers of the UPSC examination, Pawar said they were provided air fare to travel to Delhi for the assessment work. “One assessor is given 10 papers at a time and the arrangements for conducting the assessment work is top class just to ensure that the quality of work is not compromised. We are not demanding for the same treatment as UPSC assessors. We are saying that our work should be given justice by paying us well,” he said.

Ashok Bhosale, the secretary of the state board, said, “Whenever we increase the exam fee, we make sure that the remuneration of the teachers is also increased. The last hike was given in 2017, so the claims of no rise in remuneration for the last seven years are baseless.”

Title: Showers bring chill back to Bareilly, neighbouring districts
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Bareilly: The much-needed respite that the sunny days had brought from the cold weather conditions was short-lived, with the afternoon showers on Tuesday lashing the city and bringing the chill back.

The maximum temperature was recorded at 17.6 degrees Celsius and the minimum remained at 11.5 degrees.

The Indian Meteorological Departmental (IMD) has, meanwhile, predicted rain and thundershowers with gusty winds in Western UP districts, including Bareilly, Moradabad, Meerut, Ghaziabad, Hapur, among others, in the next 24 hours. There was not much fog on Tuesday, but IMD has forecast foggy and misty weather conditions in the coming days in the city.

Though it didn’t make much difference in the minimum and maximum temperatures, the 1.4 mm rainfall revived the chilly weather conditions that lasted throughout day.

According to IMD, the minimum temperature was recorded at 11.5 degrees Celsius, four degrees above normal, while the maximum remained at 17.6 degrees, three notches below normal. The humidity level was high and recorded at 93% while the minimum humidity remained at 80%.

Showers were also witnessed in neighbouring districts , including Rampur and Moradabad, while cloudy conditions persisted in Shahjahanpur and adjacent areas.

In Moradabad, the maximum was recorded at 20 degrees Celsius and the minimum remained at 10 degrees, whereas Shahjahanpur recorded a minimum of 11.5 degrees, five degrees above normal, and the maximum was 17.8 degrees Celsius, two degrees below normal.

The IMD has predicted that many places in the state will witness cloudy weather conditions that will convert into scattered rainfall in the next couple of days, resulting in a dip in both maximum and minimum temperatures.

Speaking to TOI, head of geography department, Bareilly College, Neeru Agarwal said, “Western disturbances and fresh snowfall in the Himalayan region have revived the cold conditions, which will continue for some time. The mercury will fall in the coming days as the state will be in the grip of cold wave. There is a possibility of another round of winter rains in coming days.”

The moderate rainfall in the city, however, did not hamper day-to-day activities and schools also remained opened. The showers, however, made roads in Choupla, Ayub Khan and Shyamganj-satellite area slushy due to the on-going construction work.

Ruksar Mirza, a local student, said, “Though there was no fog in the morning, there was significant chill in the air since afternoon soon after it rained. Later in the evening, visibility was okay but the climate was misty. There was some relief from biting cold last week, but it seems that the cold conditions are back.”

Title: 3 yrs after derailment, train engine turns into scrap
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kannur: The diesel locomotive of 16308 Kannur-Alappuzha executive express, which derailed while shunting near Kannur railway station in 2016, has turned into scrap.

The loco engine, which is more than 25 years old, was not worthy of rehabilitation following the accident and hence it was decided to sell it as scrap, said the officials. The dismantling process has already began inside the railway station compound.

Though the old engines are sometimes sold to countries like South Africa for loco purpose only, this diesel engine, with 2200 HP power and 4,000 litre fuel capacity, was totally damaged after the accident, according to the inspection conducted by the engineers, said railway officials.

The accident happened at 4:30am on July 5, 2016, when the train was being shunted. The locomotive pilot lost control owing to poor visibility due to rain and it skid off the track and fell into a gorge breaking the concrete wall near Chettiarkulam near the railway station.

A Chennai-based company had bought the engine during an auction conducted by the deputy chief materials manager of Golden Rock Railway Workshop, Tamil Nadu, one of the workshops of Southern Railway zone. The scrap fetched Rs 20,77,000, an official said adding that today it would cost around Rs 8 core to manufacture such an engine.

The auction was held on December 6 last year and the bidder was confirmed on December 24. The dismantling process which began on January 3 is expected to be completed by January 14, said officials.

Though condemned engines are usually dismantled in the loco shed, here it was decided otherwise considering the complexities involved in its transportation from Kannur to Palakkad, said officials.

Title: Fabricator dies as dumper hits bike
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Pune: A 32-year-old fabrication worker was killed and his friend suffered injuries after a garbage dumper of the PCMC rammed their motorcycle on Monday afternoon on Spine Road in Moshi.

The police identified the deceased as Samir Kumar Sitha and registered an offence against the dumper driver for negligent driving. Sub-inspector Amardip Pujari of the Bhosari MIDC police said Sitha and Jena worked as fabrication workers. They had gone to a company in Chakan on Monday. The accident occurred when they were returning. “Their motorcycle collided with the garbage dumper.. Both fell off the motorcycle,” Pujari said.

Police constable of the traffic branch Manoj Alapure took Sitha to a nearby hospital, while Jena was rushed to the hospital by some others. “Sitha succumbed to the injuries during treatment,” Pujari said.

Initially, it was thought that Jena left Sitha lying injured on the road and fled. Later, it was revealed that Jena, too, was undergoing treatment.

Title: Pune: Four booked for stalking bike-borne couple
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Kondhwa police on Monday booked four men travelling in a car on the charge of stalking a motorcycle-borne couple around 2am on January 1.

The incident occurred between NIBM Chowk and Undri when a 19 year-old woman and her husband were on their way home after attending a New Year party on M G Road in Camp. The woman was riding pillion.

“The woman in her complaint said that while they were riding on a stretch along the NIBM Chowk in Kondhwa, a car coming from behind started to chase their motorcycle. The woman alleged that one of the person inside the car tried to inappropriately touch her,” an officer from the Kondhwa police said.

The officer said, “The car followed them till the couple’s residence in Undri. The driver of the car picked up speed when the woman called her brother in-law from inside the house to intervene. One of the wheel of the vehicle ran over the right leg of the woman’s brother-in-law, critically injuring him.”

The officer said the woman lodged an FIR after an inordinate delay since her brother in-law was undergoing treatment. “We have managed to get the car’s registration number. The driver and the other three men would be traced soon,” the officer added.

Title: Burglars sprinkle chilli powder, escape with gold jewellery, Rs 4.50 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Sniffer dog at the house burgled in Ariyalur

TRICHY: Unidentified burglars have decamped with 22 sovereigns of gold jewellery and Rs 4.50 lakh from a locked house in Ariyalur town. The incident came to light only on Tuesday morning when the neighbours found the lock broke open.

Police sources identified the house owner as Vasugi Varadarajan, 48, located at Kamarajar Nagar on Sendurai road.

On January 2, 2020, Vasugi and her family members left for Sendurai to attend a family function. Meanwhile, neighbours of the house owner have found the lock of the front door of the house broke open and belongings inside the house ransacked.

Subsequently, they alerted Vasugi on her mobile phone. As Vasugi and her family members rushed back home on Tuesday morning, they found the steel almirahs broke open and valuables missing.

The victims have complained that the unidentified burglars have sneaked away with Rs 4.50 lakh and 22 sovereign gold jewellery kept in the steel almirahs.

To evade being tracked, the burglars had sprinkled chilli powder at the entrance of the house. The victim on Tuesday lodged a complaint with the Ariyalur police station.

A sniffer dog was pressed in for service and forensic personnel collected evidence from the burgled house. Ariyalur police have registered a case and are investigating.

Title: 10 Janpath a centre of violence, arson, alleges Shivraj Singh Chouhan
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Shivraj Singh Chouhan

BHOPAL: BJP vice-president Shivraj Singh Chouhan sparked controversy on Tuesday by alleging that 10 Janpath — the residence of Congress president Sonia Gandhi — is the “centre of violence and arson in the country”. Congress reacted by saying that Chouhan has been sidelined in BJP and is trying to be in news by making bizarre statements.

“Congress has been involved in the biggest mob lynching. After the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in 1984, Congress pushed the entire country into violence by saying that ‘when a big tree falls, the earth shakes’. Questions are still being raised on Congress’s involvement in mob lynching. Now, the party is trying to push the country into a spiral of violence in the name of Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and 10 Janpath is its centre,” Chouhan told mediapersons in Ludhiana.

Chouhan, Madhya Pradesh’s CM for three terms, had triggered a major controversy in August last year when he called former Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru a “criminal”. Chouhan had attacked Sonia Gandhi recently, asking why she did not say a word in Parliament during the debate on Citizenship Amendment Bill, but staged protests after it became a law.

Justifying the implementation of CAA, Chouhan said that during Partition, Hindus, Sikhs and other minorities living in Pakistan had suffered severe torture. “Punjab suffered the most. Minorities in Pakistan are still suffering torture and people are not safe. They are living in fear,” said Chouhan.

“The incident of stone pelting in Nankana Sahab is unfortunate. Congress is misleading the public to instigate violence. I want to ask Sonia ji, Punjab CM Amrinder Singh ji and MP CM Kamal Nath ji, what is wrong with CAA? What are they opposing? They should come clear on whether they do not want Hindus, Sikhs and other minorities, who have lost their lives in Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh, to be given Indian citizenship? They should make it clear if they want these Hindus, Sikhs, Christians, Buddhists and Parsis to be sent back to Pakistan to die,” said Chouhan.

The BJP leader questioned Congress’s “silence” on the attack on the Nankana Sahab gurdwara in Pakistan. “I want to ask why Sonia ji and Rahul ji took 15 hours to condemn the attack on Nankana Sahab? Leaders from Punjab, who talk loud, did not react on the attack. Is their friendship with Imran so strong that they do not think of their own country? This is Congress character and I condemn this,” said Chouhan.

The former CM accused Rahul and Priyanka of creating misconception in the country on CAA. “But we will not let them succeed. Our leaders, including Prime Minister Modi and BJP national president Amit Shah and acting president JP Nadda are touring the country to make people aware of citizenship law,” he said.

The Congress reacted strongly to Chouhan’s allegation. “Chouhan has turned irrelevant since he lost power. He has been sidelined in his own party and wants to remain in news through bizarre statements,” said Congress state media coordinator Narendra Singh Saluja. “Chouhan has been shunted out of active politics. He should clarify who was held with bombs and explosives. He should also identify who were charged with anti-national activities for being involved in explosions.”

Title: Man who ‘bludgeoned’ wife to death says kin killed her
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Pilibhit: A 29-year-old woman’s body bearing multiple injuries was found in her house at Mohammadpur village under Bilsanda police station. Police suspect that she was severely beaten up.

The deceased, identified as Renu Devi, was married 11 years ago to Shridhar Tiwari of Mohammadpur village. The couple had three daughters and two sons.

According to her brother, Jagat Narayan, of Chausara village under Bisalpur Kotwali police station, Tiwari and his family members had been harassing Renu for dowry. She was often beaten up, he alleged. The beatings continued despite intervention by the elderly.

Narayan accused her husband, his cousin, Hori Lal, the latter’s wife, Neeraja Devi, and their son Abhishek of brutally beating his sister on Monday evening, resulting in her death.

On his part, Tiwari told police that he had property dispute with his cousin Hori Lal and the latter and his family had attacked his wife when he was out on an errand on Monday evening. He, however, failed to explain why he did not admit his wife to a hospital when he found her injured on his return. She breathed her last on Tuesday morning.

Hari Shankar Verma, SHO, said on the basis of the written complaint filed by the deceased’s brother, police had booked all four named accused under IPC section 498 A (subjecting a woman to cruelty by husband and his relatives) 304 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) of IPC and provisions of the Dowry Prohibition Act. The accused were yet to be arrested, he added.

Title: Local bodies bound to clear unattended lands, says Kerala high court
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The HC said corporations and municipalities are bound by law to abate nuisance from an unattended or unmaintai... Read More

KOCHI: Corporations and municipalities are bound by law to abate nuisance from an unattended or unmaintained property within its limits and to recover the expense for the same from the land owner, said the high court .

The decision by Justice Devan Ramachandran came on a petition filed by S Rema of Popular Road in Vaduthala through advocate S Nikhil Sankar. A mini forest has grown in an unattended property next to her house and it has creepers, dense vegetation and uncontrolled undergrowth, making it the abode of reptiles and snakes, thereby causing danger to her and other residents, she had complained in the petition.

Advocate P K Soyuz, who represented Kochi corporation, submitted that action has been taken to clear the ‘mini forest’ as soon as the petition was filed before the HC and he produced photographs of the works done.

Referring to the Kerala Municipality Act, 1994 (sections 426, 427, and 430), the court said in the judgment, “It is without doubt that it is statutorily enjoined upon the secretary of the municipal corporation , under the provisions of the afore extracted Sections of the Act, to ensure that the properties within its territory are maintained without filth and noxious or wild vegetation.”

The judgment stated further, “The conjoined reading of the aforementioned provisions renders it perspicuous that when a citizen approaches the secretary of the corporation with a complaint - that an unattended and unmaintained property is causing nuisance as specified under Section 426 or is covered by filth or noxious or wild vegetation as specified in Section 427 of the Act - then, in my firm view, the said authority becomes obligated in law to take swift action against the owner or occupier of such premises and complete it under the mandate of Section 430 of the Act.” When any building or land becomes a nuisance due to abandonment, the secretary of a corporation or municipality issue notice to the owner to secure, enclose, clear or cleanse the property within a stipulated time, as per section 426.

The secretary of a corporation or a municipality can also issue a notice to the owner of any building or land to remove filth or noxious or wild vegetation within a period of 24 to 48 hours, stipulates section 427.

If the owner of a building or land fails to act despite receiving a notice from the corporation or municipality, the secretary can get the work done and recover the expenses from the owner, says section 430.

Title: Triple treat: Three new cubs spotted in Nauradehi
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Tiger

Bhopal: Almost two years after a tiger ‘couple’ was translocated to Nauradehi Wildlife Sanctuary in Damoh, two healthy cubs were photographed following their mother, for the first time — sending cheer all around. As per forest officials, there are three cubs, but the third is behind the mother and cannot be seen in the picture.

It is believed that the tigress gave birth sometime in June or July last year, but kept the cubs hidden.

The news is a cause for celebration as before this, tigers have not been sighted in Nauradehi for many years.

“This is very good news. After the success story of tiger reintroduction in neighbouring Panna, now Nauradehi is heading in the same direction,” said divisional forest officer (DFO), Nauradehi, Naveen Garg.

In April 2018, Kanha National Park’s Radha and Bandhavgarh’s Kishen were brought to Nauradehi. Initially, the two were kept in separate enclosures adjacent to each other and released in the wild shortly after.

Like other collared tigers, Radha and Kishen were later coded N1 and N2 respectively by the sanctuary staff.

Radha was an orphan and was raised in an enclosure in Kanha for two years and three months before being relocated with a mate to Nauradehi — spread over 900 square km in Sagar, Damoh and Narsinghpur districts of the state.

According to the latest tiger census, at 526, Madhya Pradesh has the maximum number of tigers in the entire country.

Title: Close shave for three passengers as car catches fire
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Pilibhit: Three people who were travelling in a car had a narrow escape when the vehicle caught fire near the bridge over Mala river on Pilibhit-Basti national highway 730, under Gajraula police station, late on Monday night.

The car owner and two of friends were on way home to Bareilly after attending a wedding ceremony in Puranpur city. The three people jumped out of the car minutes before it turned into a ball of flames.

Police rushed to the spot and tried to douse the fire with river water but the car was gutted in no time.

Naresh Kumar Kashyap, SHO of Gajraula police station, said car owner Amit Saxena of Prem Nagar locality in Bareilly city said the car caught fire due to a short circuit – first the headlights went out and then, heavy smoke swirled out of the bonnet.

All the three men in the car immediately came out and soon, the car caught fire, he added.

Title: Access marriage records from 1914 to 2010 online
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Panaji: The state government has successfully digitised marriage records from 1914 to 2010 — covering almost a century. Basically marriage records since 1914, when the Portuguese enforced the common civil code in the state, can be accessed online.

If a citizen wants to search the record of his/her marriage registered in the state, he or she may access it by visiting www.goaonline.gov.in and registering themselves to avail the service, which was launched by chief minister Pramod Sawant along with law minister Nilesh Cabral on Tuesday.

With the new system becoming functional, citizens won’t have to visit a taluka registrar’s office to search for marriage records between 1914 and 2010. People can visit the website, search, view and download a non-certified marriage record. Cabral said for now people will still have to visit a taluka registrar office to get certified copies, but shortly marriage certificates will be available online.

Within two to three months, people will able to register their marriages online, the law minister said. People won’t have to visit the registrar’s office for marriage or marriage certificate , he said.

To a query that some people face problem in obtaining certificates of marriages registered 50 years ago, the minister said his department is committed to resolve the problem and the process of reconstruction of marriage certificates will start within the next few months.

The chief minister termed the latest service by the state registrar office as “historic” in the country.

“It is a big achievement for Goa to make marriage records of the Portuguese-era online,” Sawant said.

Cabral said credit must be given to the chief minister who intervened to sort out the matter with Prithvi Services Pvt Ltd, which was appointed, in 2010, for digitising the documents. The dispute with the agency was resolved amicably, he said.

About 8,60,000 documents have been scanned and uploaded. The marriage documents from 2010 to 2019 will also be made available online in coming months, he said.

On an average, 12,000 marriages are registered in the state. The new facility has been launched in association with Goa Electronic Ltd, under e-District mission mode project.

Cabral said the state registrar’s office has become over 99% corruption-free.
