Title: Congress hurls list of scams at Vijayvargiya; baseless, says BJP
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kailash Vijayvargiya

BHOPAL: The Congress vs Vijayvargiya war rages on, with the party on Tuesday accusing the BJP national general secretary of involvement in a series of scams, including Simhastha scam and pension scam.

State Congress spokesman Narendra Saluja released the list of scams and reeled out some names, asking Vijayvargiya if they were “nationalists or members of mafia groups”.

“Kailash Vijayvargiya should say who is Yuvaraj Ustad. Whose supporter is this man and who is the leader with whom he appears in hoardings and posters? Is he a nationalist or mafia? Who is Hemant Yadav? Who is Munna Doctor?” Saluja asked.

The Congress spokesman, who hails from Indore — the same city as Vijayvargiya — said, “Tai (former Lok Sabha Speaker Sumitra Mahajan ) and several BJP leaders have told the party’s top leadership who is the patron of mafia. The list of mafia goons is long, but let Kailash Vijayvargiya identify these persons first.”

Saluja also released a list of scams and accused the BJP leader’s involvement in them. “These scams and financial irregularities occurred during your tenure. Who is involved in them?” he asked. The list includes the pension scam, which allegedly happened during Vijayvargiya’s tenure as mayor of Indore, ‘Simhastha scam’ of 2004 when the BJP general secretary was minister for energy and PWD, the ‘Navratan garden scam’, ‘pipes scam, tubewell boring scam, plastic plant scam and drip scam’.

“The list of scams is a long one, but let Kailash Vijayvargiya reply to these. Let him explain when these scams occurred, in whose tenure and who is responsible for them. And where should those responsible be sent — to jail or on a pilgrimage?” Saluja asked.

TOI tried contacting Vijayvargiya, but he was not available for comment. BJP spokesman Rajneesh Agarwal said, “Kailash Vijayvargiya’s point has been that whatever action is taken by the government should be according to rules and laws and with transparency. Whether Vijayvargiya has been involved in any scam or patronized mafia will be decided as per rules, laws and with transparency. It cannot be decided in the state Congress office.”

BJP argued that a year has passed since Congress came to power in Madhya Pradesh, yet it has found nothing to pin down Vijayvargiya. “Instead of making baseless allegations against Vijayvargiya, Congress should concentrate on implementation of promises it made to the people. They should stop this politics of accusations and start proving their worth in governance,” Agarwal added.

Title: Water quality is good in 18 of 45 Bengaluru lakes: Study
Content:
Water of Jakkur (in pic) and Ulsoor lakes falls in the good category. It can be used for domestic and irrigati... Read More

BENGALURU: Contrary to the perception that lakes across the city are cesspools, a study by CSIR-National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (Neeri) has certified that water quality in 18 (40%) of the 45 lakes it examined is “good”, implying it can be used for domestic and irrigation purposes. However, it’s not fit for drinking.BBMP had commissioned Neeri to assess water quality index (WQI) of all its 206 lakes on directions of the high court, which is hearing a batch of petitions on the condition of various Bengaluru water bodies. In its interim report released recently, the institute said it assessed 45 lakes and quantified their WQI under five classifications: excellent, good , poor, very poor and unsuitable for drinking.According to the study, excellent category means the water is fit for drinking, irrigation and industrial purposes, while good water is fit for domestic, irrigation and industrial uses. Water of poor quality can be used only for irrigation, very poor for ‘restricted’ irrigation and that which is unsuitable for drinking needs proper treatment.The interim report puts the WQI of 22 lakes at poor and two at very poor. Three lakes had no water from August to December last year. The three, incidentally, are yet to be developed, while the remaining 42 have been revived. Also, water in none of the lakes was found to be excellent and fit for drinking.“On HC directions, we engaged Neeri to conduct a comprehensive study of Bengaluru lakes . It has submitted the interim report. We will examine it and augment efforts in improving WQI in all lakes, both which have been developed or have to be developed by BBMP,” said Ravikumar Surpur, special commissioner, major projects and health.Incidentally, the Palike has fully developed only 75 of the 206 lakes it its custody. Sources said shortage of funds is the primary reason for poor maintenance.Asked why water quality of many lakes is certified as poor, a senior BBMP official said: “Lakes in outer areas have not seen development for the past few years. With sewage not being diverted, they continue to receive filth.”Citing the example of Parappana Agrahara lake whose water has been classified as very poor by Neeri, the senior official said it’s because the STP which treats water released from the nearby Central Jail has stopped functioning. “We have issued a notice to jail authorities asking them to fix it. The quality of water will improve within a few months once the STP starts working. Thirumenahalli Lake, which also has very poor water quality as per the study, doesn’t have a proper outlet to release accumulated sewage. We are working on it.”Asked about the green colour of water in most lakes, the official said, “That is not a reflection of the water quality. Soil and sediments of a lake play a vital role in determining the colour.” He added: “Frequent rejuvenation, good rain and STPs can contribute to clearer water,” he added.Making it clear that water termed good is not potable, BBMP commissioner BH Anil Kumar said, “It is used only for domestic, irrigation and industrial purposes.”Lake expert Ramprasad said the perception of city lakes will change now.A senior Neeri official said they’ve surveyed all 206 lakes under BBMP and the final report will be submitted soon.

Title: Lending a hand to those who’ve lost theirs
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: Like everybody else, Raghu Arikapudi goes through newspapers every morning, intently reading stories about accidents, health disorders and the likes. However, he does not stop after a read through. Raghu then makes clippings and sets about on his way to stitch back lives of victims who are undergoing difficulties.

For over two decades, Raghu has been helping people in need, most of them are differently-abled. “The struggles of real people are unimaginable. Can you understand what it means to take three hours to cross a room?” he asks when speaking of a family in which four people suffer from muscular atrophy.

“I read about them in the paper and tracked this family down to Nizampet. The small room in which the family sat was dark and leaking. There were three sisters, all survivors of muscular atrophy. One of their adult sons also suffers from the disorder. The only girl in the family Bhagyalaxmi is unmarried and cannot work as she has to fend for the rest,” said Raghu. Since he met the family, Raghu has helped them out with their rations, medical costs and other expenses. Now, he has taken it on himself to get the Bhagyalaxmi married. “This year for sure,” he says.

In another case, Ravi Kiran and his two brothers suffer from the same disorder and their 80-year-old mother takes care of them. “Their situation will never change, but we can hope to reduce their struggle and make them as independent as possible,” Raghu says. From a middle-income family himself, Raghu works at Bharat Dynamics Limited’s (BDL) assembling section. The time he gets away from his job is spent travelling to be in service of others. He says his wife and kids hardly find him at home but are supportive of his efforts and even help out when they can.

“Helping hands are more powerful than praying lips,” Raghu says reiterating his idol, Mother Teresa’s words. He helps around 30 families with his limited means and is also helped by his BDL employees. “I, as well as other volunteers, regularly follow-up every single case,” he says. For him, the people he helps are not charity cases, they are a lifelong commitment.

Among many who Raghu has been helping is 10-year-old Madhukumar. His family had lost hope when one fateful day, while playing, Madhukumar came in contact with an iron rod connected to an electric line. He received a severe electric shock and lost his limbs.“We are trying to teach him how to use a brush and paint. The idea is to make him independent,” Raghu says.

Dreaming big for the child, Raghu says he eventually plans to get him robotic limbs like ones seen on TV. “Nothing is out of question,” Raghu says with a smile.

Title: 25-year-old hangs self in Kondapur
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: A 25-year-old woman from Gurugram near Delhi hung herself to death in her flat in Kondapur on Monday night. Police suspect Monika Rao took the extreme step over personal problems.

Monika was working in the marketing department of Oyo, a hotel chain. A flatmate found her hanging from the ceiling fan and immediately alerted others. Monika shifted to Kakatiya Residency apartments in Rajarajeswari Nagar Colony just a month ago and shared the flat with two others.

Police said Monika shifted to Hyderabad in 2015 to pursue her studies. Later, she got a job. She did not leave any suicide note. A suspicious death case was registered and enquiry is on.

Title: Amartya Sen underlines benefits of surmounting borders
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Infosys Foundation chairperson Sudha Murty with economist and Nobel laureate Amartya Sen, during the Infosys P... Read More

Title: Maharashtra: Industrialists raise permission delays, tax issues with new CM
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Uddhav Thackeray with Ratan Tata, Mukesh Ambani, Anand Mahindra, Adi Godrej, Sajjan Jindal, Gopichand Hinduja ... Read More

MUMBAI: In their first interaction with Chief Minister Uddhav Thackeray on Tuesday, leading industrialists based in Maharashtra raised issues such as the long list of permissions required to set up a company, delay in permissions, high land cost and government taxation while seeking discounts on power tariffs and setting up of new industrial townships and special economic zones.

Thackeray promised them the government would ensure that permissions are fast-tracked.

He also assured them of a conducive business climate so that not a single industry leaves for another state.

Some industrialists said the government should look at expanding the scope of dairy business in the state. Issues regarding pending infrastructure projects, too, were raised. The meeting with prominent business barons was held at the Sahyadari guesthouse in Malabar Hill. Held to gather inputs for formulating a new industrial policy, it lasted two hours. Industries minister Subhash Desai said the government has taken note of issues raised and discussions will be held at the administrative level to resolve them.

Desai said the state plans to host a Magnetic Maharashtra event in Mumbai in November 2020, for which it plans to invite global companies to invest in the state.

Title: Hyderabad tops charts in country’s office space market for second half of 2019
Content:
Amazon campus building in Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: Setting a blistering pace of growth in office transactions thanks to the soaring demand from the IT/ITeS sector, Hyderabad overtook India’s Silicon Valley, Bengaluru, to emerge as the city with the highest office space transactions in the country for the second half of 2019, according to global real estate consultancy firm Knight Frank .While Hyderabad clocked 8.9 million sq ft of office transactions in the July-December 2019 period, Bengaluru could record only 7 msft office transactions in the same period. In H2 2018, Bengaluru was ahead in the office market with 6.9 msft transactions vis a vis Hyderabad’s 4.3 msft. Mumbai clocked the third highest office transactions during H2 2019 at 5.1 msft but recorded flat growth as compared to the corresponding period of 2018.The IT/ITeS sector accounted for a chunk of the total office transactions in Hyderabad at 58% in H2 2019, up from 44% in H2 2018. Co-working players, on the other hand, accounted for 1.36 msft or 15% of the total office space transacted in Hyderabad, Knight Frank said in its latest report ‘India Real Estate: H2 2019’ that compared the performance of eight cities.The year 2019 also saw Hyderabad record an all-time high of 12.8 msft in terms of office transaction volumes, an 82% jump over the 7 msft figure it clocked in 2018. However, despite its record breaking performance, the city emerged second in office transactions for 2019 after Bengaluru, which topped the charts with 15.3 msft transactions in 2019 vis a vis 13.4 million in 2018. Mumbai came third here too with 9.7 msft office transactions during the full year as compared to 7.9 msft in 2018.Knight Frank pointed out that infrastructure constraints in Bengaluru are prompting IT/ITeS occupiers to consider Hyderabad for their expansion plans. Adding to Hyderabad’s attractiveness quotient is the availability of a rich and diverse talent pool thanks to the presence of premier educational institutions.“Hyderabad’s remarkable surge brings it at par with other major markets.... Primarily driven by organic growth of technology and ITeS companies, this demand is expected to remain stable in the near future. Increased activity in the co-working segment is further supplementing the city’s growth momentum,” Samson Arthur, branch director-Hyderabad, Knight Frank India, said while releasing the report.

Title: Don’t show papers, oppose CAA, says Prakash Ambedkar
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Prakash Ambedkar

MUMBAI: Addressing an anti-CAA, NPR and NRC meeting of clerics and imams on Tuesday, Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi ( VBA ) chief and Dalit leader Prakash Ambedkar said the best way to oppose the “black law” is not to cooperate with the authorities when they come to verify citizenship.

At a meeting called by senior cleric Maulana Moin Ashraf Quadri (Moin Mian) at his Grant Road-based madrassa, Ambedkar slammed the Centre for framing a law that he alleged is not just against Muslims but against nomadic tribes, Dalits and OBCs too.

“CAA and NRC are part of RSS’s plan to impose their exclusivist, Vedic cultural nationalism which is against the inclusive, syncretic culture of India as established by Mahatma Phule and other saints and Sufis. We will have to fight a sustained battle,” he said. “Don’t show the papers when they come asking for them. The government already has enough documents to prove that we have been living here for centuries.” CAA and NRC are against the poor who cannot show documents, said Ambedkar. “Either you fight and get the law repealed or go to detention camps,” Ambedkar added.

Title: 34-yr-old missing, brother says cops not doing enough
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: A 31-year-old advocate has been going around the city asking locals if they had spotted his elder sister. On December 25, Kuthuru Parikshith’s elder sister, 34-year-old Rohitha left her rented accommodation in Gachibowli and her cellphone behind and has not returned home since.

“It has been 12 days (on Tuesday) since she went missing. She was spotted in Secunderabad recently. I gave police a lookout notice so that they can paste it at every possible public place, however, I still have not gotten any confirmation if this has been done. Initially police told me that she might have gone to a New Year’s party just days after I filed a missing complaint. I was shocked (by police’s response). Why would anyone go to a party without their phone?” Parikshith said.

Meanwhile, police suspect that Rohitha is going around wilfully. “We were initially fearing, that she was kidnapped. As she left her cellphone at home, tracing her has become difficult,” said Gachibowli inspector R Srinivas. He added that cops in Secunderabad were alerted and nine teams were formed to trace her.

Since the past week, the advocate and his friends have been going around the city in search and scouring social media for leads. “The police should be doing all this. Instead, I am giving them leads. On Saturday, I got word that my sister was seen around Patny circle. I asked around and few people told me that she had been seen around Secunderabad station. But since then even police has no further information,” the advocate said.

Title: ACB: Shell firm’s role deep-rooted
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: In the ongoing multi-crore Insurance Medical Services (IMS) scam, ACB sleuths stumbled upon more leads involving Legend Enterprises which operated out of a fake address and furnished different addresses to different government agencies. “In one of the (three) addresses mentioned, Legend Enterprises had an office but other than a refrigerator and a table, there was nothing. There was not even a board mentioning that it’s an office space. This clearly indicated that it was a shell firm ,” said an ACB investigator.

In three different letters submitted to government agencies, including Drugs Control Authority (DCA), commercial tax department and IMS between 2013 and 2015, the Legend Enterprises office door number was mentioned differently. “When our investigators tried to visit the three addresses in Rajiv Gandhi Nagar of Kukatpally, they found that one address did not even exist. In the second address, a private individual, Siraj, was staying and the place has got nothing to do with Legend Enterprises,” the investigator said.

According to ACB officials, Legend Enterprises was established in 2013 with Krupasagar Reddy as a proprietor. ACB officials allege that Omni Medi’s proprietor K Srihari Babu, one of the accused in the scam, was the brain behind the establishment of Legend Enterprises with Krupasagar as its proprietor.

The sleuths said Srihari was in collusion with IMS officials and Krupasagar and resorted to multi-crore fraud by purchasing medical kits at a higher price.

According to ACB officials, Rs 54 crore was transferred from the SBI Balkampet account of Legend Enterprises to Omni Medi bank account between April and December 2017. So far, ACB has registered seven cases and arrested 23 persons.

Title: 46-yr-old man held for raping 5-yr-old girl
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: A 46-year-old man allegedly raped the five-year-old daughter of his tenant in Kalapathar area. The accused was arrested on Tuesday. The accused, who works as a carpenter, took the girl, a class 1 student, to a room near the house and raped her. When the girl began crying, the accused let her go.

“The incident occurred on Sunday around 7pm, when the girl was playing outside her house. As the man knew the girl, she went with him when he called her. The family has been staying in that house for the past five years as tenants,” said Kalapathar inspector, S Sudarshan.

The girl’s mother found out about the incident after she came back home crying. Later, on Monday morning, a case was registered, and the girl was sent for medical tests. A rape case was registered, apart relevant sections of the Pocso Act. The girl’s parents work as daily wage labourer at function halls.

Title: Mason chokedto death in Yakutpura
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: A mason was strangled to death by a vagabond on a busy road at Dhobi Ghat area in Yakutpura on Tuesday. Police said the 50year-old accused, Mani, who was charged with murder , is mentally unstable .

At 12 noon when Dayanand was sitting on a footpath near Dhobi Ghat crossroads, Mani came there and picked up an argument with him. “During the argument, Mani suddenly wrapped a towel around Dayanand’s neck and strangled him. After Mani released his grip, Dayanand collapsed on the footpath and his head hit against the hard surface and died. Alerted by locals, we reached the spot and shifted Dayanand’s body for an autopsy,” Saidabad inspector K Srinivas said.

Mani was arrested. During questioning, he told cops that he hails from AP’s West Godavari. “We booked a murder case. He will be produced before court on Wednesday,” the inspector said.

Title: Plea accuses Sukesh Gupta of Rs 2k cr scam, bizman denies fraud
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: A public interest litigation (PIL) has been file in the Telangana high court against businessman Sukesh Kumar and his companies alleging that they had cheated public sector units and banks to the tune of Rs 2,000 crore. The petition was filed by BJYM worker and activist Arun Kumar Goshamallu against the businessman and his companies MBS Impex, MBS Jewellers, Aashish Realtors and others. Sukesh Gupta denied the allegations saying they had been made with vested interests.

“CBI and ED investigated into MMTC gold purchase fraud by Sukesh Gupta’s companies. But there are several loose ends. CBI, ED and CVC are not responding to my fresh complaints. No FIR has been registered regarding loans granted by Andhra Bank and approved accorded by the bank for assignment of debts of Sukesh Gupta and his companies to Asset Reconstruction Company,” Arun Kumar said.

“The CVC has ordered declaration of MBS Jewellers’ and MBS Impex’s bank accounts as fraud since directors had been declared wilful defaulters by various banks. In 2014, Anurag Gupta had been accused of hawala transactions worth Rs 8 crore. The alleged links of Sukesh Gupta to Dubai and Hong Kong-based companies need to be checked,” the petitioner said and alleged foul play with regards to a property in King Koti.

Responding to the allegations, Sukesh Gupta told TOI: “People with vested interests are digging up old cases. The MMTC case with CBI and ED are pertaining to derivative laws. We have not done committed any fraud. The issues are about forex loss where the rupee depreciated during the course of a business transaction. I have also settled the issue with MMTC. High Court has observed that why an agency should probe when the issue is settled.”

Title: Disha’s kin welcomes death warrant to Nirbhaya convicts
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: Family members of the veterinarian who was raped and murdered in Hyderabad last year, welcomed the death warrants served to four convicts in the Nirbhaya case, but have called for a speedier justice system. Shortly after a Delhi court on Tuesday issued death warrants to the convicts, the father of 27-year-old Disha said the judiciary system needs to improve.

“The verdict is no doubt satisfying for the whole country, but the family of the girl had to wait for seven long years for justice. The judiciary system needs to improve. In such gruesome cases, the judgment should be given within six months, so that family does not suffer the pain for years,” said Disha’s father on Tuesday.

Reacting to the verdict, the sister of the government veterinary doctor said that seven years is a long time. “Seven years is not a short span for a grieving family. They must have gone through pain and trauma while they waited for the verdict. But I am happy that the accused were given a death sentence,” said the sister.

On November 27 last year, the government veterinary doctor was gang-raped and burnt to death by four truck drivers at an underpass in Shadnagar. The incident took place a stone’s throw away from the city’s outer ring road and close to a toll plaza. Days after the four accused were arrested, they were killed in an encounter by the Cyberabad police on December 6 near the scene of the crime.

Title: Students hold on-campus candlelight vigil to express solidarity with JNU
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The vigil at St Joseph’s College of Commerce

BENGALURU: City students continued to decry Sunday’s violence on Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) campus. Interestingly, in a deviation from the earlier protests witnessed in Bengaluru, Tuesday saw a candlelight vigil inside the campus of a private institution: St Joseph’s College of Commerce on Brigade Road.

While hundreds of St Joseph’s students dressed in black gathered in the morning to mark their protest against the JNU attack , a candlelight vigil in the evening saw the participation of other college students as well. “I always wanted to be a part of the protests in the city. However, safety was always a concern. Due to the safety net provided by St Joseph’s College, I didn’t want to miss the chance,” said Dadi Christopher, a BCom student.

The vigil was against the rampant violence against students across the country. “There are students who support the Citizenship (amendment) Act and those who don’t. But we have all come together because the government is trying to suppress dissent. That is a sign of fascism. We have the constitutional right to dissent and doing so doesn’t make us anti-national,” said Mohammed Maqdoom, a BBA final-year student.

Though others wanted to join the event, the organisers ensured it was only for students. “As my own institution didn’t organise such an event, I thought I must extend support to my peers who are socially and politically aware and believe in constructive nation-building,” said Shruti Lal, student of St Joseph’s (autonomous).

Students from institutions like Kristu Jayanthi, St Joseph’s Evening College and Jain University participated in the vigil. Yashik Ravi, student of Jain College, Jayanagar, said: “There’s no point in cribbing about things unless you do something about it. This was a great platform to show our dissent.”

Indian Institute of Science (IISc) students also conducted a protest march on Monday night. The institution also held a talk on CAA. A 24-hour student protest began at 6pm at Maurya Junction, Race Course Road.

‘Violence unacceptable’

Students and youth are the present and future of any democracy. It is imperative that our voices be heard and our opinions respected by any state that wishes to progress as a democracy. The (JNU) situation is a violation of basic principles of a humane democracy. The violence faced by students and teachers on their own campus is unacceptable

-Statement by St Joseph’s College of Commerce

Title: TenderSURE work puts Margosa Rd users on unsure footing
Content:
Clumps of mud and dug-up stretches make driving an arduous task on Malleswaram’s Margosa Road

TimesView Be it TenderSURE roads, whitetopping, expansion of the Metro corridor or laying of pipelines, infrastructure projects in Bengaluru are perennially a work in progress. Civic agencies have a barrage of excuses up their sleeve — sometimes rain throws cold water on their plans and often, lack of coordination/funds is to blame. In the case of Margosa Road, the delay has been attributed to lack of space. While some disruption is a given during execution of a civic project, prolonged delays are not acceptable. BBMP should pull up its socks so that frequent users of the road are spared further misery.

BENGALURU: The snail’s pace of TenderSURE work on Margosa Road , the lifeline linking northwest Bengaluru to central and southern parts of the city, is unleashing chaos on the roads of Malleswaram . This is exasperating residents, motorists, shopkeepers and people frequenting hospitals.Several stretches of the road are paved with gravel with no topping. Clumps of mud on the street make riding and driving arduous tasks. The pavements demand some tightrope walking.The work began in January 2019 and was slated to end in December. While the deadline has expired, BBMP officials say only a 300-metre sidewalk on one side from Maramma Temple Circle to 18th Cross may be ready in another two weeks. Though they asserted the project will be completed by March, it seems highly unlikely as work has been taken up only on one side of the pavement along the entire road length.BBMP officials blamed the delay on lack of sufficient space to execute the project and also the widespread roots of trees on either side of the road.“We are trying to expedite the work and have nearly 40 labourers at any given point of time. Tree roots and underground pipeline work are slowing it down,” an official said, adding that any effort to take up more space only ends up further choking the road.The 1.6km-long Margosa Road cutting through Malleswaram links Maramma Circle Temple to Mahakavi Kuvempu Road and is widely used by people heading from Yeshwantpur and Rajajinagar to commute to Malleswaram Circle, Seshadripuram, Majestic, City Market, Chamarajpet and other areas.The road is lined with residential plots as well as commercial establishments including hospitals, educational institutions and eateries among others. Some of the city’s oldest and prestigious educational institutions too are stone’s throw away. The road comes under three wards: Malleswaram, Kadu Malleshwara and Rajamahal.Malleswaram corporator Jaypal N said, “I’m aware of the troubles faced by motorists due to the tardy pace of work, which is not only slowing down traffic but also kicking up dust in the air. Since the stretch comes under major roads, I don’t directly have a say but I have apprised the authorities concerned and asked them to speed it up.”“We’ve been dealing with the situation for many days. We have tried to bring it up at ward committee meetings but corporators say since it’s a TenderSURE road they don’t have a say and won’t be able to help us with the deadline,” said Rekha Chari, president, Malleswaram resident welfare association.A manager at Laxmi Maternity Home on Margosa Road said, “Things have become very problematic for patients. Most of them pregnant woman, who have a hard time walking on the gravel. Our security guards have to handhold them.”“Last week, a patient in labour was brought in but the ambulance didn’t have a place to stop. Finally, our nurses had to carry her on the stretcher for some distance because pushing the stretcher on wheels was not an option,” she said.

Title: FDA inspects Sanchi tankers, samples taken for purity test
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

FDA staff inspect a milk tanker at Sanchi Dugdh Sangh HQ on Tuesday

BHOPAL: Officials of the food safety department on Tuesday continued their anti-adulteration drive and checked milk tankers arriving at Sanchi Dugdh Sangh headquarters in the state capital.

Milk from six tankers coming from Sehore, Rajgarh and Betul was checked at the main gate of the Sanchi Dugdh Sangh at around 8am. Six samples from these tankers were taken and sent for purity test. The samples were taken after breaking the seal of the tankers that were inspected, said senior food safety officer D K Verma.

The food safety officials also took two samples of milk from the collection and chilling centre of the Sanchi plant at Tara Sevaniya and Mugaliya Haat. Milk is put into tankers at these places for supply in areas around Bhopal city.

On December 14, sleuths from the crime branch had seized a milk tanker from Misrod, which also carried a motor that had the capacity to siphon off as much as 2,000 litres milk from the tank.

Traces of urea was found in the milk and tanker driver Farhan was arrested from the spot while his other companions were able to escape.

Later, tanker owner Yogendra Pandey and Gopal Gurjar through whom the stolen milk from the tanker was supplied in the market were also arrested. The GPS in-charge and quality control in-charge of Sanchi Dugdh Sangh at Bhopal were also placed under suspension.

Title: 13 booked for kidnap, murder of 25-yr-old man
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Rajkot: Thirteen people including a woman were booked for abduction and murder of 25-year-old man in Monpar village of Palitana taluka in Bhavnagar.

The Palitana taluka police booked Ramesh Rathod, Kanti Ratod, Rahim Kalu and 10 others for abduction and murder of Pata Rathod and burning his body to ashes.

According to complaint filed by Pata’s elder brother Pravin Rathod (35), a resident of Nani Rajasthali village of Palitana, Pata had left home on January 4 after he allegedly received a call from a woman. However, when Pata did not return back home till evening on January 5, Paravin lodged a missing complaint with the police.

During investigation, police received information that burnt remains of a human body was found outskirts of Monpar village. Pravin after coming to know about the remains, alleged that it was his brother’s bones who was murdered by the accused. He further stated in his complaint that Ramesh, Kanti and Rahim had earlier assaulted Pata on February 20, 2019 after altercation over a petty issue.

Pravin has alleged that the accused had killed his brother over an old grudge. Police had lodged a case against the 13 accused and started investigation.

Title: Ninder farmers begin unique stir to oppose Jaipur Development Authority land grab
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

A farmer sits half-buried on land acquired by JDA in Ninder.

JAIPUR: After a gap of nearly two years, farmers of Ninder village near here re-launched zameen samadhi satyagraha (half-bury their bodies in the ground) as a mark of protest against Jaipur Development Authority (JDA) for forcefully acquiring their agriculture land to develop a housing colony.

On Monday, farmers protesting under the banner of Nindar Bachao Sangharsh Samiti again sat half-buried on land acquired by JDA demanding compensation as per the new Land Acquisition Act. They were supported by women in large numbers who did not sit inside the pit, but were present on the spot.

Nagendra Singh, coordinator of Ninder Bacho Sangarsh Samiti said, “Our demands have fallen on deaf ears of JDA officials. We also tried to meet chief minister Ashok Gehlot and urban development and housing minister. The JDA did not adhere to the past agreement and we will continue our protest in a democratic manner till the time our demands are met.”

The farmers claimed that the affected owners were issued award for acquisition on May 31, 2103, whereas the new Land Acquisition Act came into force only on January 1, 2013. The government should have provided compensation as per the new Act, they claimed.

It was further alleged that the JDA failed to adhere to the agreement and started work at the site without paying compensation to farmers.

Sitaram Shrama, another protester said, “Most of the affected farmers have not surrendered the land. However, the JDA claims that the land has been surrendered with the consent of the affected owners. We were jailed for 11 days by the previous government, but we didn’t surrender our lands.”

According to the JDA records, a housing scheme is proposed on 327 hectares. Till date, approximately 204 hectares has been surrendered by farmers, while possession of 123 hectares is yet to be taken by the JDA.

A senior JDA official said, “The process of acquisition of land has already been completed. In such a situation, farmers demand to deacquire the land is unjustified. The affected people had also approached the Supreme Court. However, the petition dismissed on September 4 2018.”

During the BJP government, farmers for the first time started this unusual agitation on October 2, 2018. The farmers sat inside the pits and trenches and buried themselves waist-deep in the mud for 44 days. The state government acquired 1,350 bighas in several stages since 2010 for a housing project despite the land owners’ refusal to accept compensation.

Title: Woman found dead at home in Jaipur, 2-year-old son missing
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: A 35-year-old woman was found murdered at her residential apartment in city’s Pratap Nagar area on Tuesday. Her two-year-old son is missing, which has led cops to believe that the crime was possibly carried out, or at least planned, by a close acquaintance since all valuables — including the jewellery on the victim’s body — were found intact.

Around 5pm, neighbours found blood oozing out of the woman’s living room and entered the apartment to find her lying in a pool of blood. On receiving information, police and forensic experts rushed to the spot to assess the crime scene.

“When we went inside, we found everything in place,” said a senior police officer.

“All the almirahs, safes and even the clothes and jewellery worn by the woman, were intact. She was found with grave head injuries, and might have been hit on the head with a pestle,” said a senior police officer.

The woman’s husband was not at home and arrived after cops intimated him of the murder . “That is when we realized the couple’s two-year-old son was missing,” the officer added.

Based on the crime scene assessment and circumstantial evidence, police prima facie believe the murder was carried out, or at least planned, by a close acquaintance. A senior officer said the possibility of rape has also been ruled out since the victim’s body and clothes were found intact. Police have also found a blood-stained teddy bear. “We have sought CCTV footage of the apartment and nearby locations,” the officer added.

“There was no trespassing, no robbery attempt, which means someone close to the woman must have been behind the crime. In an attempt to mislead the investigation, the child has also been taken away,” police commissioner Anand Srivastav told TOI over the phone.

Title: Youth injured in leopard attack in Khed taluka
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD : An 18-year-old youth was injured in a leopard attack in Vadgaon Patole village in Khed taluka around 2pm on Sunday, prompting the forest department to start night patrolling and public awareness drive in and around the area.

AG Shendge, range forest officer, Khed, told TOI, “The forest department officials are monitoring the movement of leopards in the region since the Sunday attack. One cage has already been installed in Dondi village, adjacent to Vadgaon Patole. Leopards have a long range and move constantly in search of food and water. So, we will decide in a few days whether to shift this cage to the spot where the attacked occurred or install another cage there.”

The attack happened when the youth, Amol Jadhav, was on his way to meet his father, Kaluram, a farm labourer, at Shiroli village — 3km from the attack site. “Amol had walked around 1.5km and was passing through the jowar fields in the Khapardara area of Vadgaon Patole village when a leopard came out of the fields and pounced on him,” Siddharth Kohinkar, a member of the gram panchayat, said.

Amol suffered severe injuries and scratches on his hand in the attack.

“His cries for help frightened the leopard, which fled into the jowar fields,” Kohinkar said.

Villagers later rushed Amol to a nearby private hospital. “The doctors there advised us to take him to a government hospital for vaccination. I then contacted the forest department officials and took him to the nearby rural hospital where he was given preliminary treatment. Later, the forest department officials took him to the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation-run Yashwantrao Chavan Memorial hospital in Pimpri for vaccination,” he added.

Dondi village is located 3-4km from Khed town. Sugar cane is grown on a large scale in the village, one of the main reasons for the leopards to be found there in large numbers.

When contacted, village sarpanch Swati Kohinkar said, “There is panic among the villagers after Sunday’s leopard attack. We expect the forest department officials to catch the elusive leopard as soon as possible.”

Title: Water board coffers run dry, govt bodies named major defaulters
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Secunderabad: The two primary civic departments in the city Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) and Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) which cater to the needs of nearly one million citizens, have locked horns over payment of outstanding water dues amounting to nearly Rs 20 crore.

The fund-starved HMWS&SB has been doing the rounds of several civic bodies to recover dues that have been pending for a long time, said sources. According to official records, the Buddha Bhavan, North Zone GHMC circle office, Hari Hara Kala Bhavan and traffic police station near Parade Grounds are major defaulters.

Buddha Bhavan, located on MG Road, is maintained by GHMC for official and commercial purposes. The complex, which is one of the top defaulters among government departments in Secunderabad, has a due of nearly Rs 1.67 crore.

Offices of the director general, Special Protection Force (SPF), executive engineer, Hussainsagar and Telangana State Women’s Commission are housed at Buddha Bhavan.

The ground floor of the 8-storey structure has also been let out by the GHMC to 19 commercial establishments on rent. HMWS&SB supplies water to these establishments on alternate days.

“The water board had stopped supplying water to Buddha Bhavan during the course of last year, after GHMC failed to pay the dues. But later, the supply was restored after top officials from the state government mounted pressure on then GHMC commissioner, Janardhan Reddy. The water board has been regularly serving notices to GHMC to clear the Buddha Bhavan dues,” sources in HMWS&SB told TOI.

The next major defaulter was found to be Hari Hara Kala Bhavan, in Secunderabad. The auditorium, which of one the largest in the twin cities has outstanding dues of Rs 67 lakh. The 30-year-old auditorium that hosts award ceremonies, plays, and film festivals is busy throughout the year. It can seat over 1,400 people and has three water connections.

The zonal office of GHMC at Marredpally was found to have dues amounting to Rs 50 lakh for the past three years. Other GHMC wings such as sports, veterinary, roads, parks and town planning and engineering are located in the same premises.

According to sources at HMWS&SB, the dues have not been cleared despite multiple reminders. GHMC authorities, however, said that they have been ‘adjusting’ the pending amount towards payment of property tax for water board’s assets, such as Operation and Maintenance (O&M) Divisions, spread across the city.

The issue of the payment of outstanding dues can only be resolved after both major departments come to a consensus on matters such as payment of property tax etc, officials said.

The dues can only be cleared if a decision is made by higher authorities on the matter, which can then be followed by both parties, said GHMC sources.

Title: Bareilly, Budaun among three UP districts to report malaria API more than one
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Bareilly: An increase in the annual parasite incidence (API), a measure of malaria morbidity for a given year at any given geographical level, in three UP districts of Bareilly , Budaun and Sonbhadra — 8.95, 5.45 and 1.69 respectively — in 2019 against the set government guidelines of one is a matter of concern. Officials are, however, confident that the high API can be controlled by taking various measures.

The API — important for epidemiological surveillance and planning the control strategy for malaria — is calculated by multiplying the total number of positive slides for parasite in a year by 1000 and divided by the total population in a given geographical region (total no. of positive slides for parasite in a year X 1000 / total population).

The health department tested blood samples of a total of 58,54,414 people in 2019 in the state and found 92,732 positive for malaria. Of the total 92,732 malaria cases, Bareilly reported 46,717 cases, Budaun (20,339) and Sonbhadra reported (3,689). Health department officials said both Bareilly and Budaun had reported malaria outbreaks in 2018 and 2019 consecutively, while Sonbhadra was declared malaria endemic-hit a few years ago.

According to officials, the annual blood examination rate for malaria should be 10% of the total population according to the government’s guidelines. And thus, going by the government’s guidelines, the blood samples of around two crore people (in accordance to the state’s population) should have been carried out for 2019 instead of only 58.54 lakh.

Joint director (malaria) Dr Awadhesh Yadav said, “Bareilly, Budaun and Sonbhadra are only three districts in UP where API is more than one. API can be reduced by increasing blood examination rate, proper surveillance, treatment, ensuring malaria patients’ complete (full course) treatment and vector control. We are hopeful of increasing blood examination rate in the current year and will take steps to reduce API in the given three districts.”

Of the total 92,732 cases reported in UP in 2019, 14,457 were of “killer” malaria strain — plasmodium falciparum (PF) — while 78,725 were of milder form of malaria — plasmodium vivax (PV). In Bareilly district, 46,717 cases, including 12,141 PF cases, were detected last year. Budaun, however, reported 18,302 PV cases and 2,037 PF cases in 2019.

According to the health department, in 2018, a total of 86,486 cases — 64,352 PV and 22,134 PF — were reported in UP. “The state, however, saw a decline in PF cases in 2019 as compared to 2018, but an increase in the number of PV cases,” said officials.

Title: ABVP president on fast over union office inauguration in Ajmer
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Ajmer: ABVP and NSUI at Samrat Prithviraj Chauhan Government College of Ajmer are at loggerheads over the issue inauguration of student union office.

Student union president Vikas Gora of ABVP wanted to call BJP leaders to inaugurate the union office but was disallowed by the principal. In protest, he sat on a hunger strike outside the institute on Monday along with two of his supporters.

He alleged that when BJP was in power in the state, NSUI candidate had won the college elections and the principal gave him a free hand to call Congress leaders to inaugurate the office.

On Tuesday, Clock Tower police took the three agitators for medical examination. ABVP spokesman Mohul Garg alleged that they will continue the strike.

NSUI on Tuesday gave a memorandum to the district collector alleging that the principal had already issued dates for the inauguration of student union office but ABVP wanted to put undue pressure on the principal and teachers. NSUI has demanded action against these students.

Title: Pune: Major dip in chain-snatching & robbery cases in one year
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: An enhanced emphasis on pre-emptive actions, such as externment and detention under the MPDA Act, helped in drastic drop of chain-snatching and robbery cases in the city last year.The Pune police recorded 64 chain snatchings in 2019 as against 105 in the previous year, accounting for 41% drop in the number of cases. When it comes to robberies, 221 cases were recorded in 2019 in comparison to 336 in 2018, translating into 34% decline in the cases, the city’s annual crime data released by police commissioner K Venkatesham revealed on Tuesday.In 2013, the city police had recorded 373 chain-snatching cases, the highest between 2009 and 2019, but it’s jurisdiction was then spread over 39 police stations, including the nine that were later merged into the Pimpri Chinchwad police commissionerate on August 15, 2018.As per the annual crime data, the city recorded a a 9% drop in serious crimes like murder, attempt to murder and body offences. Such cases stood at 9,552 in 2018 and came down to 8,677 in 2019. The rate of detection of these cases was 68.3% in 2019, the police claimed.The number of rape cases at 224 in 2019 was 6% lesser than the 236 registered in 2018, while that of molestations was 419 in 2019 as against 516 in 2018.Venkatesham attributed the drop in crime figures to preventive actions, mostly targeting repeat offenders, and a series of initiatives towards maintaining a tab on crime and criminals. “We won’t be sitting on these figures and will definitely go for an analysis of each and every finding of our crime statistics,” he said.A PowerPoint presentation by deputy commissioner of police (crime) Bachchan Singh showed that body offences, property crimes and crimes against women went down by 10%, 17% and 14%, respectively, over the last one year. The city recorded 74 murder cases last year as against 72 in 2018, while 121 attempt to murder cases were registered in 2019 as against 128 in the previous year, the police data showed.It also revealed that property offences went down by 17%, while daytime and nighttime house break-ins reduced by 21% and 24%, respectively. Vehicle thefts went down by 14% in last one year.

Title: Laxman apprises defence min of Cantt issues
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Secunderabad: The Telangana Bharatiya Janta Party’s (BJP) state president K Laxman met the Union defence minister Rajnath Singh and G Kishan Reddy, Union minister of state for home, and submitted a representation regarding Secunderabad Cantonment issues on Wednesday.

In the representation, Laxman apprised the defence minister of on various issues such as closure of roads, shortage of funds resulting in poor development in the areas falling under the Secunderabad Cantonment Board limits. The meeting was held ahead of the SCB elections which are expected to be held in February. TNN

Title: Expired, poor quality food items seized from shops in Coonoor
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Officials found four shops in the bus stand functioning after their licences had expired

UDHAGAMANDALAM: Food security officials seized Rs 25,000 worth food items that have crossed the expiry date or for violating safety norms from shops around the bus stand in Coonoor on Tuesday.

During a surprise check, the officials checked about 20 shops and seized food items including chocolates, biscuits and coloured drinks.

“Large quantity of coloured ice liquids packed in plastic tubes was seized during the check. These packets had no specification of the colouring agents used or other details,” Govindarajan, a food security officer, said. The government is already conducting awareness programmes at schools in connection with coloured food items packed in plastic covers, he added.

The officials also found four shops in the bus stand functioning after their licences were expired. A fine of Rs 5,000 was levied on them. About 12kg of expired chocolates and biscuits were kept in the shops for sale.

“All the expired food items were confiscated and destroyed. Shop keepers were issued a warning notice,” Govindarajan said.

Besides, banned plastic items were confiscated from a few shops and a fine of Rs 2,000 was imposed on each shop by food security officials. Such drives will continue in future, the official said. tnn

Title: 2 labourers die in borewell as soil caves in
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Jaisalmer: Two labourers were killed while repairing a leaking pipe inside a 30ft-deep borewell in Barmer district. The duo was buried inside when soil caved in. The bodies could be taken out after a four hour-long rescue operation.

Bakhasar police along with 500 people, two JCBs and tractors launched a rescue operation to save the duo, but they were dead by the time they could be rescued. Bakhasar SHO said that Kamal Khan, a resident of Meetjadi, lodged a report that his brother Kabal Khan and nephew Kadra went inside a borewell to repair a leaking pipe in it. This was then that the soil caved in and they were buried inside the borewell.

Police and others reached the spot and started the rescue efforts. Kadar’s body was taken out in half-an-hour, while it took four hours to take out Kabal’s body. The bodies were handed over to family members after post-mortem.

It may be noted that, one person died on May 22, 2019 near Shivkar in a similar incident.

Title: Building fire kills 3 labourers in Jaipur, condition of 2 critical
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Rescue operations underway at Anita Colony in Jaipur on Tuesday.

JAIPUR: Three labourers were killed and three others were injured after a fire broke out at an under-construction building in Anita Colony area near Gandhi Nagar railway station here on Tuesday evening. All the three died of suffocation and did not sustain major burn injuries, a doctor at the Jaipuria Hospital said.

The incident took place at 8.15pm when the six labourers were working in the building where wooden interior work was in progress, police said. Five of the six, who were working on the fifth floor, were trapped inside the building as its doors, woodworked walls and false ceiling caught fire. The sixth, who was on the first floor, managed to come out of the building with minor burn injuries, they added.

A team of senior police officers and three fire tenders rushed to the spot. “We used ropes and other equipment to bring the trapped labourers out of the building while continuing our efforts to douse the fire,” said Devang, assistant fire officer.

By 8.45pm all the five trapped labourers were taken out. “None of them had grave burn injuries and they, along with the sixth, were rushed to the Jaipuria and SMS hospitals. Three of them were unconscious when they were rescued from the building,” said a senior police officer.

At the Jaipuria hospital, the three unconscious labourers — identified as Azhar, Nizam and Saurabh — succumbed.

“None of them had grave burn injuries and prima facie it appears that they died of suffocation as they were unable to have enough oxygen. Also carbon dioxide got into their windpipe, which blocked their respiratory tract,” said a doctor at Jaipuria.

Two other injured labourers were undergoing treatment at SMS hospital. Their condition is said to be critical. The one who had managed to come out on his own, was sent home after first aid.

Fire officials got the nearby buildings evacuated and the fire was doused by 9.15pm.

Police said a case of causing death due to negligence would be registered against the owner of the building.

Title: Nana Peth man held in Satara for footwear shop owner’s murder
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Chandan Krupadas Shewani

PUNE: The Satara police arrested a Nana Peth-based man, Afridi Rauf Khan (23), in connection with the kidnapping and murder of Chandan Krupadas Shewani of Sadhu Vaswani Chowk and handed him over to the city police late on Monday night for investigations.

A city court remanded Khan in police custody till January 15.

Confirming the arrest of Khan, joint commissioner of police Ravindra Shisve said, “We have also ascertained the identity of three other men involved in the crime. We shall soon arrest them,” he said, adding that Khan was giving misleading answers to the questions posed to him.

A source said the four men behind the abduction and murder of Shewani did not establish contact with each other over the phone after the committing the crimes. Khan was left with no cash and he visited a few houses seeking money to travel to Pune. One of the villagers alerted the Satara police about Kahn’s suspicious movement and then he was arrested.

Shewani, an unmarried man, was found murdered at Padegaon village near Lonand in Satara district on Sunday morning. Police had found a note near his body stating that he was killed because he did not give them Rs2 crore.

The police said the note was kept there to mislead the police probe. “None of the Shewani family members received any extortion calls either on Saturday or on Sunday. Thus, we feel that Shewani was not abducted and murdered for extortion. There might be some other reason,” said a senior police officer.

Shewani owned a footwear shop on Laxmi Road. After closing it late on Saturday night, he was returning home in his car when the unidentified persons kidnapped and murdered him.

Additional commissioner of police Sanjay Shinde said, “Prima facie the motive was extortion, but it was not the main motive. Things will be clear only after the arrest of the other three men in the case. The search for them is on.”

The police are yet to recover Shewani’s cellphone, Shinde added.

Title: Activists see red as health department transfers reins of BMHRC back to ICMR
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The Union health ministry’s order transferring BMHRC’s administration to ICMR said that the move would help bu... Read More

BHOPAL: After maintaining in the M P high court for over a year that merger of the Bhopal Memorial Hospital & Research (BMHRC) with All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS), Bhopal, is being considered in the interest of both institutions, the ministry of health and family welfare has handed over the BMHRC 's administration back to the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR). The department of health & research (DHR) had earlier taken charge from the ICMR .

An order issued with the signature of Vinod Kumar, deputy secretary in the government of India, says: “With the approval of competent authority, a high-power committee (HPC) was constituted by the department of health research (DHR) under the chairmanship of secretary, DHR, with members from department of health & family welfare, BMHRC, AIIMS, New Delhi, AIIMS, Bhopal, Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute for Medical Sciences and Technology, Trivandrum (Kerala) to decide the modalities for smooth functioning of BMHRC, Bhopal. The committee after detailed deliberations finalized and submitted its recommendations to the government. The committee recommended transfer of BMHRC to ICMR as one of its institutes. The recommendation of the HPC for transfer of BMHRC to ICMR was considered in the department and accepted by the competent authority. Accordingly, the administrative control of BMHRC stands transferred from DHR to ICMR”. The order was issued on November 29, 2019.

Rachna Dhingra, co-convener of Bhopal Group of Information & Action, which is one of the petitioners in the PIL regarding medical care of gas victims, while reacting to the fresh order on transfer of BMHRC to ICMR, said: “The HPC was set up to look into the merger of BMHRC with AIIMS and how does it go back to ICMR? Also, in the entire order, there is hardly any mention of gas victims. The entire order is focused on the welfare of the director and employees of BMHRC. That is why orders like these get passed because we have an insensitive and incompetent system, which fails to recognise the problems being suffered by gas victims.”

Member of Supreme Court Monitoring Committee, Purnendu Shukla, said: “The DHR should have informed the committee about transfer of BMHRC back to ICMR. It should also have sought permission of the high court, which is seized of a contempt petition accusing DHR of not complying with the Supreme Court order on BMHRC. We shall bring it to the notice of the court.”

The order doesn’t specify who is the competent authority and considerations on which Vinod Kumar approved the BMHRC's transfer back to ICMR, which had expressed its inability to administer the hospital following which the apex court had transferred the hospital's administration to DHR in 2015. This was the fourth time that BMHRC's administration was transferred from one agency to another.

While the apex court -- in its August 2012 order -- had asked the DHR to develop BMHRC like an autonomous medical education institute so that it could attract competent doctors, the order transferring the hospital's administration to ICMR talks of “exploring the possibility of its affiliation to Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute for Medical Sciences for award of medical post graduate (MD/MS) and super speciality (DM/MCH ) degrees to medical graduates who join the post graduate and super speciality courses in BMHRC. It would also help BMHRC in capacity building and making it an institute of excellence”, says the order.

The order proposes to retain the present director, BMHRC, and allow her to complete the tenure of five years from the date of her appointment as director, BMHRC, on deputation.

The BMHRC employees will have the option to continue their service under the government of India or work with BMHRC under ICMR. If he/she decides to continue with the government of India, his/her case would be referred to the surplus cell of DoPT for posting in some office/organization under the government of India as per the policy laid down for the purpose.

Title: BJP minority cell leader quits post ‘due to NRC & CAA’
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

BJP state minority cell secretary Akram Khan

Bhopal: The state secretary of BJP minority cell in Madhya Pradesh, Akram Khan, resigned from his post over CAA and NRC on Monday, saying he couldn’t bear ‘indecent comments on a class-specific community’.

In his letter to state BJP minority cell president Sanvar Patel, Khan said, “I am resigning from the post due to NRC and CAA. Please accept my resignation.”

Later, talking to reporters, Khan said, “I have been serving the party for 25 years and respect the party’s decision on NRC and CAA. However, BJP colleagues were involved in indecent comments on a class-specific community. This is hurting sentiments. Hence, I have decided to quit.”

The BJP leader said that he had informed senior leaders, including state office-bearers, but no action was taken. “I am a part of BJP and I am here because of the party but, I cannot resist provocative remarks of fellow BJP workers,” he reiterated.

The BJP has denied that party workers were targeting a ‘class specific community’. "We have instructed all party workers not to incite or create confusion among public on NRC and CAA. Special instructions have been issued not to hurt public sentiments on this issue. We will talk to the leader concerned,” said BJP state spokesperson Deepak Vijayvargiya.

Title: 24-year-old hangs self in Roorkee
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Roorkee: A 24-year-old man committed suicide in Roorkee by hanging himself from a ceiling fan in his house on Tuesday evening. The victim, identified as Pankaj Sharma, used to run a mobile repair shop.

According to Civil Lines Police, Sharma was alone at his house at the time of the incident. When his family members came back home, they found Sharma had locked himself in his room. They managed to take him to a hospital, but doctors declared him dead. Police haven’t found a suicide note.

According to sources, the victim had been depressed and hadn’t interacted with his family for two days. “The reason behind his suicide is unclear. However, we do know that he was depressed over his relationship with a woman,” said sub inspector BS Chauhan.

Title: Two special trains to Srikakulam from Sun
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Secunderabad: To clear extra rush of passengers, South Central Railways will run two Suvidha special trains between Srikakulam and Secunderabad from January 12.

Train no. 82712 Secunderabad– Srikakulam road Suvidha special train will depart Secunderabad at 5.50 pm on January 12, (Sunday) and arrive at Srikakulam road at 8.55 am the next day. Train no 07025 will depart Srikakulam road at 4 pm on January 13, and arrive at 7.40 am in Secunderabad, the next day. TNN

Title: Water on alternate days for 183 villages
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: Residents of 183 villages and seven municipalities located near Outer Ring Road (ORR) and within GHMC limits, will soon have water supply on alternate days.

The Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board has assured to provide 25 million litres of potable water to meet the growing demand. The increased quantity is in addition to 88 million litres, which is being currently supplied to the area. TNN

Title: Ambulance at Dehradun assembly kept on alert for accidents-prone NH 72
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

DEHRADUN: The health department, on Tuesday, put the 108 ambulance service stationed at the state assembly on high alert after a local resident made a complaint regarding an “accident-prone zone” at National Highway 72. The complaint was made at chief minister’s complain portal and the complainant claimed that the accident fatalities at the spot could have been lesser if the ambulance had reached the victims on time.

According to the officials of health department, the 108 ambulance, stationed at state assembly, has been put on high alert and it will be sent to NH 72 (near Mani Mandir, Harrwala) in case of any accident. Earlier, an ambulance from Doiwala (around 8 kilometre from the spot) was sent to attend the cases near Mani Mandir. The ambulance service was sent to attend as many as nine major accident cases in this area in the past eight months.

“The assembly is situated barely four kilometre away from the spot and hence we have put the ambulance there on high alert,” says the press statement issued by the third party agency that manages 108 ambulance service in the state.

Meanwhile, Dr Amita Upreti, director general (health), in a review meeting of chief medical officers of all 13 districts, stressed on ensuring that the machines remain functional in all the hospitals in their respective areas.

“At present, 56 different types of medical tests can be conducted at district hospitals. Soon, this count would be increased to 134. Meanwhile, we are also ensuring that facilities for 97 different types of medical tests are provided at community and primary health centres,” added Dr Upreti.

Title: Aishe Ghosh's mother walks the talk in hometown
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Worried about her daughter’s safety on JNU campus, Aishe’s mother Sharmistha went about her usual routine at h... Read More

DURGAPUR: As news reached Durgapur that Delhi Police had filed an FIR against Aishe Ghosh , the Jawaharlal Nehru University Students’ Union (JNUSU) president, her parents remained undaunted back in her home town. Far from being demoralized, Aishe’s mother Sharmistha chose to hit the streets by joining a protest rally against the assault on her daughteron JNU campus.

“I am proud of my daughter. She is a fighter and will continue with her struggle. I demand resignation of the JNU vice-chancellor for the assault. All this is happening under the VC who owes allegiance to the saffron fold. With such a VC on the chair, I am not finding it safe to keep my daughter on the campus any more. It is very difficult for outsiders to enter the campus.

“Whenever I go to meet my daughter, I have to seek permission at four different stages. My daughter has to inform the authorities that her mother will be visiting her on campus. I want to know how could people enter the campus and attack my daughter?” asked Sharmistha.

The march Sharmistha took part in on Tuesday started from Durgapur’s DTPS Colony near the quarters of DVC staff. Many locals and DVC employees joined in the rally. Many students and youth of Durgapur were seen in the protest march.

“A JNU student named Najib remains untraced. For this reason, I am worried about my daughter as I fear she may be harmed as well,” added Aishe’s father Debashish.

The FIR against Aishe and 19 others was registered on a complaint by JNU authorities. It is among three FIRs filed over the violence inside the JNU campus. Delhi Police is yet to arrest anyone on any of the FIRs.

Title: Maharashtra: Real estate sector still sluggish, agencies say investors vanished
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Sale of residential units in the second half of 2019 remained tepid and belied the promise the first half of the year had held out, data available with various research agencies revealed.Battered by regulatory changes, liquidity constraints and a general slowdown in economy, the real estate sector had hoped in the first half of 2019 that the worst was behind.The sales data revealed that the sector was not yet out of the woods (see graphic). In fact, the sales were currently at least 30% lower than the highs of 2011 and 2012.“The investors have vanished from the market. Earlier, there were many investors and now the residential sector is more of an end-user market,” said Paramvir Singh Paul, branch director for the Pune region at Knight Frank India.Vivek Rathi, vice-president for research with Knight Frank, said the prices in the sector should remain more or less the same in 2020.The Gera report revealed that the prices were largely constant across the city and even in the broader Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority (PMRDA) localities in 2019. He said though sales have increased, considering the broader areas of PMRDA, more needed to be done to stimulate the projects where houses were on hold.“The stimulus fund will not be enough. What is needed is that the buyers should come forward and pitch in a little more money to save what they have already invested. The government can waive the interest in such cases and tell the buyers only to pay back the principal on the top-up,” said Rohit Gera, managing director, Gera Developments.The Gera report estimated that over 40,000 units were in the 242 odd held-up projects and over 16,000 of them have been sold.The first half of 2019 had offered some hope that the industry might be turning around and the effects of demonestisation and GST effect might be wearing off. “While H12019 saw significant housing sales growth, it was the second half (H2 2019) that derailed the growth story in 2019,” said Anuj Puri , chairman, Anarock Property Consultants.

Title: Researchers rue lack of ‘clear’ info on official site
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Pune: Information on the state property department’s registration website do not give a clear picture of the realty market transactions despite daily updates, data researchers feel.

The work of update and providing simplified information of sale and purchase of new properties and lease property registrations was proposed almost three years ago, officials in the department said. The update process has been delayed with several other projects lined up in the department, the officials admitted.

For now, the government provides the number of documents registered and taxes collected against them on the site. These are a mishmash of sales of new and second-hand homes, commercial space and land sales and delayed conveyance, among others, making it difficult to understand the market behaviour over a period.

“We are working towards ensuring detailed sale, purchase and lease agreement registration data to help the analysts. We should be able to take it up this year,” an official said.

Another worry is the lack of district-wise numbers on the sale, purchase and lease agreement registrations. The historical data have also been updated only till 2017. Real estate data researcher N Kelshikar said the data available on government website was complex in nature. “The way the data are presented is very technical and difficult to understand. This creates ambiguity in the minds of people,,” he told TOI.

“Lack of official data is a major hindrance in calculating actual sales in a region. There is no system in the registrar office to collate sales data on a regular basis. MahaRERA is a good platform, having the provision of showing the units sold. We observe many of the developers do not update the data on a quarterly basis,” a representative of JLL said.

Anarock Property Consultants chairman Anurj Puri said the lack of official data on registration “impacts the overall estimates to some extent”. He said, “More accurate official data may largely help in giving the sales scenario in the secondary or the re-sale market.”

Title: Access marriage records from 1914 to 2010 online
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Panaji: The state government has successfully digitised marriage records from 1914 to 2010 — covering almost a century. Basically marriage records since 1914, when the Portuguese enforced the uniform civil code in the state, can be accessed online.

If a citizen wants to search the record of his/her marriage registered in the state, he or she may access it by visiting www.goaonline.gov.in and registering themselves to avail the service, which was launched by chief minister Pramod Sawant along with law minister Nilesh Cabral on Tuesday.

With the new system becoming functional, citizens won’t have to visit a taluka registrar’s office to search for marriage records between 1914 and 2010. People can visit the website, search, view and download a non-certified marriage record. Cabral said for now people will still have to visit a taluka registrar office to get certified copies, but shortly marriage certificates will be available online.

The chief minister termed the latest service by the state registrar office as “historic” in the country.

“It is a big achievement for Goa to make marriage records of the Portuguese-era online,” Sawant said.

Cabral said credit must be given to the chief minister who intervened to sort out the matter with Prithvi Services Pvt Ltd, which was appointed, in 2010, for digitising the documents. The dispute with the agency was resolved amicably, he said.

About 8,60,000 documents have been scanned and uploaded. The marriage documents from 2010 to 2019 will also be made available online in coming months, he said.

On an average, 12,000 marriages are registered in the state. The new facility has been launched in association with Goa Electronic Ltd, under e-District mission mode project.

Cabral said the state registrar’s office has become over 99% corruption-free.

aa

Title: Maharashtra zilla parishad elections: BJP faces uphill task to win Dhule, Nandubar polls
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Voters stand in a queue at a booth in Dhule in the ZP polls.

NASHIK: After Nashik, the BJP is again up against the Maha Vikas Aghadi in the zilla parishad elections in Dhule and Nandurbar . The voting for the 56 seats in each of the two ZPs took place on Tuesday with a voters’ turnout of nearly 65% both in Dhule and Nandurbar.

In Dhule, BJP has put up candidates in all the 56 seats and the local unit exuded confidence that it would be able to defeat the combine Congress, Shiv Sena and NCP in the election.

“In five seats, we have won uncontested as the opposition failed to put up candidates. We are confident that our party will win the ZP polls in Dhule,” Anup Agarwal, the district BJP president said.

However, the Congress, NCP and Shiv Sena combine is set to give BJP a run for its money. While Congress is contesting in 27 seats, NCP has put up candidates in 21 seats. Sena has put up candidates in the few of the remaining seats.

Former Dhule city MLA Anil Gote, who joined NCP recently, said the united opposition would ensure that the anti-BJP votes do not get split. “The BJP camp should not rejoice as they won five seats uncontested. Our combine will come to power,” added Gote.

In the tribal-dominated Nandurbar, BJP is locked in a direct contest with Congress in the ZP polls. Unlike Dhule, the Congress, Sena and NCP could not reach a pre-poll understanding here and all these parties are contesting the polls independently.

Despite this, BJP insiders in Nandubar admitted that it would be difficult for the party to win the ZP polls. BJP is contesting all the 56 seats, while Congress has put up candidates in over 48 seats. Similarly NCP candidates are in fray in over 37 seats and Sena in 41 seats.

“There is a pro Congress wave in many parts of the district as its legislator from Akkalkuwa, K C Padvi, has been made the tribal welfare minister in the new state government. We apprehend that it would help Congress win a majority in the seats,” said a BJP functionary from the district.

Title: Rajasthan Board of Secondary Education Class XII math exam rescheduled
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

Rajasthan Board of Secondary Education (RBSE) has rescheduled the mathematics optional exam for Class XII. RBSE secretary Meghna Choudhary said that mathematics optional exam for senior secondary and Varishtha Upadhyay was to be held on March 25. But because of a holiday announced on March 25 due to Chetichand, the exam will be held on March 26. The direction has also been uploaded on RBSE website.

Title: RPS demands capital in Rayalaseema, says it will help region regain past glory
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Rayalaseema Porata Samithi (RPS) has demanded that the government should set up the capital city in Greater Rayalaseema to help it regain its lost glory. RPS convener P Naveen Kumar Reddy, who spoke to media persons here on Tuesday, asked the government to take a decision soon. “YS Jaganmohan Reddy himself hails from Rayalaseema, he could develop this region by setting up capital at any of the four districts including Kurnool, Anantapur, Kadapa and Chittoor”, he demanded.

Title: 500 amputees in Syria to get Jaipur Foot
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Jaipur: Syrian minister for social affairs Rima Al Qadri and deputy minister for social affairs Wael Badeen inspected a Jaipur Foot artificial limb camp currently underway at the Syrian capital of Damascus. In the camp, over 500 Syrian amputees will be provided with artificial leg Jaipur Foot and artificial hand.

The camp at war-torn Syria has been organised by the ministry of external affairs in association with the Bhagwan Mahaveer Viklang Sahayata Samity (BMVSS).

According to D R Mehta, founder and chief patron of the organisation, the camp has been oprganised under the Indian government’s ‘India for Humanity’ programme to commemorate the 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi.

The 40-day camp follows similar efforts in Vietnam, Myanmar, Malawai, Tanzania, Senegal, Egypt, Iraq, Nepal, Ethiopia, Namibia and Bangladesh.

Title: Four soldiers hurt in CME bridge accident out of intensive care unit
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Pune: Four soldiers, including a Major, who had sustained multiple injuries during an internal exercise, have recovered in the last 12 days and are out of the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) of the Military Hospital Khadki.

Two soldiers were killed while nine soldiers suffered injuries when heavy metal panels fell on them during construction of a Bailey suspension bridge as part of the Combat Engineering Instructor Course at the training node of the College of Military Engineering (CME) on December 26.

“The injured officer has been discharged while the remaining three sappers are still under observation. One sapper is expected to get discharged on Wednesday. None of the soldiers had sustained ‘permanent injury’ in the accident,” a senior army officer from the CME told TOI on Tuesday.

The college has ordered a Court of Inquiry (CoI) to investigate the matter. A Colonel rank officer has been appointed as the presiding officer of the inquiry panel.

“The panel has already recorded statements of some sappers, including Junior Commissioned Officers (JCOs) and Non-Commissioned Offices (NCOs) involved in the exercise. It is probing technical and human errors aspects of the accident. Each facet related to the bridge construction is being validated and probed by the panel and senior officers. Besides, the panel has gone through every detail of the exercise by verifying documents related to it. Each aspect related to Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) is being verified and investigated by the experts,” another senior army officer from the Corps of Engineers told TOI on condition of anonymity.

The inquiry panel is yet to conclude the inquiry. “Establishing sequence of events is a daunting task.
