It will have to collate information provided by the sappers who participated, officers and observers in a logical way before giving its presentation and formal report to the higher-ups,” the officer added.

Title: Haridwar: Couple attempts suicide, boy dead, girl critical
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

HARIDWAR: A 20-year-old boy and his 19-year-old girlfriend attempted suicide at the boy’s residence in Ferupur village under Pathri police station, Haridwar , on Monday night. The boy died after he hanged himself from a ceiling fan while the girl, who consumed poison , has been hospitalized in a critical condition. No suicide note was recovered. As the couple’s parents were not against their relationship, it is still unclear what led them to take the extreme step.

The deceased was identified as Shashikant and his girlfriend as Shivani, both of whom use only their first names. Shivani had gone to meet Shashikant on Monday, which is when the duo decided to take their lives.

Station house officer (SHO) Pathri Sukhpal Singh Mann said, “We found Shashikant’s naked body hanging from the ceiling, while Shivani was found unconscious in the same room. She was taken to the district hospital, from where doctors referred her to a higher centre as her condition was critical. We did not find any suicide note. Shashikant’s parents said that they knew about the couple’s relationship, as did Shivani’s parents. The cause of the suicide is still unknown and an investigation is on.”

Title: 2 booked for extortion in Panchavati
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Nashik: Two people have been booked by Panchavati police for trying to extort money from a vegetable transporter.

According to police, the 27-year-old vegetable transporter — a resident of Vinchur Gawali near Madsangvi — in his complaint has said that the suspects came to him on Monday at 11 am and started threatening him of dire consequences near the vegetable market on Dindori Road in Panchavati. They also asked the complainant to pay Rs 200.

“The duo got into an altercation with the transporter and said the latter will have to pay Rs 200 every time he brings vegetable to the market. The suspects also threatened to damage his vehicles and kill him if he did not pay the amount demanded by them. The complainant said that the suspects had earlier as well harassed him for money,” a police officer said.

Tired of the continuous demands of extortion, the transporter then lodged a complaint with Panchavati police on Monday.

Title: Restrictions on Karve Road for bikers due to Metro work
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Pune: Traffic restrictions will be in place for motorcyclists on Karve Road at the mouth of Yashavantrao Chavan bridge (Chavan Chowk) near Garware school from Wednesday to January 20. The two-wheeler users would not be able to take a turn from the Yashavantrao Chavan bridge towards Deccan Gymkhana.

Bikers from Karve Road would not be able to enter the bridge from Chavan Chowk. They will have to take U-turns from the next immediate chowks to proceed towards Deccan Gymkhana or take the bridge.

The restrictions would be in place to assist Metro work in the Chavan Chowk, stated Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation Limited (MahaMetro), which is executing the project.

The civil work of the Metro viaduct is under way on Karve Road — from Paud Phata Chowk to the Chavan bridge Chowk. The Metro will run on the road median. The construction of the pillars has been completed on the entire stretch.

MahaMetro has now started launching segments on the pillars. The work proposed from Wednesday near the mouth of Chavan bridge is of the segment launching.

Title: Rajasthan: Family sells ancestral property to set up rescue centre for stray dogs
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Jyoti Khandelwal with her dogs at the centre. Nayhesh tags a dog with radium belt.

JAIPUR: Jyoti Khandelwal of Mount Abu has turned out to be a good samaritan for injured stray dogs . She has set up a rescue centre for the canines at the hill station in Sirohi district by selling a part of her ancestral property.

Now her whole family of three – herself, sister and brother – all highly educated, are fully devoted to the care of stray dogs, leaving aside their careers.

Jyoti said their love for stray canines began about four years ago. She said that a stray dog gave birth to six pups in her neighbourhood. The pups used to cry at night due to the biting cold and hunger. They took them home and it was then that there began a new journey for them and the dogs.

Jyoti said she had to sell off a part of her ancestral house to make money for the initiative. Now, their housing board residence on Abu Road houses the rescue centre on its top two floors, while they stay on the ground floor. The family supports the rescue centre and themselves with some rental income as all the three had left their lucrative careers for tending to the street dogs.

Now, her rescue centre has about 60 street dogs, rescued and rehabilitated after accidents or suffering from various illnesses. She had recently registered the rescue centre as an NGO named ‘People for Street Dogs’ under her sister Chandini Khandelwal as the president. The reason is that it would help them to get some help from the government veterinary hospitals.

Dr Amit Chaudhary, a veterinary surgeon of a government hospital has been of immense help to them to conduct complex operations of the dogs injured in accidents.

The sisters said though they love all animals, the reason for choosing street dogs has been deliberate as it is the most neglected lot. “When we used to telephone the local nagar palika about an injured dog, they used to mock at us saying they had better things to do than tending to dogs,” said Chandini, who is a MSc Biotechnology and law graduate, now acting as the president of the NGO.

Their brother Nayhesh Khandelwal, an engineering graduate, who is an expert in handling even dogs with rabies said, they have initiated tagging dogs with radium belt with numbers, perhaps the first such initiative in the country. He said they had plans to tag 1,200 street dogs on January 16 and are launching immunization of dogs in a big way.

They have been focusing on immunization of street dogs from rabies as people kill rabies-affected dogs straight away.

Title: Kolkata: Cops change with time, learn lessons on student control
Content:
Kolkata cops baton charge students of Jadavpur University during a protest. (PTI File Photo)

TimesView Cops have had their hands full keeping the city moving as protests have surged over the last few weeks. It would help — both cops and citizens going about their work — if protesters stay off each other's route and avoid deliberately needling rivals.

KOLKATA: Aware of the emotion of students after the JNU attack, the police brass at Lalbazar has asked the force to be patient, try to open up as many communication channels as possible and show restraint while dealing with young protesters. The advice came hours after education minister Partha Chatterjee posted on Facebook that he was expecting “more restraint” from cops in a reference to the alleged lathicharge near Sulekha crossing on Jadavpur University students on Monday evening.The police efforts to reach out to students begun almost immediately after Chatterjee posted his comment on Monday. To begin with, Kolkata Police posted on their official Twitter handle: “Kolkata Police is making all efforts to cooperate with students and law-abiding citizens to maintain peace. Senior officers are in the Jadavpur area to help you. In case of any assistance or complaints, please contact us immediately.” Thereafter, DC (Jadavpur) Sudip Sarkar met the protesting students along with the Jadavpur OC. The initial provocations notwithstanding, the dialogue helped soothe nerves.The efforts to reach out to students though are a well laid-out strategy that had its genesis in JU’s Hokkolorob movement in 2014. “The midnight action painted us in the negative and it was decided that using force would be the last resort. Days later, during the massive march towards central Kolkata by students, we deliberately shunned our traditional lathi. It was discussed that we will continue with dialogues, create multiple barriers on the march path and bring in various innovations to ensure that law and order is not disturbed. Water cannons, tear gas shells and lathis are to be used only as a last resort. Had the stone pelting not taken place at Sulekha, we can assure that no student would have got caught in our attempt to use mild force to free up the area,” explained an officer.“So much has been the focus on institutes that we have asked Jadavpur and Jorasanko police stations to depute men to open up dialogues with students of JU, Calcutta University and Presidency University,” said a top Lalbazar source.Also, senior officers present at the spot and local cops have been asked to guide those coming from outside for duty. The entire protest is usually videographed, at times beamed live back to the Lalbazar control room. Drones are used during massive rallies. “That helps to see who crossed the line,” said an IPS officer. Traffic, too, now is allowed to flow as much as possible. “The idea is to keep normalcy as much as possible,” added an officer.

Title: Kashmir now free, time to free PoK, says Shivraj Singh Chouhan
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Shivraj Singh Chouhan

BHOPAL: Reacting to the ‘Free Kashmir’ poster seen at a protest in Mumbai against the JNU violence, former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan said Kashmir is already free.

“Don’t worry, Kashmir is now free from the draconian Article 370. It’s time to fight to free POK,” Chouhan tweeted on Tuesday, adding: “In the meantime, ‘Free Kashmir’ from Islamic Radicalisation! Free Kashmir from decades of corruption. ‘Free Kashmir’ from shackles of fake stakeholders of Kashmir.”

The protester has clarified that she was referring to the internet shutdown in J&K following the abrogation of Article 370.

Chouhan also accused the Congress government of “not allowing BJP workers and public to hold pro-CAA protest in district headquarters”. “In Ujjain, the public sought permission to hold a peaceful rally in support of citizenship law (CAA) but the administration refused at the instance of the chief minister. The public took out a massive rally. But, the arrogant government registered a case against the organisers. The public will crush their ego,” said Chouhan.

The former CM also criticised the Congress government over law and order. “Madhya Pradesh is screaming. Daughters are not safe. Their screams are heard everywhere. But, their painful voice is not reaching the deaf ears of the government. The government has closed its eyes and ears. What will happen to my daughters, my Madhya Pradesh ? MP wants an answer,” tweeted Chouhan.

Title: Statues of MGR, Jayalalithaa crop up overnight in Mannargudi
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Tiruvarur: Statues of former chief ministers M G Ramachandran and J Jayalalithaa were found unveiled at Mannargudi in Tiruvarur district by unidentified people without obtaining police permission. However, no parties have staked claim for erecting the statues.

M G Ramachandran’s life-size statue was erected by the district wing of the AIADMK on South Street of Mannargudi in 2015. However, owing to some litigation, the statue has not been unveiled till Sunday. Functionaries of the AIADMK had been battling to unveil the statue in a proper manner. A few months ago, wall posters demanding to unveil the MGR statue were appeared around the town.

Meanwhile, to the surprise of the AIADMK, AMMK and the general public alike, the statues of MGR along with a new statue of J Jayalalithaa were found erected on Tuesday morning. However, no parties have staked claim for erecting the statues. The garlanded statues are standing on a tree-foot high pedestal, residents said.

AIADMK functionaries and municipality authorities were unaware of the incident creating confusion among party cadres.

Residents said that some unidentified people arrived there carrying a Jayalalithaa statue in a truck, erected it beside the MGR statue and garlanded them and left the spot.

Title: Justice hurried could be justice buried, warn experts
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: On December 13 last year, AP became the first state in the country to enact a law aimed at awarding death penalty to those found guilty in specified offences against women . Called the AP Disha Act , it also calls for completion of trial in such cases within 21 days of the arrest of the accused. After it was passed in the assembly, the government released a GO on Dec 31 last year mentioning the provisions and budgetary allocations for the Act.

While hailing the commendable move, most stakeholders, however, feel 21 days could be too short a period to complete investigation and trial in such cases. Senior advocate Kuppili Muralidhar, who has been dealing with such cases for a long time, said examining the witnesses, gathering relevant documents and evidence may not be practically possible within 21 days.

“Just like justice delayed is justice denied, even justice hurried is justice buried, as stated by the Supreme Court in a recent case in which the trial was rushed in 13 days. As per standard operating procedure, the police can take 90 days to file a chargesheet under section 167 of the CRPC. If there are gaps, the court can send back the chargesheet for reevaluation,” said Muralidhar, who is also the president of Forum of Legal Professionals.

“Sometimes, the shocked victim may not be in a psychological and physical condition to give a statement to the police. Taking all these practical problems into consideration, it may not be possible for the police and judiciary to dispose of such cases within 21 days. Instead, six months can be given to dispose of such cases,” he added.

Child rights activist Abdul Raqueeb echoed the same thoughts. “It is not practically possible to dispose of cases within 21 days as reports from forensic labs, including second opinions, often take several weeks or even months to arrive,” said the former panel advocate of Juvenile Justice Board.

The doctors, however, say they can give the victim’s medical examination report within 24 hours. “Our department is equipped to send medical examination reports to the police and dispatch samples collected for forensic tests at the earliest so as not to lose any evidence. But the onus is on the police and judiciary to gather all the evidence, prepare the chargesheet and expedite the trial process. The police should ensure that the forensic labs give them the test reports on a priority basis for Disha cases,” said Dr P V Sudhakar, principal of Andhra Medical College.

Officials of women and child welfare department opine that if adequate and upgraded infrastructure and trained manpower are in place, including exclusive police stations and courts to deal with such cases, it is possible to file the chargesheet within 21 days. “Given the pending of such cases since years, it is important that the investigation and trial is fast-tracked for which upgrading of infrastructure and manpower are a must,” said district child protection officer A Satyanarayana.

Vizag women police station ACP Prem Kajal too said the police can meet the 21-day deadline provided other departments cooperate and give the medical report within 24 hours and forensic lab reports within 72 hours. “If a magistrate is present during recording of statement under Section 164 of CRPC and adequate manpower and infrastructure is available, it is possible to prepare the chargesheet within the stipulated time,” Kajal said.

Title: Farmer killed, enraged kin torch house of accused
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: Following the murder of a 38-year-old farmer in front of his wife at Golanukonda vilage in Yadadri-Bhuvanagiri district, his family members ransacked the house of the accused, on Tuesday and torched it.

The victim, K Venkat Reddy, was attacked by Parashuram, 35, of the same village on Monday. “Parashuram suspected that Reddy was having an extramarital relationship with his wife. He hit Reddy on the head with a stick,chased him and stabbed him to death,” Bhuvanagiri DCP Narayana Reddy said.

Soon, Parashuram fled from the scene. On Tuesday, Reddy’s family members torched Parashuram’s house. “A murder case was registered based on Reddy’s brother’s complaint. A case will be registered against those who torched Parashuram’s house,” the DCP said. TNN

Title: 2,200 more cyber crime plaints in Pune last year
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The number of cyber crimes in the city is increasing steadily with the Pune police receiving 7,795 complaints in 2019 as against 5,500 complaints in 2018.

“Our workload is shifting towards cyber and economic offences. We are yet to complete an analysis of the reasons behind the rise, but we feel more needs to be done here,” city police commissioner K Venkatesham said on Tuesday. A separate cyber crime police station was set up in the city in July last year.

The city police has been receiving cyber crime complaints ranging from matrimonial/gift fraud, online job and loan offers fraud, bank transaction fraud, offences originating from posts on social networking sites, crypto currency transactions, internet network system hacking, online sale, insurance policy fraud, use of cell phones for harassment and call centre frauds, among others.

Usually, the cyber police verify the details of letters it receives from complainants, including the mode of commission of crime, before a formal FIR is registered either by the cyber crime police station or the local police station. The process usually takes months to translate into an FIR, depending on the complexities involved in verification of details. However, the number of complaint letters provides a strong indication of the rising trend of cyber crime.

Out of the 7,795 complaint letters last year, 280 letters have translated into FIRs as against 175 cyber crime FIRs registered in 2018 and 214 FIRs in 2017. The police arrested 71 people in relation to cyber crimes in 2019 as against 100 in 2018 and 90 in 2017.

“The actual number of complaints and that translating into FIRs appears to be far less compared to the cyber offences that go unreported,” said lawyer Gaurav Jachak, who specialises in cyber law cases. “There is also the issue of the cyber crime police station having limited number of personnel who are adequately trained and equipped to handle the probe in such cases,” he said.

“Investigation of cyber crime complaints often suffers from prolonged delays in securing information from internet service providers as part of the verification process before an FIR is lodged,” Jachak said.

Former IPS officer Rajendra Sonawane said, “The growing internet penetration and digital transactions has opened avenues for cyber criminals to cash in on the online users’ vulnerability to easy money. The criminals know that the user can be easily defrauded as there is no face-to-face contact and people fall to netbanking, insurance and other online frauds by sharing personal details. Besides, hacking activity also continues during the night hours. Lack of consciousness among the net users is also a factor behind cyber crimes.”

Sonawane said, “To some extent, the rise in cyber crimes also indicates that the criminals are fairly aware about the shortcomings of the police like limited resources and expertise in handling cyber crime cases. Often, it is seen that victims of cyber crimes are senior citizens, women and even those from the IT sector.”

Title: Haridwar: Underground cabling to be completed by year-end, say officials
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

yyyyyyyyy

HARIDWAR: The officials of Integrated Power Development System (IPDS) of Uttarakhand Power Corporation Limited (UPCL) claim that underground cabling would be completed in Haridwar before the November 2020 deadline set for the Rs 400 crore-worth project.

"We started the construction work in May, 2019, and efforts are being made to complete the project by June 2020," project manager Sanjiv Sharma told TOI on Tuesday. The official added that besides finishing the work under the set deadline, IPDS will also maintain the quality of work.

"Once the project is completed, there will be no poles and feeders visible on the streets or in the lanes, except the ones for street lights. This will give the city a smart look," Sharma said, while pointing out that Haridwar is the only city in Uttarakhand to have been awarded with underground cabling project by the Central government.

The city has been divided into seven zones for the project and works are going on simultaneously in all the zones. “In the first phase, underground pipes are being laid in 1.5-to-2 metre deep pits and cables are being inserted in the pipes. In the next phase, installation of equipment would take place. And in the last one, equipment will be charged,” Sharma said.

Talking about the quality of work, he said that cross link poly-ethenyl (SLPE) cables are being used in the project and they do not get damaged by water or any atmospheric factors.

Local residents also expressed their delight with the project. “The project will be a great help during Kumbh, 2021, especially in traffic management,” says Vinay Kumar, a Shivaliknagar resident. He added that the project will reduce the power cut issue considerably.

Title: Dehradun: Government to form Dam Safety Review Committee to check status of existing dams
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

DEHRADUN: The state government on Tuesday announced to form a Dam Safety Review Committee to conduct a detailed study of existing dams, including those made in the British era, in the state. The committee will prepare a report on the status of dams, changes and repair works required and hand it over to the irrigation department at the earliest.

Independent MLA from Bhimtal Ram Singh Kaida through assembly asked irrigation minister Satpal Maharaj if he was aware that the dam on Bhimtal lake was in a “poor condition and in case of further damage it could pose a serious threat to people living in the area.” The MLA said, “After Nainital , most people come to Bhimtal. In case of any damage to the lake, it can lead to major crisis. I would like to ask the minister about steps being taken to make amends.”

He also requested the minister to tell the age of the dam and if any study has been carried out in the past. In his reply, Maharaj said that the Bhimtal lake dam was over 100 years old and was made in the British era. He also mentioned that no study of the dam has been carried out in the past.

“The process to conduct the study of the dam by National Institute of Hydrology, Roorkee, is under way. The irrigation department workshop of Roorkee will study the gate of the dam. The process to conduct the study is in the final phase,” said the minister.

Congress MLA from Ranikhet Karan Mahra termed it a serious issue saying, “Most parts of Uttarakhand fall in seismic zone 4 and 5. Earthquakes often jolt the state and keeping these factors in mind, it is extremely important to know the present status of bridges and dams which have been made in the state.”

To this, Maharaj said, “We are taking the issue seriously. A Dam Safety Review Committee comprising senior officers and experts will be formed to conduct the study and hand over its detailed report at the earliest.”

Title: TDP leader booked for derogatory language
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Narsipatnam police registered cases against former minister and senior Telugu Desam Party ( TDP ) leader Ch Ayyanna Patrudu for taking out a rally, organising a road-show and allegedly using derogatory language against the police, YSR Congress government and chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy.

It may be recalled that Narsipatnam police had registered a case against Ayyanna Patrudu a few days ago for obstructing police from performing their duty and instigating an argument when police visited his house, following a dispute between Ayyana and his brother.

On Monday, Ayyanna Patrudu and his followers visited Narsipatnam police station after organising a rally, where he submitted bail papers.

After submitting bail, Ayyana conducted a road-show near Abid Central, in which he said the police have granted permission for holding cockfights in East and West Godavari districts during the Sankranti festival, but denied permission for cockfights in Visakhapatnam district.

Ayyanna also allegedly spoke against the chief minister. Cases against the leader were registered under Sections 504, 188, 189 and 341 of the IPC.

Title: Nainital: High Court upholds death sentence for rape, murder convict
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

NAINITAL: The Uttarakhand high court ( HC ) on Tuesday upheld the death sentence awarded to Jai Prakash, convicted for raping and murdering a 10-year-old girl in Sahaspur area of Dehradun in July, 2019.

The special POCSO court of Dehradun had already convicted him and pronounced death sentence in August 2019.

The bench of Justice Alok Singh and Justice Ravindra Maithani held that the case falls in the category of “rarest of rare cases” and because the charges have been proved beyond reasonable doubt, therefore, it calls no other punishment than death penalty. “The act committed by appellant is so brutal that it pricks or shocks not only the judicial conscious but even the conscious of society and this case certainly falls in the category of “rarest of rare cases,” the judgment by Justice Alok Singh read.

Title: Maharashtra: Teachers’ unions to wear black badges for JNU
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

JNU campus after the attack on JNU students (PTI Photo)

The Maharashtra Federation of University and College Teachers’ Organisations (MFUCTO), Shikshak Bharati and Bombay University and College Teachers’ Union (BUCTU), as representative organisations of teachers of schools, colleges and universities in Maharashtra and Mumbai, respectively, have decided to join the all India strike on January 8. They have called on students and teachers to wear black badges to protest attacks at JNU. All activists will participate in the joint demonstrations of trade unions at Azad Maidan on Wednesday. “The entire country will witness yet another historic protest on January 8, 2020, by all trade unions, for the devastating effects of the economic policies on the working people of the country. Further, we severely condemn the barbaric attack on students and teachers of JNU ,” said Tapati Mukhopadhyay, president, MFUCTO.

Title: Nainital: In Harish Rawat sting High Court orders CBI to inform court before filing chargesheet
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Harish Rawat

NAINITAL: The Uttarakhand high court (HC) on Tuesday said that it will hear the petition about the petition about former chief minister Harish Rawat on March 2.

The order came after the lawyer appearing for CBI demanded more time to respond to the challenge by the Harish Rawat to the legality of FIR filed against him. “The court has said that they will hear the matter on March 2 when the CBI’s lawyer will file their response,” said Kapil Sibal, the lawyer appearing for Rawat.

“We had asked the court to direct the CBI to not file a chargesheet till the court decides the matter. To this, the court directed the CBI to inform them before filing a chargesheet,” Sibal added.

Sibal had argued that once the chargesheet is filed, the case will move to a criminal court therefore the high court must grant the ex-CM protection against it.

Title: 'All Urdu versions of novel on Gen Zia death seized'
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

ISLAMABAD: The well-known satirical writer Mohammed Hanif , has said that men claiming to be from Pakistan 's spy agency, Inter-Services Intelligence ( ISI ), had raided the offices of the Urdu publisher of his novel as well as bookshops in Lahore and Islamabad and confiscated all copies of the translated version of his 2008 bestseller, "A Case of Exploding Mangoes".

In a series of posts on Twitter, Hanif said the purported raids had occurred on Monday afternoon. "This afternoon some people claiming to be from the ISI barged into my Urdu publisher Maktaba Daniyal's offices, confiscated all copies of Urdu translation of 'A Case of Exploding Mangoes'. Threatened the manager, wanted information about our whereabouts," he said, adding that the people (ISI agents) would be coming back tomorrow to get lists of booksellers.

The book shops Fiction House Lahore and Saeed Book Bank Islamabad confirmed the confiscation of copies of the Urdu transalation of Hanif's novel.

His satirical novel, published in English in 2008, chronicles the final days of military dictator General Zia-ul-Haq's rule and the myriad conspiracies behind the plane crash that killed him in 1988. The award-winning book has been widely acclaimed for its comic look at life in Pakistan during the peak of Islamisation that was the hallmark of Zia's leadership tenure. It was released in Urdu in October last year.

In another tweet, Hanif said they had last week received a defamation notice from Gen Zia's son, Ejazul Haq, demanding Rs 1 billion (Pakistani currency) for maligning his father's name. "Our lawyers are preparing a reply. Is ISI acting on Ejazul Haq's behalf?" he asked.

Hanif noted that his novel has been in publication for 11 years but no one had a problem with it. "Nobody has ever bothered me. Why now? I am sitting here wondering when they will come for us. ISI is World's No 1 spy agency. I am sure they have better things to do," he tweeted.

His fans on Twitter noted that Hanif might have been able to escape scrutiny so far because his novel was in English, a language that a relatively small percentage of Pakistanis read. With its translation in Urdu hitting shelves just last year, it might have attracted a critical audience that was thus far unaware of its existence.

The Human Rights Commission of Pakistan (HRCP) "deplored" the raid at the publishing house. "The authorities must revoke this action immediately," the HRCP posted on Twitter.

"This is a craven attempt to stifle artistic freedom of expression. The original work, a political satire set in Gen Zia-ul-Haq's time, came out 11 years ago and has remained a bestseller in Pakistan and abroad for years. @mohammedhanif was also awarded the Sitara-i-Imtiaz (Pakistan's highest civilian award)," the HRCP said in a subsequent tweet.

Title: ACB holds raids at suspended forest official’s properties
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Eluru: Teams of the central investigation unit (CIU) under the Anti-Corruption Bureau conducted raids at the properties of a suspended divisonal manager with the Andhra Pradesh State Forest Development Corporation (APSFDC).

Simultaneous raids were also held at Jangareddigudem, Hyderabad and Chennai to unearth the officer’s disproportionate income. Upon receiving credible information, the ACB team led by the deputy superintendent of police (DSP) DN Mahesh raided the house of divisional manager Kona Rama Krishna and seized Rs 8.67 lakh in cash, gold and silver ornaments.

The team also seized 500 gm of gold ornaments and 1.5 kg silver ornaments from a locker belonging to Rama Krishna in the Primary Agriculture Cooperative Credit Society (PACCS) at Tadikelapudi under Kamavarapukota mandal. Officials also seized promissory notes worth Rs 16 lakh and documents related to agricultural and housing sites.

Title: Only 1 EDM fest a year, Sopte tells Ajgaonkar
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Porvorim: Days after tourism minister Manohar Ajgaonkar made a case for hosting two electronic dance music ( EDM ) festivals in the state every year, Goa Tourism Development Corporation ( GTDC ) chairman Dayanand Sopte has conveyed to the minister that one festival is adequate.

“I have told the tourism minister that only one EDM must be permitted to be held in the state. We have seen the quality of tourists that such festivals attract. We need quality tourists,” Sopte said.

Asked if EDMs should be banned in Goa due to allegations of drug abuse during the festival, Sopte said he was not opposing EDMs, just the organising of two festivals a year.

Use of drugs and consumption of liquor in the open should be stopped, he said. “We have seen the video clip that was in circulation showing drunk men sleeping on Calangute beach. Such incidents bring Goa a bad name,” Sopte said.

Following the death of three tourists during the recent three-day EDM festival, opposition parties criticised police and the government.

Two tourists had collapsed while waiting in a queue to attend the festival while the third collapsed on the last day of the festival. Police are awaiting the chemical analysis reports to determine the cause of death.

Ports minister Michael Lobo recently said that the government needs to put in more efforts to stop sale of drugs in the state.

Title: Vizag as capital can alter north AP, says min
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Minister of roads and buildings Dharmana Krishna Dasu said Vizag as the state executive capital will change the face of north-coastal AP. Addressing the media here in Visakhapatnam on Tuesday, the minister said the chief minister will take a final decision on shifting the secretariat to Visakhapatnam. “The three capital proposal will lead to decentralised development and will benefit every section of society,” said Dasu.

Meanwhile, to improve vehicular traffic along National Highways, a representation was given by Sudhir Mulagada, chairman of AP Chambers of Commerce and Industry Federation, Visakhapatnam Zone at an interactive session with TG Venkatesh,chairman, parliamentary standing committee on transport, tourism and culture at Vizag Conventions here on Tuesday.

Suggestions for improving traffic include removing toll gates within city limits and widening service roads to a minimum of 40 to 60 feet on both sides of highways passing through cities, towns and villages to enable pedestrians, two-wheelers and three-wheelers pass.

The organisation also put forward the need to develop parking areas for trucks on both sides of the city limits, on a minimum of 50 to 100 acres, with adequate infrastructure such as petrol pumps, washrooms, food plazas and vehicle repair services.

It also recommended that road repair works on National Highways--such as filling potholes--be taken up immediately.

Title: Nainital: JNU Vice Chancellor, Delhi Police chief must resign: Kapil Sibal
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Sibal was in Nainital on Tuesday to represent former chief minister Harish Rawat in the sting operation when h... Read More

NAINITAL: Senior Congress leader and Rajya Sabha MP Kapil Sibal on Tuesday demanded the resignation of the Jawaharlal Nehru University ( JNU ) vice-chancellor ( VC ) M jagdesh Kumar and Delhi Police commissioner Amulya Patnaik saying that after the violence in the university, the two must be held accountable.

Sibal was in Nainital to represent former chief minister Harish Rawat in the sting operation case. While speaking about violence at JNU, he said that the JNU administration and the Delhi Police failed to protect the students. “The rampage in one of the premier universities of the country continued for hours still neither the police nor the university administration did anything. Therefore, both the VC and the commissioner must resign,” he said.

Sibal, who is also a senior lawyer, questioned the reason for shutting off the street lights in the area when the masked mob attacked the students in JNU. “The street lights were on in the area and police was standing outside the gate of the university. They should explain how the mob entered the university. And what the VC was doing. Why didn’t he inform police and if he did, why didn’t the commissioner take any action?” he said.

More than 30 students, teachers and some officials have been injured in the attack by masked goons in the JNU and police are yet to make any arrests.

When asked about the FIR on students’ union president Aishe Ghosh, Sibal said that this has become the new norm in the country where the victims are booked by police. “We saw it happen in UP, in Kashmir and many other places,” he said.

Comparing the response of the governments in Hong Kong and India, he said that even the people of Hong Kong have been protesting against the Chinese government yet no violence has erupted there. “Masked protests have been going on in Hong Kong for months still there has not been any major news of violence or attack by police. Then why are people being shot in India,” he asked.

Title: Coimbatore: Man held for raping mentally challenged woman
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

Title: Empty liquor bottles found in Tirumala
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Tirupati: Empty liquor bottles found at a parking lot near TTD-run Annamaiah Bhavan in Tirumala on Tuesday has once again exposed the chinks in TTD’s ‘foolproof security set-up’ at the Alipiri checkpoint.

The hill town of Tirumala, which is the abode of Lord Venkateswara, is a highly venerated pilgrim centre for Hindus where consumption of alcohol, non-vegetarian food, chewing tobacco and smoking are prohibited under the AP Endowments Act. The TTD has set up a state-of-the-art security checkpoint at Alipiri, the gateway to Tirumala, to prevent smuggling of prohibited goods into the hill town.

Nearly 200 security personnel man the Alipiri checkpoint 24 hours. . Though the security apparatus at Alipiri checkpoint is upgraded regularly, miscreants have time and again managed to bypass it. The latest incident has raised calls for security personnel posted at Alipiri checkpoint to be more vigilant.

AVSO Venkataramana of the TTD’s vigilance and security wing said, “The liquor bottles may have been sneaked in by some drivers. We will enquire into the incident.”

Title: Coimbatore: Government sanctions Rs 7.24 crore to prevent man-animal conflict
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Besides, the forest department has decided to set up a human – elephant conflict mitigation cell at the distri... Read More

COIMBATORE: The state government has sanctioned Rs 7.24 crore for the Coimbatore forest division to take measures to prevent man– animal conflicts.

To start with, the forest department will install thermal imaging cameras with a range of more than 1km to watch elephant movements on forest fringes and inform villagers if the animals come closer to the human habitats.

On July 1, 2019, the state forest minister announced in the assembly that man-animal conflicts had been on the rise in the villages on the forest fringes in Western and Eastern Ghats.

“We have identified 13 vital areas in the forest division where we plan to install thermal imaging cameras. While officials in the control room will alert the range authorities through SMS, the forest field staff will alert villagers,” a forest officer said. The department is also planning to use drones to detect animal movements.

The Coimbatore forest division has seven forest ranges – Madukkarai, Boluvampatti, Coimbatore, Periyanaickenpalayam, Karamadai, Mettupalayam and Sirumugai.

Earlier, the principal chief conservator of forests had sent a proposal for resolving human-elephant conflict through remote-based technology in Coimbatore at a cost of Rs 7.24 crore. Subsequently, the government has sanctioned the money, of which, Rs 6.83 crore was allotted to set up cameras and other systems in the seven ranges and Rs 27.07 lakh for extension of railway track and installation of early warning system.

Besides, the forest department has decided to set up a human – elephant conflict mitigation cell at the district forest officer’s office and estimated the cost as Rs 13.8 lakh.

Thermal imaging cameras are devices which translate thermal energy (heat) emanating from objects into visible light in order to analyse them. The proposed technology can be used to locate wild elephants, humans and conduct search and rescue operations during day and night.

Title: Dehradun: Mercury dips as widespread rain, snow lashes parts of Uttarakhand
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

DEHRADUN: Light to moderate snowfall lashed high-altitude areas of Uttarakhand throughout Tuesday, while the plains and foothills received continuous rainfall, throwing daily life out of gear in the state.

The regional meteorological centre had issued a warning of heavy snowfall in the hills of Uttarakhand for Tuesday and Wednesday. Mostly, places located at 2,500 meters and above, including Auli and Munsyari, received good snowfall.

Giving more details, Bikram Singh, director of regional meteorological centre, told TOI, “Widespread rainfall has been witnessed in Uttarakhand on Tuesday. The higher reaches, mainly situated at 2,500 meters and above, received a good spell of snowfall.”

The state capital Dehradun witnessed continuous rainfall, resulting in cold conditions and subsequently throwing normal life out of gear. The maximum temperature in Dehradun was recorded at 12.5 degree Celsius, seven notches below normal, while the minimum settled at 10.1 degree Celsius.

Meanwhile, the Met office issued a red warning of cold to severe cold conditions at a few places in Uttarakhand for January 8, while heavy snowfall has been predicted at places at an altitude of 2,500 meters and above.

Moreover, hail is likely to lash isolated places in Dehradun, Haridwar, Udham Singh Nagar, Pauri and Nainital districts on Wednesday. Besides, dense to very dense fog is likely to occur in the morning hours in Haridwar and Udham Singh Nagar district during next 24 hours from Wednesday morning.

Title: SC/ST scholarship scam: Nainital High Court orders SIT to furnish investigation reports of colleges given clean chit
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Uttrakhand high court

NAINITAL: The Uttarakhand high court (HC) on Tuesday came down heavily on the Special Investigation Team (SIT) probing the multi-crore scholarship scam ordering it to submit the investigation reports of all the colleges in Udham Singh Nagar and Nainital districts which have been let off.

This comes after the bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Alok Kumar Verma, while hearing a clutch of petitions that had flagged embezzlement of funds in awarding scholarship to students from underprivileged backgrounds of Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribes, on Monday ordered the SIT headed by officer Sanjay Gunjyal to submit the details of investigations done so far in districts other than Dehradun and Haridwar.

The PIL, meanwhile, has also alleged that the benefits of scholarship which was meant for students whose family income is less than Rs 2.5 lakh has been availed by even senior government officials. “They informed the court that so far 52 colleges have been investigated in Nainital, of which FIR has been filed against four colleges while in US Nagar, more than 60 colleges have been investigated and FIR has been filed against 15. The court then asked about the basis on which only 8% colleges in Nainital and only a fourth in US Nagar were booked when in places such as Haridwar and Dehradun, a number of colleges have come under scanner,” said MC Pant, the lawyer appearing for petitioner.

The court has now ordered the SIT to furnish the investigation reports of all the colleges which have been let off till February 10. “We deem it appropriate to satisfy ourselves as to whether the investigation was carried out properly or whether it was shoddy. We therefore consider it appropriate that the head of the SIT will place before us, by the next date of hearing, the investigation report relating to private colleges in US Nagar and Nainital districts who are held not to have indulged in these acts of misappropriation after inquiry,” the court order read.

Title: Kerala native nabbed with drugs worth Rs 50k
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Saligao: The Anjuna police on Tuesday arrested Manas Krishna, 22, a native of Calicut, Kerala and presently residing in Oxel, near Siolim , for being in possession of a narcotic drug suspected to be LSD , worth Rs 50,000.

Anjuna police said they conducted a raid at Gumal Vaddo, Anjuna. A case under the NDPS Act has been registered and the accused is presently in police custody. PSI Sujay Korgaonkar is investigating the case.

Title: Coimbatore: Botanic garden to host concert to raise funds
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

COIMBATORE: The Nilgiri Biosphere Nature Park in Thuvaipathi, Anaikatti, will host a music concert on January 25 to raise funds to meet the park’s expenses in a long run.

The event, “Ooh la la”, will feature playback singers Haricharan, Anand Aravindakshan and Swetha Mohan and will be compered by Priyanka. The park, which is a botanic garden spread over 70 acres, hopes to raise at least Rs 1 crore from the concert.

The park was an initiative by the Coimbatore Zoological Park and Conservation Centre in 1992 to recreate the bounty of the Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve , which comprises forests of the Western Ghats covering Kerala, Tamil Nadu and Karnataka, in a limited zone. The place, which is now home to more than 450 varieties of native trees, flora and fauna, has a butterfly park, an apiary and amphibian ponds.

Though it has become a popular attraction for school and college students and an outbound activity centre for corporates, the entry fee, Rs 25 for children and Rs 50 for adults, hardly earns a third or even lesser of the park’s expenses, a park’s patron said. A group of patrons, mainly comprising of Coimbatore’s industrialists including D Vijay Mohan, G Rangaswamy, D Vidyaprakash and N Krishna Samaraj, helps the park to sustain financially, said chairman of the centre S V Balasubramaniam.

Title: Haridwar: Tiger attacks 34-year-old van gujjar in Terai west forest division
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

This is the year's first tiger attack reported in Uttrakhand

HARIDWAR: A 34-year-old Van Gujjar Taj Mohammad was attacked by a tiger in Aam Pokhra range of Terai West forest division on Tuesday morning. The victim was referred to Sushila Tiwari Medical College hospital from Ramnagar in a critical state. His condition is told to be stable at present.

“He has sustained deep canine and paw marks in neck area. It was clearly a tiger attack . Our ENT specialist is continuously observing his condition. At present, his vital signs are stable and he has not been kept in the ICU,” said CP Bhaisora, principal of Sushila Tiwari Medical College.

The attack took place when the victim had gone deep into the forest while taking his livestock for grazing. Forest officials say that Taj could escape the big cat as the tiger attacked in self-defence and not to kill.

“When tiger attacks in self-defence, it pounds on the victim and then recedes itself. Such attacks are made when tiger feels threatened by the presence of anyone around itself or its cubs,” said Himanshu Bagri, divisional forest officer, Terai West.

This is the year’s first tiger attack and it comes barely a few days after a pregnant tigress was crushed to death in a road accident in Terai West forest division.

In a similar incident in Western Circle last year, a person had escaped a tiger attack with grave injuries. “Despite repeated instructions, villagers and forest dwellers don’t refrain from entering into restricted or vulnerable areas. This leads to such life-threatening attacks,” added Bagri. The forest department will be compensating the victim by giving an amount in the range of Rs 15,000-Rs 50,000. The amount would depend on the medical certificate provided by the doctor. “In case of minor injuries, we give Rs 15,000 and for grave injuries, we pay Rs 50,000,” explained the official.

Last year, three people were killed in tiger attacks in Uttarakhand, according to the forest department data on human wildlife conflict. All the three victims had lost their lives inside Corbett Tiger Reserve and they all were staff members of the wildlife sanctuary.

Title: Relief for Khadki Cantonment Board, gets Rs 29.3 crore as arrears
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Ammunition Factory Khadki (AFK) recently paid Rs29.3 crore service charge arrears to the Khadki Cantonment Board (KCB).

The payout has come as much-needed relief to the cash-strapped cantonment board, reeling from financial crunch for the past two years.

“We want to be able to provide essential civic facilities to the citizens of the cantonment. The recovered arrears will make our task easier in the coming months,” KCB president Brigadier MJ Kumar told TOI.

Last year, the AFK and High Explosives factories, which are governed by the Ordnance Factory Board (OFB), were told to clear Rs47 crore service charges arrears owed to the cantonment board. While the AFK has now released the payment of Rs29.3 crore, the decision on the collection of the remaining Rs17.7 crore is pending before the authorities concerned.

“These ordnance factories pay the service charges for services rendered like maintaining cleanliness on land owned by them. The factories have asked us to give exemption from paying charges for playground and firing range maintenance. But we cannot take a decision on this matter unless the old provisions are changed,” KCB’s chief executive officer Pramod Kumar Singh said.

As per the provisions of Section 109 of the Cantonment Act, 2006, and guidelines issued by the ministries of urban development and finance, service charges are leviable on the Centre’s properties by the local bodies. This has been further settled by the Supreme Court in 2009 and subsequent judgment of the Allahabad high court .

Singh said the board had to raise revenue inflows from different fronts, as it is yet to get its goods and services tax (GST) share from the state government.

“The cantonment expenses have increased due to expenditure on welfare projects, payment of pending bills. The implementation of 7th Pay Commission has increased the salary expenditure significantly. We had to dip into the board’s fixed deposit, once considered as ‘safe money’, to incur avoidable costs,” a senior KCB official told TOI on condition of anonymity.

Meanwhile, the Director General Defence Estates (DGDE) has set up a committee to discuss and address the issues pertaining to the collection of service charges and its legal aspects.

“Recovering service charges has become crucial for cantonments across the country. Due to old records and complexities involved in their respective agreements, it has become a contentious issue for OFB and DGDE. To reach a consensus, the committee will hold its meeting on Wednesday in New Delhi,” a senior official of DGDE told TOI on condition of anonymity.

Title: Mid-day meal set to get nutrition boost
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Amaravati: The menu for the mid-day meal scheme for schoolchildren in the state will be revamped after the Sankranti holidays.

Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy has directed officials to implement the fixed menu and use fine quality rice for the meals. At a review of the implementation of the scheme, the chief minister said there should be no compromise in the quality of food supplied to students. An additional budget of Rs 200 crore will be allocated for the revised menu. Eggs will be served on five out of six school days.

The chief minister also directed officials to prepare plans for the second phase of the ‘Nadu-Nedu’ programme, which aims to transform government schools in the state. Officials said work under the first phase of the programme would commence in 15,715 schools on January 15. The chief minister said all infrastructure, including washrooms, cupboards and beds in hostels, tables and chair, be in place and high standards be maintained in the execution of welfare schemes.

Title: Ecologist takes home top festival honour
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Pune: Debal Deb is an ecologist of some repute, having fought hard to preserve traditional landraces of rice and other crops.

“Large seed corporations have aggressively marketed genetically modified seeds to farmers, promising higher yields in cash and food crops. But what have these seeds caused to small farmers in India,” Deb asked while speaking about farmers suicides in various parts of India.

On Tuesday, Deb received the top festival honour for his work to preserve, distribute, and grow crops from traditional rice varieties during the closing ceremony of KVIFF. He was also part of an interactive session during the ceremony at Balgandharva Rangmandir.

As part of his work, Deb has a laboratory at his hometown of Kolkata for his work with seeds. In 1996, he founded the seed bank Vrihi, Sanskrit for rice, to store and distribute traditional varieties of seeds.

At a press conference, Deb spoke about the durability of traditional seeds against extreme climates, including a variety that grows in 12 feet deep water, where farm work has to be done using canoes. But, Deb said, the allure of genetically modified seeds is still too large for farmers.

Title: Coimbatore: Man held for duping ATM customers
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

COIMBATORE: The city police on Monday arrested a 48-year-old man for allegedly cheating people in the garb of helping them to withdraw cash from ATM.

The arrested has been identified as A Kathiresan, 48, of Thirumangalam in Madurai district. He was booked under section 406 (punishment for criminal breach of trust) of the Indian Penal Code and remanded in judicial custody.

According to police, he was held based on the complaint lodged by Suresh Kumar, 46, a resident of Vellalore who works as a home guard with the Podanur police.

On December 19, he had gone to an ATM centre at SIDCO on Coimbatore-Pollachi road at Sundarapuram to withdraw cash. When he was unable to withdraw cash, Kathiresan came to the ATM and offered to help Suresh Kumar. He also attempted to withdraw money by using the debit card belonging to Suresh Kumar but in vain.

A few hours later, Suresh Kumar received messages mentioning that Rs 19,500 was withdrawn from his bank accounts from two ATM centres. On intimating bank officials, Suresh Kumar was informed that the amount was withdrawn using his original ATM card at Othakkalmandapam and Kinathukadavu . Only then Suresh Kumar realized that the man had given him a duplicate card.

Suresh Kumar lodged a complaint with the Podanur police (crime) who arrested Kathiresan on Monday. Kathiresan told police that he had cheated more than 30 people from Madukkarai, Perur, Podanur and Saibaba Colony police station limits. He was lodged in the Coimbatore central prison .

Title: Coimbatore: Police remain mute spectators as video of women changing dress goes viral
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

All India Democratic Women's Association (AIDWA) petitioned the city police commissioner seeking action again... Read More

COIMBATORE: A video of women staff changing dress in a room at a petrol bunk in the city went viral on Tuesday. The All India Democratic Women's Association (AIDWA) has petitioned the city police commissioner, seeking action against the man who took the video.

In another development, a male staffer of the petrol bunk was thrashed by other staff when he questioned the management for not acting against the culprit. The wife of the male staffer, Manikandan, also works in the same bunk at Kannappan Nagar.

The video was apparently taken four months ago by one of the staff named Subash. The issue came to light when Manikandan’s wife found a hidden camera in the dressing room while changing her dress. She immediately informed her husband who in turn informed the management. Subash was suspended and a case was registered against him under Section 75 C (1) (creating nuisance) of the Tamil Nadu Police Act by the Saibaba Colony police based on a complaint lodged by the management.

Subash had apparently stored the video on his mobile phone, which was seized by police and the video was deleted.

Meanwhile, the staff of the bunk thrashed Manikandan on Monday when he questioned the management for not taking strict action against Subash. Manikandan was admitted to the Coimbatore Medical College Hospital with injuries on Monday night.

However, the management of the bunk alleged that Manikandan had stolen petrol from the bunk.

Since Tuesday morning, the 16-minute video of women staff changing dress has gone viral on social media.

In the afternoon, All India Democratic Women’s Association (AIDWA) secretary A Rathika and members of AIDWA submitted a petition to city police commissioner Sumit Sharan, demanding the arrest of the person who recorded the video.

Police maintained that they would arrest Subash only if they get a written complaint from the management of the petrol bunk.

Police also suspect Manikandan’s hand in circulation of the video as he would have forwarded the video from Subhas’s mobile phone to his phone before handing it over to the police.

Title: ChrysCapital exits drug company IPCA Labs in Rs 560 crore deal
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Private equity major ChrysCapital has exited mid-size drug firm IPCA Labs , offloading its entire stake to 10 mutual funds , for around Rs 560 crore. The PE firm offloaded its 4% stake in the company recently, sources said, mopping up returns of nearly 2.5x on its investment.

The firm had invested Rs 245 crore spread over two lots - in 2014 and 2016. ChrysCapital, the largest homegrown PE fund, has approximately $4 billion of assets under management (AUM) across eight funds, with marquee investors including sovereign wealth funds, endowments and pension funds .

ChrysCapital officials were not available for comments, while IPCA Labs did not respond to a email till the time of going to press.

The firm has invested in over 80 companies, with strategic mid-to-high teens' stake in companies like Intas Pharma, Mankind Pharma , GVK Bio and Curatio. At present, ChrysCapital has half a billion invested in healthcare firms, with a bulk - around $320 million in Mankind alone. The firm picked up around 10% stake in Mankind in 2018. This is the second time ChrysCapital invested in the Delhi-based drug firm, after exiting its 11% stake in 2015 to Capital International for $214 million, with a tenfold return in seven years.

The PE firm has mopped up returns of around 5x on the investments made in healthcare, making it one of the best bets for investors.

Title: Central funds for flood relief inadequate: BS Yediyurappa
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

BS Yediyurappa

BENGALURU: The second instalment of flood relief funds from the Centre, announced on Monday, has left BS Yediyurappa less than cheerful, with the chief minister insisting that it is barely adequate. The CM on Tuesday said he will urge the Union government to release more.

On Monday, the Centre announced it will release Rs 669.8 crore in addition to the Rs 1,200 crore it had released earlier towards flood relief and rehabilitation. The total sum is a small fraction of the loss, which the government pegged at a staggering Rs 38,000 crore.

“The Centre has released assistance in two instalments so far, but it is inadequate given the magnitude of the damage. I will request for more funds and I am confident the Centre will oblige,” Yediyurappa told reporters.

When Prime Minister Narendra Modi had visited the state last week, Yediyurappa had urged him — even openly at a function — to release funds. This followed several pleas over the past four months, which barely drew a response from the Centre. Now, the CM himself suggests it’s barely a drop in the ocean.

The opposition has been criticizing both Yediyurappa and the Centre for their handling of the situation and on Tuesday, leader of the opposition Siddaramaiah of the Congress criticised the CM for “misguiding people” on the sum released by the Centre.

Siddaramaiah tweeted, “Reports from State govt officials say only Rs 669 cr of addl funds are released in 2nd instalment as opposed to the claim of Rs 1,870 cr by Karnataka BJP leaders. At a time when manufacturing industries are closing, BJP’s fake news factory is running at full potential ".

In another tweet, he said, “Moved by the plea of chief minister, Yediyurappa, Prime Minister Narendra Modi released an additional Rs 669.8 crore, taking the total amount to Rs 1,869.8 crore. BJP leaders, who are devotees of the god of lies, attempts to depict the total relief amount as 1200+1869.85 = Rs 3,069 cr is ridiculous.”

A high-level committee chaired by Union home minister Amit Shah had sanctioned the National Disaster Response Fund (NDRF) funds on Monday. While the Press Information Bureau claimed Rs 1,869 crore was approved on Monday, state government officials clarified that the figure included the Rs 1,200 crore released in October.

Meanwhile, sources say the two instalments is all the assistance the state can expect from the Centre towards flood relief. Sources say the Rs 1,870 crore is roughly 60% of the funding — Rs 3,000 cr— which was supposed to be allocated for Karnataka, based on an inter-ministerial team’s assessment of losses in the state.

“Compared to other states for the same period, Karnataka has received the highest amount in flood relief. We cannot expect more,” said a revenue department official, who said the government will not approach the Centre for a special package.

However, revenue minister R Ashoka said the state will pitch for the entire Rs 3,000 crore. “The state government will pursue the matter with the Centre until it releases the entire Rs 3,000 crore. The state government will cover the remainder of the Rs 38,000 crore loss. We will not go back on our word,” Ashoka said. Incidentally, the state has spent about Rs 6,000 crore on relief and rehabilitation so far.

Title: Bharat bandh: Calcutta high court bats for no disruption, West Bengal promises extra buses, insurance
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Calcutta High Court

KOLKATA: The Calcutta High Court on Tuesday asked the state government to take steps to maintain normalcy so that public life is not affected during the nationwide bandh called by trade unions. Keeping in mind the ongoing JEE (mains) examinations, the state has asked the police to ensure that roads and railway tracks are not blocked. The police has also been directed to take stern action if any school bus is stopped or students are affected.

State transport minister Suvendu Adhikari said about 22% additional buses will ply on Wednesday. “All vehicles registered within Bengal have been insured by the transport department with coverage up to Rs 6 lakh. Any vehicle damaged on Wednesday will be covered under this insurance,” the minister said. He added that in case of any damage to vehicles, FIRs will have to be lodged within 24 hours of the incident and insurance will have to be claimed at the WBTIDCL office at Kasba.

Majority of bank branches are, however, expected to remain shut as five Left- and Congress-backed bank employees’ unions — AIBEA, AIBOA, BEFI, IMBEF and INBOC — have supported the strike.

Schools, such as Don Bosco School and Modern High School, have already announced a closure due to the bandh. South Point School authorities said that if the students fail to turn up, they will not be penalized. Mayor Firhad Hakim said Kolkata Municipal Corporation offices would function as usual on Wednesday.

Kolkata Police will deploy special forces on the roads from 5am and senior officials will monitor the trouble-prone spots. Nearly 5,000 personnel will be deployed on the streets. There would be special deployments at all government offices.

Trinamool secretary general Partha Chatterjee said that the Mamata Banerjee government is against any bandh and harassment of people.

The state finance department has asked all employees to attend office on Wednesday and that no casual leave will be granted. Those staying away on January 8 will be issued showcause notices. The HC Bar Association has appealed that no ex-parte orders be passed by the HC if lawyers failed to attend the court.

Title: Downsizing, vacant posts hamper TB control work
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Reduction in sanctioned posts and inordinate delay in filling those vacant have severely hampered the monitoring of tuberculosis control in the city.Some of the key posts of workers, technicians and supervisors directly involved in tuberculosis (TB) screening, treatment monitoring and follow-ups have been lying vacant in the city TB unit for more than five years now. Besides, the number of sanctioned posts for the city TB unit has been reduced to 54 this year from 63 earlier.“As per the earlier sanctioned posts, we currently have 21 crucial posts lying vacant in the city TB unit for more than five years. Of the 21 posts, the state officials have curtailed 10 posts this year. We have already raised concerns over the sudden downsizing with the higher authorities. In all, the vacant posts are hampering the routine work of TB control in the city. We are making the most of available human resource to keep things in check,” city TB officer Vaishali Jadhav told TOI.Earlier, civic officials had the authority to release the recruitment advertisement and fill up the vacant posts. “However, as per the latest diktat, we cannot carry out the recruitment as the responsibility has been shifted to state officials,” Jadhav said.Among the important posts required for routine monitoring work are the posts of health volunteers, laboratory and overall TB supervisors. “The health volunteers are the field workers who keep track of TB patients till they are cured. They ensure that patients maintain drug compliance by visiting them regularly. Similarly, laboratory supervisors carry out diagnostic tests and senior TB supervisors ensure coordination among the field staff,” Jadhav said.When contacted state TB officer Padmaja Jogewar, joint director of the state health department was in a meeting. She expressed her inability to comment on the issue.

Title: Coimbatore: Corporation may seek Anna University aid to study rise in garbage generation
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Coimbatore: The Coimbatore Corporation is likely to approach Anna University or a private concern, which specializes in the field of solid waste management, to study the reasons behind the sudden raise in the garbage generation in the city.

In the last few months, the quantity of garbage dumped in the Vellalore dump yard has increased from 800 tonnes to 1,000 – 1,200 tonnes per day.

To understand the actual reasons behind it and to design projects for the scientific disposal of the wastes, the corporation sought the assistance of the Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU) a couple of months ago.

“The civic body requested the university to conduct the study on three aspects – quantification, composition and analyzing the quality of the wastes. But the university agreed to do the analysis part alone,” a corporation source said.

“The exact contents, like percentage of heavy metals, its caloric values and pH value, could be figured out only through analysis. Based on the results, the corporation could design a project for the safe disposal of the garbage. For example, if the presence of heavy metal is high at the garbage collected from a collection point, then it could not be turned into compost and a different solution needs to be found out,” the source explained.

But it is only the last stage of the study and before that we will have understand the two other aspects, the source said, explaining that by studying the composition of the garbage, percentage of recyclable wastes, biodegradable wastes, non-biodegradable wastes and hazardous wastes could be identified.

As the TNAU is firm on its stand that they could do only analysis part, we have no option but to look for alternative source to conduct the study, the source said, adding that they have been planning to approach either Anna University or a private company who has specialized in the field of solid waste management.

An official from the university said the discussion is still in the preliminary stage and they are yet to arrive at a final decision.

“There are about 500 garbage collection points in the city, so the number of samples that would be involved in the process on the daily basis would be really high. With the limited manpower that the university has, we could extend our assistance only to an extent. So, we have asked the corporation to provide us the final samples to analyze them,” the official added.

Title: Uttrakhand: We pay anganwadi workers better than other states
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Minister of state for women empowerment and child development Rekha Arya at the state assembly on Tuesday

DEHRADUN: In response to anganwadi workers protesting for better pay and facilities, minister of state for women empowerment and child development said that Uttarakhand provided better wages to the workers than its neighbouring states.

“There are 20,066 anganwadi workers and assistants in the state, apart from 14,900 mini anganwadi workers. We give a monthly honorarium of Rs 7,500 to anganwadi workers, Rs 3,750 to their assistants and Rs 4,750 to mini anganwadi workers. The honorarium given by us is better than that given by neighbouring states like Uttar Pradesh and Himachal Pradesh .”

Arya also denied the anganwadi workers’ claim that the state government didn’t listen to their issues. “Several delegations of anganwadi members have met me and we have discussed their issues in length. It is wrong to say that no one from the state government has met them. As for their meeting with the CM, I will soon meet him and we will decide a time for the meeting,” Arya said.

Independent MLA from Dhanaulti Pritam Singh Panwar said, “It is unfortunate that for over a month, anganwadi workers have been staging a protest, but no one from the state government is bothered to address their issue. They have tried to approach the chief minister on numerous occasions but he is yet to take out time for them. The matter needs to be taken up seriously, as it is directly linked with thousands of women and their families.”

Arya contended that the honorarium of anganwadi workers had been raised in 2018 and would be increased again, if needed. On the issue of keeping tabs on a worker’s attendance through the smart phone given to her, the minister said that it was a directive of the union government and had to be complied with. However, if a worker’s phone got damaged, the cost of its repair would be reimbursed at the block level, she added.

While the age limit for anganwadi workers of general category is 45 years, there is a relaxation of five years for those belonging to reserved categories.

Title: Bhagwat case:AICC secy goes to HC
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: AICC secretary V Hanumantha Rao has decided to go to the high court against the Telangana police for not registering a case against RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat. Rao had lodged a complaint with LB Nagar police on December 30 against Bhagwat for terming all the 130 crore Indians as Hindus. In the complaint, the Congress veteran said the RSS chief’s statement is against the spirit of the Constitution.TNN

Title: Coimbatore: Valankulam lake to be soon decked with floating decks
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The city corporation has strated to set up floating decks in the lake as part of the Rs 24.31 crore lake resto... Read More

COIMBATORE: As part of lake beautification and restoration project, the city corporation has strated to set up floating decks in Valankulam lake .

The first-of-its-kind attraction in the city seems to have gone down well with the public, who have started to throng the lake in large numbers to watch the work that is underway.

The restoration and rejuvenation of the lake was commenced nearly one and half years ago at a cost of Rs 24.31 crore.

“The project includes components like walkers’ plaza, children’s play area, non-motorized tracks and food kiosks. Floating decks are just one of the components that would provide recreational space for the public,” said a source with the city corporation.

The floating decks have already gained a lot of public attention. S Vijayalakshmi, a commuter, said, “With the ongoing works, the lake has started to look beautiful. It is one of the productive steps taken by the city corporation. The lakes were once filled with sewage and garbage.”

She said people would for sure throng the lake just to experience a walk on the decks. “There is a need to maintain it properly.”

The city corporation has, meanwhile, obtained the high-power committee’s approval to implement the lake restoration and rejuvenation project at Kurichi lake at a cost of Rs 52 crore.

Under the project, the city corporation source said, a vehicular lane, cycle track, footpath, kids’ play zone and a Japanese garden that comprises a green community centre and a viewing deck would be set up along the lake. “We would also improve the stormwater and waste management along the lake.”

Title: RTO begins week-long drive against buses, vans ferrying students
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Nashik: The Regional Transport Office ( RTO ) has initiated a drive against vehicles ferrying school students to check if buses and vans are following the laid down norms and to refrain autorickshaw drivers from transporting pupils.

A senior police officer said they have formed three squads to check if school buses and vans were adhering to the rules regarding safety of the students. “At the same time, we are also checking if these vehicles have a valid permit,” he said, adding that the drive will conclude on January 14.

While figures of action taken against vehicles concerned could not be known till late evening, the RTO official said their aim was to penalize maximum number of drivers who were carrying more than permissible number of students, driving without permit, among other offences.

“We also appealed to the autorickshaw drivers to refrain from ferrying school students as we would soon start taking strict action against all autorickshaw drivers found ferrying school students,” he said.

Parents of large number of students are against the ban on autorickshaws for ferrying students as the bus service is extremely poor and at the same all schools in the city do not have their own bus service.

Last month, the RTO had received instructions from the state transport department to take action against rickshaws ferrying students.

“During our week-long drive we would take action against erring school bus and van drivers and at the same time also take action against rickshaw drivers who carrying more than permissible number of seats in their vehicles,” the officer said.

“The three squads are taking action in different parts of the city. The combined figures of the action taken by the concerned squads would be available on Wednesday,” he added.

Meanwhile, police have also decided to conduct a meeting with parents to inform them about the hazards of sending their children to school by autorickshaws. The meetings will be conducted at school-level across the city.

Title: Dehradun: Vacant seat of bureaucrats annoys opposition
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

DEHRADUN: Soon after the question hour came to an end, the opposition Congress pointed at the vacant chair of bureaucrats in the state assembly saying, “This shows the intent of the state government and the seriousness of officers on important issues.” The issue led to a verbal tussle between Congress MLA and state chief Pritam Singh and forest minister Harak Singh Rawat .

On the issue Pritam Singh said, “On one end, the ministers are unable to provide satisfactory answers and the bureaucrats, who are supposed to help them, are missing. There is not a single official present in the House and that too at a time when the ministers are unable to provide satisfactory answer.”

In a sarcastic jibe, Rawat said, “At times, Singh tries to prove himself senior and at times junior to me. It looks like the number of his eye lens has increased. Two officers are seated on the seats allotted to them but unfortunately he cannot see them.”

Taking a serious note, Singh termed Rawat’s remark as “objectionable” and added, “On several occasions, the ministers have found themselves cornered on various issues and have been unable to provide even the simplest of answers. The absence of state bureaucrats shows that even the officers do not take the ministers seriously. My friend, it is a serious issue and a major concern for the government.”

Title: Coimbatore: Two men pose as cops, extort Rs 200 from man
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The city police arrested two men for posing as cops and extorting money from a man at the central bus stand at Gandhipuram on Monday morning.

K Abudhahir, 44, of Gandhipuram and L Anandh, 55, of Kattoor in Mettupalayam woke up R Sivakumar, 35, of Thuraiyur in Trichy, who was sleeping on a platform in the bus stand on Monday morning. The duo, who were in plain clothes, told Sivakumar that they were cops and questioned him why he was sleeping there. Sivakumar is searching for a job in the city, a police officer said.

“The duo threatened him that he looked suspicious. They checked his wallet and took Rs 200 from it,” the officer said.

Sivakumar doubted the duo and informed the Kattoor (crime) police. Immediately, a team led by assistant commissioner Chandrasekar reached the bus stand and questioned commuters. They traced the duo and arrested them.

A case was registered under Section 170 (personating a public servant) and Section 383 (extortion) of the Indian penal code . The accused were produced before a judicial magistrate court and later remanded in judicial custody. Subsequently, they were lodged at the Coimbatore Central Prison.

Title: Kolkata: Man found with kin’s body on ice
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The Sur residence; (right) one of the boxes, in which Sur’s brother-inlaw brought the ice blocks to preserve t... Read More

KOLKATA: A man in his 50s was caught by locals and handed over to the police on Monday night for allegedly trying to preserve the body of his elderly brother-in-law in a trunk, using ice blocks, at Regent Colony in Tollygunge .

His wife and daughter were away on a vacation in Shimla. Cops have sent the body for post-mortem and detained the accused, Biswanath Das .

Locals were alerted by a stench and water seeping out of the house of Samir Ranjan Sur (68) around 8.30pm. When they knocked on the door, Das answered. Locals followed the trail of the water to find Sur’s body lying on an iron trunk filled with ice blocks.

Das claimed Sur had died earlier in the day and since his wife and daughter were away, he was preserving the body. But locals called the police, who sent the body for post-mortem and sealed the house.
