“Das said he used to go to Sur’s residence to feed him. On Monday, he found that Sur was dead. He informed his elder sister, Sur’s wife and his niece, over phone. So, Das got hold of a death certificate from a local doctor and arranged to keep the body in the house. Some locals alleged that the accused had tortured Sur to death. We registered a case of unnatural death,” a senior officer said.

A few locals also alleged that Sur was tortured even by his wife and daughter to pressure him to sell the two-storey house.

Rachana Barik, a neighbour, said,“We knew Sur had been too sick to get out of bed. But when I saw Das bringing in large blocks of ice, we became suspicious.” “Eventually, when we questioned him, the entire incident was revealed,” she added.

Title: Uttrakhand assembly ratifies bill to extend quota to SC/ST in Lok Sabha and state assemblies
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

A special session of Uttrakhand assembly was held on Tuesday

DEHRADUN: The Uttarakhand assembly in a special Session on Tuesday unanimously ratified the Constitution (126th Amendment) Bill, 2019, which proposes to extend quota to SC/ST in Lok Sabha and state assemblies by another 10 years. However, no such extension was provided to Anglo Indian quota in state assemblies and Lok Sabha.

The Constitution (126th Amendment) Bill was passed by the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha on December 10 and 12, respectively, in 2019. The provisions under the Bill will be effective from January 25, 2020. As per Article 168 of the Constitution, the Bill must be ratified by at least 50% of the state assemblies before its implementation.

In his speech, parliamentary affairs minister Madan Kaushik said that, “BR Ambedkar had called the constitution a document of social justice. There has been an improvement in the present scenario but it is still required. Therefore, the Centre has decided to extend it for another 10 years.”

Presently, there are over 20 crore members of SC community and 10.39 crore STs in the country. “The need for this reservation was felt as despite efforts more efforts are required for uniformity. All of us sitting here believe that in the overall development of the county and its people and it was not possible without the growth of SCs/STs,” he added.

“As for the second issue of Anglo Indian, their total count in the country is 296. I have the data of most states on basis of the census of the country. It is an authentic number,” Kaushik said, adding that the tenure of present Anglo Indian nominated member will continue till the stipulated time but will not be extended further.

“This is a historic movement and the entire country has welcomed the move,” he added.

BJP MLA from SC reserve seat of Pauri, Mukesh Koli said, “There is no denying the fact that earlier there was a lot of discrimination but the situation has changed a lot. Earlier, be it marriage or any other functions, SCs and STs were avoided but it is not so now, things have changed. However, at the same time, more efforts are required in this direction. We welcome the move aimed for betterment of SC/STs.”

Leader of Opposition Indira Hridayesh said, “We are in favour of the decision to extend quota to SC/ST in Lok Sabha and state assemblies by another 10 years. However, it would have been better if the Anglo Indians were also given a similar extension.”

Congress state chief and Chakrata MLA Pritam Singh said that one should not forget the contribution of Anglo Indians in shaping and strengthening the society. “In different fields they have played an important role for the country,” he added.

Deputy leader of opposition Karan Mahra said, “The Anglo Indians should not be sidelined on the basis of number. They have contributed immensely for the society and country.”

Incidentally, the reservation for members of SC and ST community, given to them for past 70 years in Lok Sabha and state assemblies, is due to end on January 25, 2020. The Lok Sabha passed the constitutional amendment bill to this effect in early December last year, which now has to be ratified by at least 50% of the assemblies before it comes into force.

Title: German held in Siolim with LSD worth Rs 75L
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Panaji: A German national who had come to the state four days ago was arrested for possession of a narcotic substance worth Rs 75 lakh late on Monday.

Anti-Narcotic Cell (ANC) superintendent of police Shobit Saxena on Tuesday said an ANC team conducted a search at a rented room at Uddo, Siolim , and apprehended a German national Mathias Waack, 36, for being in illegal possession of LSD papers worth over Rs 75 lakh in the international market.

Chief minister Pramod Sawant complimented police and ANC teams, which seized the drugs and caught the foreign national. We will continue to work relentlessly to strengthen our fight against drugs, he said.

The contraband was concealed in the room and meant for sale to tourists visiting the state during the ongoing tourist season.

An FIR under the relevant sections of NDPS Act was registered at ANC on Tuesday against the accused. Further investigations are being carried out by ANC PSI Rohan Madgaonkar.

A senior police officer said that they focussing on big seizures so that they can break the back of the drug mafia.

Title: Jadavpur University girl gets online threat but says will run the course
Content:
Monday’s rally to Sulekha to protest against attacks at JNU.

KOLKATA: A 25-year-old Jadavpur University student, a known face in the anti-CAA movement in Kolkata, who played a crucial role in drumming up support for the protest march to Sulekha on Monday, claimed to have received rape and murder threat on social media on Tuesday morning.The student approached her friend, who in turn, alerted Kolkata Police on their Facebook page about the threat, which was riddled with obscene and undemocratic statements about the woman and her family. The student herself later narrated the incident on her Facebook page, and received immense support from peers. Though the cops’ cyber cell has not yet registered a formal complaint, sources said they were monitoring all such threat and hate messages. “We are not ruling out the chance that the accused might be involved in a number of similar cases,” said an officer.The threat, however, could not dent her confidence or determination to fight the new citizenship law and the attack on JNU. Unfazed, she joined another protest rally in the city. “I had tried to engage with them before. But they are paid for what they do. Engaging with them makes little sense,” she wrote to her friend on FB.She later told TOI that cops called her up but expressed certain problems in taking legal recourse. “But I told them that it was a cyber crime that they need to probe under mandate. They told me to send them a mail with the entire complaint and I am in the process of doing that,” she said. Police, however, denied not to have treated her complaint seriously. But by evening, the complaint was blocked from being viewed on the FB page. “We are taking legal opinions on what can be done next,” an officer said.CID sources said their probe into online trolling had so far found several groups active on Facebook who “choose their targets on the anti-national plank”. “These groups target individuals, especially those with different opinions, and instigate others like themselves to join them in the online trolling. We have approached social networking giants to develop leads about them,” claimed a source.

Title: Over 60% vehicles arriving at toll plazas still without FASTags
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Nashik: With January 15 deadline fast approaching for FASTags being mandatory to pay fees at toll plazas , over 60% vehicles arriving at toll booths in Nashik on the Mumbai-Agra highway are still without the Radio-frequency identification (RFID) enabled tag.

Initially, it was decided to make FASTags compulsory at all toll plazas across the country from December 15, 2019. However, the deadline was later postponed to January 15 given the unavailability of FASTags.

An official from National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) said though the deadline of FASTags has been extended by a month, a large number of motorists are still paying the fees by cash.

“Around 80% of the motorists arriving at the Ghoti toll plaza did not have the FASTag. Motorists arriving without FASTags at Pimpalgaon toll plaza are around 60%, while at Chandwad toll plaza the number is around 65%,” he said.

“Though the FASTags are available at toll plazas and various banks, many people said they have made online application for the FASTags with their banks, but are yet to receive it,” he added.

Harshal Pawar, marketing executive, said, “I often travel to my native place in Dhule but of late did not get the opportunity to travel by my car. Still I decided to buy the FASTag online. It has been over 15 days since I applied for one, but I am yet to receive it,” he said.

The NHAI official, however, said that FASTags are available in sufficient numbers with the toll plazas. “There will be only one lane for cash payment at toll plazas from January 15. Thus, the rush of such vehicles in that single lane can only be imagined,” he said, adding that motorists should ensure that they buy the FASTag before January 15 to avoid inconvenience.

“Those entering the Electronic Toll Collection (ETC) lanes at the toll plazas despite not having the FASTag will have to pay double toll fee, the official said.

Title: Elderly woman loses Rs70,000
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Nashik: The mistake of writing down the personal identification numbers (PIN) on the debit cards cost an elderly woman dear as she lost Rs 70,000 from her bank accounts after her wallet containing the cards was stolen from an auto-rickshaw on Saturday.

An officer from Upnagar police station said they would collect the footage from Automated Teller Machine (ATM) kiosk from where the money was withdrawn to ascertain the identity of the suspect.

The complainant, a 70-year-old woman from Shikhrewadi, took a sharing autorickshaw from the Central Bus Stand (CBS) at 11 am on Tuesday.

While she was travelling home from CBS, some unidentified passenger opened her bag and stole the wallet containing her Aadhar Card, PAN card, driving license, registration certificate (RC) of a her vehicle, a medical card and two ATM cards of different banks.

“The woman had written the PINs on the debit cards. Thus, the suspect had no trouble in entering withdrawing the cash from ATMs. The suspect withdrew Rs 20,000 from one card and Rs 50,000 from another,” the officer said.

“The suspect must have been captured by the closed-circuit television (CCTV) camera at the ATM centre while withdrawing the cash. This will help us identify him,” he added.

Meanwhile, Upnagar police registered another case against an unidentified conman for duping a 69-year-old man of Rs 14,000 at an ATM kiosk in Nashik Road area.

The complainant, a resident of Jail Road, said he went to an ATM centre near Durga Mandir in Nashik Road at around 12 noon, when the conman watched him pressing the PIN on the ATM.

The suspect then somehow managed to replace the complainant’s debit card with another card and later withdrew Rs 14,000.

Title: CM seeks bankers’ support
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Amaravati: Making an indirect reference to the plan about shifting the capital city, chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy said the government wanted to ensure overall development of the state.

He said the government was focused on reducing unnecessary expenditure.

Addressing bankers at State Level Banker Committee (SLBC) meeting here on Tuesday, the CM said the government’s priority was judicious use of resources. “You might be reading headlines in newspapers for the past few days. We are taking every decision with an eye on the state’s future,” said the CM indirectly hinting at controversies around plans to shift the capital city.

The CM said the government has many ambitious plans such as completing irrigation projects in underdeveloped regions and it needed support from bankers. He said that Godavari-Penna linkage project, completion of all major irrigation projects in north-coastal region, Rayalaseema and Polavaram project were top of the government agenda.

He said that water reserves in the Krishna basin have dwindled in the last decade while about 3,000 tmc untapped water in the Godavari is going into ocean. “We can put economic growth on fast track only by completing major irrigation projects,” said the chief minister.

Title: Another blow for flood-hit farmers as mills refuse to buy sugarcane
Content:
Representative image

TimesView Karnataka is witnessing one of the worst instances of agrarian distress due to last year’s floods and the biggest victims are sugarcane farmers. The lack of government effort to provide relief has added to their woe. The decision of mills to reject produce has come as the last straw. A big reason for the crisis is the dominance of private mills over cooperative ones. The government must focus on reviving cooperative mills as it will ensure politicians and rich farmers do not call the shots.

BENGALURU: Sugarcane farmers who toiled and salvaged their crops from devastating floods that hit North Karnataka last year, face a bigger challenge that could see all their efforts go in vain — indifferent sugar mills.Sugar mills are reportedly shunning produce from Belagavi, Bagalkot and Gadag districts — the districts that were the most severely affected by floods — citing poor quality.“We are into the second month of the harvest season, but no mill has evinced interest in purchasing our crops,” said Subhash Siraguru, a farmer leader from Bagalkot. “They say it is of low quality because it was affected by floodwaters.”Thousands of acres of sugarcane crops were affected in the three districts as fields were inundated with floodwater for weeks in August last year. As a result, the cane is stunted. Sugar yield is also expected to be low as farmers did not water their crops after floodwaters receded for fear that the moisture would destroy it completely.Now, mills are reluctant to purchase cane from the affected regions fearing low confection. “How can we be expected to purchase sugarcane that has no sugar content at all?” asked a sugar mill owner.Cane growers are now at their wits’ end. Many had lost houses and other crops in the floods and were hoping to secure some income through sale of cane. They are willing to take a price cut.“We know the quality is not very good which is why we are asking mills to pay less than what they are paying for good quality cane. But they are not heeding our requests,” said Dundappa, a farmer from Mudhol, who cultivated sugarcane on 20 acres. He also wanted the government to intervene and direct mills to buy produce on humanitarian grounds.Farmers in Bagalkot district too have pleaded with mill owners to buy their produce, but in vain. “Last week we met Nirani Sugars and Ugar Sugars with a request to purchase cane affected by flood. They responded positively, but nothing has happened so far,” said Subhash, a farmer, who also called for government intervention.However, some mill owners say they have been purchasing cane from flood-affected regions and are only rejecting crops which are completely damaged.“We are aware of the problems our farmers face and we have been purchasing as much sugarcane from flood-affected areas as we can. Even in Belagavi district, which was the worst hit, cane is being purchased. But the problem is with cane that has no sugar yield at all. It is difficult for mills to purchase it,” said Sangamesh Nirani of Nirani Sugars, Mudhol.

Title: Doubling farmers’ income a far cry in T
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: The much-hyped promise of doubling farmers’ income (DFI) by the state government remains a far cry in Telangana. Despite the implementation of direct benefit transfer (DBT) schemes like Rythu Bandhu, the average income of farmers continues to hover between Rs 4,800 and Rs 5,000 per month. This has been the trend in the last five years.

With the Ashok Dalwai Committee on DFI estimating that farmers’ income in Telangana will not touch more than Rs 11,000 a month even in 2022-23, agriculture experts said a scientific approach is the need of the hour to achieve a higher farmers’ cumulative income. The Centre had constituted the Dalwai committee in April 2016 to recommend measures required to fulfil the target after Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced to double farmers’ income in six years.

The major reasons cited for the incomes not going up as desired are increasing costs of agriculture inputs, increased risk in farming, decreasing government support, unremunerative price and increasing costs of living.

Experts said direct income support measures could help narrow down the gap in incomes when farmers’ families fall below a minimum income level needed for a dignified living. Though the Rythu Bandhu scheme falls under the investment support category, it hasn’t really paid the dividends for the farmers, point out experts.

“There is no particular data to arrive at a rational number on the investment support for farmers. Nothing can be said if Rs 6,000 per family per year or Rs 4,000 per acre per year is enough,” GV Ramanjaneyulu of Centre for Sustainable Agriculture (CSA) pointed out.

He said whenever government employees’ salaries had to be increased, the pay revision commission looks into factors like cost of living, annual increase linked to wholesale price index, etc. “However, when it comes to farmers’ incomes, none of this is taken into consideration,” he explained.

Agriculture activists argue that a farmers’ income security system should be introduced through an Act. “Real cultivators should be identified who could be tenant farmers or sharecroppers so that they benefit instead of absentee landlords,” an activist said.

According to the report of the Dalwai committee, the average annual income of the farmer at the national level was estimated at Rs 96,703 in 2015-16. The targeted annual income of a farmer at the national level should be Rs 1,56,154 (at 2015-16 constant price) or Rs 2,42,998 at current price in 2022-23, the committee had said in its report.

Title: High power committee in favour of decentralisation
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Vijayawada: The high power committee consisting of ministers, IAS and IPS officers positively responded to the two reports submitted on decentralization of power, including the state capital. The committee, at its meeting on Tuesday, looked into the recommendations of the two committees that were constituted by the government on the issue.

The expert committees headed by retired IAS officer G N Rao and the Boston Consulting Group (BCG) have recommended decentralization of power and trifurcation capital. The GN Rao committee recommended relocation of judicial capital (high court) to Kurnool, executive capital (secretariat) to Visakhapatnam, while retaining the legislative capital (assembly) in Amaravati .

However, the BCG, while recommending three capitals, went one step forward by distributing the executive into six groups and favoured Amaravati and Visakhapatnam.

The high power committee, headed by finance minister Buggana Rajendranath, too is said to have favoured distribution of various government departments between Visakhapatnam and Amaravati, as suggested by the BCG. The committee, in principle, also agreed to observations of the two committees that construction of capital in Amaravati would be a financial burden on the government.

The committee observed that both the GN Rao committee and the BCG have pointed out financial constraints before the government in continuing the capital project in Amaravati as proposed by the previous government. It also referred to the recommendations of the Siva Ramakrishnan committee on the capital, which recommended against financial burden to the government by going for a huge architectural capital. The Ramakrishnan committee, too, had recommended decentralization of development, including the capital, but did not recommend concentration of government offices in one location based on the Hyderabad experience. This point, too, was discussed at the meeting of the high power committee, sources told TOI.

The committee also listened to the views of retired IAS officer G N Rao, who headed the expert committee. The retired bureaucrat reportedly gave a comparative presentation of his report and that of the BCG for the benefit of the members of the high power committee.

The committee has now decided to hold more meetings in the next two weeks and submit its recommendations to the government by January 20.

Title: Seems like systematic assault, say students
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: Slogans of ‘JNU tum Sanghrash karo, hum tumhare sath hain’ ( JNU students march ahead, we stand with you) resonated at Osmania University Arts College on Monday where students, women activists among others participated in a protest. Students of Maulana Azad National Urdu University (Manuu) and University of Hyderabad (UoH) also staged protests on their campuses.

At OU, close to 200 people participated in the protest condemning the brutal attack on JNU students on Sunday midnight. Amidst tight security, students stood with placards and raised slogans of ‘students unity zindabad’. Many were wearing black badges.

OU students held a rally from Arts College towards administrative building and EFLU students also joined the rally. “What happened in JNU seems like a systematic attack by a group of people. Universities should be open for discussions where students need not go through a formal bureaucratic gateway to hold protests, considering spaces where people can raise voices of dissent are shrinking day by day,” said Darun, research scholar at EFLU.

NSUI members held a ‘Shavyatra’ of BJP, while flash protests and candle-light marches were held at Sathupally, Ambedkar Statue at Tank Bund, People’s Plaza and Darulshifa. ABVP members held a protest and blamed left-wing student organisations for the incident.

The Students Union of MANUU accused ABVP members for JNU violence and claimed it is a futile attempt to divert attention from protests against CAA and NRC. “Government wants to muzzle the voice of students against CAA, NRC, NPR,” said Ataullah Niazi, former president of Manuu Students Union.

“As there is no opposition, the youth are the only ones questioning the government on their wrongdoings. That’s why the government is attacking students of varsities — Jamia Millia Islamia, Aligarh Muslim University, JNU. If we don’t protest now, next can be Manuu or UoH,” said Faizan Sarwar, national joint secretary of All India Students Association, who was part of protest at Manuu.

Shouting slogans against Delhi police and JNU administration, the teaching and non-teaching staff, who organised a procession from Directorate of Distance Education to main gate of the university, said lately no one is safe at varsities. “It is shameful that JNU students and teachers are targeted for raising their voice against fee hike,” said Firoz Alam, Manuu professor.

UoH students had organised midnight flash protest on Sunday. “The Centre is attacking on constitution, rights of people, attacking students mentally and physically through police, ABVP and RSS. Being united has become more necessary than ever as the PM himself is addressing protesters as tukde-tukde gang and urban naxals,” said Abhishek Nandan, president, UoH Student Union.

Title: Almora: Youth Cong, NSUI hold prayer meeting against JNU violence
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

ALMORA: Youth Congress and NSUI held a prayer meeting against JNU violence and against the alleged police brutality throughout the country on Tuesday at Gandhi Park in Almora. The NSUI and Youth Congress workers sang patriotic and prayer songs in front of the Gandhi statue in the prayer meeting.

Addressing the meeting, district president of Youth Congress Nirmal Rawat said, "The current government is attacking universities and institutions in several ways. College fees are being hiked. And when students protest, then they are subjected to brutality with the help of police and masked goons.” Rawat added that the Youth Congress will support young students in their struggle against such attacks.

After the prayer meeting, NSUI district secretary Vipul Karki told TOI, "The path of non-violence shown by Gandhi is the most accurate way of fighting state-sponsored violence. This prayer meeting is also part of this fight.”

Title: West Bengal: Railway nod to Tallah level-crossing
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

KOLKATA: The Railway Board has approved the temporary level-crossing on the tracks under the arterial Tallah Bridge for heavy vehicles when the structure is demolished.

Prodded by the state public works department (PWD), Eastern Railway (ER) had recently submitted the proposal for the level-crossing to Railway Board to facilitate movement during the reconstruction of the Tallah road overbridge (ROB).

ER pegged the cost of building the level crossing at Rs 14 crore. PWD has given the money to the railways, which will start setting up the level-crossing near the Chitpur lockgate flyover.

The 625m ROB is due to be razed in April.

Railway officials said the level-crossing will be operational for five years. The state will bear the cost of construction, maintenance and manning the level-crossing. In case the new bridge is not commissioned in five years, the level crossing will be retained as required.

The railways, on the state government’s request, cited an exceptional situation — the unsafe condition of the Tallah bridge — to set up the temporary level crossing. There is a blanket ban by the ministry of railways on new level crossings in sub-urban sections to prevent accidents.

Title: 25 Anganwadis doing well, courtesy govt’s PPP model
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Nashik: The 25 Anganwadis that have been allotted to a private firm are doing quite well in terms of child development through reform in the education system, the child development project officer of the Union ministry of women and child development said here on Tuesday.

The official, Sunil Dusane , was in Nashik to review the functioning of the 25 Anganwadis. The ministry had roped in a private entity, Ampersand, under the PPP ( Public Private Partnership) model to improve the quality of teachers in the Anganwadis to strengthen the concept of early childhood training.

“The 25 Anganwadis that were allotted to this company are doing better than before as the teachers now can explain various concepts to the students through digital aids. After the age of six, when the child is sent to primary schools, he/she is ready for advanced education,” said Dusane.

“It took one-and-a-half years and 175 hours of training to the teachers as the minimum eligibility criterion of the teachers appointed by the government is SSC pass. They are called Anganwadi Sevikas and require extensive training in lesson planning and technology teaching,” said Dusane.

The private company has established Adarsh Anganwadis in the district. Reeta Sonawat, director, Early Childhood Education, Ampersand, said, “Fortunately, our teachers are highly motivated. They learnt through experiential training that a child’s 90% brain develops by the age of six.”

The state has 1,08,010 Anganwadis. The private company was allotted 25 of the 140 Anganwadis in Nashik district in July 2018. Every Anganwadi with around 30 students, who come for three hours, has one teacher and a helper .

“The behavioural education given at the tender age helps build values in future citizens. Also, identification of special children and their medical care at an early age is possible through the programmes that are followed here,” said Sonawat.

Title: Woman ASI held by Raj cops for carjacking
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kurukshetra: Rajasthan Police arrested assistant sub-inspector (ASI) Kailash Kaur of Kurukshetra Police in a carjacking case registered in Rajasthan. The woman cop is allegedly a member of a carjacking-gang, Kurukshetra superintendent of police Astha Modi said. “A case of carjacking against ASI Kailash Kaur was registered on December 25, 2019, at Pallu police station in Hanumangarh district of Rajasthan. She, along with members of her gang, had snatched away an Innova Crysta (RJ49UA1307) from a cab driver.

The investigation of this case was handed over to Kurukshetra crime investigation agency, which conducted a joint operation with Rajasthan Police and arrested ASI Kailash Kaur on Monday. The teams have also recovered the snatched vehicle from Punjab,” the officer said.

SP Modi added, “Somebody hired a Innova Crysta from Hanumangarh district and on reaching Ambala district, they assaulted the driver and dumped him there. The accused stole the vehicle from the driver. An FIR was registered at Hanumangarh district on December 25. This accused ASI was a part of gang involved in this robbery and was in the car when it was brought from Rajasthan. They sold the vehicle in Punjab.”

Meanwhile the Rajasthan Police took along the accused ASI Kailash to Hanumangarh for further investigation.

Title: A first in 30 years: St Stephen College students boycott classes, read Preamble in rain
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Leaving classrooms empty, the students assembled on the lawns around 10am. They were joined by teachers too

NEW DELHI: As there was a call for a nationwide strike on Wednesday, it was the students of St Stephen’s College coming out to protest, that took everyone by surprise. Many applauded the students of the college for standing in solidarity with their counterparts from Jamia Millia Islamia and Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU).

Students of the DU college braved rain to protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act and National Register for Citizens.

A teacher, Ashley NP, said that this was for the first time in 30 years after Mandal agitations that students of the college went on strike and boycotted classes. Leaving classrooms empty, they walked towards the lawns to join the protest around 10 am.

Raman Mohora, president of the student’s union, said that almost all the students of the college participated in the protest. “It was a collective decision that the students of the college took. The movement across the country is being led and inspired by women. Even in Stephen’s too, that happened,” said Mohora.

Shouting slogans of azadi, reciting poems and carrying placards, students marched around the college. They later marched along with other Delhi University colleges. Students stuck posters on the doors of students’ common room, which read, “hum kaagaz nahin dekhaenge” and “Chankrasheekar Azad ko azad karo”.

The students even read the Preamble as teachers joined them. Mathematics teacher Nandita Narain addressed the students in the college and they sang songs by Faiz Ahmed Faiz — “Laazim hai ki hum bhi dekhenge”. Among several placards, a few read: “We are here for rights and not riots” and “The darkest places in hell are reserved for those who maintain their neutrality in times of moral crisis”.

“It was heartwarming to see almost entire college coming out together to protest,” said a student, who did not want to be named.

As pictures of the students protesting in the campus started getting circulated on social media, the alumni of the college took to twitter.

Actor Richa Chadha tweeted, “Alma..mater speaking on what matters.” While Konkana Sen Sharma put an emoji of a red heart on the pictures of the protest.

Journalist and author, Saba Naqvi, said, “Can’t believe my old college that insulated itself from politics, has this moment. Very liberating.”

Title: FIRs name BJP leaders, not students
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kolkata: Hours after police used “minimum force” to ensure BJP supporters did not clash with JU students after the two sides came face-to-face at the Sulekha crossing on Monday evening, cops registered two FIRs against both.

While the first FIR mentions unidentified JU students, the one against BJP named some of its leaders , like former MP and south Kolkata organizational leader Somnath Banerjee. Both cases were registered suo motu by Jadavpur police sub-inspector Chandi Charan Banerjee.

FIR No. 9 dealt with JU protest. “On January 6, at about 10.50 pm, JU students formed an unlawful assembly with lathi and bricks... In spite of repeated orders by police, they blocked the road... They assaulted police by throwing burnt tyres at them...” the FIR stated.

FIR (No. 8) against BJP leaders and supporters is stronger, where it said they attacked cops and even molested woman cops. “On January 6, about 8.45pm, the accused, Somnath Banerjee, Anupam Hazra, Sarbari Ganguly and Arunava—all forming the core BJP leadership—made an unlawful assembly with lathi and other objects at Sulekha... They disobeyed police order, assaulted cops and outraged modesty of woman police...” it stated.

Title: Coimbatore gets own suicide prevention helpline
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: A city-based holistic wellness and counselling centre, Nitya Gurukula (NG), has launched its first exclusive suicide prevention helpline called “Prana”. People, who feel suicidal or extremely depressed, could call the toll-free number 1800-121-203040 between 10am and 3pm. The calls will be attended by counsellors at Nitya Gurukula or student volunteers trained by them.

Sudha Sundaram, one of the counsellors, said the helpline will be manned by a team of 15 full-time counsellors and eight volunteers, who are being trained. “Eventually, we will have a team of fully-trained volunteers manning the helpline on their own. While the helpline has been launched, it will work in a full-fledged manner only from February 15.”

Sashi Chandran, managing trustee of Nitya Gurukula Foundation and Charities, got the idea to start the helpline when she was pursuing her PhD on suicides at the Madras University. “That was when she was exposed to the high number of suicides in the country, especially in Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra, Sikkim and West Bengal. We also began getting a lot of student volunteers, who want to help in counselling. So, we decided to launch the helpline,” Sundaram said.

The district had seen 556 suicides in 2018 and 468 in the first nine months of 2019. Psychiatrists in the district have long felt the need of a suicide prevention helpline in the district as in Chennai, which has Sneha and 104. Dr N S Moni, of Balaji Neuro Psychiatric Centre, had earlier told TOI that “the number of people who need such helplines are much higher as a majority of attempts to suicide are not recorded by police.”

According to psychiatrists, a suicide prevention helpline could be successful in stopping a suicide only if it is manned by experienced psychologists. “People usually decide to commit suicide in a moment of agitation. They call a helpline in a second of self-doubt. Often, a good counsellor could bring down the agitation to the extent of them changing their mind. But for this, the counsellor needs to be an experienced psychologist or psychiatrist trained in preventing suicides,” Moni had said.

Title: Coimbatore: At 91, modernist artist Akbar Padamsee passes away
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Tributes on social media mourned the loss of the legendary Mumbai painterwho believed an artist needed the min... Read More

Title: 1,000 turn up for FTII-SPPU protests against JNU violence
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Around 400-500 students and members of the civil society gathered at FTII around 6pm on Tuesday to take part i... Read More

PUNE: Film and Television Institute of India (FTII) students took out a march on Tuesday evening from the institute’s campus to the Savitribai Phule Pune University in protest against Sunday’s violence at New Delhi’s Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU).

Members of various student and youth organizations joined the rally brought out amid heavy police arrangements — from FTII to Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU). As the FTII students started the march from the institute’s Law College Road campus, hundreds of people joined it along the route.

Besides raising slogans against the attack on the JNU students and teachers by some masked men, the demonstrators carried placards against the Citizenship Amendment Act and the National Register of Citizens (NRC) that have also been the focal points of protests over most of the past month across the country.

Though the rally was primarily led by students and youth, several senior citizens and some social activists matched steps and walked the entire 4.2km route from FTII to the BR Ambedkar statue on the SPPU campus. The organizers of the march were also taken aback by the size of the rally.

“This is a huge crowd. We never thought so many people would turn up. I think there are more than a thousand here,” an FTII student student said.

The police said the march started with around 700 protesters, but it swelled to a few more hundreds as students from various departments of SPPU joined once the rally entered their campus. For some of them, the rally was a statement in itself against “the prevailing political condition in the city too”.

Sachin Ghodeswar, one of the SPPU students who participated in the rally, said, “Pune city has its MP and many MLAs from the ruling party at the Centre. The same party is also in control of the corporation. It is good to see that politics of dissent are prevalent in this city, unlike what happened at JNU,”

A spontaneous rally started around the Ambedkar statue started with speakers from FTII and SPPU, along with the ones from youth organisations like Naujawan Bharat, rasing their voice against the attack on the JNU students and teachers . Some of them also resorted to songs and poems to express the dissent. A number of JNU alumni had also turned up to demonstrate.

“They (ABVP) had always wanted to damage the JNU campus and terrorise its students, but never had this kind of impunity from the Centre and the Delhi Police. I remember that during the India-Pakistan semi-finals of the 2011 World Cup, the ABVP had tried to beat up some Kashmiri students at JNU. A students’ peaceful march on the campus stopped it all,” said Nikhil Narkar, an academic and professor.

Title: NRI’s Rs 18L diamond necklace stolen from beauty parlour
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hisar: The police have registered a case against unidentified women for allegedly stealing a diamond necklace worth Rs 18 lakh from an America-based NRI woman, at the counter of a beauty parlour at Sector 16-17 of Hisar. Police have started investigation but have not been identified the accused yet.

Civil Line police station has registered a case under Section 380 (theft) of Indian Penal Code on the complaint of Prem Gaur, a resident of Sargathal village of Sonipat district, against unknown person.

In the complaint given to police, Gaur said she lives in America with her husband and children and had been in India for the last 10 months.

She said on December 30, she had come to meet her brother Peshl Kumar Sharma at his house in Sector 9-11 of Hisar. On the same day, she along with her sister-in-law Rajbala went to Chugh beauty parlour at the house of Monika Chugh. While getting her facial, she had taken off her diamond necklace and gave it to her sister-in-law Rajbala, who was busy talking to somebody on the phone. Rajbala put the necklace on the counter of the beauty parlour, she said.

Gaur said soon after they returned home, she and her sister-in-law realised that they did not have the necklace. The duo, along with their other family members went to the beauty parlour, but Gaur said they could not find the necklace at the counter.

Title: 275 PhD seats up for grabs, admissions begin
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Panaji: Goa University has announced 275 PhD seat vacancies in the state, including on its campus, in research centres in affiliated colleges and national institutes based in the state. The admission process for the seats has already begun with Goa University accepting online applications on its website. The varsity will accept applications up to January 24.

Of the total seats available, 147 are general category seats and 128 are reserved category seats.

Seats for which students can apply include those in national institutes such as the National Centre for Polar and Ocean Research (23 seats), National Institute of Oceanography (30) and Central Coastal Agricultural Research (2).

Students who have a masters degree, with 55% marks in aggregate or equivalent, are eligible to apply for the seats, Goa University has announced. For SC/ST/OBC (non-creamy layer), differently–abled or for those who have obtained their masters degree prior to September 19, 1991, the eligibility has been relaxed to a masters degree with 50% marks in aggregate or equivalent, the varsity has said.

At the university campus, the highest of 35 PhD seats are available in the faculty of life sciences and environment, followed by 26 seats in the faculty of social sciences and 20 seats in faculty of natural sciences.

Fifteen seats each are available in the faculty of language and literature and the school of earth, ocean and atmospheric sciences and 10 in the school of chemical sciences. Nine are up for grabs in the Goa Business School.

During the first round of interviews, seats will be allotted to those who have qualified through the JRF, M Phil, NET, SET, GATE, GPAT examinations, Goa University said in its notification.

Seats are also available in research centres affiliated to the university. Goa Engineering College, Farmagudi has six seats available while four are available at the VM Salgaocar College of Law, Miramar. Five seats are available at the Goa College of Pharmacy, Panaji, four at the Goa College of Music, Altinho, Panaji, and one at the Dada Vaidya College of Education, Ponda.

“Candidates of Goa University whose M Phil dissertation has been evaluated and viva is pending, are eligible to apply for the PhD programme,” the varsity has said.

In the case of state-run general stream colleges, Government College, Khandola, is offering 33 PhD seats; Government College, Pernem, is offering 13 seats and the Government Colleges at Quepem and Sankhali are offering 12 seats each.

Title: Cops bust arms unit, arrest one
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kolkata: The detective department on Tuesday busted an illegal arms unit in the Port area . Police said they had arrested the head of the factory — Abdul Kayum, alias Munna (28). Another suspect, Md Kalim, is absconding. Police said local criminals bought arms from the unit. However, they are also probing if there is a Bangladesh connection.

“We acted on a tip-off and raided the Nadial area in this regard. The factory was operating from a building at Z-block in Waris Nagar, Nadial. Kayum hails from Rampur in Munger and was putting up at a rented accommodation in Ayubnagar, Nadial. He was caught red-handed while making firearms in a shed on the terrace of the building,” said joint CP (crime) Murlidhar Sharma.

Police said apart from Kayum, owner of the building — Md Kalim and several others — were also engaged in the same job. “But they are yet to be nabbed,” said an officer.

Police recovered a 7mm pistol, one magazine, semi-finished magazine, one barrel, three drills, steel sheets, iron bars and other equipment.

Title: Undelivered Aadhaar cards: 6 postal staff suspended
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Secunderabad: Six postal department staff have been suspended following the discovery of thousands of undelivered Aadhaar cards and mails at a plot in Keesera last Friday. A man was found burning the mail at the plot following which the postal department initiated an inquiry.

Two postal clerks, one postman, one postwoman, two grameen dak sevaks were found responsible for non-delivery of mail and were placed under immediate suspension, the senior superintendent of post offices, Secunderabad division informed on Tuesday.

Speaking to TOI, C Pawan Kumar, assistant superintendent post offices, east sub division, said that the staff instead of delivering the mail themselves, were assigning it to someone else.

A complaint was lodged at Keesera police station on Friday, after one Gangi Shetti Bikshapathi carrying bags from Indian postal department with thousands of letters and Aadhaar cards, burnt them at a plot in the area.

After being informed of the incident, postal department officials rushed to the spot in Ahmedguda and took charge of the bags. They found that most of the mail pertained to Balanagar township post office. “The mail has already been sorted out and delivery is underway to the respective addresses. Aadhaar cards would be delivered within two days,” said Kumar.

The departmental investigation is in progress and officials said that strict action would be taken against those found responsible.

Title: KCR, Jagan likely to discuss bifurcation issues on Jan 13
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: After a gap of four months, chief ministers of Telangana and Andhra Pradesh — K Chandrasekhar Rao and YS Jaganmohan Reddy respectively — will meet here on January 13. Both the chief ministers met in September last to discuss inter-state issues.

Officials said both the chief ministers are likely to discuss bifurcation issues, especially division of electricity employees between the two states. Recently, the Supreme Court-appointed one-man committee had allocated 631 employees to AP. But, the AP government is not ready to induct them and give postings.

In June last year, during a joining meeting of the chief ministers, a committee of senior officials was constituted to sort out bifurcation issues. But, no meeting of the committee had taken place.

Apart from the bifurcation issues, the chief minister may disucss political issues in the wake of the Centre passing CAA and implementation of NPR and NRC.

Jagan may also discuss the issue of three capitals issue with KCR, sources said.

Title: Notice board placed outside ABVP office blackened
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Pune: Tension prevailed near Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad’s (ABVP) office at Sadashiv Peth on Tuesday afternoon after members of the Nationalist Congress Party’s (NCP) students’ wing blackened a notice board.

The police said that there was no confrontation between representatives of either student body as the ABVP members were busy at a rally organized at a college located on Karve Road.

Later in the day, Vishrambaug police booked an NCP worker and his accomplices, all from the Rashtrawadi Vidyarthi Congress, for blackening the board and for breaching the prohibitory orders of the police.

“We have invoked sections 143 (unlawful assembly) and 427 (mischief causing damage) of the Indian Penal Code as well as provisions of the prohibitory orders of the city police against them,” said inspector Ram Rajmane.

The incident took place at around 12.30pm following which a large number of ABVP members gathered at the spot while some raised slogans.

In order to control the situation, assistant commissioner of police Pradeep Aphale, inspector Ram Rajmane and a team of police constables rushed to the spot. The policemen pacified the students and promised appropriate legal action.

“The person, who has been identified and booked, is an NCP office bearer,” Rajmane said.

The members of Rashtrawadi Vidyarthi Congress had organized a protest in front of ABVP office on Tuesday morning condemning the attack on JNU students in Delhi.

An ABVP member said, “We had gone to attend a pro-CAA rally at a college located on Karve Road and there was hardly anyone in the office when they blackened the board.”

Title: Tamil Nadu: Shola trees to turn barren land green in Nilgiris reserve forest
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Around 5,000 shola tree saplings will be planted in 50 hectares

UDHAGAMANDALAM: The forest department is all set to plant around 5,000 saplings of various species of shola trees in the reserve forest areas in the Nilgiris district .

A source with the forest department said the drive was already on and that they were removing bushes inside forest areas to plant the saplings.

District forest officer Guru Swamy Baddal said, “To fill the barren land, from where the bushes and shrubs are being removed, plantation works will be undertaken in a massive scale this year. Our target is to cover 50 hectares, where shola trees will be planted under the special area development programme.”

Under the programme, Rs10 lakh is allocated for the plantation drive. “The plan is to plant about 5,000 shola species in the forest areas of Coonoor, Kotagiri, Kattabettu and Ooty south range,” the officer said.

In Ooty, Cairn hill, Elk hill and Avalanche forest areas have been chosen for the programme.

“This year, we have taken special efforts to ensure that all the sapling grow healthy. We have selected taller seedlings and will now provide protection with green guard. We will also ensure protection from frost,” Baddal said. Shola saplings for the drive are produced by the forest department in its nurseries.

Title: 14 candidates in fray for bypolls in two civic wards
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Nashik: Over 60,000 voters will decide the fate of 14 candidates who are contesting from ward 22 (A) and 26 (A) of Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ), the election for which are scheduled for January 9.

While eight candidates are in the fray in ward 22, six are in ward 26. A total 520 employees are to be deployed on election duty.

Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) has fielded NCP candidate Jagdish Pawar from ward 22 while Shiv Sena’s Madhukar Jadhav will fight from ward 26.

The BJP has fielded candidates in both the wards.

A triangular fight is expected among MVA, BJP and MNS in ward no 26 (A); MNS has fielded Dilip Datir while BJP Kailas Ahire from this ward. The MVA has fielded Madhukar Jadhav from Shiv Sena.

The other three candidates contesting from the same ward are CPM’s Mohan Jadhav, Aam Aadmi Party’s Eknath Sawle and Suvarna Kothawade, an independent.

The ward no 22 (A) is expected to see a straight fight between BJP and NCP. The MVA has fielded NCP’s Jagdish Pawar while BJP Vishaka Shirsat.

A total 30,165 voters, including 14,753 women, will decide the fate of eight candidates in the by-poll for ward 22.

There are a total 32,880 voters in ward 26, including 13,821 women.

The post of corporator in ward 22 (A) fell vacant after BJP’s Saroj Ahire resigned and joined NCP to contest the state assembly elections from Deolali assembly constituency.

Election in ward 26 (A) has been necessitated after Shiv Sena corporator Dilip Datir resigned and joined MNS to contest the Nashik West seat of the state assembly.

Title: Man booked on molestation charge
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Pune: A man was booked on Monday on the charge of molesting a seven-year-old girl on the premises of a housing society in Thergaon on Sunday night.

The Wakad police said the man, around 22-year-old, sneaked into the society while the girl, along with other children, was playing on the society premises.

The FIR, lodged by the girl’s mother, said after entering the society, the man asked a boy to help him download a game on his cellphone.

“While the man was talking to the boy, other children, along with the girl, arrived there. As soon as the game was downloaded, he told the children that he will play hide and seek with them. He then sent the children, except the girl, to hide,” an officer of the Wakad police said.

After other children went away, the suspect then took the girl to a parking area, which remains dark, and molested her, the officer said, adding that the girl ran away from the parking lot and went to her home.

The police have launched a hunt for the suspect and are also collecting CCTV footage from the society to ascertain his identity. “The suspect has been booked for molestation and under POCSO Act,” the officer said.

Title: Protests continue against JNU violence
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

NASHIK: Students of Samyak Vidyarthi Andolan continued their protest for second continuous day on Tuesday for the violence against Jawaharlal Nehru University ( JNU ) students.

The protest, which was conducted at the Golf Club Ground and Shalimar, was joined in by close to 40 students with banners and posters. The students stated that they were scared after the violence at one of the biggest varsities of the country and requested the government to assure them of no such action to happen in the state.

Santosh Bhalerao, the district head, Samyak Vidyarthi Andolan, said “The incident that happened at JNU is very unfortunate. All the students are petrified of such acts happening across the country. We want the government and the police authorities to protect the students of the city.”

The organisation had taken prior permission for the protest. After protesting at the Golf Club ground the students moved to the Ambedkar Statue at Shalimar and continued their protest. By 1.30 pm, the students met the district administrative authorities and requested that peace should be maintained in the city.

“We wanted to meet the district administrative officers and express our protest. They have accepted our request and said that they will take our plea to the governor and also to the president soon,” Bhalerao told TOI.

On Monday, the functionaries of the Nationalist Youth Congress protested outside the office of the Akhil Bhartiya Vidyarthi Parishad, who claimed the responsibility of the attacks.

Title: Capital dreams likely to hurt city vegetable market
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The proposal to set up the executive capital of the state at Vizag city has farmers worried that fertile land will pass out of their hands for construction work on the capital. The capital construction works pass through their farm lands.

Farmers in villages in Anandapuram and Padmanabham mandals under the Bheemili assembly constituency in Visakhapatnam—Velanki, Girijala, Yenugupalem, Mucharla and Sontyam, among others—have been cultivating vegetables and flowers on around 250 acres and paddy on 200 acres for the past few decades. PA Naidu, a farmer from Anandapuram, said, “If we sell our lands, we will get a one-time sum but will also lose our livelihoods,” adding that real estate agents have started to purchase farm land in the two mandals.

Anandapuram is one of the key suppliers of vegetables and flowers for Vizag. The variety of brinjal grown in Velanki is also popular in the region. K Lokanadham, district secretary of Communist Party of India (Marxist), said the executive capital would not promote development of the region or generate employment, but hasten the takeover of farmlands in and around the city. A section of farmers are hopeful that setting up the executive capital here would push up land prices, while others fear loss of livelihood, Lokanadham added.

“On average, each farmer in the Anandapuram and Padmanabham region gets at a profit of at least Rs 50,000 per acre in a year by cultivating vegetables and a profit of Rs 1 lakh per acre for growing flowers,” said P Ramu, a farmer. Most farmers in the region grown tomato, beans, okra and cauliflower.

Members of Confederation of Real Estate Developers Association of India (Credai), Vizag chapter stated that farmers would sell their lands if realtors offered lucrative prices. The real estate sector on the city’s outskirts and in neighbouring Vizianagaram district would also be given a boost, they said.

The requirement of vegetables in the city stands between 6,000 to 7,000 quintals a day, at present.

If the executive capital is set up here, this requirement will increase over time and the city may face a shortage of supply if farm land in Anandapuram is taken over for real estate projects.

Title: Nirbhaya case: All over for four convicts? Not quite
Content:
Perhaps the only man hanged for rape and murder in India in recent memory was Dhananjoy Chatterjee. He was han... Read More

NEW DELHI: Though Delhi court order picked 7am as the time and January 22, 2019 – as the day of hanging of the four convicts in the 2012 Nirbhaya case, these men still have the option of their remaining legal remedies – a curative petition in the Supreme Court and a mercy plea before the President of India.Dr Yug Mohit Chaudhry, an advocate who specialises in death penalty cases, said, “They can file a curative petition. They can file a mercy petition — the most important thing. The government will consider it in all sincerity and not rubber stamp its rejection.”Chaudhry also highlighted that legal remedy has to be considered seriously. “This is one of the most solemn powers of the Constitution — the power of life and death exercised by the state. They have the power to give clemency. They should exercise their powers independently and mercifully,” he added.The four convicts in the Nirbhaya case have been ordered to be hanged in Jail at 7am on January 22. A trial court had on September 10, 2013, convicted Mukesh, Vinay, Akshay and Pawan of 13 offences, including gang rape, unnatural offence and murder of the woman and attempt to murder her male friend. Three days later, it had awarded death to all four convicts and referred the case to Delhi high court for confirmation of death sentence.Advocate AT Ansari was a part of the trial of the Nirbhaya case as a prosecutor. He felt satisfied that justice had prevailed finally. He was concerned that despite the rising number of convictions in rape cases, such crime hadn’t seen a downturn.Recalling the days of trial, Ansari was proud of the team led by senior lawyer Dayan Krishnan, who did not leave any stone unturned in assisting the court. Ansari remembered one such instance during the trial when during the examination of one of the prosecution witnesses, an issue of improper administering of oath was raised. “The portion of his already recorded statement was discarded by the prosecution. The oath was administered again, so was his deposition,” he said.The trial saw the prosecution relying amply on scientific evidence. The case also stood out for having utilised the technology of forensic odontology for the first time in India. “It was used to establish the traces of bite of marks found on the victim's body to prove that it had been caused by the accused persons,” added Ansari.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Vegetable growers in Nilgiris march against ban on highly toxic pesticides
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Around 2,000 people participated in the rally that commenced from Ooty main bus stand and concluded at the dis... Read More

UDHAGAMANDALAM: The members of Nilgiri Potato and Vegetable Growers’ Association (NPVGA) on Tuesday took out a rally in Ooty to protest the district administration’s bid to ban pesticides and weedicides bearing ‘red’ and ‘yellow’ labels as part of its drive to go fully organic. They also submitted a memorandum to collector J Innocent Divya.

Earlier, the district administration and the horticulture department had in a draft circular unveiled it plans to ban the pesticides and weedicides containing highly toxic components, which are denoted by ‘red’ and ‘yellow’ labels, by March 2020 considering the health of soil and fragile environment system prevailing in the hills. The circular was based on Section 43 of the Insecticides Act, 1968.

Opposing the move, around 2,000 people from various walks of life on Tuesday took out the rally that was supported by Ooty English Vegetables Merchants’ Association, Ooty Lorry Owners’ Association and Traders of Pesticides and Weedicides Association. They marched to the district collectorate from Ooty main bus stand.

Stating that agriculture would collapse in the district if pesticides were to be banned, C Gopal, joint secretary, NPVGA said, “We have submitted a memorandum to the collector opposing the decision to ban pesticides and weedicides. Let the government first experiment organic farming in its farms. If they become successful, they can implement it in the district gradually.”

The collector, meanwhile, said they had asked the members of NPVGA to produce a list of pesticides and weedicides that they wanted to use. “The list will be sent to the agricultural university for lab test. A draft circular regarding the ban has been sent to all the panchayats in the district. After receiving their resolutions, a proposal in this regard will be sent to the government for further action,” she said.

According to Innocent Divya, training in organic farming will be provided to farmers.

Title: Delhi FIRs against Aishe Ghosh ‘victim-bashing’
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh

KOLKATA: Two FIRs filed against JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh , whose bloodied face after an attack by alleged masked intruders on JNU campus triggered nationwide protest since Sunday, has outraged Kolkata.

“This is shocking. It is shameful to lodge an FIR against Aishe,” said Sougata Bhaduri, a JNU English professor and a Bagmari resident, who was also assaulted at JNU on Sunday night. Patuli resident Mousumi Mandal, who is doing her PhD at JNU, said she found it baffling that the police were so prompt in registering FIRs against Aishe but yet to arrest, or even identify, any of the attackers. “We no longer feel safe on the campus. Instead of making us feel safe by arresting the goons, cops are now indulging in victim bashing. We will not sit back if anything happens to Aishe,” Mandal said.

Senior criminal lawyer Milon Mukherjee said the police move had left him puzzled. “On one hand, the Delhi Police aid they were not alerted, indicating they were absent from the campus. Yet, they lodged an FIR,” he said. Criminal lawyer Jayanta Narayan Chatterjee felt when the FIR was questionable, a possible recourse was to immediately move the high court to quash it.

Similar sentiments resonated on the Kolkata streets on Tuesday. IIT Kharagpur research scholar Debjani Roy, who was part of the JNU alumni association protest meet in the city, said, “This government is quick to take action against the victim herself. This shows their real intentions.” Jhelum Roy, a JU PhD scholar, said, “If Aishe is arrested or anything happens to her, we will mobilise our protests further.”

Sambuddha Tarafdar, who is pursuing his PhD at JU, has even launched a “I support Aishe” campaign on social media that garnered support from 62 people within a couple of hours. Kolkatans also vowed their support on Aishe’s Facebook page. “Comrade, all sensible people are beside you. Red salute to you and to other comrade,” wrote Samir Dutta Gupta, who retired as an academic sections officer from Asiatic Society. Arnab Ganguly, former Presidency student and now studying at ISI Delhi, sarcastically posted that it (FIRs) would mean Aishe had taken a steel rod and hit her own head to get injured.

Criminal lawyer Chatterjee, who has argued against several false FIRs, said, “Once an FIR is lodged against Aishe, it will have to be taken to legal closure. Even if she, or those who were with her that night, were to lodge a counter complaint, this FIR will stand. The option other than moving a quashing petition in the high court is to seek an anticipatory bail and help cops with evidence to prove her innocence. But given the police’s haste in lodging an FIR against her, I am not sure whether that would be the correct path or not.”

Title: Protest cloud over PM Modi’s visit
Content:
PM Narendra Modi

KOLKATA: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who is likely to visit Kolkata over the weekend, may run into protests with several social and political outfits planning agitations. During his visit, the PM is scheduled to kick start the sesquicentenary celebrations of Kolkata Port Trust (KoPT).‘No NRC Movement’, an organisation that had called the largest non-political anti-NRC rally in Kolkata, has given a call to boycott Modi’s visit. It has also given a call to block the road leading to the airport. “We will also stage a protest at Raj Bhavan gates and block the roads. We are getting support from people across the state,” said Kamal Sur, convener of ‘No NRC Movement’. Students from JNU , Jamia Milia Islamia, Delhi University and Hyderabad University may also attend the two-day agitation programmes in the city.Socio-cultural organisations like ‘Sahaman’ is planning to block the road at Kaikhali, said Suman Sengupta, spokesperson of the organisation.Sensing that there could be widescale protests around the time of his visit, an advanced Special Protection Group (SPG) team reached Kolkata on Tuesday itself and held several rounds of meetings with senior officers like special commissioner Jawed Shamim. Though an initial deployment around all the routes that Modi may take has been finalized, the SPG is likely to visit each venue to carry out the recce themselves. The police said a three-layer security would be in place.Modi is scheduled to reach the airport at 5pm and head straight to the Old Currency Building in Dalhousie. Later at 7pm, he will inaugurate a unique light-and-sound show on Howrah bridge to mark the start of KoPT’s 150th year celebrations. He will then leave for Belur Math and return to Raj Bhavan after 9pm.On Sunday around 11am, the PM is scheduled to be present at a KoPT programme at Netaji Indoor Stadium.

Title: Congress, TJS call for judicial inquiry
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Hyderabad: The Congress, Telangana Jana Samithi and Left parties condemned the attack on JNU students and demanded judicial inquiry into the incident.

Telangana State Youth Congress spokesperson SP Kranthi Kumar said there is a strong suspicion that ABVP is allegedly behind the attack. “How can masked miscreants enter the university and beat up students, without any plan and backing by some organisation. A judiciary inquiry should be done,” he said.

Telangana Jana Samithi founder-president M Kodandaram termed the attack as undemocratic and uncivilised. “The video clips circulated on social media and flashed on news channels clearly showed masked men launching an attack and injuring the students. This issue has to be dealt with all seriousness and culprits should be booked. Whoever is behind this attack should be exposed,” Kodandaram said and also condemned the attack on Swaraj Abhiyan chief Yogendra Yadav.

AICC secretary V Hanumantha Rao questioned what was the police intelligence wing doing? They would have got some tip prior to the attack. It seems to be handiwork of right-wing organisations, he alleged.

Title: Schools warned of kidnapper posing as teacher
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The directorate of education has warned schools in the state about a kidnapper Dhaval Harishchandra Trivedi, whose modus operandi is to reside in remote areas, seek employment in schools or pose as a tuition teacher and then abduct minor girls. CBI special crime branch in Navi Mumbai is currently on the lookout for Dhaval, for abducting a minor girl from Chotila in Surendranagar, Gujarat , on August 11, 2018.

Based on the directive of the Gujarat high court, Dhaval’s photograph has been sent to schools across the country, as provided by the CBI special crime branch.

“As per his modus operandi, he used to reside in remote areas of different states, impart tuition classes in English subject, getting employed in schools as principal/vice-principal/administrator/teacher and then kidnap minor girls. It is therefore requested to all heads of government, government aided, unaided primary, secondary, higher secondary and special schools to bring content of this circular to the notice of the staff and students,” a circular by director of education Vandana Rao states.

Schools have been told to put up the notice by CBI special crime branch on their notice boards, to help identify and trace the accused and the victim.

“It is also requested to provide information of the person if found in the school area. Kindly inform the nearest police station or the CBI special crime branch,” Rao said. The notice includes phone numbers of CBI special crime branch officials where the whereabouts of the accused can be reported 24X7.

Title: Pune: Burglars strike in three areas
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Cash and gold ornaments collectively worth Rs10.48 lakh were stolen in three separate burglaries — one each in Swargate, Kothrud and Chinchwad .

Tehmu Postwala, a 70-year-old resident of Coyaji Road in Camp, lodged an FIR with the Swargate police on Monday, stating that his flat in Mira housing society on Shankar Sheth Road was broken into and that the burglars had made off with a small case containing a wristwatch and gold, silver and diamond ornaments Rs3.58 lakh. The burglary happened between January 2 and 5, when Postwala’s flat was locked.

In the second case, the burglars struck at a bungalow in Navsahyadri society in Kothrud in the early hours of January 2. The burglars stole Rs8,000, some foreign currency and gold and silver ornaments, totally worth Rs3.09 lakh. The theft was discovered on Monday, when the bungalow’s owner returned from a trip to Gujarat.

In Chinchwad, the burglars broke into the flat owned by Amit Dandekar (39) of Gawde Park, and stole valuables worth Rs3.81 lakh. The incident happened in the early hours January 1, when Dandekar was not at home.

Title: Pune: Focus on environment at Kalyani School
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The students perform at the cultural programme.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Sakthivel takes charge as Apparel Export Promotion Council chairman
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

TIRUPUR: A Sakthivel has taken charge as chairman of the Apparel Export Promotion Council (Aepc). He succeeds H K L Magu and would hold the post for the next two years.

“In the past three years, readymade garments export has witnessed a slump. I am committed to bringing the export back on the growth path. I will take steps to find out new markets for the Indian apparel goods,” Sakthivel said.

He said he would work closely with the governments on this front and try to help exporters avail all the government schemes. “I will work to revive Tirupur apparel cluster.”

Sakthivel was one of founders of the Tirupur Exporters’ Association, and also its first president. tnn

Title: Booming real estate demand may gobble up more farmland
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: With the state government exploring its option of setting up an executive capital in the city, demand for real estate is likely to go up.

In the last one and half decade, roughly 35,000 acre arable land in the outskirts of the city was turned into housing plots. But a host of issues, including agitation for the bifurcation of the state, had dampened the demand. According to sources, these layouts and plots are now coming under the real estate radar. With the capital proposal, another 20,000 acre farmland would be converted into layouts very soon, said S Naidu, a man dealing in real estate.

“It is inevitable since the capital would give a boost to business. The sales would be on Vizianagaram and Srikakulam routes from Ananadapuram. There were layouts in a few areas on those stretches up to Poosapatirega, Bhogapuram, and Ranastalam,” he pointed out.

In the last 15 years, 13 mandals surrounding the city and a few close to the seashore in the district have lost more than 60,000 acre farmland to real estate and industries from Atyutapuram, Anakapalli to Anandapuram, Pendurthi, Sabbavaram and other areas.

85% of cultivable lands at Parawada, Sabbavaram, Vepagunta, Pendurthi, Purushottampuram, Chinnamushidiwada, Madhurawada, Kommadi, Paradesipalem, Tagarpuvalasa, Anandapuram, Padmanabham and Bheemili were converted into layouts, and apartments. New colonies, too, have come up in these locations on the outskirts of the city.

The city is expanding towards Vizianagaram and Srikakulam route.

Title: JNU attack sajano ghotona: Dilip Ghosh
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kolkata: Bengal BJP president Dilip Ghosh has reasons to believe the attack on JNU students is “made up ( sajano ghotona )”. Ghosh also seems to doubts the injury of the JNU student, the photograph of whose bloodied face went viral on Sunday and Monday. Ghosh suspects colour might have been used to depict bleeding . “It is learnt the JNU violence is made up . Police have started an inquiry. An FIR has been lodged. How could outsiders barge into the campus… It was deliberately done to fan emotions. The masked men went away to an undisclosed location with masterminds who brought them,” Ghosh alleged.

Trinamool minister Bratya Basu didn’t take the Bengal BJP president seriously: “Dilip Ghosh has a habit of speaking trash. Nobody takes him seriously. I don’t feel like responding to him. Even the people of Kharagpur, not to mention of the state, don’t listen to him.”

Title: CRDA loss turns VMRDA gain as top govt offices prepare for Vizag move
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: At a time when the state government is fast moving towards making Vizag the executive capital, the de facto seat of power, Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority (VMRDA) is likely to emerge as the new unofficial CRDA (Capital Region Development Authority). There are enough hints from the state government to locate the secretariat, chief minister’s office and other key offices in the city.

Considering the anticipated development potential of the city as the executive capital, the region warrants meticulous urban planning or for that matter, a robust urban developmental authority to assist the state government towards achieving the desired results. The UDA must address zoning regulations, industrial development plans, service plans, environmental sustainability, public amenity plans, land use plans, policy framework, housing policies, transportation and mobility requirements, resource conservation plans, disaster management strategies etc. Here VMRDA comes in handy for the state government as the high power body for urban planning and development in its jurisdiction of three north coastal districts by virtue of the powers bestowed on it as per VMRDA Act.

Welcoming the three capital proposal, VMRDA chairman Dronamraju Srinivas said that the VMRDA is poised to play a key role in the future development of the region if Vizag indeed becomes the executive capital, in association with other line departments such as GVMC, district administration and others. “We are in the midst of preparing the master plan-2041 and perspective plan-2051 in consultation with key stakeholders and public of the region.

The plans will provide the vision for the development area, policy framework and directions of growth and identification of the thrust areas for development in each district in VMRDA’s jurisdiction. The perspective plan and development strategy are being prepared after analysing the existing issues, opportunities, infrastructure, socio-economics, physical constraints, development vision, etc. in line with the developmental policies of the state government,” said Srinivas to ToI. Srinivas further added that Vizag, being the only cosmopolitan city in the bifurcated Andhra Pradesh, already emerged as the financial capital, IT and tourism hub, fintech valley, health city, manufacturing/industrial hub, education hub, etc. “Having a coastline and best connectivity to all parts of the state, Vizag meets all the criteria to be the capital of the state,” said Srinivas.

Title: 61 industrial units under MPCB scanner
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

SLUG: Godavari River Pollution

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has provided a list of 61 industrial units — allegedly discharging waste without treating them into various nullahs linked to river Godavari — to the Maharashtra Pollution Control Board ( MPCB ).

These units are located in Satpur and Ambad industrial estates of the Maharashtra Industrial Development Corporation (MIDC).

An MPCB official said teams would now visit these units and carry out spot assessment before taking action against them.

Recently, chairman of the high-powered committee and Nashik divisional commissioner Rajaram Mane had directed the agencies to take action against those responsible for polluting Godavari. The committee was formed on instructions of the Bombay high court.

“We recently served notices to eight industrial units causing pollution. Of these eight, seven were given show-cause notices and a closure notice was issued to one unit. The seven units were asked to comply with the norms while the last unit has been shut down,” the official said.

“We will again visit the industrial areas to ensure that industries are not releasing effluents directly into the nullahs or causing river pollution. Action would be taken against units found flouting the norms,” he added.

The NMC has already informed the MPCB about the industrial units releasing effluents into the nullahs that connects to Godavari river.

According to NMC, 61 industrial units in Satpur and Ambad industrial areas are directly releasing effluents into eight nullahs. These nullahs are connected to Godavari river.

“Action should be taken against industries releasing untreated effluents into the nullahs. But at the same time government should also provide infrastructures like underground drainage lines and common effluent treatment plant (CETP) in industrial areas,” Tushar Chavan, secretary of Nashik Industries & Manufacturers Association (NIMA), said.

“Metal units have proposed CETP in Ambad industrial areas and have also given contribution, but the state government is yet to release funds for the project and this is causing delay to the project,” he added.

“Instead of giving mere notices, the MPCB should take closure action against industrial units causing pollution in Godavari,” Rajesh Pandit, environmentalist and petitioner of PIL on Godavari pollution in Bombay High Court, said.

Title: Decision taken on wrong data which shows no Anglo Indian in Uttrakhand: Nominated MLA
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand state assembly on Tuesday ratified the 126th constitution amendment bill to extend SC/ST — excluding Anglo Indians — quota in state assemblies and Lok Sabha by another 10 years.

Meanwhile, the lone nominated Anglo Indian member in the state assembly George Ivan Gregory Mann, who is likely to complete his tenure as legislator in Dehradun , termed it “unfortunate” and said that the decision was taken on wrong data.

Speaking the TOI, Mann said that he was deeply saddened by the legislature exclusion of the Anglo Indian community. “I had not expected this and I hope that the party would review its decision for the benefit of the Anglo Indian community.” On being asked about the justification of having an Anglo Indian a colonial relic, Mann said, “Don’t call it colonial.
