Anglo Indians were born in India, it is our motherland. The reservation of our representation in the state assemblies and Lok Sabha is a constitutional provision.”

Mann expressed his surprise over the fact that the census mentioned that there was no Anglo Indian in Dehradun or Uttarakhand. “I want to tell the House that there are 16 Anglo Indian schools in Uttarakhand, which are working for the development and economy of the state,” he said.

He added that the constitution had provided them a special security cover, which has been now been withdrawn. “Since Independence there is no doubting of our contribution towards the society and the country. We are known for honesty, sacrifice and hard work. We do not belong to any particular region but the entire nation is ours.”

He added that the numbers of Anglo Indians in Dehradun alone is over 110. “The definition of Anglo Indian is very clear and it follows the father’s side of lineage. We were given the reservation for the contribution in development of the country and it has nothing to do with our faith,” Mann said. He claimed to take up the issue of doing away of Anglo India reservation with national leadership in Delhi.

Mann is the third Anglo Indian MLA in Uttarakhand, before him RV Gardner who was nominated twice (first in 2002 and second in 2012) and Karen Meyer Hilton who held the position in 2007.

He added that many Anglo Indians are living below the poverty line and needs a voice to bring forward their issues. “Our PM had given the slogan of Sabka Saath, Sabka Vikas and following the principles of unity in diversity, I would like to request our CM and the assembly to reconsider the decision.”

Meanwhile, in the state assembly, within minutes of the bill being ratified, the BJP camp hailed the decision but kept silent on the need of doing away the reservation to Anglo Indian. BJP state president and Nainital MP Ajay Bhatt said, “The decision about the extension for the reservation of Anglo Indians would be considered at a later stage by the government. Our government is committed to giving all reservation facilities to SC/ST envisioned by the constitution.” Bhatt, however, added that the country has only 500 people from the Anglo Indian community which he considered too small to be given reservation under the 126th amendment.

Title: Bharat bandh: Schools shut, buses likely to go off roads
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Shop closed during Bandh (File Photo)

BHUBANESWAR: Several government and private schools in the city have declared a holiday on Wednesday on account of the ‘ Bharat bandh ’ called by trade unions.

Apprehending trouble, collectors of Khurda (of which Bhubaneswar is a part), Ganjam, Kandhamal and Dhenkanal have declared closure of all schools (both government and private) in their respective districts. The Utkal University , too, has postponed semester examinations scheduled for the day.

The Odisha Private Bus Owners’ Association has not declared support to the bandh. Sources said private buses would, however, largely remain off the roads. “Our decision on whether to ply the buses will depend on an assessment of the situation on Wednesday morning. One must understand that damages incurred during a bandh are not reimbursed by insurance companies,” association secretary Debendra Sahoo said.

Though BJD has neither supported nor opposed the bandh, food supplies and consumer welfare minister Ranendra Pratap Swain said, “We support the cause of the bandh because of rising unemployment, the economic situation in the country and the plight of farmers and workers.” He later clarified that he had made the statement in his capacity as the working president of Hind Mazdoor Sabha and that his view did not reflect the party’s.

The government has asked the district collectors ‘to take all preventive measures to maintain law and order and ensure maintenance of essential services.’ Special secretary (home) Santosh Bala wrote to the collectors to ask employees ‘to attend office by 9.30 am’.

In Bhubaneswar, police said elaborate arrangements would be in place to ensure people were not inconvenienced. “We will ensure that the national highway is not blocked, trains are not stopped, schools and government offices are not disturbed,” DCP Anup Sahoo said.

S K Majhi, Utkal University’s controller of examinations, said semester examinations were suspended as examinees might find it difficult to reach on venue on time. The National Testing Agency (NTA) is yet to issue any notice on the JEE Main exam that is also scheduled for Wednesday.

The Akshaya Patra Foundation , which supplies mid-day meals (MDM) to schools in five districts (Khurda, Puri, Cuttack, Sundargarh and Nayagarh) from its centralised kitchens, has decided not to supply meals on Wednesday. The foundation has informed the state nodal officer of the MDM of its decision.

Citu leader Janardan Pati said hospitals, medicine shops, milk vans and examinees would not be disturbed during the bandh. In the western Odisha town of Bargarh, where the annual Dhanu Yatra is under way, the trade unionists have decided against closing shops and business establishments or stopping vehicles.

Title: CBI books bank officials for Rs 90cr fraud
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The CBI on Monday registered cases against two assistant managers and a clerical staff of Indian Overseas Bank Mangalagiri branch for causing the bank a loss of Rs 90 crore.

The CBI booked IOB Mangalagiri branch assistant managers K Sireesha, V Suresh and clerk M Adinarayana under Section 120 B (read with 420 and 409 IPC) and Section 13 (2) read with 13 (1) (a) of Prevention of Corruption Act 1988. The cases were also registered against Bellamkonda Murali Krishna Sarma, owner of the Vijayawada-based Bhaktinidhi and Green Valley Ministries Welfare Association.

The Green Valley Ministries Association issued a cheque without sufficient fund in the account. IOB resource manager at Vijayawada regional office Heli Veepuri used login IDs of assistant managers Sireesha, Suresh and clerk Adinarayana to process the cheque. But the bank suspended the suspicious transaction. According to CBI SP P Vimaladitya Veepuri opened a current account in IOB Mellampudi Branch in Guntur in the name of Green Valley Ministries Welfare Association in last September.

He obtained a cheque from Green Valley Ministries Welfare Association for Rs. 90 crore drawn on an account maintained in Punjab National Bank of MVP Colony in Visakhapatnam. He deposited the cheque in the IOB branch in Mangalagiri on October 24. Veepuri had earlier in that branch as a manager.

The bank officer transferred Rs. 89 crore without waiting for the cheque clearance to the account of Bhathanidi firm that has account at HDFC Bank’s Vuyyuru branch without vouchers. He transferred Re. 1 to the savings account of the owner of the Bhakhtanidi Bellamkonda Muralikrishna Sarma who has an account at IOB, Ramavarappadu branch without any vouchers.

Sharma on October 24, approached his bank for the withdrawal of money but the amount was not disbursed. He approached the HDFC Bank, Vuyyuru branch and transferred Rs. 10 lakh to his savings account in IOB at Ramavarappadu branch.

CBI conducted searches at the office and residential premises of the accused at various places including Visakhapatnam, Krishna, Guntur and Prakasam districts.

Title: Water theft control top of my agenda, says mayor
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Nashik: Mayor Satish Kulkarni has decided to tackle the issue of water theft in the city and has asked citizens to inform him if they know of any such case. He said immediate action would be taken if he received a complaint or information in this regard.

The mayor’s decision comes after some corporators complained to him about water theft in their wards. The mayor has directed the officials concerned to look into the issue.

“Bringing water theft cases under control will be on the top of my agenda during the ‘Visit to ward’ project beginning this Saturday,” said Kulkarni. “I will immediately take action against those involved in water theft, he told TOI.

“Apart from listening to the grievances of the residents, I will also hold meetings with all four coporators of the ward during my visit to discuss their issues and problems,” he added.

The total water pipeline network in the city is 2,100km-long. At present, the non-revenue water (NRW) losses are 40% of the total supply. NRW losses are because of water leakage and water theft.

The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has set a water tax collection target of 65.42 crore for the current financial year (2019-20), but NMC has only managed to collect Rs 37 crore. The civic body will have to collect 50% more water tax to achieve the target set for the current financial year, an NMC official said.

In the financial year 2018-19, the NMC had collected water tax of Rs 45 crore and in 2017-18 it had collected Rs 29.50 crore.

The NMC collects property and water taxes through the Nashik East, Nashik West, Nashik Road, Satpur, Panchavati and Cidco division offices.

In all, there are 1.96 lakh water connections, 1.87 lakh of them residential, 4,000 commercial and the rest non-commercial.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Work gained pace as shackles broken, says Arvind Kejriwal
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Arvind Kejriwal at Central Park in New Delhi on Tuesday

NEW DELHI: At the last of his seven town halls on Tuesday, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal denied Delhi BJP’s allegations that he had worked only in the last six months . The work has speeded up after the Supreme Court order on the Centre-versus-Delhi power tussle gave more power to the AAP government, he said.

A day after the election schedule for the assembly elections was announced, Kejriwal attacked BJP’s premise of the triple-engine government in Delhi. “BJP is running the state and the municipal governments in Uttar Pradesh and Haryana, but schools, hospitals, roads are in bad shape there and electricity is costly,” Kejriwal said at Connaught Place’s Central Park. The honest intention, not triple engine, helps in the development of the state, he added.

Condemning Sunday’s attack in JNU, Kejriwal said all steps should be taken to check violence on the campus. Police can handle the situation, but they get adverse orders from their bosses, he alleged. “I can change the situation within a month if we get Delhi Police under my control,” he said.

In the wake of the death warrants for the Nirbhaya convicts, the CM highlighted his government’s work for women’s safety. “My government is always serious about women’s safety, but all sections of the society should join hands for it,” he said, adding the installation of 1.5 lakh CCTV cameras were working as a deterrent. “We will not leave any dark spot in Delhi.” Accepting that Delhi lacks the last-mile connectivity, he added that his government was working on it.

On AAP’s association with political strategist Prashant Kishor, the party’s national convener said all good people should come and join good politics. His biggest weakness, Kejriwal said, is not knowing politics.

Kejriwal said the AAP government did not implement the Centre’s Ayushman Bharat Yojna as Delhi’s scheme was better. On slow progress of some projects, Kejriwal said 500 Wi-Fi hotspots were being added every week and 800 mohalla clinics would be opened within three months. “Before the Supreme Court verdict, all files were required to be sent to the LG and he sat on them,” he alleged.

Kejriwal rubbished BJP’s repeated allegations that Delhi government was starving the municipal corporations of funds. Despite the AAP government giving “three times more funds” than earlier, why the corporations can’t distribute salaries now, he wondered.

The government, the CM said, will decide on the prosecution sanction of former JNUSU president Kanhaiya Kumar and others after consulting legal experts.

He also said that the Centre should work with all CMs to find a solution for the economic condition.

Title: 56 coaching instts get final notice over fire safety
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC )’s fire brigade department has served final notices to 56 coaching classes for not complying with the fire safety norms, the penalty for which will be snapping of water and power supply lines.

So far, 263 coaching classes have complied with the fire safety norms thus taking the total tally of 319 classes falling in the jurisdiction of the NMC.

The move comes on the backdrop of the tragic incident at a tutorial in Surat in which 18 students lost their lives in May last year.

In an effort to avoid such incidents from taking place, the NMC started a survey in May itself but as the classes were on leave for two months the total number of classes was unknown. Moreover, the scarcity of manpower also delayed the survey of tutorials in the city. The fire brigade department deployed a team of six people to conduct the survey as it was finally completed in August.

In December, the NMC had served notices to over 263 classes for not installing the fire equipment in their premises. Out of which 216 classes fulfilled the fire norms compliance, but remaining 47 failed to comply with the fire norms.

“After the notices were issued twice in the past six months, around 263 coaching classes installed all necessary fire safety equipment, complying with the fire norms. Now, we have slapped final notices to remaining coaching classes for not complying with the fire norms. We have warned them of disconnecting water and power connections if they do not fulfill the norms,” said NMC officials.

Jayant Mule, president, Nashik District Private Coaching Classes Directors’ Association said that the remaining 56 units have also installed fire safety norms, but they could not submit building completion and fire audit documents of the building. “NMC wants fire audit of the whole building, but we have sought the fire brigade department to consider the audit of the portion of the building used for coaching classes,” said Mule.

He said that they want NMC to relax some conditions or increase the time-frame to comply with the fire norms. “We recently met both municipal commissioner and the city mayor, seeking relaxation in certain conditions. We are waiting for a positive decision by the NMC for relaxing conditions of the fire norms,” added Mule.

Title: 2 youngsters killed in bike accident
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Two youngsters working with a pharmaceutical company died in a road accident when their motorcycle hit a divider near Anakapalle on Monday night.

The deceased have been identified as Palla Gopalakrishna (20) and Palla Laxmana Rao (19), both belonged to Gollapeta area in Anakapalle and were working in a Pharma company in Paravada.

Police said Gopalkrishna and Laxmana Rao were returning to their hometown after completing their shift in the pharma firm on a bike. The rider, Gopalakrishna, lost control of the bike and hit a divider on National Highway 16, skidding off the road and causing fatal injuries to the two.

The injured persons were shifted to government hospital at Anakapalle, where the doctors declared Gopalakrishna brought dead.

Laxmana Rao died while bwing shifted to KG Hospital in Vizag city for better treatment. Police have registered a case and the bodies have been sent for autopsy.

Police personnel said Gopalakrishna’s elder brother died in a road accident near the same location a few years ago. With the death of Gopalakrishna, his family lost both its breadwinners.

Title: Three arrested in Lonavla woman murder case
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Lonavla police on Tuesday claimed to have detected the murder of Resham Purushottam Bansal/Agarwal (70) in her flat with the arrest of a former employee at her husband’s grocery shop and his two accomplices.

A police team led by inspector B R Patil took the suspects — Ashokumar Sargara (20), the former employee at the shop of the victim’s husband, Jagadishkumar Jodaji (22) and Pintu Parmar (19) — into custody from Rajasthan . Sargara had hatched the plot of robbery and executed it with the help of Jodaji. The police have recovered cash and gold ornaments collectively worth Rs83,700 from the duo. Parwar was them in Rajasthan.

“After throttling Resham to death, the duo had robbed cash and silver coins collectively worth Rs2.82 lakh from her flat at Dwarkami society and fled. They were hiding in a temple on a hillock in Rajasthan,” Patil said.

Patil said while working in the grocery shop of Purushottam Agarwal — the husband of the victim, Sargara came to know that there was always a good amount of cash at his house. After working for about six months, Sargara left the job and started working as cook in a sweet shop in Lonavla.

On January 2, Sargara and Jodaji went to the victim’s flat and rang the doorbell. When Resham opened the door, they told her they had an half-empty LPG cylinder and if she needed it. “As Resham knew them, she allowed them inside. The duo throttled her to death and robbed the valuables,” Patil said.

Title: Kolkata: St Xavier’s moots admission tests
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Principal Fr Dominic Savio announces the college’s future plans.

KOLKATA: Officials at St Xavier’s College , Kolkata (autonomous) are planning to introduce admission tests in several humanities subjects from the next academic session. Principal Fr Dominic Savio said they are considering a plan to take students after the second round of screening, instead of offering admissions on the basis of Class-XII board marks.

“With high marks being awarded to students, some candidates, despite scoring 97% in the aggregate, fail to get seats in the humanities departments like English, economics, sociology and political science among others. So, we may conduct admission tests for some of the humanities subjects,” said Savio.

The principal, however, agreed that the college would face logistics problems while conducting the admission tests for 6,000 to 7,000 applicants in each subject.

“We have more than 13,000 applicants for BCom Honours. So, the tests, if held, will go on for long,” said Savio. This year the college received 23,000 applications for 2,300 undergraduate seats.

However, the criteria for selection and weightage on Plus-Two marks and admission tests will be decided later. The college authorities are also planning to increase seats for subjects like political science, economics, sociology, English, physics and mathematics, so that more students can fulfil their dreams of being Xaverians. “We may add five more seats to the subjects that are in high demand. Usually, we take 55-60 students in each subject,” said the principal.

Meanwhile, the 13th convocation and valedictory ceremony of St Xavier’s College will be held on January 16 to mark the 160th Foundation Day of the institution. Governor Jagdeep Dhankhar has been invited to grace the event as chief guest who will deliver the convocation address. Ashis Banerjee, former vice-chancellor, Calcutta University will be awarded the Nihil Ultra Award at the convocation.

The college authorities have also decided to come up with a health and wellness centre on its main campus on Park Street. “We are going to set up a centre where students can maintain fitness. Apart from indoor and outdoor games where all students can participate, this arrangement will give opportunities to our students to go for fitness practice. There will also be lectures on good lifestyle, including spirituality,” said Savio. The construction of a meditation centre is also in the pipeline.

Read this story in Bengali.

Title: Rapid visual screening of nearby houses after implosion
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kochi: A team of structural engineers from Kerala , assigned by Maradu municipality’s technical panel, will do rapid visual screening of structures situated close to the apartment complexes within minutes of demolition on Saturday and Sunday. The procedure involves visual evaluation of structures, potential vulnerability and ascertaining whether they are strong enough for people to inhabit.

Engineers, along with fire tenders, will enter the exclusion zone (200m radius) soon after the fourth siren is given. They will examine houses for cracks (possible due to impact of blasting) and how dangerous they are to the structure. Later, they will send an assessment to control room. The administration will allow residents, who were shifted to safer places before demolition, to return home based on the report.

Holy Faith will be demolished at 11am and Alfa Serene at 11.05am on January 11. Both structures come under a single, exclusion zone. “Alfa Serene will be demolished only after the demolition company of Holy Faith H2O gives a go-ahead signal. When a building is demolished there will be cloud dust in the air. Edifice team will enter the site and examine it. when the cloud subsides, fire tenders along with structural engineers will enter the area and do rapid visual screening. If everything is OK, they will pass instruction to the control room. Then only clearance for demolition of Alfa Serene will be given since demolition experts need visibility to implode the structure,” said a source

The process of inspection will take 5-30 minutes. But the process is not going to affect our schedule since the area will be declared as a no-flying zone, added the source.

Meanwhile on Monday, filling of explosives started at Alfa Serene and around 400kg of explosives were filled in the holes drilled in the two towers.

Title: Kolkata: Protests surge, so does Metro revenue
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

File photo of Kolkata metro

KOLKATA: Unrest in the city resulting in clogged roads seems to be increasing the number of passengers travelling by Metro .

On Monday, after students brought out rallies from the Jadavpur University and Presidency University against the violence at Delhi’s Jawaharlal Nehru University ( JNU ), people seem to have gone ‘underground’ to travel longer distances by opting for the Metro, instead of road transport. No wonder, Metro Railway’s earnings shot up to over Rs 1 crore — the third highest since its inception in 1984.

During the day Metro carried 6.48 lakh passengers. This is quite normal for a weekday. The additional revenue indicates that many passengers travelled longer distances by Metro.

“On Monday, Metro earned Rs 100.8 lakh. The recorded highest earnings till now are Rs 147.8 lakh on August 1, 2011 when the new smart cards were introduced and Rs 129.7 lakh on November 9, 2016,” said Metro Railway CPRO Indrani Banerjee.

Title: Palamedu jallikattu:Madras High Court seeks counter on plea by dalits
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

MADURAI: Madras high court on Tuesday directed the state government to file a counter to a petition seeking inclusion of a representative of the parayar community (a scheduled caste community) on the jallikattu organising committee at Palamedu.

C Santhanam, a Palamedu resident, stated in his petition that there were representatives of all communities except the parayar community in the Grama Podhu Mahalinga Swamy Madathu committee, the jallikattu organising committee.

In fact, when the members of the organising committee decided to conduct the bull taming event on January 16, his community’s plea to include its representative was rejected. Santhanam stated that this was discrimination under Articles 14 and 17 of the Constitution which deal with abolition of untouchability. Hence he moved the high court seeking a direction to convene a peace meeting to include the parayar community in the jallikattu committee this year as well as in the years to come. When the petition was heard on Tuesday, a division bench of M Duraiswamy and T Ravindran directed the state government to file a counter in this regard within four weeks. The judges also directed the Madurai district collector and police officials to ensure the smooth conduct of the jallikattu at Palamedu on January 16.

Title: No sentence review board meet since Oct: Plea in HC
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

New Delhi: Delhi high court on Wednesday sought the AAP government’s stand on a plea alleging that meetings of Sentence Review Board (SRB) were not held every quarter despite court’s directions.

Justice A K Chawla asked the government’s home department, SRB and the prison authority to file a status report in response to the petition that has sought contempt action against them for alleged non-compliance with high court’s direction to hold meetings as per the Delhi Prison Rules 2018.

The plea by Amit Sahni, a lawyer and an activist, has claimed that according to the Delhi Prison Rules 2018, SRB meetings have to be held every quarter. He contended that the high court on October 21 last year had directed that SRB meetings be held in accordance with the prison rules.

The plea alleged that ever since the October order, not a single meeting was held till date. Arguing that it amounts to “willful disobedience” of judicial orders, the plea sought contempt action against the officials concerned, including AAP MLA Satyendar Jain, the chairman of the board.

As per the contempt plea, the SRB chairperson has the power to hold meetings more frequently than just every quarter, but Jain failed to do so. The court said it would take up the matter on May 5.

Title: Grocery shop owner hacked to death by three-member gang
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: A 35-year-old man was hacked to death by a three-member gang near Thiruverumbur on the outskirts of Trichy on Monday.

The victim has been identified as D Rajasekaran, a grocery shop owner from VS Colony in Kattur.

According to a complaint filed by Rajasekaran’s father A Devadoss, 62, two of the accused M Gopal and M Mesack from Annan Nagar in South Kattur had a dispute with the victim for a long time.

On Monday, Rajasekaran saw the duo taking bath in a drinking water pipeline in the area and asked them to leave. This led to a verbal duel between them.

The duo left the place and returned with some sharp weapons. They barged into the house where Rajasekaran was running a grocery shop. They launched an indiscriminate attack on Rajasekaran, his father and mother.

While Devadoss and his wife escaped with injuries, the gang hacked Rajasekaran with a sword. He sustained injuries on his head, left ear, right shoulder and left hand and died on the spot. The gang then fled the scene.

On getting the information, the Thiruverumbur police rushed to the spot.

Police shifted the body to the Mahatma Gandhi memorial government hospital for postmortem, which was performed on Tuesday.

Preliminary inquiry revealed the role of a third accused in the murder, who is yet to be identified. Police have registered a case of murder, trespass and criminal intimidation against the three.

The Thiruverumbur police on Tuesday evening, said that the accused are yet to be arrested.

Title: Dialogue not VC’s cup of tea: JNU community
Content:
M Jagadesh Kumar

NEW DELHI: Among staff and teachers at Jawaharlal Nehru University, M Jagadesh Kumar is gaining a reputation as the institution’s “most unpopular” vice-chancellor. Indeed ever since he took over in January 2016, he has got embroiled in one controversy after another. Some of his decisions are seen as reflective of a certain political ideology, but even those who assess him without such considerations assert that Kumar has shut every door of dialogue and debate on the campus, taken undemocratic decisions and administered the university on whims.Not surprisingly, the JNU campus under Kumar is as polarised as the society outside it. Against those who want him urgently removed at university head, there also are teachers and students who admit he may “sometimes take unsustainable, hasty decisions” but believe he is only “a victim of a political agenda”.Just a month into office, Kumar found the university wracked by the sedition case and accusations of anti-national activities. Eight months later, Najeeb Ahmed disappeared from the campus, creating another hullaballoo. Amid other simmering issues, such as a decrease in MPhil and PhD positions, proscribing protests near the administrative block and making class attendance mandatory, he provoked outrage by deciding the students’ union leadership elected in 2019 could not be notified. And then, the violence on the campus this past week was the fallout of his unwillingness to talk to students about their demand for a rollback of hiked hostel fees. Many have pinpointed the unpopularity of Kumar, a professor of electrical engineering, to his being averse to meeting and discussing problems with the stakeholders.Sourabh Wade, a PhD scholar, cited occasions when Kumar proved “arrogant, probably because of the central government’s backing”. He said, “The vice-chancellor overlooked the Academic Council on issues like the fee hike and compulsory attendance. In fact, the Executive Council meeting discussing the hostel fee hike had to be held 18km outside the campus. The Inter Hall Administration meeting was convened with the hostel presidents being informed only 30 minutes before it. By the time, they reached the IHA, the new manual with hiked fees was signed. There is a series of such undemocratic decisions in the past four years.”Perhaps because of their own political affiliations and Kumar’s perceived closeness to the ruling regime at the Centre, the teachers aren’t happy, as indicated by the fulminations of professor D K Lobiyal, president of Jawaharlal Nehru University Teachers’ Association. “He is arrogant, an egoist. He thinks he is the power centre and everybody else is inferior,” Lobiyal said. “He hardly engages in dialogue and whenever he does, he isn’t above insulting the participants.” He added that a university system had to run in collaboration with teachers and students, but under Kumar JNUTA wasn’t invited for deliberations and dialogues.Protests over various disagreements led the teachers to go on day’s strike on July 31 in 2018, but this drew stinging reprisal, with Kumar issuing notices to 48 of them. According to Lobiyal, in a JNU Teachers’ Association referendum on August 7 that year, only eight teachers thought he should continue as vice-chancellor while 279 teachers wanted him out.However, there are some who think he is targeted for everything so he eventually “flees”. Hari Ram Mishra, professor in the School of Sanskrit and Indic Studies, said, “His unpopularity is an erroneous perception. When anti-national slogans were raised in the university soon after he joined as VC , he was very firm that the culprits should be punished. Only his being new meant he did not handle the situation in a better way. Political leaders of opposition parties joined the Left with the agenda to frustrate him by opposing his every move.” Mishra, however, agreed that Kumar took “hasty decisions” sometimes, like on the attendance issue or the hostel fee hike.But even teachers with no political leanings find it hard to accept Kumar’s tenure, believing that he has disturbed the time-tested ways of the varsity by assuming full power and rendering the centres and schools dysfunctional.“For 50 years, all academic decisions were taken the centres. Only if there was a problem would it be broached at the Board of Studies. Any problem being resolved out of the centre was a shame for us,” said a senior teacher in the Centre of French Studies. “All this changed in the past few years. There was, for example, the convention of appointing senior faculty as the dean, but now young colleagues too are appointed to that position. The whole JNU system got disturbed from the day this gentleman took over.”Kumar’s actions are perceived through a political prism, so much so that when eminent historian Romila Thapar was asked, in September 2019, to submit her CV to allow the university to determine her continuance as professor emerita, it was immediately taken to be a fallout of Thapar being a strong critic of the Centre.Yet even members of Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP), the student organisation affiliated to RSS, the Hindu body that Kumar is often accused of being associated with, frequently criticise the VC. Radhakrishnan Yadav, said, “We in ABVP are vexed with him about many issues. His biggest problem is his reluctance to have a dialogue with students. This makes it difficult for us to approach him for help or to discuss campus-related issues.”The torrid time the institution has seen on Kumar’s watch leads to easy comparisons. “I joined JNU in 2015 when the vice-chancellor was Sopory sir (professor S K Sopory),” said Wade. “There was a certain democratic culture then. To the pleasant surprise of the students, Sopory sir once even joined the protesters. In contrast, this new VC wants to run JNU as a technocratic institution.”

Title: Pune: Six held for extortion
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The crime branch of the Pune police have arrested six people, including two women, for allegedly threatening and demanding extortion of Rs5 lakhs from a restaurant owner from Baner on Tuesday afternoon.

Police said the suspects called up the restaurant owner on Tuesday morning and threatened to upload his defamatory video on a social media site if he did not pay them Rs5 lakh. The restaurant owner approached crime branch officials, following which a trap was laid down and the suspects were arrested red-handed while accepting Rs1 lakh.

Title: Potato bites as prices continue to mount
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Soaring potato prices have become a major cause of concern for people across Odisha as its price has increased by Rs 5 in the last two days. Potato is now selling at Rs 35 a kg compared to Rs 30 on Sunday and was Rs 20 a kg, a week ago. Unseasonal rain, harsh winter and short supply are the main reasons for the sharp rise in potato prices in the state.

Blaming the state government for the crisis, cold storage owners alleged that since most cold storages have become sick or closed down operations, there is no potato in stock to be used during such crisis.

“Cold storages play a vital role in making the state self-sufficient in potato and potato seed production. Twenty-three cold storages were set up after 2015 under the Potato Mission. But the mission failed and made these units sick. Despite adequate storage potential, consumers are forced to pay high price for potato,” said Janardan Sahoo, secretary of Odisha Cold Storage Association.

Odisha requires around 12 lakh MT of potato every year while the annual production in the state is around two lakh MT a year. The state depends upon West Bengal, Uttar Pradesh, Chhattisgarh and north-eastern states to meet its potato need. The short supply from these states led to the price rise.

Every year the unprecedented rise of potato prices disturbs the kitchen budget. “Government wasted so much money on the potato mission. Price rise continues to haunt people every year,” said Antaryami Panda, a bank officer.

Title: ‘Struggled to find water’: Bandh strands 2k tourists
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The two-day bandh in Visakhapatnam agency evoked good response from tribals, but has put some 2,000 odd tourists at Araku in a bit of a fix.

The bandh call given by tribals under the banner of Girijana Joint Action Committee (JAC) concluded on Tuesday. The protesters demanded strict implementation of AP Scheduled Areas Land Transfer Regulation Act 1959 (Amendment 1/1970), (LTR 1/70).

Among those who got caught in the strike unwittingly were a group of students from Telangana on a pleasure trip. When TOI ran into the Siddhartha High School team at Simhachalam temple, they said they couldn’t just turn back and leave as several roads had been blocked with boulders.

The Class X students had arrived in Visakhapatnam on January 4 for an excursion and stayed at a lodge named Saptagiri at Simhachalam. Teachers B Srinivas Reddy and P Madhukar who were shepherding the students said they arrived at the picturesque Araku Valley on January 6 in a bus.

“We were shocked to see that the roads were blocked with lorries and boulders. All shops in Araku were closed too,” said Srinivas Reddy.

“We were not aware of the bandh before we started to Araku. We struggled to find water to drink because of the strike. This has been a bitter experience for us,” Madhukar said.

Sai Madhav, among the students, said they were all thrilled to see Araku, only to be let down by shut shops and blocked roads in the tourist spot.

On a different note, when asked about Vizag’s possible emergence as executive capital of Andhra Pradesh, Srinivas Reddy said Vizag deserves the status as it has “all qualities to become executive state capital”.

“In particular, Vizag is best place for tourists and visitors as it has a lot of tourism spots and beautiful weather,” Reddy said.

Girijana JAC had called for the strike to protest against the unlawful leasing of mining land to non-tribal persons in scheduled areas.

CPM party leader Killo Surendra said “We will chalk out our action plan soon. We will resume our agitation soon if the state government fails to consider our demand seriously.”

The tourist department said nearly 2,000 tourists may have visited Araku on Sunday and would return by Monday. With the shutdown of Araku and other places from Monday morning, the tourists were hit.

Title: Subsidies for solar heating systems hiked
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Panaji: The Goa cabinet revised the solar water heating system scheme offered by the Goa Energy Development Agency (GEDA) and increased the subsidy offered under the scheme.

An eligible applicant will receive a subsidy of Rs 3,000, up from Rs 2,000, for installations with a capacity of up to 150 LPD (litres per day).

The subsidy has been enhanced from Rs 4,000 to Rs 6,000 for installations of 200 LPD to 250 LPD subject to the furnishing of an income certificate. An applicant’s annual income shall be below Rs 6 lakh to be eligible for the scheme.

The norms applicable to co-operative housing societies and other institutions remain unchanged.

Title: Iran House labels Pentagon's leadership 'terrorists'
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The Iranian parliament on Tuesday passed a bill declaring the American military 's top leadership to be "terrorists", subject to Iranian sanctions , according to news reports in state media. The bill aimed at the Pentagon's top brass mirrored a Trump administration policy implemented in April that imposed economic and travel sanctions on the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps as well as organisations and individuals with ties to it. Under the newly adopted bill, all US forces and employees of the Pentagon and affiliated organisations, agents and commanders and those who ordered the "martyrdom" of Suleimani were designated as "terrorists". "Any aid to these forces, including military, intelligence, financial, technical, service or logistical, will be considered as cooperation in a terrorist act," parliament said.

Title: Bhitarkanika, Athagarh see jump in feathered guests
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Cuttack/Kendrapada: Good news for Athagarh Forest Division as well as bird lovers as the number of winged guests has increased by 5,152 this year in the division compared to previous year. This year a total of 21,824 birds have been spotted in comparison to 16,672 last year, informed an Athagarh forest division official.

This year, 11,8326 migratory birds of 105 species have arrived in Bhitarkanika National Park compared to 10,9059 birds that arrived last year, according to the bird census conducted by the the forest department on Monday.

The bird census was conducted by the Athagarh forest division in various waterbodies and Mahanadi on Monday. The Mahanadi is playing host to 4,816 migratory birds. “The census was conducted in all five ranges of Athagarh Forest Division — Athagarh Range, Khuntuni Range, Badamba Range, Narasinghpur East Range and Narasinghpur West Range,” informed Sashmita Lenka, DFO, Athagarh.

Good weather and availability of ample food are the major reasons for the increase in number of birds this year, said Lenka.

This year 90 species of resident and migratory birds have been identified. Migratory birds like red chested pochard, pintail, northern pintail, gadwall, Brahmani duck and wigeon were spotted in large numbers on the banks of the Mahanadi. “The increase in the number of birds visiting the Athagarh forest region is attributed to successful bird conservation programmes,” said a forest official. Availability of open wetlands, which have enough prawns, fish , frogs, molluscs and snakes, are drawing the migratory birds, said the official.

In Bhitarkanika, six rare common pochard birds were sighted during the avian census after five years in Bhitarkanika, said divisional forest officer of the park Bikash Ranjan Dash.

“The number of birds have increased due to the availability of open space after the eviction of large tracts of illegal prwan gheries,” said the officer. Around 100 persons, including ornithologists from Bombay Natural History Society, Mumbai, officials of wildlife organisations and wildlife activists comprising 16 teams took part in the bird count.

Migratory birds from central Asia and Europe come to the water bodies, wetlands and mangrove forests of the park every year. In 2019, 1,09,059 birds had arrived in Bhitarkanika. The year before there were 1,12,937 migratory birds of 83 species.

However in 2017, the forest officials counted only 76,268. In 2015, forest officials counted 81,401 birds and in 2016 the authorities sighted 1,0,6,356 birds, added the forest officer.

Title: Demand for basic facilities in tribal areas
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Jana Jagarana Samithi demanded the state government provide proper road connectivity and medical facilities in tribal areas of north coastal Andhra Pradesh to make sure pregnant women reach hospitals in time during labour.

Tens of students, under the banner of JJS, staged a silent protest by wearing black badges on their mouths here at Mahatma Gandhi statue near the GVMC office on Tuesday. Speaking on this occasion, JJS city co-convenor Lokesh Chowdary said that though it has been seven decades since India achieved Independence, pregnant women in several tribal pockets of Visakhapatnam were forced to walk tens of miles to reach nearest hospitals, bearing excruciating pain and sometimes delivering en route to hospitals.

“The elected people’s representatives of the area are ignoring the welfare of tribals after winning elections. In the last 10 days, two women belonging to the Assembly constituency represented by tribal welfare minister and deputy chief minister P Pushpa Srivani in Vizianagaram district were carried on makeshift stretchers to the hospital. We demand the resignation of the deputy chief minister for failing to address the health issues of the tribal people,” said Lokesh Chowdary. TNN

Title: Maharashtra employees to join countrywide strike on Wednesday; buses, cabs, autos to ply
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Shops closed during Maharashtra bandh (File Photo)

MUMBAI: Mantralaya staffers affiliated to employees as well as gazetted officers’ union will join the countrywide Bharat Bandh on January 8. The strike call has been given by central trade unions to protest the Centre’s “anti-labour policies”.

In a press release, Maharashtra State Government Employees' Confederation said the government has been coming out with policies without holding discussions with people directly impacted by these laws.

“The public distribution system is in the doldrums. Labour policies have been changed to favour owners and corporates. The economic slowdown and growing unemployment have further added to problems of the labour class,” said the press release, adding inflation and rising prices have hit the working class hard.

The confederation had demanded implementation of the old pension scheme for all and retirement age’s extension to 60 years for state employees as well as teachers.

The state has warned employees not to participate in the strike or else face disciplinary action.

Anil Acharya, Mumbai president, Indian National Trade Union Congress (INTUC), said insurance, bank and port trust employees with aanganwadi workers, domestic workers led by Communist Party of India and All India Trade Union Congress will demonstrate at Azad Maidan. INTUC will hold demonstrations at Bharat Mata with textile mill workers. The Centre for Indian Trade Union will hold demonstrations at Bhandup while Shiv Sena’s Bharatiya Kamgaar Sena will demonstrate at the airport. “There will be no rail or rasta roko,” he said.

BEST will ply buses in full strength, though it has sought police protection and will install window grilles as a preventive step. Taxis and autos will ply too, said unions. Aggregator cabs will be available.

Title: Kolkata: Light rain on Met radar tomorrow
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

A portion of the western disturbance will reach Kolkata by Thursday, causing light rain in Kolkata. (ANI File ... Read More

KOLKATA: The mercury dipped marginally on Tuesday as the minimum temperature receded to 12.2°C from Monday’s 12.6°C. Met officials predicted that there would be a rise in temperature on Wednesday while a western disturbance would trigger light rain in the city on Thursday.

However, the temperature is likely to dip again from Friday onwards. “A portion of the western disturbance will reach Kolkata by Thursday, causing light rain in the city. But this time the rain will be of less intensity and duration,” said an IMD official.

This will be the second instance of winter rain this year. With moisture accumulating in the run-up to Thursday’s rain, the mercury could go up to around 14°C by Wednesday, according to the official.

A western disturbance is an extratropical storm that originates from the Mediterranean region and is capable of triggering winter rain in the planes of Indian subcontinent and snowfall in higher altitudes.

Title: Thane: Teacher with ‘headphones’ on dies while crossing tracks
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

KALYAN: A 29-year-old teacher with a private school died while crossing the railway tracks after being hit by a local train near Kalyan railway station on Wednesday morning. She was allegedly wearing headphones .

The deceased, Antu Dubey, was a resident of Lok Udyan building in Kalyan (East). She was a teacher with a private primary school in Patripul and studying for her DEd (diploma in education) from Saket College in Kalyan (East). A family member said, “Today she used the tracks as a ‘short-cut’ as she was in a hurry to take her exam.”

GRP officials said she was on her way to an Ulhasnagar-based college for her first-year DEd exam when tragedy struck. They said instead of using a bridge to reach Kalyan station to take a train for Ulhasnagar, she took the Sanglewadi route, which several use as a “short cut” to reach the station by illegally crossing the tracks. GRP said when Dubey was on the tracks, a down Kalyan-CST train hit her from behind, killing her on the spot.

Those who witnessed the accident said Dubey was wearing headphones and might not have heard the approaching train. Valmiki Shardul, senior police inspector of Kalyan GRP, though, said, “The deceased was crossing the railway tracks when a train hit her from behind, but we did not find any headphones at the spot.”

Following the incident, locals have demanded that the Central Railway reopen the shut path from the Servoday side so that they can directly reach Kalyan station. CR officials said they had constructed a protection wall to discourage people from using the railway tracks to reach the station.

Title: JNU VC to students: Forget past, let’s work together
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Jawaharlal Nehru University vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar (Photo: Twitter/ @mamidala90)

NEW DELHI: In a rare interaction with the media on Monday, Jawaharlal Nehru University vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar reiterated his earlier statement that Sunday’s violence had its origins in the protest against the hostel fee hike. He said police were investigating the entry of the masked assailants into the campus and the university too had set up an inquiry panel. He announced the resumption of the registration process for the new semester and said it had been extended till January 12.

When asked who the masked attackers could have been, Kumar only said, “Some students who have been protesting against the fee hike had earlier attacked me. Then on January 3, some people with masked faces entered JNU and damaged the servers in the data centre.” He added that this was the first time the institution had seen masked intruders and wondered if their demands were genuine why they felt the need to hide their faces.

As for why the administration hadn’t used the proxy servers for the registration process after the regular servers were damaged, Kumar replied, “These are technical details that we must not get into it.” He, however, revealed that the damaged set-up was now functional and the registration process had been extended to January 12. Later, he tweeted that 3,552 students had registered for the winter semester.

The VC described the mob attack on students and teachers as “very unfortunate”. He said, “Our campus is known for debates and discussions while resolving problems. Violence is not a solution.” He also requested everyone not to “add additional versions to whatever is going around and cause confusion”.

Explaining the late entry of police into the campus, Kumar said JNU had its security and did not rush to the cops unless there was an emergency situation. “On Sunday, as soon as we learnt of the possibility of violence, we called the cops,” he claimed. He disclosed that the chief proctor was holding an inquiry into the events of January 5.

“Let us make a new beginning, put whatever has happened behind us and work together to make our university a great institution,” the vice-chancellor asked students.

Kumar said the University Grants Commission would bear the utility and service charges of the hiked hostel fees and dispelled rumours that the students would be asked to bear the charges after admission. “There is nothing like that,” he said. “This is recorded in the discussions with the HRD ministry.”

Title: 2-day Manyam bandh ends peacefully
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Normal life was affected in many places in Vizag agency due to the 48-hour Manyam bandh, which ended on Tuesday night. With most of the shops remaining closed, locals struggled to purchase essential commodities and food items. The 48-hour bandh call, given by tribals under the banner of joint action committee (JAC) demanding strict implementation of AP Scheduled Areas Land Transfer Regulation Act of 1959, was largely peaceful in all 11 tribal mandals of the agency area.

Araku valley, which is crowded by tourists at this time of the year, wore a deserted look on both Monday and Tuesday as all the establishments, including hotels and restaurants, remained closed. The tourists already in Araku mostly confined themselves to their hotels. Many tourists, who were unaware of the bandh call, returned midway after noticing the curfew-like atmosphere. Most resort owners incurred losses due to the two-day bandh and expect brisk business ahead. tnn

Title: 16 NGOs keen to serve Shivbhojan Thali to poor
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kolhapur: The district administration has received 16 proposals, mainly from NGOs , to provide food at just Rs 10.

The poor will be served with ‘ Shivbhojan Thali ,’ the poll promise of Shiv Sena. Four centres serving ‘Shivbhojan Thali’ will be opened in phases. The first centre is scheduled to come up in January 26 on the occasion of Republic Day.

The district administration has claimed that after the announcement, 16 organisations, mostly NGOs from the city and the district, have approached district collector Daulat Desai expressing interest to provide food to the poor at Rs 10.

Desai said, “We have received 16 proposals so far. We are going to start the first centre on January 26. The NGO will be finalised after proper study. The food and drugs administration (FDA) authorities will be involved in the process to provide quality food to the people.”

The state government has allocated 600 thalis every day between 12 pm to 2 pm for the district. Proposals for the same have arrived from women self-help groups and hotels.

The cost of one thali will be around Rs 50. The state government is going to give subsidy of Rs 40 for each thali to the agency assigned to run the centre. The cost per thali will be lesser in rural areas.

Around 150 thalis will be made for one centre. The food served will be two chapatis, one bhaji, one dal curry and rice.

Desai said that the centre should accommodate at least 25 people at a time. The NGOs, self-help groups and hotels having their own facility will be given priority to run the centre.

The centre will be finalised in one of the busiest areas of the city.

Title: Teenager flees remand home, mom brings him back
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Bengaluru: Unable to live away from his mother, a 16-year-old boy caught for stealing goats and lodged in an observation home in Bengaluru escaped last week and rushed to his house in Kencharlahalli village, Chintamani, Chikkaballapura district. However, the boy’s mother counselled him and brought him back to the rehabilitation home.

Shamshad (name changed) was arrested for stealing three goats on December 24. He was sent to the government observation home in Madiwala two days later. On January 3, there was a scuffle in the home in which Shamshad was involved. He sustained injuries and was admitted to Victoria Hospital . On Saturday, however, he escaped from the hospital and took a goods vehicle to reach his village. Shamshad told his parents that he didn’t want to stay at the observation home. But his mother convinced him and brought him back to Bengaluru.

Title: ‘Amonkar’s fight for Goa Board’s autonomy became national case study’
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Panaji: Padmashree Suresh Gundu Amonkar , who breathed his last recently, not only headed the Goa Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education for two terms, but Amonkar also headed the organisation of education board chairpersons from across the country, educationist Madhav Kamat said on Tuesday.

It was during this time that the national education policy was framed with Amonkar’s contribution, he said.

He was speaking at a joint condolence meet organised by Institute Menezes Braganza, Goa Konkani Akademi , Konkani Bhasha Mandal, Konkani Lekhak Sangh, Jaag and Bimb.

“When he (Amonkar) was chairman of Goa Board, the then Goa governor questioned the board’s autonomy. Amonkar defended and successfully retained the autonomy of Goa Board. The case study was then circulated across the country. That was Suresh Amonkar's finest moment and Goa’s proudest moment,” Kamat told the gathering of renowned Konkani writers, intellectuals and former students of Amonkar.

Businessman Arun Baba Naik said that when he was Amonkar’s student, at Mapusa’s New Goa English High School, he recollects criticising the meagre lab facilities among fellow students at the time. “I later regretted it when I realised with what difficulty he was running the school. Later in life, he told me how his mother had finally offered to sell her gold to run the school,” Naik recalled.

Finance secretary Daulat Hawaldar, leader of opposition Digambar Kamat and writer N Shivdas were also among those who spoke at the event.

Title: Over 1 lakh to graduate at Savitribai Phule Pune University convocation
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The 116th convocation ceremony of the Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) will be held on Wednesday.

As many as 1,09,930 students will receive their degrees at the convocation. Of these, 116 will be awarded gold medals, while 398 will get doctorate degrees, a statement issued by SPPU said.

Dr Gagandeep Kang, the executive director of Translational Health Science and Technology Institute at Faridabad in Haryana will be chief guest for the event and deliver the convocation lecture. Governor Bhagat Singh Koshiyari will be the guest of honour. The gold medals will be presented to the students between 8.30am and 9.30am, while the convocation ceremony will be held in the afternoon at 3pm, the statement added.

Students who completed their degrees in the 2018-19 academic year or previously in various faculties will also receive their degrees. As many as 87,560 students will be awarded their degrees on January 9 at their respective colleges.

Title: Builder questions inadequate insurance cover
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kochi: A builder, whose project is adjacent to one of the apartment complexes scheduled to be demolished at Maradu , has approached the high court, alleging that the insurance availed by state government for possible damages is inadequate. While the policy availed by the government is for Rs50 crore, the builder said a policy of Rs125 crore is required to cover their property alone.

The petition was filed by Heera Construction Company Pvt Ltd regarding possible damage to their apartment complex named Heera Windfaire, which is adjacent to Golden Kayaloram.

In the petition, it is alleged by the builder that the authorities have not taken proper steps to cover the risk to their building, which is situated very near to Golden Kayaloram. The subcollector, who inspected the buildings several times, is not divulging the steps taken to provide compensation in case of damage, the builder has alleged. Authorities are duty bound to take sufficient insurance coverage for their property, the builder has contended.

According to the petition, there are 95 apartment units in Heera Windfaire and the builder has already spent around Rs95 crore. A total of 80% of the apartments have been sold, the petition said.

The nearest distance between Heera Windfaire and Golden Kayaloram is 6m whereas the highest distance is 11m. While authorities are liable to take insurance policy for Rs125 crore to compensate for possible damage to Windfaire, they have only taken a policy for Rs50 crore to compensate for the damage to all buildings in the vicinity, the builder has alleged while stating that the extent of insurance cover is grossly inadequate.

A court directive to the government to either avail insurance for Rs125 crore to compensate damage to Windfaire or given an undertaking in writing to compensate for the damage from demolition is being sought by the builder.

Title: Dehradun: ITBP gives go- ahead to proposed Dehradun - Mussoorie ropeway
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

yyyyyyyyy

DEHRADUN: The Indo Tibetan Border Police (ITBP) has given its go ahead to the route of the proposed Dehradun - Mussoorie ropeway project, which will go over its academy, avoiding sensitive assets like the firing range and combat training zone in the campus, which is spread over 275 acres near Mussoorie.

In March this year, chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat had laid foundation stone of the proposed ropeway, which would cut down travel time from Purkul village in Dehradun and Mussoorie to 16 minutes.

Apart from the difficult hilly slopes, the biggest bottleneck in the project was the sensitive installations of the ITBP. “After a top-level meeting, the decision (to give the ropeway route clearance) has been communicated to the state government. Meanwhile, we have sought 5 acre land in Dehradun for the ITBP,” said a senior ITBP official, who didn’t want to be named.

The site survey for the ropeway’s proposed route over the ITBP has been completed. Possible coordinates for the construction of ropeway pillars are also being identified. According to tentative plans, the ropeway route will have 23 towers and be over 5.5 km long, starting from Purkul village, passing through Kyarkuli, Bhatta village and ITBP, before terminating in Mussoorie.

The ITBP academy was set up in 1973 and gives specialised in-service training courses like bomb disposal, rock climbing, commando, and shooting to personnel. “There were many concerns like height, location and the exact time span for which the cable car would be in airspace over the ITBP academy. The route that has now been agreed upon clears all the mandatory security requirements,” said the ITBP official.

The ropeway project, worth over Rs 300 crore, is likely to be completed in three years and is expected to be a big attraction for those going to the Queen of Hills from Doon.

Title: AU to get Hoon maritime skill centre
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: In a boon to the job aspirants of Vizag city, Andhra University entered into a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with Hoon Maritime Institute, Kolkata to set up Hoon Maritime Skill Development Centre on AU campus on Tuesday.

The project, which is estimated to cost about Rs 5 crore, will offer post-sea training courses. AU registrar professor V Krishna Mohan and Hoon Maritime Institute principal Akash Hoon signed on and exchanged the MoU documents in the presence of vice-chancellor professor PVGD Prasad Reddy.

Speaking on the occasion, professor Reddy said that in the absence of institutes offering post-sea oriented courses in Andhra Pradesh, the aspirants are forced to go to other metro cities. “The proposed Skill Development Centre will do away with this major challenge for the job aspirants,” said professor Reddy. Professor Reddy added that the swimming pool on the campus, which was closed several years ago, will be excavated for the training purposes. “Andhra University and the people of Vizag city will reap benefits from the institute. There is a huge scope for employment for the post-sea trainees in foreign countries,” said Prof Reddy.

Akash Hoon, an alumnus of the varsity, said that he is happy to collaborate with his alma mater for the Maritime Institute. “Even the class X passouts can secure good jobs by getting training in the post-sea courses at the institute. This may lead to foreign shipping companies setting their offices in Visakhapatnam,” said Hoon.

Dean (Academics) Prof K Venkata Rao, Chairman of Hoon Institute Kiran Hoon and others were present.

Title: A Hindu-dominated Tamil Nadu village picks Muslim head
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Mohammed Jiyavudeen secured 554 of the 1,360 votes polled in the village which has 60 Muslim votes

TRICHY: In these times of strife and threats of polarisation on communal lines, a village panchayat in Pudukottai district stands out as an example of harmony.

Seriyalur Inam in Keeramangalam, which is dominated by Hindus, has elected a Muslim as panchayat president to express their solidarity with those opposing the Citizenship Amendment Act. Mohammed Jiyavudeen, 45, secured 554 of the 1,360 votes polled in the village which has 60 Muslim votes. “Shankar, who was among the five contestants for the post, came close, receiving just 17 votes less than Jiyavudeen,” said K Rajagopal, a villager who supported Jiyavudeen’s candidature.

The mutharaiyar and vellalar communities have the biggest vote share, besides people from the scheduled castes (SC).

Seriyalur Inam was among many panchayats in the state where president posts had been auctioned, said C Rajagopal, another villager. The post was auctioned for Rs 10 lakh.“We were not in favour of auctioning the post as it would do no good to the local people,” he said. S V Kamarasu, a resident of the village, said that citing the auction one of the candidates even got a promise from each family head that they would vote for him. “When the Union government is trying to create a divide among people of different religions by passing the CAA, we, the Hindus in the village, chose to elect a Muslim to keep our panchayat united and secular,” he said.

Jiyavudeen said that it was heart-warming when a family head came to him saying that he voted for a Hindu candidate as he had made a promise to him, but made four of his family members cast their votes in favour of Jiyavudeen. Jiyavudeen’s standing as a social worker in the village too helped to consolidate his prospects in the election. His extensive work to rehabilitate local people affected by cyclone Gaja had made him popular. Financially stable after having worked in gulf countries for decade, he founded the Seriyalur Inam Youth Development Committee in the village to create livelihood options for farmers devastated by the cyclone.

Jiyavudeen said his first task as panchayat president will be to bring Cauvery river water to the village Ayyankulam tank that is spread across 25 acres. Through the committee, he has been striving to revive a kilometre-long canal to bring the water.

Title: Power body holds public hearing
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Visakhhapatnam: The Andhra Pradesh Electricity Regulatory Commission (APERC) conducted its first public hearing of 2020 here on Tuesday. Public hearings will be held at Eluru, Vijayawada, Kadapa and Tirupati, starting tomorrow and continuing till January 12.

The hearing was held at the office of the AP Eastern Power Distribution Company Limited (APEPDCL) and headed by APERC chairman Justice CV Nagarjuna Reddy. The chairman underlined the importance of a public hearing on the annual revenue requirement (ARR) of discoms and proposed tariffs for the upcoming financial year.

The chairman also suggested that petitioners approach the commission with relevant ideas and solutions, instead of discussing issues beyond the APERC’s ambit.

The commission, said the chairman, strives to bridge the gap between consumers and power utilities and assist the government in uninterrupted power supply. The APERC also highlighted its priority to nine-hour free power supply during the day to the agricultural sector. The APERC holds public hearings after discoms submit their ARR and proposed power tariffs to the state government.

Title: Man held for biting constable
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

City police have detained a youth for biting a police constable and fleeing after he was detained for his alleged involvement in a theft at a temple in the city. The suspect has been identified as Ajinkya Suryavanshi. When police were taking him for enquiry, Suryavanshi allegedly bit a constable and ran away. He was later nabbed by police.

2 from dy registrar office in ACB net

Kolhapur: The Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB) sleuths caught two employees attached with deputy registrar office, Jaysingpur, red-handed while accepting a bribe of Rs 1,500 from complainants for regularisation of the plot purchasing transaction.

The incident has been registered with Jaysingpur police station.

Title: Telangana: Ahead of civic polls, infighting plagues TRS
Content:
File photo of TRS president and Telangana chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao.

HYDERABAD: Notwithstanding TRS president K Chandrasekhar Rao ’s hard talk that indiscipline and groupism would not be tolerated, the party leadership is very much worried about infighting and differences within the party in various districts ahead of the January 22 municipal elections. The party leadership believes this could impact the results though it is confident of winning the elections.Sources said the party was particularly wary about two groups operating in every district. While one group consists of leaders who have been with the party for a long time, the other group has members and leaders who have joined TRS after 2014. Soon after the 2014 elections, the party inducted several MLAs, MPs and MLCs and this has resulted in infighting within the party as one group tries to dominate the other.Sources said groupism and infighting was seen more in erstwhile Mahbubnagar, Karimnagar, Khammam, Rangareddy and Nizamabad districts. “KCR and working president KT Rama Rao are well aware of groups and warned leaders in the last assembly, Lok Sabha and also local bodies elections. Some leaders were denied a ticket and some were kept out of the loop,” a senior leader explained.KCR, who addressed the party workers a few days ago, made it very clear that groupism has no place in TRS. He spoke with former Medchal MLA M Sudheer Reddy who wanted more tickets for his followers in the coming polls. Ch Malla Reddy, who joined TRS and contested the 2018 elections from Medchal, is a minister now, while Sudheer is sulking.In Khammam, former minister Tummala Nageswara Rao and minister Puvvada Ajay Kumar represent two groups and in the erstwhile Mahbubnagar district, former minister Jupally Krishna Rao and Kollapur MLA Beeram Harshavardhan Reddy, who joined the party after 2018 elections, do not see eye to eye and share the dais. Supporters of both the groups came to near blows in the gram panchayat elections held a few months ago.In Karimnagar district, Manakonduru MLA Rasamayi Balakishan does not get along with other leaders and has alleged that some persons had tried to defeat him in the elections. “Infighting within TRS has gone up in recent times. It’s a worry for the leadership,” a senior leader added.

Title: Dehradun: Civic body planning to charge people for using open gyms
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

The move comes within two months of inaugUration of the open gym in city Gandhi's park

DEHRADUN: City residents may soon have to shell out money to use the newly-inaugurated open gym at Gandhi Park. The proposal to fix a price for using gym equipment at the city’s first open gym will be mooted in the board meeting of Dehradun Municipal Corporation (DMC) which is scheduled on January 9-10, officials said.

The move comes within two months of the inauguration of the open gym in Gandhi Park. The open gym, built by DMC, was inaugurated amidst much fanfare by chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat on November 18 last year. During its inauguration, DMC officials had assured the residents that using the open gym, where basic gym equipment are installed, will "always be free of cost."

However, as per sources from city’s civic body, the decision of setting a fee for using the open gym was taken after it was noticed that people had started using the machines “carelessly”. “Within a week of the inauguration of the gym, we found that most of the machines had loose screws and many of them were creaking due to careless use by the public. As we have to place permanent staff there to ensure the upkeep of the machines, the idea to charge people for using equipment was mooted,” said a DMC official.

As per DMC’s proposal, a person is likely to be charged Rs 600 for using the open gym for three months. A six-month gym membership may cost Rs 1,000 and Rs 1,800 may be charged for a one-year subscription.

Talking to TOI, municipal commissioner Vinay Shankar Pandey confirmed that the proposal to make the open gym chargeable will be mooted in the upcoming board meeting. “We will also be passing the proposal of making open gyms in all 100 wards of the city. These new open gyms would also not be free. Besides, we will be finalising proposals of making 10 more vending zones and a bio-medical waste plant,” said Pandey.

Title: Man fired at in Nashik Road
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Nashik: A 45-year-old man was shot at by two unidentified me in the Chehedi Shiv area of Nashik road on Monday evening.

The Nashik Road police immediately launched a hunt to trace the culprits involved in the firing.

Meanwhile, the victim suffered injuries on his face in the firing and has been admitted to NMC’s Bytco Hospital in Nashik Road.

The victim is identified as Vijay Yashwant Kharate of Tajanpure Mala, Chehedi in Nashik Road.

The police said that Kharate, who is into sale purchase of properties, was standing with his friends in the Tajanpure Mala area of Chehedi at around 5.30 pm, when the two suspects came on a bike and one of them fired at him from point-blank range.

Senior PI of the Nashik Road police station Suraj Bijali said that they were investigating the case. He said according to primary information the concerned suspect was furious with Kharate as the latter used to harass his wife, following which he fired a shot at him with a firearm.

ACP Ishwar Vasave said that the case was under investigation.

Title: Nagpur: Artistes weave magic as Kalidas fest ends
Content:
Nooran sisters Jyoti and Sultana cast a spell with their soulful sufi songs at Kalidas Mahotsav, on Tuesday

Nooran sisters Jyoti and Sultana cast a spell with their soulful sufi songs at Kalidas Mahotsav, on Tuesday

NAGPUR: Sufi songs have an unmatched aura around them that make connoisseurs of music do some soul-searching. May it be devotional songs or ghazals, Sufism transports people into a different realm of music.Nooran Sisters from Jalandhar, Jyoti and Sultana, caught the pulse of the audience from the word go and gave a breathtaking performance of Sufi songs, marking the culmination of three-day Kalidas Mahotsav held at Suresh Bhat Sabhagruh, Reshimbagh, on Tuesday.Representing Sham Chaurasia gharana of classical music, the sisters were trained by their father Ustad Gulshan Mir from early childhood.The sisters meandered through the mystic ‘Yeh zameen jab na thi, yeh jahan jab na tha, chaand suraj na tha, aasman jab na tha’ that showed the inner beauty of Sufi songs. There was ‘Allah hoo, Allah hoo’. Simple but effective words. And the sisters were like one when they performed.Jyoti and Sultana took the auditorium by storm with popular ‘Jhoole jhoole laal dam mast qalandar’. Their rendition was impeccable. The audience erupted in joy when they sang ‘Patakha guddi’, a famous song from Hindi movie ‘Highway’.Earlier, it was the turn of classical vocalist Aditya Khandwe who made the audience soak in Banarasi gharana gayaki. The vocalist chose raag Multani and presented a bandish in teen taal, ‘Mann kahe ko soch kar haare’. He was ably accompanied by Shrikant Pise (harmonium), Suresh Popatkar (tabla) and Rudra Pratap Dubey and Mayur Patare (tanpura).Khandwe later chose a tarana in drut teen taal and concluded the performance with high-pitched aalap.This was followed by dazzling display of Odissi dance by Sushree Mohanty. It was a visual treat when she perfectly balanced postures and facial expressions reflecting the culture of Odisha. She also presented a piece highlighting the joy of monsoon season. Sound effects of cheerful birds and thunderstorm added aesthetics to the presentation.She was accompanied by Sukant Kumar Pundu (vocals), Rameshchandra Das (violin), Awahar Mishra (flute) and Diwakar Parida (pakhavaj).Her second presentation depicted the emotions of Radha. Krishna promises her to spend the evening with her, but breaks it. It breaks Radha’s heart. Her performance depicted the saga of a heartbroken Radha.She concluded the performance with ‘Suryashtak’.Maharashtra minister Sunil Kedar, NIT chief Shital Ugle, divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar, district collector Ravindra Thakre, Sanjay Yadav, Sudhakar Telang and Madhavi Khode were present.

Title: Civic hosps face shortage of anti-rabies vaccine
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kolhapur: Civic-run hospitals and clinics are facing shortage of anti-rabies vaccine (ARV) as city is witnessing rise in number of dog bite incidents.

An official from Kolhapur Municipal Corporation’s (KMC) health department said that order for immediate procurement of 100 vials of ARV has been given and after that stock of 1,000 vials will be procured.

“The stock of the ARV vials is depleting owing to increase in demand mainly due to rise in number of dog bite cases,” he said.

A senior health official of the KMC said, “The stock of ARVs is depleting and there has been shortage since last one week. We have ordered 100 vials for immediate use which will arrive in the next two days. We are getting 10 to 15 dog bite cases every day. Citizens prefer the KMC-run hospitals, mainly Savitribai Phule Hospital, to get the vaccination over private hospitals and clinics. Since April last year we are providing vaccination at 50% of the cost charged by other hospitals and this might be the reason for increase in the number of patients approaching us.”

The cost of the vaccines in the other hospitals is high owing to which most of the government-run hospitals make the vaccines available. Major flow of patients bitten by dogs is at Chhatrapati Pramila Raje civil hospital run by the state government and Savitribai Phule Hospital run by the KMC.

Currently, there is no shortage of ARVs at the CPR hospital and the KMC health officials are advising patients to go to the CPR for the treatment.

KMC hospitals charge Rs 250 for administering ARVs as against Rs 500 to Rs 600 charged by the private hospitals.

“We have supply issues as we do not get adequate supply from the suppliers. We invite tenders from suppliers and those quoting the minimum amount are selected for supplying the vaccinations. The process takes time, however, we make cash payment so that the suppliers make the ARVs available immediately,” the health official said.

Title: Govt considering plant to turn waste plastic into useful products
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Panaji: As the state government is thinking of ways to tackle Goa’s rising plastic waste problem, a solution being explored by the government is the possibility of setting up a plant that could convert plastic waste into byproducts. Chairs, plastic sheets and pavement blocks are some of the byproducts that can be manufactured using recyclable plastic. An agency that approached the state environment ministry with the solution has been told to submit a detailed proposal for the government’s consideration.

“Plastic waste has a lot of volume, but no weight. This makes it very expensive to send the waste outside the state for recycling,” environment minister Nilesh Cabral said. More than 400 tonnes of trash is generated daily in the state with more than half of it being plastics and non-recycleables. But, currently, Goa does not have any major recycling plant and all the waste goes to plants outside the state for processing.

Cabral said that he has informed the officials of the waste management ministry that setting up such a plant in the state can be considered on a ‘build-operate-own’ basis.

“The waste management ministry will see if there is a possibility of setting up such a plant which will produce value added products from plastic waste,” Cabral said.

The environment ministry had announced that a ban on plastics would be imposed in the state, which led to many agencies and companies to come forward with solutions.

At the Saligao solid waste treatment plant, hard plastics like from TV remotes and food storage boxes are sent for recycling to plants outside Goa. Similarly, PET bottles are sent to units outside the state that powder them and use for them for various purposes.

Title: Missing junior engineer found dead in Koraput
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image
