KORAPUT: A day after a junior engineer (JE) of Rural Water Supply and Sanitation (RWSS) in Koraput district went missing in the district, police recovered his body on Tuesday afternoon .

The deceased JE is identified as M Venkat Rao, working in Borigumma block in the district.

An official said Rao, along with the sub-divisional officer concerned, two contractors and two former sarpanchs of Borigumma block, had gone to Haradiguda village in the block to provide layout for a piped drinking water project and went missing from the spot. Rao was with the team from 10am to 12noon. The team was supposed to walk a few metres down the hill to reach the spot.

“As Rao was physically weak, they asked him whether he would join them or wait on the hilltop to which he preferred the latter,” said Sasi Bhusan Mishra, executive engineer, RWSS, Koraput.

According to Mishra, when the other team members reached the hilltop after completing their job, they found the JE missing.

“Our team searched the area to trace him and when it failed in finding him, a team member lodged a missing FIR at B Singhpur police station,” said Mishra.

Meanwhile, police said the body was found near a forested area near Haradiguda village on Tuesday afternoon and investigation is on to find the reason behind the death. Scientific team has been used to assist in the probe.

“Investigation is on to find out how the official died. All angles will be probed and the body handed over to family after autopsy,” said SDPO (Borigumma) H K Majhi.

Title: When mess workers put safety of students first
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

New Delhi: On Sunday, it was not just teachers but also many mess workers who protected students from the masked mob. At Tapti Hostel , they stood as a shield and stopped the assailants from even entering the premises. At Sabarmati , one of the vandalised hostels, a mess worker got injured.

Everyone at Tapti, including the mess manager, on Wednesday spoke about Gurdiyal Singh, one of the workers, who had played a major role in keeping its inmates and the staff safe. “He was the one who saw everything that day as he was at the forefront. Thankfully he did not get injured,” a colleague said. Singh was off on Wednesday. “Students came running and entered the mess. We also got scared that the mob would enter the hostel and quickly closed the gate,” said another worker.

On Tuesday, JNU Students’ Union president Aishe Ghosh had said, “When the goons tried to enter Tapti, the ones who stood up for the students were the mess workers. It is important to remember them.”

Tapti is closest to Sabarmati Hostel, where around 20 students were hidden in the kitchen area. “When the violence erupted, we sheltered over 20 students — both girls and boys — in our kitchen area. The situation was tense and we only wanted to save our students,” said Radheshyam, a mess staffer who was then preparing food for dinner. As the violence went unabated, some workers were also attacked. Rakesh, one of them, said he was hit on the left leg near the kitchen by a masked man.

Late in the night, many mess workers were around to serve food to the worried hostel inmates. “They ate dinner very late but it was our duty to serve them,” said Radheshyam.

Title: Pak Senate bills set tenure and age limit for the service chiefs
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

ISLAMABAD: Pakistan's national assembly on Tuesday approved three amendment bills fixing the tenures of chiefs of the armed forces, namely, the chief of army staff, the chief of air staff, the chief of naval staff, and the chairman of joint chiefs of staff committee.

Now, the tenure of all the three service chiefs and that of the chairman of the joint chiefs of staff committee have been fixed at three years each on appointment, which may be extended by another three years by the government, while the upper age limit for all the four has been set at 64.

Also, the amendment bills lay out that after an appointment or an extension, the discretion of the appointing authority in this regard cannot be challenged in any court.

The Senate Standing Committee on Defence also gave its nod to the bills, after the NA's approval.

In the Senate, the bills were presented by federal minister Azam Swati. While the main opposition parties - Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) and Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) - supported the government, some voices from members of the opposition benches belonging to Jamiat Ulema-i-Islam-Fazl (JUI-F), Jamaat-i-Islami (JI), Pakhtunkhwa Milli Awami Party (PkMAP), and National Party (NP) opposed the bills, chanting slogans of "No, no!".

Chairman Senate Sadiq Sanjrani, nevertheless, forwarded the bills to the standing committee for approval.

Earlier, defence minister Pervez Khattak tabled amendments to the Pakistan Army Act 1952, Pakistan Air Force Act 1953, and Pakistan Navy Ordinance 1961 in the National Assembly. The bills had sailed through the NA's Standing Committee on Defence for the second time on Monday.

Prime Minister Imran Khan-led Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf government had proposed the bills following the Supreme Court's verdict calling for a legal cover to Army Chief General Qamar Javed Bajwa 's extension through the parliament within six months.

Last year, PM Khan had given a three-year extension to General Bajwa, a decision that was challenged in the top court. On November 28, 2019, the SC allowed the federal government to grant a six-month extension to the army chief. The court also directed the government to legislate and remove the lacunae in the re-appointment or extension of tenure of an army chief within six months.

Under the new, the president, on the advice of the prime minister, can specify tenure and terms and conditions of the service of the chiefs of the army, naval, and air staff, and the chairman of the joint chiefs of staff committee. This includes the grant of extension and re-appointments of the services chiefs. The amendment also fixes the age of the services chiefs at 64 years.

Most importantly, the amendment bill ensures that future extensions won't be challenged before any court on any ground whatsoever.

"Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act or any other law, or any order or judgement of any Court, the appointment, reappointment or extension of the Chief of the Army Staff, or the exercise of discretion by the appointing authority in this regard, shall not be called into question before any court on any ground whatsoever," the bill says.

Once the amendment bills are passed by Senate, the documents will be sent to the president to be signed into law.

Title: AAI to fund Rs 15cr biodigester plant
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Vasco:As part of their corporate social responsibility, the Airport Authority of India has approved an amount of Rs15 crore to fund a 10-tonne biodigester plant in the vicinity of Chicalim village.

They will also set up four materials recovery facility (MRF) sheds, besides a baling machine, forklifts and dustbins to help curb the garbage menace around the Goa international airport in Dabolim.

The biodigester plant will treat garbage generated from Chicalim panchayat, Chicolna - Bogmalo panchayat, Sancoale panchayat, part of Hollant and from AAI , and will help them generate electricity. Panchayats and transport minister Mauvin Godhino said, "The decision was taken at AAI’s board meeting held in Delhi on December 6, to come up with a state-of-the-art 10 tonne biodigester plant for Chicalim."

A memorandum of understanding will be signed between Chicalim panchayat, Goa Waste Management Corporation (GWMC) and AAI. GWMC officials gave a presentation on the project to the AAI board and they were convinced about the importance of a biodigester plant.

The AAI will look after its maintenance and operations for the first five years, after which the state government will take over , sources said.

Title: Congress steps up heat on TRS, to make power tariff hike scare a poll plank
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: With just two weeks left for 120 municipalities and 10 municipal corporations to go to polls on January 22, the Congress has intensified its election campaign against the ruling TRS by telling the voters that chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao-government will increase the power tariff if it wins the urban local body polls.

Congress leaders including TPCC president and Nalgonda MP N Uttam Kumar Reddy , working president and Malkajgiri MP A Revanth Reddy, working president and former MP Ponnam Prabhakar and MLC T Jeevan Reddy, among others are cautioning the people that the TRS government hiked the RTC bus ticket fares immediately after winning the Huzurnagar by-elections and that it will increase the power tariff after the municipal elections.

During their election campaign in municipal areas falling under Nalgonda, Malkajgiri, Karimnagar and other parliamentary constituencies, Uttam, Revanth and Jeevan Reddy are explaining to people that TRS government is just waiting for ULB polls to be completed to hike “current (power) charges.”

Uttam has called upon the voters to inflict a pinch on the ruling TRS by defeating it. “KCR has failed to give Rs 3,016 per month unemployment allowance to jobless youth, has not filled up 2 lakh vacancies in government sector, crop loan waiver has not been implemented and three acres land distribution to Dalits is not being done,” he said.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: AAP to name candidates in a week, new faces likely
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

AAP Delhi convener Gopal Rai

NEW DELHI: AAP is likely to release within a week the list of its candidates for the Delhi assembly elections scheduled on February 8. AAP Delhi convener Gopal Rai on Tuesday said the list would be released by January 14.

The outcome of multiple qualitative and quantitative surveys being conducted in all 70 assembly constituencies will decide the fate of the 61 sitting party MLAs. “Most of our MLAs have worked well but wherever we need to change the MLAs, we will do it,” chief minister and AAP national convener Arvind Kejriwal said at his last town hall on Tuesday.

AAP had stormed to power in 2015 with 67 seats, but had lost Rajouri Garden to BJP in the 2017 bypoll and towards the end of the term, five of its MLAs were disqualified under the anti-defection law. AAP is now assessing the performance, public connect and opinion, and winnability of each MLA through the surveys, being conducted by it and some agencies.

There is speculation that AAP may drop close to 25% — or around 15 — of the sitting MLAs. The party, which claims to be on a strong footing due to its work in the past five years, is trying to not allow the anti-incumbency factor affect its performance in the elections.

Senior functionaries Raghav Chadha, Atishi and Dilip Pandey, who had unsuccessfully contested the 2019 Lok Sabha elections from South, East and North East Delhi constituencies, respectively, are likely to be fielded in this election. They have been handling various responsibilities in the party and representing it at various forums. The party is, however, yet to declare any seat for any of them.

Title: 3 mutton shops to sell meat at Rs 480 per kg from today
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kolhapur: Even as mutton shops continue to be shut on the second day of the indefinite strike, the forum of activists and citizens have decided to set up meat selling centres at three places in the city from Wednesday.

The forum also condemned mutton sellers for shutting down the shops. Meat sellers in the city said that they cannot afford to sell mutton at Rs 480 per kg as fixed by the 25-member panel appointed by district collector Daulat Desai. They said that mutton is being sold at Rs 560 per kg outside the city limits and that the new rate was forced upon them.

They also claimed that agencies such as Foods and Drugs Administration (FDA) and Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) are harassing them by seizing mutton samples and closing down the shops over sanitation concerns.

Meanwhile, a meeting of activists and citizens was held at Shivaji Peth on Tuesday afternoon. The activists and citizens have formed a forum demanding mutton to be sold at the reasonable rates. They condemned the decision by mutton sellers to keep their shops shut claiming that they are facing inconvenience.

Baba Indulkar, convenor of the forum said, “Citizens will get mutton. We will not respond to the decision taken by the mutton sellers. We are going to set up mutton selling centres to sell the quality mutton at Rs 480 per kg in Rajarampuri. We will follow all the rules of the FDA and health administration. We will get the goats certified from the KMC’s veterinary officer. Citizens can get mutton as much they want at Rs 480 per kg.”

Some of the activists claimed that the mutton sellers have challenged the citizens by shutting their shops.

On the other hand, citizens demanded that the FDA should continue their action against mutton shops on a regular basis.

Meanwhile, mutton sellers continued with their indefinite strike. Many claimed that there are less number of goats in the market and that the farmers and shepherd community are not ready to sell their goats at the rates demanded by them.

Title: PWD, IIT-KGP study asphalt alternative
Content:
This story is from January 8, 2020

Kolkata: A layer of concrete has been used as the surface on 1km stretch of 3-lane Kharagpur Bypass to study the use of white topping to replace the asphalt black top layer. Sensors have been embedded in the concrete layer to study the stress and strain on the surface from traffic. The pilot project is being done by PWD and IIT Kharagpur .

To opt for the white topping that costs Rs 1.25 crore per kilometre, the expense is Rs 25 lakh more than black top that costs Rs 1 crore per kilometre. But the extra cost is offset by longevity, fuel saving for cars and safety. Former PWD engineer in chief Srikumar Bhattacharya said the study would find an alternative to black top following the ban on asphalt plants by NGT .
